Our results indicate that treatment of cells with Mithramycin reduces or even suppresses the binding of Sp1 on the c-promoter, thus revealing a new mechanism of c-globin gene activation and subsequent production of foetal haemoglobin which may lead to an improvement in the treatment of b-thalassaemia and other haemoglobinopathies.

Design of gene-switches in mammalian cells: can insect ecdysteroid hormones be useful? 3 Intrexon Corp, PA, USA Introduction: The ecdysteroid receptor (EcR) is a ligand-inducible transcriptor factor activated by the insect moulting hormone, ecdysteroids. This nuclear receptor can be exploited for the design of ligandinducible gene regulatory systems (gene-switches) in mammalian cells, which find a variety of biomedical applications, including gene therapy. Methods: To investigate the nature of the ecdysteroid ligand-receptor interactions, we performed multi-dimensional quantitative structureactivity relationship (QSAR) studies, including Comparative Molecular Field Analysis (CoMFA) and four-dimensional (4D)-QSAR analysis, after collecting an extensive set of natural and semi-synthetic compounds and screening their activities using the Drosophila melanogaster BII bioassay.

Results: Significant 3D-and 4D-QSAR models could be generated from the assembled ecdysteroid library. These models were examined in relation to the EcR ligand-binding domain protein structure from the recently solved ecdysteroid-bound EcR crystal structure (1) . Conclusions: While the effectiveness of EcR-based ligand-inducible gene expression systems have been demonstrated in mouse models (2) , further studies are needed to improve the potency and efficacy of ecdysteroids in mammals. Focussing on elucidation of the ecdysteroid structure-activity relationships, this work contributes to improve our understanding of the structural features determining the molecular recognition between the EcR and ecdysteroid ligands, and therefore may be useful for a rational design of novel EcR-based gene-switch actuators. GILZ is an ubiquitous protein whose expression is induced by glucocorticoids in thymocytes and peripheral T-lymphocytes. We showed that GILZ expression is rapidly and transiently induced upon IL-2deprivation of the T-cell line CTLL-2, protecting these cells from the onset of apoptosis. This protection is conferred through inhibition of FoxO3 transcriptional activity, resulting in down-regulation of proapoptotic Bim expression. Nuclear import of FoxO factors follows stress signals such as oxidative stress or growth factor-deprivation, leading to up-regulation of target genes (bim, fasl), whereas nuclear export mainly results from Protein Kinase B phosphorylation. The aim of this work was to determine the mechanism of FoxO factors inhibition by GILZ. First, we showed that GILZ inhibits FoxO1, FoxO3 and FoxO4 transcriptional activities in the acute promyelocytic leukaemia cells HL60 independently of PKB phosphorylation, suggesting that GILZ is a general inhibitor of FoxO factors with an original mechanism of action. We demonstrated by fluorescence microscopy that GILZ is mainly cytoplasmic in HL60 cells and identified a Nuclear Export signal which appears to be functional and Crm-1-dependent. Experiments using cytoplasmic and nuclear GILZ mutants suggested that GILZ cytoplasmic localization is a pre-requisite for FoxO3 inhibition.

Interestingly, we showed that GILZ expression favors a cytoplasmic locolization of FoxO3, avoiding the transcription of its targets genes within the nucleus. GILZ could affect FoxO3 import or export. All together, our findings raise the possibility that deregulated expression of GILZ could lead to a general inhibition of FoxO signalling pathways.

Amorphastilbol enhances adipocyte differentiation in 3T3-L1 preadipocytes through PPAR-gamma transactivation KIST Gangneung Institute, Gangwon-do, KOREA, 2 Kwandong University, Gangwon-do, KOREA, 3 Korea University, Seoul, KOREA Introduction: Peroxisome proliferator activated receptor gamma (PPAR-gamma) is a ligand-dependent transcriptional factor that belongs to the nuclear hormone receptor superfamily and forms a heterodimer with a retinoid X receptor. PPAR-gamma plays a key role in adipocyte differentiation and insulin sensitivity. In the present study, we show that amorphastilbol leads to adipocyte differentiation through the trans-activation of PPAR-gamma in 3T3-L1 cells. Methods: An established luciferase reporter gene assay system was used to test trans-activation of amorphastilbol to human PPARgamma. Fluorescence polarization (FP) ligand binding assay was based on purified recombinant human PPAR-gamma ligand-binding domain and a selective fluorescent PPAR-gamma ligand. EC 50 values (concentrations at which 50% of the fluorescent ligand is displaced) was determined for amorphastilbol by measuring millipolarization values for a series of concentrations. To further characterized the effects of amorphastilbol on differentiation, cellular triglyceride content and GPDH enzyme activity were measured. And we observed the changes of C/ EBP alpha, PPAR-gamma, aP2, adiponectin and resistin mRNA by using RT-PCR and Real-time PCR. Results: Amorphastilbol was determined to be a novel PPAR-gamma agonist because it strongly induced luciferase activity on human PPARgamma and directly bind to PPAR-gamma LBD (EC 50 = 1.26 uM). Amorphastilbol enhances adipocyte differentiation as evidenced by increased triglyceride accumulation, glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase (GPDH) activity. Using RT-PCR and quantitative RT-PCR analyses, we also confirmed that amorphastilbol increased the expression of genes critical for acquisition of adipocyte phenotype. Conclusions: We suggested that amorphastilbol is a novel agonist of PPAR-gamma and may be beneficial for reducing insulin resistance through its potency to regulate adipocyte differentiation.

Abstract Withdrawn PP2B-18 Co-ordinate induction of PPARa and SREBP2 in multifunctional protein 2 deficient mice Introduction: Mice with inactivation of the D-specific multifunctional protein 2 (MFP2), a crucial enzyme of peroxisomal b-oxidation, develop multiple pathologies in diverse tissues already starting in the post-natal period and causing death before the age of 6 months. Methods and results: Gene expression profiling performed on liver of 2-day-old pups revealed up-regulation of PPARa responsive genes in knockout mice. Surprisingly, also genes involved in cholesterol biosynthesis were markedly induced. Real-time PCR confirmed the induction of PPARa target genes and of HMGCR and SREBP2, both involved in cholesterol synthesis, as well in 2-day-old pups as in adults. In accordance, the rate of cholesterol biosynthesis was markedly increased in liver of knockout mice but the hepatic cholesterol concentration was unaltered. In PPARa/MFP2 double knockout mice, upregulations of SREBP2 and HMGCR were less pronounced suggesting a link between PPARa induction and cholesterol synthesis. Conclusion: These data indicate that impaired peroxisomal b-oxidation causes an accumulation of PPARa ligands in the intact animal and a concomitant up-regulation of genes of cholesterol biosynthesis through increased expression of SREBP2. Since the hepatic cholesterol concentration was not different between the genotypes, it appears that the up-regulation was not triggered by a reduced level of cholesterol, neither resulted in increased cholesterol levels.

Dominant negative mutant of CREB inhibits TrkCinduced activation of the nur77 promoter J. Matuszyk and D. Klopotowska L.Hirszfeld Institute of Immunology and Experimental Therapy, Polish Academy of Sciences, Wroclaw, POLAND nur77 (also termed NGFI-B, TR3, NR4A1) and its family members Nurr1 and Nor-1 are orphan nuclear receptors that play important roles in neuronal differentiation, memory consolidation, stress response, and apoptosis. The promoter region of the nur77 gene contains four near AP-1 (NAP) sites 5'-TGCGTCA. Results of Yoon & Lau [1] supported the hypothesis that JunD, but not CREB, binding to two proximal NAP elements is responsible for induction of the transcription of nur77 in response to nerve growth factor. However, the results of the present study indicate that A-CREB (the dominant negative mutant of CREB) inhibits the activation of the nur77 promoter in response to the activation of TrkC. In conclusion it is suggested that activation of the nur77 promoter in response to neurotrophins requires the co-operation of both CREB and JunD. PP2B-20 Genome-wide location of glucocorticoid receptor binding sites Introduction: Glucocorticoids (GCs) are essential steroid hormones that regulate a variety of physiological processes including growth, differentiation, programmed cell death, glucose homeostasis and protein, lipid and carbohydrate metabolism. GCs exert their functions through the glucocorticoid receptor (GR), a ligand inducible transcription factor that binds to a variety of promoter elements, including glucocorticoid response elements (GREs), and regulates gene transcription in a cell-specific manner. The mechanisms by which GR selectively regulates cell-specific transcription and the global networks regulated by GR are not well established. In the present study we mapped the human GR binding sites on a genome-wide scale. Methods: To identify the global profile of GR binding sites we used chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP), with a monoclonal antibody against GR, combined with either hybridization on genomic microarrays covering the entire genome (ChIP-on-chip) or massively parallel sequencing (ChIP-seq). Results: We mapped the genome-wide GR binding sites in immortalized human hepatocytes (IHH) and HeLa cells and identified known and novel cis regulatory elements and target genes in cell-specific contexts. This study revealed the presence of GR binding sites in previously un-explored regions of the genome as well as networks of transcription factors underlying glucocorticoid signalling. Our data demonstrated distinct mechanisms of glucocorticoid-mediated gene regulation and shed light on the global networks modulated by GR. Conclusions: Analysis of GR chromatin occupancy in human genome substantially contributes to our understanding of the mechanisms and molecular networks underlying the diverse biological effects of glucocorticoids.

PP2B-21 CD40 ligation induces immunoproteasome gene expression via the co-ordinated action of NF-jB and of NF-jB mediated de novo synthesis of IRF1 Interferon regulatory factors (IRFs) comprise a family of pleiotropic transcription factors which influence development, immune homeostasis and disease pathogenesis. In this study, we demonstrate that stimulation of CD40, a TNF receptor family member with a pivotal role in adaptive and innate immunity, rapidly induces the expression of IRF-1 in carcinoma cells. Using a combination of small molecule kinase inhibitors, RNA interference and CD40 mutagenesis approaches, we show that p65 (RelA) NF-jB but not MAPK signaling is required for the CD40 ligand-induced up-regulation of IRF-1. Chromatin immunoprecipitation and gel-shift assays demonstrated recruitment of p65 NF-jB to the IRF-1 promoter. When fused to a luciferase reporter gene, the IRF-1 promoter responds to CD40 stimulation whereas mutations which abolish NF-jB binding render it unresponsive. Evaluation of NF-jB pathway components suggests the involvement of TAK1, IKKb and IjBa in IRF-1 promoter regulation. NF-jB and de novo synthesized IRF-1 converge to regulate immunoproteasome gene expression, as evident by the recruitment of both transcription factors to the promoter regions of transporter for antigen processing (TAP)-1, TAP-2, tapasin and the low molecular mass polypeptide (LMP)-2 and LMP-10. Moreover, the RNA interference-mediated knock-down of IRF-1 reduced, whereas inhibition of NF-jB abolished the effects of CD40 on TAP-1 up-regulation. Collectively, these data reveal a novel mechanism of IRF-1 induction by CD40 which ensures that IRF-1 functions concurrently with NF-jB to facilitate immunoproteasome gene transcription.

Inhibition of the ubiquitous transcription factor Yin Yang 1 by phytosteryl ferulates and their therapeutic potentials R. Nagasaka, K. Ohara and H. Ushio Tokyo University of Marine Science and Technology, Tokyo, JAPAN Rice bran oil accepted worldwide contains a lot of phytosteryl ferulates, one of hydroxycinnamic acid derivatives ubiquitously found in plants, compared with other plant oil. We have reported that phytosteryl ferulates inihibited DNA-binding of NF-jB. In this study, we evaluated the effects of phytosteryl ferulates on DNA binding activities of over 300 transcription factors in RAW 264.7 macrophages. It suggested that phytosteryl ferulates would inhibit one ubiquitous transcription factor Yin Yang 1 (YY1) activation. The transcription factor YY1 is known to have a fundamental role in normal biologic processes such as embryogenesis, differentiation, replication, and cellular proliferation. YY1 exerts its effects on genes involved in these processes via its ability to initiate, activate, or repress transcription depending upon the context in which it binds. It is also generally accepted that the transcription factor acts as an initiator of tumorigenesis. Thus, phytosteryl ferulates might prevent metabolic and immunological diseases by NF-jB inhibition and cancer by YY1 repression. The potential clinical significance of the functions will be discussed in this paper, in special the regulation of and the resistance to metabolism and cancer, subsuming complicated cell-cell interactions.

The effects of phytosteryl ferulates on multimeric form of adiponectin secreted from 3T3-L1 adipocytes K. Ohara, R. Nagasaka and H. Ushio Tokyo University of Marine Science and Technology, Tokyo, JAPAN Adiponectin has been postulated to play an important role in the modulation of glucose and lipid metabolisms in insulin-sensitive tissues in mammals. Adiponectin secreted from adipocytes and circulating in blood forms a wide range of multimers from trimers and hexamers to high molecular weight (HMW) multimers, and the ratios among them are closely correlated with insulin sensitivity. Rice bran contains a lot of plant sterols and their ferulic acid esters as compared with other plant oil. It is reported that the phytosteryl ferulates have the LDL cholesterol lowering effect in some mammals. We have recently demonstrated that phytosteryl ferulates enhance adiponectin secretion from adipocytes. In this study, we have investigated the effect of phytosteryl ferulates on the adiponectin multimers secreted from 3T3-L1 adipocytes. Mouse 3T3-L1 cells differentiated to adipocytes were treated with phytosteryl ferulates. The culture media was subjected to SDS-PAGE under non-reducing, non-heat-denaturing conditions, followed by western blotting with anti-adiponectin antibody. Phytosteryl ferulates restrictedly enhanced the HMW multimers secretion of 3T3-L1 adipocytes, while monomer, trimer and hexamer secretions were relatively low, compared to pioglitazone, a PPAR gamma agonist. The results suggest that phytosteryl ferulates might regulate adiponectin multimer formation in part through pathways different from thiazolidine diones. Phytosteryl ferulates might thus prevent and/or ameliorate the type 2 diabetes and its related metabolic syndromes. The family of proteins TSC-22D (Transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-b)-stimulated clone-22 Domain) is constituted by GILZ (Glucocorticoid-Induced Leucine Zipper), TSC-22 (TGF-b)-stimulated clone-22) and THG-1 (TSC-22 Homologous Gene-1). These proteins have both a TSC box and a leucine zipper domain, allowing them to homodimerize or hetero-dimerize. We have shown before that GILZ inhibits FoxO3 activity leading to inhibition of bim expression and apoptosis. As these homologous proteins have the ability to interact, we hypothesized that TSC-22 and THG-1 are able, like GILZ, to inhibit FoxO3 activity. We determined by RT-PCR the expression of GILZ, TSC-22, and THG-1 in different tissues of human origin and in tumour cell lines. THG-1, GILZ, and TSC-22 are present in all the tissues tested. THG-1 mRNA is expressed in all tumour cell lines tested whereas GILZ mRNA and TSC-22 mRNA are deficient in CTLL-2 and Kit 225 T lymphocytes that need IL-2 for their proliferation. The ubiquitous expression of TSC-22D proteins suggests an endogenous role in FoxO3 activity regulation. We then over-expressed TSC-22 and FoxO3 in HL60 cells to measure the transcriptional activity of FoxO3, using a dual-luciferase reporter assay. Results showed that TSC-22 inhibits FoxO3 activity measured using a synthetic IRS promoter composed of three FHRE binding sites. We analysed also the expression of FoxO3 target genes in cells over-expressing TSC-22 or GILZ as a positive control. The following genes were selected: bim, p27, puma, and MnSOD. Preliminary results showed that in CTLL-2 cells, IL-2 deprivationinduced bim was repressed in the presence of TSC-22 or GILZ. Geranylgeranoic acid (GGA) and (R)-2,3-dihydrogeranylgeranoic acid (R-2,3-diGGA) are geranylgeraniol-derived metabolites. We examined their effects on HL-60 cells. The cells were differentiated into neutrophils by the former stimulation like retinoic acid stimulation. In the case of cells stimulated with the latter, neutrophils were not detected, but the formation of lipid droplets was induced. On the other hand, when the cells were cultured in the presence of 0.1% FBS instead of 10% FBS, apoptotic cells were induced not only by GGA stimulation but also with R-2,3-diGGA. In the latter case, when the cells were cultured in the co-presence of a caspase-3 inhibitor, the lipid droplets formation was observed in the cells. These results suggest that GGA and R-2,3-diGGA are extremely different from each other with respect to their effects on HL-60 cells. To further understand the difference, we chemically synthesized several GGA derivatives including 4,8,12,16-tetramethyl-heptadeca-3,7,11,15-tetraenoic acid (homo-GGA). As a result, homo-GGA did not induce the cell differentiation into neutrophils but the lipid droplets formation was induced as observed in the case of R-2,3-diGGA stimulation. In the case of S-2,3-diGGA stimulation, the lipid droplets formation was similarly induced and in this case unusual morphology was observed. These results are discussed in the context of the relationship between structures of GGA derivatives and their effects on cells.

Transcription regulation of the microbial nitril hydratase gene cluster Although the wild-type strain was found to grow on methacrylamide as a sole nitrogen source, the nhpR-disruptant did not grow in the same medium. Furthermore, real-time PCR analysis indicated that the transcription of the eight genes (including nhpR) in the NHase gene cluster was not induced in the nhpR-disruptant on the addition of methacrylamide to the medium, although transcription of these genes in the wildtype strain was significantly induced, demonstrating that nhpR encodes a transcriptional positive regulator in the NHase gene cluster. NhpR was founed to be the first transcriptional regulator of NHase belonging to the XylS/AraC family. The Peroxisome Proliferator-Activated Receptors (PPARs) belong to the nuclear receptor superfamily and are involved in several physiological and pathological processes. Agonists of the a and c subtypes, such as fibrates and glitazones, are currently used to treat patients with metabolic disorders. Therefore, aim of this study was to find novel compounds able to activate both receptors. We analyzed two enantiomeric ureidrofibrate derivates, (S)-1 and (R)-1. By using cell-based reporter assays and co-activator recruitment assays we show that the (R)-1 is a full agonist whereas the (S)-1 is a partial agonist of PPARc. We also provide a molecular explanation for the different behavior as full and partial agonists of PPARc by reporting the crystal structures of PPARc ligand-binding domain respectively complexed with the Rand the S-enantiomer. The analysis of the two crystal structures shows that the different degree of stabilization of the helix 12 induced by the ligand determines its behavior as full or partial agonist. The comparison of the two structures of the complexes with the partial agonist reveals significant differences and is suggestive of the possible coexistence in solution of transcriptionally active and inactive forms of helix 12 in the presence of a partial agonist. Mutation analysis underscores the key role of Gln 286 in the PPARc activity. Gene expression analysis shows that these ligands increase mRNA levels of typical PPARa and c targets. In conclusion, our results identify novel PPARa/c dual agonist and provide the structural basis of their activity on PPARc. Acknowledgements: Supported by a grant from MIUR-COFIN-PRIN2003033405.

Purine nucleoside phosphorylase gene expression in response to 9-deazaguanine and its derivative in human leukemia and lymphoma cells In insects, ecdysone plays a central role in orchestrating a number of developmental processes. Ecdysone acts through a heterodimeric transcription factor comprising ecdysone receptor (ecr) and ultraspiracle to directly regulate transcription of target genes. Insect ecr gene encodes two or three different isoforms (ecr-A, B1, and B2), which share common DNA binding and ligand binding domains, but differ in N-terminal domains. In Drosophila, ecr-B1 is a key molecule to destruct larval tissues during metamorphosis. Although ecr-B1 has been identified from dipteran, lepidopteran and coleopteran insects, it has not been identified from primitive holometabolous insects, hemimetabolous and ametabolous insects, and thus its functions in these insects remain unknown. To gain insights into molecular evolution of ecr-B1, we performed phylogenetic analysis of ecr-B1 in insects. Sequences comparison of ecr-B1 cloned from various insects including ametabolous and hemimetabolous insects first revealed four conserved motifs at the N-terminal region of ecr-B1. Furthermore, the results suggested that motif-level modification occurred during insect evolution: the N-terminus of holometabolous insect ecr-B1 contains a conserved motif, whereas this motif is lacked in the hemimetabolous insect ecr-B1. Additionally, hymenopteran ecr-B1 contains a conserved N-terminal extension just adjacent to the holometabolous insect-speciifc motif. These motifs might function as binding sites of ecr-B1 isoform-specific cofactors, and the motif-level evolution suggests that modification of ecr-B1 mediated transcriptional regulation occurred associated with the insect evolution. Adipocyte differentiation is a highly complicated process and it includes several signaling pathways. Molecular regulation in the very early stage of adipocyte differentiation is not fully appreciated yet. Several inducible genes at the early stage during pre-adipocyte differentiation have been identified, including the regulator of G-protein signaling 2 (RGS2) gene. RGS2 is a member of the RGS protein superfamily, which primarily acts as a negative regulator in G-protein signaling by enhancing the intrinsic GTPase activity of the G alpha subunit. The aim of this study was to clarify the precise RGS2 induction profile and to evaluate the important DNA transcriptional element(s) mediating RGS2 expression in the 3T3-L1 preadipocyte differentiation. RGS2 mRNA was demonstrated to elevate 1 hour after differentiation initiation and its level remained high until the late stage of differentiation. Meanwhile, the putative 5'-flanking sequence [~3000 base pairs (bp)] of the RGS2 gene was isolated and fused with a luciferase reporter gene. With transient transfection assays, RGS2 promoter activity was provoked 12 hour after inducing differentiation. A sequential deletion and site-directed mutagenesis strategies were adopted to define the critical elements in the RGS2 promoter sequence. The RGS2 promoter could be reduced to 80 bp of the 5'-flanking sequence with the retention of full inducibility by differentiation stimuli. Mutation of a Sp1 site within the 80 bp of RGS2 promoter region significantly blocked the promoter activity. Taken together, our data suggest that RGS2 expression was immediately induced after the initiation of 3T3-L1 preadipocyte differentiation and it remained consistently high through the differentiation process, and the Sp1 site within the 80 bp region appeared as an essential regulatory element for transcriptional activation of RGS2 gene. showed there is also an ARF tumour suppressor pathway that is p53 independent. The ARF protein is localized to both the nucleolar surface and the nucleoplasm. We have analysed the nucleolar protein dynamics of the ARF tumour suppressor pathway using mass-spectrometry-based organellar proteomics and stable isotope labelling, i.e., SILAC. We performed a quantitative analysis of the nucleolar proteome from a human ARF inducible model cell line, called NARF2, and compare this with another ARF inducible cell line, called E6, which lacks functional p53. NARF2 is a stable cell line established from U2OS human osteosarcoma cells. Endogenous ARF expression is prevented in U2OS cells by hyper methylation of the ARF gene promoter region. However, these cells also contain an exogenous, inducible copy of the wild type ARF gene whose expression can be induced in NARF2 cells by addition of IPTG. The E6 cell line was established from the NARF2 cells and expresses the adenoviral E6 protein that deactivates p53. We will present data showing a time course of ARF induction where we use SILAC MS to characterize the responses of over a thousand nucleolar localised proteins, including proteins whose response to ARF is independent of p53.

PP2B-37 Differential expression of hormone receptor-like in 38 (HR38 ) in the honeybee brain depending on the caste differentiation and division of labor of the workers The European honeybee (Apis mellifera L.) is a eusocial insect and the females differentiate into two castes: queens and workers. Workers are sterile and perform various behaviors to maintain colony activities. Young workers (nurse bees) nurse their brood, while older ones (foragers) forage for nectar and pollen. However, the molecular mechanisms underlying the social behavior still remain obscure. To analyze the mechanisms, we used the cDNA microarray to identify a candidate gene, the honeybee homologue of Hormone Receptor-like in 38 (HR38), which encodes an orphan nuclear hormone receptor that mediates ecdysone-signaling. Quantitative RT-PCR revealed that HR38expression is higher in forager brains, when compared to nurse bee and queen brains. Furthermore, HR38-expression was enriched in a subset of mushroom body neurons, a higher center in the insect brain, suggesting its role in expression of forager-specific behaviors. In mosquito, HR38 inhibits transcription of vitellogenin (Vg) gene in the fat body before the blood intake. In honeybee, the hemolymph Vg titer elevates in queens and nurse bees, but not in foragers. It will be interesting to test whether HR38 co-operatively inhibits transcription of the Vg gene in the fat body in foragers. Bacterial LPS has been identified as a major cause of septic shock and stimulates macrophages to produce inflammatory cytokines such as IL-6 and TNF-a. We previously demonstrated the interaction between NF-jB and STAT1 in endotoxin shock model mice, however, it is not fully elucidated the mechanism of the induction of the NF-jB/STAT1 complex. Here we studied the synergistic role of NF-jB and STAT1 in IL-6 production, especially from the viewpoint of phosphorylation. Raw264.7 macrophage cells were stimulated with LPS, and electrophoretic mobility shift assays (EMSA) and the luciferase reporter assay were performed using NF-jB specific probe and reporter plasmid to characterize functionally the in vitro DNA binding. These demonstrated that LPS induced NF-jB activation and IL-6 promoter activity, which are synergistically enhanced by over-expressed STAT1alpha. Furthermore, over-expressed STAT1 with mutation on tyrosine 701 (STAT1mY) also enhanced LPS-induced NF-jB activation. Together with these results, the cross talk between NF-jB and non-phosphorylated STAT1 complex play an important role for the induction of inflammatory cytokine, which causes endotoxin shock. Parkinson's disease (PD) is a common neurodegenerative disorder, characterized by the progressive loss of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra. Even though the cause of PD remains to be answered, several lines of evidence strongly suggest the involvement of oxidative stress and mitochondrial dysfunction. The major mitochondrial defect in PD appears to be associated with inhibition of respiratory chain complex I activity. 1-methyl-4-phenylpyridinium ion (MPP+) has been shown to selectively and potently inhibit complex I of the mitochondrial electron transport chain and induce a syndrome closely resembling PD in cellular model. Okadaic acid is a polyether compound isolated from a black sponge, Halichondria okadai, and is a specific inhibitor of protein phosphatase 1 and 2A. In this study, we investigated the protective effects of okadaic acid on MPP+ induced apoptosis in human neuroblastoma SH-SY5Y cells. Treatment of MPP+ induced the loss of cell viability, condensation and fragmentation of nuclei, which was associated with the elevation of ROS level, the increase in Bax/Bcl2 ratio, and the activation of caspase-3. These MPP+ induced phenotypes were reversed by okadaic acid. These results suggested that the protective effects of okadaic acid on MPP+ induced cytotoxicity and okadaic acid might provide a useful therapeutic strategy for the treatment of progressive neurodegenerative disease. Introduction: This report describes a high-level expression of b-glucosidase gene from Bacillus halodurans in E. coli using T7 expression system, and the effect of codon usage on folding of the product.
body_text.section: 2B. Nuclear Receptors and Control of Transcription Abstracts

body_text.text: Methods: The b-glucosidase gene encoding 447 amino acids, found in the complete genome sequence of B. halodurans C-125 retrieved from NCBI database was amplified by PCR using gene specific primers. The amplicon was ligated into pET-22b and expressed in E. coli BL21-CodonPlus at different temperatures. The effect of secondary structure on translational efficiency was studied by introducing silent mutations in the initial codons of the 5¢-end region.

Results: Native b-glucosidase gene was expressed to over 40% of the total E. coli cellular proteins in soluble form at 37°C, when induced with IPTG or lactose. Intriguingly when the +3 codon TCG in the initial coding sequence 5¢-ATG GTG TCG -3¢ was changed to TCA most of the expressed b-glucosidase was produced at 37°C in insoluble form, although the expression level was quite similar to that in the case of the native sequence. However, when the E. coli transformed with the mutated construct was cultivated at 18°C most of the expressed enzyme was produced in the soluble form. The rate of the protein synthesis at 37°C seems to be too rapid to allow it to fold to a soluble active form in the cells transformed with the mutated construct.

Conclusion: The free energy value (DG°) of the secondary structure in the early part of the coding mRNA, as determined by the mfold webserver, and also perhaps the more preferred serine codon at the +3 position, are the likely factors to explain the above-mentioned results.

Pre-and post-translational study of the CD40 system in children and adolescents with type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM): evidence for differences in CD40 mRNA isoforms expressed by peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCS)

Methods: PBMCs'-CD40 of 35 uncomplicated T1DM-patients and 10 healthy controls (HCs) was measured by immunoblotting and CD40 mRNA isoform expression by semiquantitative RT-PCR (and confirmed by sequencing). Plasma-sCD40 was measured by ELISA. CRP, apoB, HbA1c, LDL-C and Lp(a) were estimated per subject.
Results: Patients' PBMCs expressed higher CD40 than HCs (P = 0.082).

T1DM-females showed significantly higher PBMCs'-CD40 than T1DMmales (P = 0.037 Methods: Rat osteoblasts prepared from neonatal rat calvaria were pretreated with low concentrations of nitric oxide (NO) and then exposed to oxidative stress. Cell viability and alkaline phosphatase activity were assayed by colorimetric methods. Oxidative stress, DNA fragmentation, apoptotic cells, translocation of Bax and Bcl-X L , and the mitochondrial membrane potential were quantified using flow cytometry. Analyses of Western and RT-PCR were carried out to evaluate the biosyntheses of Bcl-X L and Bax protein and mRNA. EMSA assay and RNAi were analyzed to determine the roles of GATA-3 in osteoblast survival.

Results: Pretreatment of rat osteoblasts with NO could protect osteoblasts from oxidative stress-induced apoptotic insults. Administration of NO significantly increased the syntheses of Bcl-X L mRNA and protein and its translocation from the cytoplasm to mitochondria. In comparison, NO pretreatment increased Bax protein production and its translocation without affecting the RNA synthesis. Pretreatment with NO increased GATA-3 translocation from the cytosol to nuclei and its binding to the consensus DNA-binding elements. Knockdown of GATA-3 translation significantly decreased NO-involved protection from oxidative stress-induced apoptotic insults.
Conclusions: This study shows that GATA-3 plays a critical role in transducing survival signals in rat osteoblasts through regulation of anti-apoptotic bcl-x L gene expression.

Twelve basic amino acids in a row tend to induce translation arrest, followed by endonucleolytic cleavage and proteasome-mediated nascent peptide degradation in yeast L. Dimitrova 1 , K. Kuroha 1 , T. Tatematsu 2 and T. Inada 1,2   1 Nagoya University, Nagoya, JAPAN, 2 JST, PRESTO, Tokyo, JAPAN Poly (A) tail is an important factor in mRNA stability and translation initiation. Another significant role of poly (A) is its involvement in nonstop mRNA quality control where its translation in a poly Lys sequence leads to translation arrest and destabilization of the protein product (1) . In order to study in detail the mechanism by which poly (A) regulates the above-mentioned events we inserted sequences encoding 12 consecutive amino acids (Lys, Arg, Phe, Glu) between two genes (the first lacking a stop codon). Translation arrest was observed only in the case of poly-Lys and poly-Arg and it was followed by degradation of arrest products by the proteasome. Moreover, deletion of NOT4 ubiquitin ligase, a member of the multifunctional Not-Ccr4 complex, led to significant increase of the arrest product which level remained unchanged when a proteasome inhibitor was added. Northern blot analysis suggests that ribosomal arrest might be followed by an endonucleolytic cleavage at a site upstream to the insertion, with the upstream fragment being rapidly digested and the downstream fragment being blocked by the ribosome stalled at its 5¢end. In conclusion, the translation of positively charged amino acids in a row, induces translation arrest, endonucleolytic cleavage and Not4-mediated nascent polypeptide degradation by the proteasome. This mechanism might be another important step utilized by the cell for the control of translational rate and protein level, respectively. Introduction: During translation initiation, the m 7 GpppG structure (CAP) at the 5¢ end of mRNAs is recognized by eIF4E. Through its interaction with eIF4G the eIF4F complex is formed and recruits the ribosome to the mRNA. Two antigenically distinct eIF4F complexes exist in plants. Early reports evidenced differential expression patterns and CAP-binding affinities for these complexes in different plant species. Particularly, eIF(iso)4F is most abundant in maize non-germinated seeds, whereas both, eIF4F and eIF(iso)4F, are equally present in germinated seedlings. Methods: We tested the in vitro translation activity of eIF(iso)4F and eIF4F on the set of stored mRNAs (non-germinated seeds) and newly transcribed mRNAs (24-hour-germinated seeds). Further, we identified novel components of each complex by mass spectrometry (LC/MS/ MS). Results: eIF(iso)4F accounts for most of the translation activity using as substrate the stored mRNA pool, whereas both complexes are active in translating mRNA from 24-hour-germinated seedlings. The heat shock protein HSP101 was identified in the complexes from non-germinated, but not from germinated seedlings. Lipoxigenase LOX1, containing the conserved YXXXXLU. eIF4E binding motif, was identified in complexes from both 0 and 24-hour-germinated seedlings. Initiation complexes resolved through sucrose gradients revealed that HSP101 preferentially associates with RNPs and 48S complex. In addition, It co-elutes from m 7 GTP-Sepharose column along with the eIF(iso)4F complex.

Conclusions: Novel components of the cap-binding complexes from maize non-germinated and germinated seedlings were identified. HSP101 and LOX1 may contribute to selective eIF(iso)4F-mediated translation of the stored mRNA pool.

Introduction: Environmental stresses, among others heavy metal loading, produce multiple cellular changes that ultimately affect protein structures and functions. To protect against the damage induced, cells respond to toxic metals via activation of metallothionein (MT) gene expression. This induction is mediated by transcription factor MTF-1 (Metal-responsive Transcription Factor), a zinc-dependent MRE (Metal Responsive Element) binding protein. Beside MTs, important target genes of MTF-1 are the Zn-transporter-1 (ZnT-1), gamma-glutamylcysteine synthetase heavy chain (c-GCS hc ), a-fetoprotein (AFP), tear lipocalin, placenta growth factor (PIGF). Methods: The expression pattern of the MTF-1 gene was followed in several tissues (e.g. liver, kidney, muscle, brain and heart) with reverse transcription coupled polymerase chain reactions (RT-PCR).

Results: Under physiological condition the highest mRNA level was found in the brain, comparable to that of b-actin (65%), slightly less in the heart (45%), even less in the muscle (35%). The lowest level was found in the kidney and liver, 25% and 18% of the b-actin mRNA, in the organs most involved in detoxification of heavy metals. In addition, MTF-1 expression was measured under different stress treatment, cold shock and Cd 2+ exposure in liver and in two isolated brain region of carp.

Conclusions: Basal MTF-1 expression showed tissue specificity and under different stress conditions the expressions altered in stress-and tissue-specific manner. Concentration-sensitive sodium channels (Na C ; c: concentration) are present in lung, dorsal root ganglia, peripheral nerve, and circumventricular organs. Na C expression during mouse development in lung markedly changes, but its involvement in physiological roles and the mechanism of expression regulation is not yet known. In this study, we explored expression regulation of Na C in mouse lung. Na C mRNA and protein had low expression at mouse embryonic day (E) 15 in lung. Na C mRNA expression strongly increased from E17 and was highly sustained until mice were mature. On the other hand, although Na C protein level exhibited a similar pattern to Na C mRNA expression between E15 and 5 weeks of age, it decreased from 6 weeks of age unlike the pattern of Na C mRNA expression. The drop in Na C protein from 6 weeks of age to adult suggested that Na C was post-transcriptionally regulated in developmental stages of mouse lung. 3¢ untranslated region (3¢-UTR) of mouse Na C mRNA is 2-kb length containing several poly A sites and AU rich elements that are bound by RNA binding proteins. To explore whether Na C 3¢-UTR regulates Na C protein expression, we performed luciferase reporter gene assay using A549 lung cancer cells that were transfected with vectors containing various length of Na C 3¢-UTR. As a result, luciferase activity was suppressed in Na C 3¢-UTR-dependent manner. Na C 3¢-UTR may be involved in expression regulation of Na C during mouse development in lung.

Identification and analysis of genes that are expressed strongly in the optic lobes in the honeybee brain Introduction: The honeybee (Apis mellifera L.) has excellent visual processing capacities and exhibits various exquisite behaviors based on the visual sense. In the honeybee brain, visual information is processed in the visual center (optic lobes; OLs), which has three layer structures (lamina, medulla and lobula). Little is known, however, about the molecular bases that characterize neural circuits of the OLs. With the aim to identify candidate genes involved in visual information processing, we searched for genes that are expressed strongly in the OLs in the honeybee brain. Methods: We used cDNA microarray to search for genes expressed strongly in the OLs, when compared with other brain regions. Expression patterns of the candidate genes were investigated using in situ hybridization. Results: Forty-five candidate clones were identified by cDNA microarray. In situ hybridization revealed that two of them have unique expression patterns in the honeybee brain. The first one was identified as a homologue of misexpression suppressor of KSR2, which is involved in RAS/MAPK pathway in Drosophila, and was expressed strongly in a cluster of neurons that are located dorsally in the middle layer (medulla) of the OLs. The second one encoded a novel protein with an arrestin domain, and the expressing cells were scattered in the outer layer (lamina) of the OLs, whereas they were spread in the inner layer (lobula).
Conclusions: These findings suggest that the honeybee OL neurons that comprise layer structures can be classified into some clusters and/ or cell populations that have distinct signaling pathways.

Cytoplasmic polyadenylation in translational regulation during meiotic maturation of porcine oocytes P. Karabinova and M. Kubelka Institute of Animal Physiology and Genetics, Libechov, CZECH REPUBLIC Introduction: Meiotic maturation of mammalian oocytes is controlled by time-specific translation of essential mRNAs. The crucial features of this translational regulation are masking/unmasking of mRNAs related with their cytoplasmic polyadenylation. Elongation of poly(A)-tail enables interactions of 3¢UTR-binding proteins and factors associated with 5¢UTR of mRNA and thus initiation of translation. Methods: Specific antibodies were used to observe the expression levels of factors involved in cytoplasmic polyadenylation and initiation of translation -cytoplasmic polyadenylation element-binding protein (CPEB), Aurora-A, poly(A)-binding protein (PABP), PABP-interacting proteins 1 and 2 (Paip1, 2), Maskin -during in vitro maturation of porcine oocytes. For analysis of interactions between 3¢and 5¢UTRbinding proteins, the 7-methyl GTP-Sepharose pull down assay was used.

Results: All studied proteins are expressed during in vitro maturation of porcine oocytes, while expression patterns of PABP, CPEB and Aurora-A differs during the progress of meiosis. The interaction of PABP, Paip1 and Maskin with 5¢UTR-binding proteins occurs during all the crucial stages of meiotic maturation. Conclusions: Our results imply that the interaction between 3¢and 5¢UTR mediated by PABP occurs during meiotic maturation of porcine oocytes, while translation of specific mRNAs is likely inhibited by binding of the inhibitory protein Maskin to the cap-binding protein eIF4E. Early activation of CPEB by Aurora-A is infirmed, as Aurora-A is activated later during meiosis. Introduction: Endometriosis defined as the present of endometrial gland and stroma with in the pelvic peritoneum and other extrauterine site, and it has been well characterized as an estrogen dependent disease. The diagnosis of peritoneal endometriosis at the time of laparoscopy is often made by the observation typically black lesion and numerous subtle appearance of peritoneal endometriosis, atypical lesions. Recently, increasing attention has been drawn atypical form of endometriosis. It has been reported that aromatase is expressed highly in endometriosis and is stimulated by prostaglandin E 2 (PGE 2 ). This result in local production of estrogen, which induces PGE 2 formation and make a positive feedback. The aromatase (CYP19) is well known as a key enzyme specifically involved in the conversion of C19 steroid to estrogen and cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) is the key enzyme in the conversion of arachidonic acid to PGE 2 . The objective of this study was to compare he aromatase and cyclooxygenase-2 (COX-2) expression in two different form of peritoneal endometriotic implants, typical and atypical endometriosis. Methods: Normal peritoneum (n = 18), typical (n = 6) and atypical (n = 7) tissues were collected from 21 women with endometriosis. To compare aromatase and COX-2 expression, we quantified expression levels using real-time PCR and immunohistochemical technique.

Results: Aromatase was expressed in a higher in typical endometrial peritoneum but COX-2 was significantly higher in atypical endometrial peritoneum than normal peritoneum and typical endometrial peritoneum.

Conclusions: It suggests that typical endometriosis is more advanced form of endometriosis and atypical endometriosis could be more associated with PGE 2 synthesis and active painful lesions. Methods and Results: Macrophage-like J774 cells were stimulated with LPS (100ng/mL) for 0, 1, 2, and 4 hour. After separation of polysomal, free mRNP, and totall cellular fractions from the cells, their mRNA profiles were investigated using Affymetrix GeneChips. Comparison of the profiles of the fractions suggested total 533 of 19 791 transcripts were translationally modulated after LPS stimulation. Surprisingly, gene-ontology analysis implied that the translationally suppressed genes significantly contained those for the mitochondrial respiratory chain. In fact, RNA blotting analysis represented LPS influenced abundance of transcripts for components in the complexes I, IV and V in free mRNP and polysomal fractions. Moreover, LPS also decreased amounts of total and metabolically labeled COX5a in complex IV without any change of its mRNA level in total cellular fraction. In accordance, the total amounts and activities of complexes I and IV were attenuated by LPS stimulation, followed by decrement of intracellular ATP level. The LPS-mediated attenuation of respiratory chain was not restored by a nitric oxide synthestase inhibitor L-NAME.

Conclusions: Translational suppression critically participates in the LPS-mediated attenuation of mitochondrial oxidative phosphorylation in a nitric-oxide-independent manner in J774 cells. Biochemical analyses of the activities of yeast ribosomes carrying sitedirected mutations in 18S rRNA reveal that helices h18, h34 and h44 of 18S rRNA are crucial in protein synthesis. Mutations G517A (rdn2) and C526A (rdn12A) in helix h18 displayed opposite translational phenotypes; rdn2 caused hyperaccuracy and resistance to paromomycin, an aminoglycoside antibiotic that binds to the ribosomal A-site. In contrast, rdn12A caused infidelity, sensitivity to paromomycin and less efficient enzymatic translocation in the presence of cycloheximide. In helix h34, C1054A (rdn1A) caused infidelity and sensitivity to paromomycin, halved peptidyltransferase activity, an activity of the large ribosomal subunit, and caused less efficient enzymatic translocation; C1054U (rdn1T) caused hyperaccuracy but had no effect on peptidyltransferase activity. Apparently, different substitutions at the same position (C1054) may cause opposite effects. Finally, two mutations in helix h44 of yeast 18S rRNA were investigated. The first, A1491G (rdn15), creates in yeast the same C1409-G1491 base pair as in Escherichia coli and has behaved as an antisuppressor in genetic studies. Ribosomes from rdn15 were errorrestrictive but their peptidyltransferase activity remained unchanged. The second, U1495C (rdnhyg1), was initially isolated as a hygromycin resistant mutation in Tetrahymena thermophila. Ribosomes carrying rdnhyg1 were slightly error prone; they did not affect catalytic activity, but affected translocation, confirming the importance of nucleotide 1495 in the communication between the two ribosomal subunits.

In the presence of paromomycin, the error-restrictive rdn15 became highly error-prone and sensitive to this antibiotic, while mutation rdnhyg1 was relatively resistant. In conclusion, several helices of 18S rRNA participate in the fine-tuning of ribosomal activity.

Upregulation of heme oxygenase 1 as an adaptive response to acrolein in human umbilical vein endothelial cells PP2C-21 c-myc and MDR1 mRNA CRD-BP/IMP1 recognition elements are involved in the regulation of translation CRD-BP/IMP1 is an oncofetal RNA binding protein whose aberrant expression in various malignances associates with aggressiveness. Target sequences of this protein have been identified in a handful of coding and non-coding RNAs, some of them playing a pivotal role in carcinogenesis. The available data indicate that CRD-BP/IMP1 can affect more than one aspect of the post-transcriptional processes of its RNA targets on a transcript and/or cell-type dependent manner. To further investigate the CRD-BP/IMP1 mode of action, the post-transcriptional effects of two cis elements recognized by this protein i.e. the ones present in the coding regions of c-myc and MDR1 (MultiDrug Resistance1) mRNAs, were tested. Fusion of these elements, in frame, within the coding region or in the 3¢Ú TR of a reporter luciferase gene, were constructed and transiently transfected in the 293T cell line. Luciferase activity and protein levels, as well as luciferase mRNA levels and stability were determined. The normalized luciferase activity/ mRNA ratio was used as measure of translatability. Both elements when placed either in frame within the coding region or in the 3¢UTR, had little or no effect upon the reporter gene mRNA stability. On the other hand, when placed within the coding region, the c-myc element caused a 50% decrease in translatability while the MDR1 element nearly annihilated translation. On the contrary, these two elements increased reporter gene translatability when present in the 3¢UTR.
These data indicate that both the c-myc and MDR1 CRD-BP/IMP1 binding elements play a role in the regulation of translation of both genes.

Analysis of physiological state of workers in queenless colonies of the European honeybee T. Nakaoka, H. Takeuchi and T. Kubo University of Tokyo, Tokyo, JAPAN Introduction: The honeybee (Apis mellifera L.) is a eusocial insect and the females differentiate into two castes: queens (reproductive caste) and workers (labor caste). In addition, the workers shift their labors from nursing their brood (nurse bees) to foraging for nectar and pollen (foragers) according to their age after eclosion. When the queen is lost from the colony, however, some workers become 'laying workers' whose ovaries develop to lay eggs. Here we investigated whether the physiology of laying workers is more similar to that of nurse bees or foragers by examining the hypopharyngeal gland (HPG) and the hemolymph vitellogenin titers. Methods: In normal colony, nurse bees have well-developed HPGs that synthesize 'major royal jelly proteins' and high vitellogenin titers, whereas foragers have shrunken HPGs that synthesize 'alpha-glucosidase' and low vitellogenin titers. We measured the size of HPG acini and analyzed protein expression pattern of HPG and hemolymph in queenless workers using SDS-PAGE and Western blotting. Results: In queenless colonies, workers with developed ovaries (putative laying workers) tended to have more developed HPGs and synthesized major royal jelly proteins, whereas workers with shrunken HPGs tended to have undeveloped ovaries and synthesized alpha-glucosidase. Furthermore, the workers with developed ovaries had higher vitellogenin titers than nurse bees, whereas those with undeveloped ovaries had lower vitellogenin titers.

Conclusions: These findings indicate that the physiology of laying workers is similar to that of nurse bees, but opposite that of foragers, suggesting close relation between mechanisms that determine physiology of laying workers and nurse bees. European honeybee (Apis mellifera L.) is a social insect and the workers show highly advanced social behaviors, such as age-related division of labor (age-polyethism) and usage of dance communication. The neural/molecular basis of the honeybee social behaviors, however, remains largely unknown. Honeybee brain is characterized by a welldeveloped higher-order center, mushroom bodies (MBs), whose proportion in the worker alters depending on the division of labor. With the aim to understand the neural/molecular basis underlying the honeybee social behaviors, we performed proteomic analysis to search for proteins expressed selectively in the MBs in the worker brain. Four protein spots were detected in a MB-selective manner by 2-dimentional electrophoresis. These were identified, by LC-MS/MS analysis, as farnesoic acid O-methyltransferase (FAMeT) and juvenile hormone diol kinase (JHDK), which are the enzymes involved in JH biogenesis and metabolism, respectively, and two calcium-binding proteins: calreticulin and reticulocalbin. In situ hybridization analysis revealed that the expression of famet is restricted in the cells localized outer bottom of the MB calyx, while that of jhdk is inside of the MB calyx. Since JH accelerates division of labor of the workers, these results suggest that MBs might be a target of JH effect and different MB cell types are involved in JH biogenesis/metabolism. In addition, the MB-selective expression of calreticulin and reticulocalbin suggest that neural plasticity based on the calcium-signaling is enhanced in the MB neurons, which might be related to the brain functions involved in worker behaviors. Aberrant activation of human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 (HER2) in breast tumors results in increased metastasis and reduced survival. Trastuzumab, a humanized monoclonal antibody to HER2 is indicated for patients whose tumor exhibit an amplified copy number and/or overexpression for HER2. The mechanisms of trastuzumab action are not fully understood and resistance to this treatment is frequent. Trastuzumab effect is related in vitro to the PI3K/Akt pathway, which is linked to translational control. Additionally, in some reports activation of HER2 pathway is associated with translation of several genes including CXCR4, VEGF and c-src. Our goal is to evaluate the role of trastuzumab in the regulation of protein synthesis in HER2overexpressing breast tumor cell lines. We demonstate that the trastuzumab-dependent inhibition of the PI3K/Akt pathway is correlated to the phosphorylation state of a major translation initiation regulator, the eIF4E-BP1 protein. Moreover, trastuzumab treatment leads to a sequestration of eIF4E by its inhibitor eIF4E-BP1, as determined by cap affinity pull-down assays. This results in the disruption of the translation initiation eIF4F complex and therefore in the translational deregulation of several genes. Translationally-regulated genes are identified by using real-time qPCR and Northern Blot on mRNAs isolated from polysomal fractions. In addition, we showed that eIF4E-BP1 phosphorylation was associated with the response to trastuzumab treatment in human breast tumor specimens, indicating that it can be a diagnostical target for treatment orientation. Comprehension of trastuzumab translational regulation and identification of target genes may help us to design therapeutic strategies based on translation mechanisms. a variety of functions inside cells, such  as transcriptional regulation, chromosome replication, protein translocation and degradation, apart from their more traditional role in protein expression. These RNA molecules that never get translated into proteins are called non-coding RNAs (ncRNAs). Their increasing importance calls for an increasing demand for bioinformatics tools that will allow us to detect them. We perform a genome-wide computational screening for conserved structures and transcriptional signals in Corynebacterium glutamicum, a gram-positive bacterium, important in biotechnology, due to its glutamic acid production capabilities. With this search we test the functionality and reliability of ncRNA finding tools.

ref_spans.text: a variety of functions inside cells, such  as transcriptional regulation, chromosome replication, protein translocation

body_text.text: Methods and Results: The role and functionality of ncRNAs relies on their 2D structure, therefore from an evolutionary point of view it is important to look for structure conservation as well as sequence. We created whole genome alignments of C. glutamicum strains and closely related species and we performed a genome-wide scan for ncRNA using RNAz, a relatively new ncRNA finding algorithm. We also use a more direct approach by applying INFERNAL on the C. glutamicum.

The results of both methods were compared. We also used bioinformatic tools such as PromScan and TransTerm to search for promoters and terminators, respectively. We identified approximately 300 potential ncRNAs. Some predictions had already been registered in ncRNAs databases while others show concordance with microarray data. Discussion: We suggest a bioinformatics method for finding non-coding RNAs in bacteriaof the genus Corynebacterium. The results are promising and the method could be in the future applied to other bacterial species. Human papillomaviruses (HPVs) are involved in the pathogenesis of cancer of the cervix (CaCx). HPVs are also associated with a subset of squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck (SCCHN). Interactions between viral and cellular genes are important for the progression of HPV-associated cancers. We analyzed the expression of cellular miR-NAs in HPV-16 positive cervical cell lines and tissues. Using the Ambion MirVana microarrays, we found that 3 miRNAs were overexpressed and 24 underexpressed in cervical cell lines containing integrated HPV-16 DNA compared to the normal cervix. Interestingly, microRNA-218 (miR-218) was specifically underexpressed in cell lines, cervical lesions and cancer tissues containing integrated HPV-16 DNA as compared to both the HPV-negative cell line C-33A and the normal cervix. Expression of the HPV-16 E6 oncogene in transfected cells reduced miR-218 expression, and conversely, RNA interference of E6/ E7 oncogenes in an HPV-16 positive cell line increased miR-218 expression. One of the predicted targets of miR-218 is the epithelialspecific gene LAMB3 which is involved in cell migration and tumorigenicity. The 3¢ untranslated region of LAMB3 mRNA contains a putative target site of miR-218, and exogenous expression of miR-218 in HPV-16 positive cell lines decreased LAMB3 expression at both RNA and protein levels. We have also identified differentially expressed miRNAs in HPV-positive and HPV-negative SCCHN cell lines and tissues. Our findings demonstrate specific regulation of cellular miRNAs in the presence of HPVs and its oncogenes, and our results may contribute to a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms involved in HPV-mediated carcinogenesis.

Real-time RT-PCR quantification of mature microRNA let-7a expression in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) In the early stages of Drosophila spermatogenesis the microRNA machinery is necessary for germ stem cell maintenance. The stem cell daughters divide mitotically before entering meiosis to produce mature sperm. These mitotic sperm progenitors produce mRNAs that remain untraslated until the onset of meiosis, an event in which miRs could potentially play a role. We are studying whether particular miRs act during Drosophila spermatogenesis and reveal their expression pattern. Methods: Transgenic Drosophila lines carrying EGFP-3¢UTR fusions act as sensors for miRs that recognize the specific 3¢UTR. We studied the expression of sensors responsive to 4 specific miRs in larval and adult testes.

Results: Based on sensor analysis, miR-2 and miR-13 (K-box family) as well as miR-7 and bantam were found to be enriched at the apical testis tip. This area contains somatic niche cells, germline stem cells, as well as their mitotic progeny. As sperm progenitors progress towards meiosis, EGFP expression is strongly induced, suggesting a downregulation of all four miRs.
Conclusions: A set of miRs was found to act during the early spermatogenesis stages and silence EGFP sensor transgenes. However, as progenitors enter meiosis, these miRs appear to be inactivated.

Micro-RNAs expressed in human microvascular endothelial cells Ribonuclease P (RNase P) is a ubiquitous enzyme that endonucleolytically cleaves all precursor tRNA transcripts to produce the mature 5¢ ends. RNase P from Dictyostelium discoideum is comprised of an essential RNA and seven probable protein subunits (dPop1, DRpp14, DRpp20, DRpp25, DRpp29, DRpp30 and DRpp40) as revealed by sequence similarity. We present herein the cloning, overexpression and preliminary characterization, as well as molecular modeling of DRpp29. Purified recombinant DRpp29 was used for the production of rabbit polyclonal antibodies. Immunobiochemical analysis revealed that DRpp29 indeed participates in the enzyme's architecture. In order to address this protein's role, we investigated DRpp29-RNA interactions within the ribonucleoprotein complex. Therefore, we employed electromobility shift assays, but we could not detect specific binding of DRpp29 either to the RNase P RNA or the pre-tRNA substrate. Reconstitution experiments of DRpp29 and M1 (RNA subunit of E. coli RNase P demonstrate that this hybrid complex is sufficient for 5?cleavage of pre-tRNAs in agreement to the exposed positively charged surface area on the modeled DRpp29 structure. Reconstitutions assays performed with increasing concentrations of MgCl 2 demostrated that the optimum ionic requirement was at 10 mM Mg 2+ . Moreover, kinetic analysis of the heterologous holoenzyme was performed and the kinetic constants were estimated. Interestingly, DRpp29 is not sufficient to form catalytically active complexes with the RNA subunit from D. discoideum. Hydrophobic cavities revealed on the surface of this protein suggests its potential implication in protein recognition. It will be our future goal to understand the role of this protein in the RNase P enzyme functional core.

Studies on ribonuclease P (RNase P) from the ethanologenic bacterium Zymomonas mobilis Ribonuclease P (RNase P) is a ubiquitous enzyme that endonucleolytically cleaves all precursor tRNA transcripts to produce the mature 5¢ ends. Most forms of RNase P enzymes are ribonucleoproteins. RNase P activity has been identified in bacteria, archaea, and eucarya and in subcellular organels. In vitro, the RNA subunit of the bacteria as well as the relevant subunit of some archaea is catalytically active in the absence of protein at high ionic conditions. Here we report, the partial purification and characterisation of RNase P from the ethanologenic bacterium Zymomonas mobilis. The enzyme was purified using anion exchange chromatography. pH and temperature optima were determined as 8 and 37 o C respectively. The holoenzyme shows optimal activity in the presence of 100 mM NH 4 Cl and 25 mM MgCl 2 . Inhibition of Z. mobilis RNase P by proteinase K and micrococcal nuclease strongly indicates that the activity requires both protein and RNA components. We also characterized both the RNA and the protein subunit of the holoenzyme. The gene which encodes the RNA subunit of the bacterial RNase P was cloned in the appropriate vector and expressed in Escherichia coli cells. The expected catalytic activity of the RNA subunit was explored by screening of temperature, pH, and ionic requirements. Furthermore the protein subunit of the enzyme was cloned and overexpressed in a heterologous system. In order to study the structural and functional attributes of the enzyme, reconstitution experiments have taken place using the RNA and protein subunit from Z. mobilis as well as from E. coli. 3 - ions. Carbonic anhydrases are ubiquitous metalloenzymes present in prokaryotes and eukaryotes that are encoded by five evolutionarily unrelated gene families, namely a-CAs, b-CAs, c-CAs, d-CAs and e-CAs. In mammals, 15 a-CA isozymes or CA-related proteins have been described with different catalytic activity, subcellular localization and tissue distribution. The hCAII enzyme is the target for drugs, such as acetazolamide, methazolamide and dichlorphenamide for the treatment of glaucoma. However, since the specificity of sulphonamides against CA enzymes is low, the adverse effect could be encountered during the treatment of the related diseases. Therefore, it is important to elucidate the inhibition mechanism of the enzyme in order to develop more specific novel inhibitors. In this work, we plan to identify some amino acids that may be involved in catalytic centre of hCAII enzyme. PCR based site-directed mutagenesis strategy has been performed replacing Asn67 to a hydrophobic amino acid, Isoleucin and Leu204 to a hydrophilic amino acid, Serin. The related mutations have been confirmed by sequence analysis. The mutant proteins were expressed in E coli by inducing IPTG. The expressed proteins were purified by sepharose 4B-Ltyrosine-sulphonamide affinity chromatography. The hydratase, esterase activity and inhibition manner of the mutant enzymes were compared to the wild type enzyme. HSA (human serum albumin) is a major circulatory protein of wellknown structure having 585 amino acids. HSA binds a wide variety of endogenous ligands and some drugs such as warfarin, diazepam, ibuprofen, salicylate and so on. In this study, the interaction between HSA and a new synthesized anti-cancer drug (2, 2(-bipyridin butylglycinato Pd(II) nitrate) have been investigated by fluorescence quenching and CD techniques at different temperatures of 27 and 37°C. By the analysis of fluorescence intensity, it was observed that Pd(II)-complex has a strong ability to quench the intrinsic fluorescence of HSA through a static quenching procedure. The number of binding site and the association binding constant of Pd(II)-complex were calculated at 27 and 37°C. From DH and DS˚values, it can be concluded that hydrophobic interactions may play an important role in the binding of Pd(II)-complex to HSA. The distance (r) between donor (Trp of HSA) and acceptor (Pd(II)-complex) was obtained according to the Forster's theory of non-radiation energy transfer at different temperatures. Far-UV-CD results represented that Pd(II)-complex induced decreasing in content of a-helical structure of protein.

From above results, it can be concluded that the blood carier protein of HSA could bind and transfer of this new anti-cancer drugs, but the stability of the protein decreased upon the interaction with this complex.

Free and calixarene encapsulated sinomenine binding by human serum albumin as determined by HPLC procedure Retention behaviour of alkaloid sinomenine -derived from traditional Chinese medicinal plant Sinomenium acutum Rehdder and Wilson and indicating a range of bioactivities including immunomodulation, antiinflammation, arthritis amelioration -has been determined in the narrow-bore isocratic and gradient HPLC-DAD systems employing calix[6]arene-, calix[8]arene-as well as tert-butyl calix[4]arene-bonded stationary phases for preliminary evaluation of inclusion process of this compound by hydrophobic cavities of peptidomimetic surface of cyclic oligophenoles. Formation of the 1:1 inclusion host-guest complexes between each calixarene-type stationary phase and sinomenine were studied with MM + and AM1 molecular modelling methods. Next, the freeze-drying process was developed for preparation of sinomenine/ calix[6]arene complex and influence of the processing technique on the drug content followed by dissolution behaviour was studied in detail by HPLC. Using an immobilized human serum albumin (HSA) stationary phase the in vitro binding affinity of free and calixarene encapsulated sinomenine to HSA were determined by HPLC-DAD assay and compared with results achieved with in vivo equilibrium dialysis technique. The analysis of the obtained complexes and trajectories has shown that substrate nitrogen atom is always sorbed near Trp84(82) benzol moiety. Substrate orientation and complexes dynamics properties depend on protonation state of the enzymes catalytic residues. It has been concluded that sorption of a substrate molecule in ChE active site is conditioned by the mooring of the substrate nitrogen near Trp84(82). The active serine must be deprotonated and the active histidine must be double protonated such that the ligand is properly placed near serine for the reaction to proceed.
Study of the interaction of Helix pomatia agglutinin with anticancer drug roscovitine V. Bogoeva and G. Russev Institute of Molecular Biology, Bulgarian Academy of Sciences, Sofia, BULGARIA

Our previous study has shown that a snail lectin Helix pomatia agglutinin (HPA) has a dual function and besides its carbohydrate binding property, can accommodate hydrophobic ligands as: arylaminonaphthalene sulfonate TNS and adenine. We have also found that this lectin binds hydrophobic physiological ligands as: steroid hormones with high affinity of kDa (1.9-2.4 lM) which has suggested an important biological role of HPA. Steroids may represent the relevant physiological ligands of HPA, occupying the quaternary structured based 'hydrophobic' site, located in the central cavity of the oligomeric molecule. The present investigation analyses the interaction of HPA with the hydrophobic anticancer drug roscovitine, a purine analogue, applied in clinical studies. Binding of HPA to roscovitine is accompanied by a significant enhancement of the Trp fluorescence (up to 50%), characterizing the conformational changes within lectin molecule. The value of the dissociation constant kDa (4.1 ± 0.2) for roscovitine is similar to the previously calculated kDa (1.9-5.4 lM) for steroids and adenine which shows high affinity binding for this ligand. The hyperbolic shape of the binding curve for roscovitine-HPA complex indicates one high affinity site for this ligand, suggested to occupy the previously identified 'hydrophobic' site in the protein molecule. Since HPA has already been applied as a cancer marker, recognizing primary tumours in tissue sections, our results suggest this lectin might be viewed as a potential drug carrying molecule which could be exploited for targeted delivery, and to be useful in anticancer therapies.

Structural comparison of l-opioid receptor selective peptides and peptidomimetics A. Borics and G. To´th Institute of Biochemistry, Biological Research Center, Hungarian Academy of Sciences, Szegeb, HUNGARY Structural determinants of binding to the l-opioid receptor -an important target in analgesia -attracts great scientific attention. Many natural and synthetic peptides and peptidomimetics were shown previously to bind to the l-opioid receptor selectively but there is no consensus about what structure is responsible for such biological activity. No high resolution structure of this receptor is available and the binding site of ligands is not exactly known despite numerous sitedirected mutagenesis studies. This suggests that the determination of structural aspects of l-opioid activity should focus on the ligands. l-Opioid ligands with similar affinity and selectivity should possess at least one common structural feature in which they differ from other ligands of different affinity and selectivity. Comparative structural analysis of such ligands, considering adequate representation of binding conditions may reveal key features of bioactivity. In this study ten l-opioid receptor ligands, DAMGO, Tyr-W-MIF-1, morphiceptin, endomorphin-1 and 2 and their analogues, possessing different affinity and selectivity were examined using molecular dynamics. Conformational preference of these molecules was determined in aqueous environment along with structural properties previously proposed to be important for binding. No structural trend was observed in correlation with previously measured bioactivities. It was observed, that increased backbone flexibility do not have a negative impact on receptor affinity and selectivity, which supports the idea of induced fit binding. Results, however, suggest that binding does not occur on the surface of the receptor, which condition is modeled by the aqueous environment.

, a sympathomimetic beta adrenergic receptor agonist used to treat asthma, and its dimethylcarbamate ester were studied as inhibitors of human erythrocytes acetylcholinesterase (AChE; EC 3.1.1.7) and plasma butyrylcholinesterase (BChE; EC 3.1.1.8). The aim was to determine dissociation or rate constants and to compare the selectivity of the two related enzymes as well as of native BChE variants (U, A and F). Results: Homozygous usual BChE (UU) has the highest affinity for isoproterenol (i.e. the lowest dissociation constant, K i = 0.47 mM) while AChE has the lowest affinity (K i = 2.5 mM). The dissociation constants for the homozygous atypical BChE (AA), fluoride-resistant (FF) and heterozygote UA were 1.6, 0.99 and 0.72 mM, respectively. Dimethylcarbamate ester of isoproterenol inhibited usual BChE 90 times faster than AChE, while the inhibition rate constants of BChE variants ranged from 0.021 minute -1 lM -1 for AA to 0.20 minute -1 lM -1 for UU BChE. Conclusions: Both inhibitors are more potent for BChE than AChE, but carbamoylation by dimethylcarbamate of isoprotenerol is more selective. Since isoprotenerol is the leaving group of the ester and a product of cholinesteraseres carbomoylation, the ester could be used as a prodrug because slow hydrolysis of dimethylcarbamate of isoproterenol by plasma BChE could ensure a slow release of isoproterenol in the organism.

body_text.text: The fluorescence study of covalent conjugation of peptide epitopes of foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV) with anionic polyelectrolytes and bovine serum albumin B. Mansuroglu, S. Acar Derman, Y. Budama Battal, K. Kizilbey and Z. Mustafaeva Department of Bioengineering, Yildiz Technical University, Esenler-Istanbul, TURKEY Water-soluble protein-Polyelectrolyte (PE) complexes as functional biopolymer systems represent a specific class of polymer-PE compounds that have important applications in various areas. Synthetic PEs have been widely used to modify proteins via covalent attachment, increasing the immunogenicity of antigenic peptides. Fluorescence techniques have recently been used to study peptide-protein or peptide-PE conjugates. From the fluorescent emission shift of tryptophan residues in protein or peptides, it is possible to localize the interaction between protein and PE at certain protein domains. In this study, we investigate covalent binding mechanism of FMDV synthetic peptides 135-161 amino acid residues with copolymers of acrylic acids and N-vinylpyrolidone (VP\AA) and Bovine Serum Albumin (BSA), depending upon the weight concentration ratio of components by fluorescence and HPLC methods. From the analysis of peptide-BSA and Peptide-PE conjugates, it is possible to discuss the mechanism of the conjugate formation and structure of forming particles. According to the fluorescence analysis results, free peptide which containing Trp residue, gives fluorescence at k max 353 nm, free BSA which containing two Trp gives fluorescence at k max 339 nm. However, after the conjugation reaction it is observed that products k max decreased and it is characterized as blue shift of k max . This indicates that when conjugates formed, Trp is completely isolated from aqueous solution.

The study of the interaction of bovine serum albumin with anionic polyelectrolytes by fluorescence method Y. Budama Battal and Z. Mustafaeva Department of Bioengineering, Yildiz Technical University, Istanbul, TURKEY In this study, the interaction of Bovine Serum Albumin (BSA) with anionic polyelectrolyte (polyacrylic acid, PAA) have been examined and the formation of interpolymer-protein complexes based on the variation of the fluorescence aspects of the tryptophan amino acid present in protein molecules have been researched. It has been determined that water soluble and insoluble polymer-protein complexes have been formed depending on the initial molar ratios of the components and the pH values. BSA-PAA polycomplexes have been synthesized at values of pH = 4.0-7.0 and at initial molar ratios and have analyzed by different methods. The polycomplexes have been examined using UV-VIS Spectrophotometer, Steady State Flourescence Spectrometer and HPLC System. The soluble complexes were characterized by the structure of particles in which protein molecules are densely covered by the shelf of a polymer coil. The fluorescence method is applied to the water soluble PAA-protein mixtures, the water solubility of the system has been researched by turbidimetric method depending on the polymer/protein ratio and the pH value of the mixture, and insoluble systems have been determined. Aggregation of intrapolymer complexes has been found depending on the ratio and pH value. kmax and Imax values of tryptophan in the protein molecule change according to the ratio and pH. These systems have been researched in detail using fluorescence method and new information has been gathered. Dioxygenases catalyze the ring cleavage of aromatic compounds in the alkylphenol degradation pathway, thus are responsible for the catabolism of the alkylphenols in aerobic bacteria. To date, crystal structures of previously reported dioxygenases showed a similar active-site, but revealed the structural differences in the substrate specificity. Therefore, the structural studies of bacterial dioxygenase LapB (for long-chain alkylphenols) will lead to detailed information about the mechanism of phenolic moiety ring cleavage and the substrate-recognition system for LapB. To elucidate the functional features of LapB, we successfully expressed, purified and crystallized the enzyme from Pseudomonas sp. Strain KL28. The enzyme was expressed as the C-terminal His-tagged protein in Escherichia coli, followed by purification using immobilized metal affinity chromatography. The molecular mass of the purified LapB was estimated to be about 140 kDa by Superdex 200 gel filtration chromatography, corresponding to a homotetramer. LapB was crystallized using the hanging-drop method, and its structure was determined by the molecular replacement using the 2.3 Å resolution data which were collected at Pohang Accelerator Laboratory, Korea. The crystal belongs to a space group P2 1 2 1 2 1 with the unit-cell parameters a = 94.9, b = 97.0, c = 133.4 Å , a, b, c = 90°, and four monomers per asymmetric unit. We are now in the middle of determining the structure in a complex with various in vitro substrates.
Role of the C-terminus in the secondary structure stability and unfolding properties of apolipoprotein E4

The investigation of FBPase and aldolase structure with atomic force microscopy (AFM) Introduction: Muscle fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase (FBPase) and aldolase are the enzymes indispensable for the glyconeogenesis. The both enzymes are globular homotetramers of molecular mass 37 kDa (FBPase) and 41 kDa (aldolase).
