A very abundant basic PLA in this venom (designated as Mfu-PL-I) is non-neurotoxic but highly lipolytic and lethal with an i.v. LD 50 of 0.18 mg/kg, and causes myoglobinuria (dark urine) in mice. The in vivo effects of Mfu-PLI on mice suggested that it may cause hemolysis and general myotoxicity. Amino acid sequences of many group I venom PLAs eliciting dark urine were aligned and compared with those without such effects; we found Lys69 and Trp 19 or Trp31 are important for the PLA to interact with cell membrane and elicit myotoxicity. Additionally, neurotoxicities of two of the 3FTxs were confirmed by assays on chick biventer-cervicis tissue. Venom NP peptides of 34amino acid residues was also identified and its sequence is 71% identical to the NP from Micrurus corallinus venom. Molecular phylogenetic trees of these venom proteins confirmed that Mfu is a rather unique elapid species.

Using trehalose as an enhancer for the transgene expression mediated by DNA-PEI complexes Background: Using enhancers to improve the transfection efficiency of polyethylenimine (PEI) can circumvent the needs of chemical modifications as well as subsequent purification and characterization of the modified PEI. Methods: Flow cytometry was used to measure the cellular fluorescence of ethidium monoazide labeled plasmid and green fluorescent protein, which represented the plasmid entry and transgene expression, respectively. We examined the effects of various trehalose concentrations on the enhancements of transfection efficiency as well as the effects of the timing of trehalose treatment and the duration of trehalose treatment on the plasmid entry and transgene expression. Results: We found that incorporating trehalose into the transfection reagent could improve the transgene expression mediated by DNA-PEI complexes. Such enhancements were not observed when other disaccharides were used. In an effort to explore the mechanisms, the treatments with trehalose for 5-120 minute prior to transfection could cause drops in transfection efficiency by 30-50%; such treatments, however, hardly affected the amounts of intracellular plasmid. The transfection efficiency remained almost unchanged when the transfected cells were treated with trehalose after the removal of transfection reagents. Despite the enhanced transgene expression, the presence of trehalose during transfection showed inhibitory effects on the internalization of DNA-PEI complexes. Additionally, the extent of enhancement in transgene expression strongly depended on the duration of trehalose.

Conclusions: As the above observations suggested, only during the transfection process when complexes and trehalose coexisted, trehalose became an effective enhancer of transgene expression mediated by DNA-PEI complexes possibly by affecting the mechanisms of intracellular trafficking.
In vivo flux control coefficient of glycogen synthase in frog oocytes
Glycogen synthesis is generally considered to be regulated by glycogen synthase (GS). However, in vivo studies have cast doubts on this view.

In vivo experiments in frog oocytes, based on metabolic control analysis, show that the control coefficient of hexokinase is 0.5-0.6 suggesting that this is the main controlling step. Control coefficients of phosphoglucomutase and UDP-glucose pyrophosphorylase are 0.19 and 0.12, respectively. Because of the summation theorem, a maximal value for GS control coefficient should be around 0.1-0.2. The lack of homogeneous GS has prevented microinjection in oocytes to measure its control coefficient. Instead, we have chosen to modify GS endogenous activity by microinjection of glucose-6-P, a known activator of GS. We report that glucose-6-P effectively raises GS endogenous activity. Experiments were performed microinjecting unlabeled glucose-6-P followed, after 8 minutes, by 3 mM UDP-[U-3 H] glucose. After 12 minutes incubation, glycogen radioactivity was measured. Maximal activation of GS was about 2-to 3-fold at 2 mM microinjected glucose-6-P. The ester effect was transient being maximal between 5 and 10 minutes. Therefore, the control coefficient determination was performed by microinjecting different glucose-6-P concentrations. After 8 minutes of incubation, oocytes received [U-14 C]glucose (6 nmoles). After 12 minutes incubation, glycogen radioactivity was measured. Flux coefficients were calculated and found to be 0.01, i.e. almost zero. We conclude that GS does not control the flux of glycogen synthesis in oocytes. Acknowledgement: Support: FONDECYT 1040886.

Studies concerning the obtaining and characterization of new pharmaceutical products from Ginkgo biloba species Increased incidency of afections with the effect of reducing the cerebral capacity among the population, on a global level, has led to the conduct of interdisciplinary research for the obtainement of bioactive substances and products used in the therapy, but especially in the prevention of the estabishement of these afections. The current tendencies are oriented towards the elaboration of a strategy for the prevention of disease with the help of nutritional supplements and bioactive products of vegetable origin, etc.

Purpose: This study had as a purpose the obtainment and characterization of a new natural pharmaceutical products of the Ginkgo biloba L species used for the improvement of cerebral activity. Materials and Methods: The vegetal material consisted in the leaves of the Ginkgo biloba L species. For the obtaiment of the total extracts the clasique methods were used and for the enriched fractions the selective extracting methods and purifications or the hydrolysis and purification were used. For the obtaining of pharmaceutical products, the total extracts have been conditioned as capsules (pelletes). The obtained products have been characterized by performant analysis techniques(HPLC, HPTLC, UPLC-MS).

Results: The purified extracts of Ginkgo biloba leaves contains: 20-26% total ginkgoflavonoides (quercitin, kaempherol, isorhamnetin) and 5-7% biflavonoids (amentoflavon, bilobetin, ginkgetol). Conclusions: A new methods was developed from obtaining and characterisation of new natural pharmaceutical products used in for the improvement of cerebral activity. 7) is a b-fructofuranosidase which cleaves b-(2,1) linkages between fructose residues in inulin, a storage polysaccharide accumulated in the underground organs of plants such as chicory, dahlia and Jerusalem Artichoke. The single step production of fructose by inulinase makes this enzyme an appropriate candidate for production of High Fructose Syrups in the food industry. Inulinase has been produced in various microbial sources, among which Aspergillus species are one of the most common choices for commercial applications. In this work, Aspergillus strains were studied for their inulinase production capacity. Methods: The strains were purchased from the Persian Type Culture Collection and grown on inulin (extracted from chicory root and Jersusalem Artichoke) or sucrose as the sole carbon source. Presence of inulin in the extracts was detected by TLC. Inulinase and sucrase activities were determined by measuring the amount of released reducing sugar. Enzyme production was also verified by SDS-PAGE. Results: A. awamori showed the highest Inulinase activity (3.63 U/mg) and Inulinase/Sucrase activity ratio 3.7. It seems that sucrose is a better carbon source for enzyme production.
Conclusions: Aspergillus awamori (PTCC:5097, ATCC:16877) could be a suitable candidate for production of inulinase for use in the production of High Fructose Syrups.

Chemical proteomic characterization of the novel synthetic quinolone compound repressing the transition from metaphase to anaphase In contrast, MCF-7 cells exhibited a lower susceptibility to colchicine and paclitaxel. Importantly, CHM-1 is less toxic to normal fibroblasts (NIH3T3) cell. The effect of CHM-1 on cell cycle progression was examined by flow cytometry. CHM-1 caused a time-dependent accumulation of MCF-7 cells in the G2-M phase. Moreover, CHM-1 interacted with tubulin, markedly inhibited tubulin polymerization, and disrupted microtubule organization. In contrast, colchicine caused cellular microtubule depolymerization with short microtubule fragments in the cytoplasm, paclitaxel resulted in microtubule polymerization with an increase in the density of cellular microtubules. However, the biologic and physiologic significance for the anticancer effects of CHM-1 is not clear. Identification of new proteins binding with CHM-1 should help in the design of new strategies to prevent cancer. We used the MCF-7 cell line to identify novel proteins that bind with CHM-1. Proteins from MCF-7 cell lysates were subjected to affinity chromatography using CHM-1-Sepharose 4B. Fractions containing proteins binding with CHM-1 were analyzed by two-dimensional electrophoresis and MALDI-TOF to identify proteins that directly bind with CHM-1. Our preliminary results indicated that CHM-1 binds with the eIF4a and GRP78. Finally, we carried out xenografts with MCF-7 cells in athymic SCID mice. CHM-1 induced a dose-dependent inhibition of tumor growth. Tumors were removed, the weights of tumors from CHM-1-treated groups were also smaller than vehicle-treated group. These results suggest that the anti-tumor activity of CHM-1 may against MCF-7 breast cancer cell line in both in vitro and in vivo assays.

The targeted generation of free oxygen radicals promoting apoptotic death of cancer cells A number of human tumours require high amounts of hormones for sustained growth. The most common types of these tumours are breast cancer and prostate cancer. About 60% of breast tumours are rich in estradiol receptors (ER) and these tumours are hormone-dependant.

Administration of antiestrogens such as tamoxifen helps to inhibit the tumour growth. Despite the advantages, tamoxifen primarily acts as a cytostatic and not cytotoxic agent. As a result, most patients ultimately experience disease recurrence or progression during or after therapy. We have suggested that to overcome the tamoxifen drawbacks and to enhance its anticancer activity, iron-containing derivatives of this compound could be used. Numerous tumour cell strains produce large amounts of hydrogen peroxide (H 2 O 2 ). Ferrocene and other iron-containing compounds readily react with hydrogen peroxide producing free hydroxyl radicals. These radicals cause damage to DNA which, in turn, triggers the pathways leading to elimination of cancer cell via apoptosis. We used tamoxifen as a carrier for delivery of ferrocene to breast cancer cells, and synthesized a conjugate of ferrocene and tamoxifen (Tam-Fer). We have shown that the frequency of apoptotic events in MCF-7 breast cancer cells treated with Tam-Fer is significantly higher than in the control cells treated with 4-hydroxytamoxifen or ferrocene, and this increase well correlates with the increase in generation of free radicals in these cells. These results show that the accumulation of hydrogen peroxide in tumor cells can be used as a therapeutic advantage for treating cancer. Tetrahymena thermophila is a unicellular eukaryotic model organism for a variety of biochemical, molecular and biological studies. Its macronucleus genome sequence was annotated in 2006 and is approximately 104 Mb in length and composed of approximately 225 chromosomes. According to this it is expected to contain more than 27 000 protein-coding genes, a number comparable to that of human and other metazoan cells; however in recent databases only 43 proteins are integrated. In the present study, after removal of DNA and RNA molecules, total Tetrahymena's protein extracts were separated by twodimensional gel electrophoresis and analyzed by MALDI-MS and MALDI-MS-MS. Protein identification was carried out by peptide mass fingerprint (PMF) and peptide sequencing by post source decay (PSD). By that process we have been able to identify a total of 371 different proteins including 117 putative uncharacterised proteins with unknown functions. Thus, 33.67% of the identified proteins were hypothetical or predicted, 30.35% of the proteins were enzymes that participate in various metabolic processes, 12.24% were binding proteins such as ATP, GTP, RNA binding proteins and calcium-binding proteins, while 11.22% corresponded to structural proteins like actin, tropomyosin, centrin, dynein and GRL proteins. 3.06% were ribosomal proteins that take part in protein synthesis, 2.04% were translational proteins such as EF-1, and another 3.06% were chaperones like Heat shock proteins 90, 82 and DnaK. 3.10% were regulatory proteins like 14-3-3, AhpC/TSA and NSF and finally 1.02% of the identified proteins are known to participate in signal transduction as Ras and Mov34/MPN/PAD-1 proteins do.

Use of zero-length cross-linking to form lysozyme, horseradish peroxidase and lysozyme-peroxidase dimers Introduction: Zero-length cross-linking is defined when the peptide chains are covalently linked through existing functional groups without incorporation of a spacer group first crosslinking was performed for lysozyme, peroxidase and between lysozyme-peroxidase molecules in three separate experiments. Methods: The in vacuo cross-linking procedure was performed by the method of Simons et al. Lyophilized proteins were obtained from the supplier, reconstituted in distilled water to a concentration of 10 mg/ml for lysozyme and 5 mg/ml for peroxidase. Protein solutions were placed in glass tubes and lyophilized. These glass tubes were sealed under a vacuum of approximately 9 · 10 -5 mbar and after heating periods (24 hours) at 85°C.

Results: Approximately one-third of the total lysozyme becomes crosslinked and the dimer form was the major product for both enzymes. This modification induced some changes in the kinetic properties of the dimer peroxidase, as evident by two-fold increasing of V max compared to the monomer but the enzymatic activity of cross-linked lysozyme dimer was the same as monomer. The activity of lysozyme dimer remained constant up to 10 minutes at 80°C. The structural changes of the enzymes were investigated by circular dichroism and intrinsic fluorescence techniques. At the end formation of heterogeneous dimer, peroxidase-lysozyme, was achieved using this method.

Conclusion: In the present study we showed that in vacuum crosslinked proteins retained their biological activity when returned to an aqueous environment and even in the case of peroxidase dimer higher activity was obvious in comparison with the monomer form. In other cases, zero-length cross-linking of a protein or proteins may confer advantageous properties that are useful for applications in medicine and industry.

Diagnostic kit studies for hepatitis B viruses and application of a quick sandwich ELISA F. Yucel, E. Akcael, A. Manav, C. Saatcilar and A. Basalp Tubitak, Marmara Research Center, Institute for Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology, TURKEY Introduction: Hepatitis B virus is one of the major cause of acute and chronic hepatitis, cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma, and it is a serious global public health problem. Worldwide, 2 billion people have been infected with hepatitis B and an estimated 1 million people die each year from hepatitis B. The diagnosis of acute and chronic hepatitis B infection is based on the detection of hepatitis B virus surface antigen (HBsAg). One of the most sensitive and specific methods for diagnosing HBV infections is ELISA and early detection of HBsAg may help for simplifying the treatment of HBV-associated dieases. In our country, the use of imported diagnostic kits causes important economical losses due to its high cost and dependency to supplier countries.

Methods: In this study, we developed diagnostic kit systems based on sandwich ELISA by using 2G3 monoclonal antibody which has high specificity for HBsAg. It was recently developed in a previous project in our lab. The monoclonal antibody was conjugated with horseradish peroxidase (HRP) and treated to accelerated stability test and then used in the quick sandwich ELISA system. Results and Conclusion: When our quick sandwich ELISA test was compared with the other conventional sandwich ELISA tests by using hepatitis B positive and negative infection serum, it was shown that our system gave reliable results. In our 'sandwich' system, the same 2G3 monoclonal antibody was used for both capturing and detecting. This system is quite practical and time-saving when compared with common and commercial sandwich ELISA. Introduction: Enzymes capable of hydrolyzing a-1,6 glycosidic bonds in pullulan are defined as pullulanases. Pullulanases have industrial applications in the starch industry like production of maltose syrups and highly pure glucose and fructose. Methods: A thermophilic strain L14, isolated from Iranian hot springs, produces pullulanase. 16S rDNA analysis was done. The enzyme was purified by ammonium sulfate precipitation, anion exchange and gel filtration chromatographies. The K m and V max for the enzyme activity on pullulan and starch was estimated by Lineweaver-Burk plot. Substrate specificity and end product analysis was done by thin layer chromatography.

Results: With regard to 16s rDNA analysis, it seems that L14 is a Geobacillus stearothermophilus strain. The enzyme was purified with a yield of 21%. Optimal conditions for the enzyme activity were pH 5.5 and T opt =65°C. It had good stability at 60-70°C. The apparent K m and V max for the activity on pullulan were 0.48 mg/ml and 0.044 mmol/minute and for soluble starch were 5 mg/ml and 0.08 mmol/minute, respectively. The products of enzymatic reaction on pullulan were glucose, maltose and maltotriose as well as conversion of starch to glucose and maltose. Also this enzyme can hydrolyze different types of sugars like maltotriose, maltotetraose, maltopentaos, maltohexaose and maltoheptaose. Conclusion: Our data establish that the strain L14 produces a new type of pullulanase that produces glucose, maltose, maltotriose from pullulan and attacks both a-1,4 and a-1,6 linkages in pullulan and starch. Therefore, this is the first report on the presence of a specific debranching enzyme which can produce glucose from pullulan. This unique enzyme can operate at temperature between 60 and 80°C and has a potential application for enhancement of the starch saccharification process in industry.

Protective effects of uric acid against experimental allergic encephalomyelitis-induced oxidative stress Although the pathogenic mechanisms involved in EAE/MS are not well understood, accumulating data suggest that oxidative stress plays a major role in lesion development, since modulation of oxygen free radi-cal production represents a new approach to the treatment of inflammatory and autoimmune diseases. Central nervous system tissue is particularly vulnerable to oxidative damage, suggesting that oxidation plays an important role in the pathogenesis of MS and EAE. To establish more conclusively whether uric acid (UA) is protective or therapeutic in EAE through inactivation of oxidant factors involved and sustain antioxidant capacity. Methods: We have assessed the effects of UA administration on several parameters relevant to the disease process and balance between oxidant and antioxidant system including Lipid peroxidation, superoxide dismutase and catalase enzyme activity, glutathione (GSH) and ferric reducing ability of plasma (FRAP) as well as Blood Brain barrier (BBB) permeability and also the clinical symptoms of EAE in the three interval (prior to, after onset and development) of disease.

The results of the present study demonstrate an ameliorating effect of UA on oxidative damage in actively induced EAE in C57/bl6 mice and a significant increases in antioxidant factors in the EAE + UA group versus the EAE group especially at prior to or after onset of EAE (first and second group of this study).

The impact of an ionizing radiation on fluoropyrimidine metabolism: a study in vitro Radiotherapy and fluoropyrimidine-based concurrent chemotherapy are commonly combined in effort to improve treatment efficacy of various cancers. The mechanism of interactions between fluoropyrimidines (5-fluorouracil, capecitabine) and ionizing radiation (IR) is, however, not fully clarified. An accelerated anabolism of fluoropyrimidines (FP) to the active forms due to induction of enzymes involved in their metabolism in irradiated cells might cause this effect. To verify this assumption, we measured the expression of enzymes involved in FP metabolism thymidine phosphorylase (TP), thymidine synthase (TS), thymidine kinase (TK) and dihydropyrimidine dehydrogenase (DPD) in HeLa cells after a single dose of 200 cGy in vitro. We used real-time RT-PCR and Western blot analysis to quantify the levels of mRNA and protein at several time intervals after irradiation (from 10 min. up to 120 h). Although a trend towards increased level of TP and TS was detected 6 h after irradiation, only a slight but insignificant change at protein levels was found. These preliminary results do not support the hypothesis that an accelerated FP metabolism to the active forms due to irradiation is responsible for the synergistic effect of radio-chemotherapy.

FIGREF71.text: Novel mode of ubiquitin recognition by the UBA domains of Cbl-b and Swa2p G. Kozlov, E. Matta-Camacho, P. Peschard, J.-F. Trempe, T. Lin, M. Park and K. Gehring McGill University, Montre´al, QC, CANADA Introduction: Ubiquitin-associated (UBA) domains are found in a variety of proteins involved in ubiquitination processes. The threedimensional structure of a UBA domain consists of a bundle of three a-helices, which contain surface patches of hydrophobic residues binding ubiquitin and ubiquitin-like (UBL) domains. The previously determined structures show that the first loop and the C-terminal part of helix a3 of the UBA domain bind to the b-sheet of ubiquitin. Despite the existing structural information, there is insufficient understanding of ubiquitin recognition for a number of UBA domains.Methods: We performed X-ray crystallography, NMR and mutational analysis of the UBA domains of Cbl-b and Swa2p. We applied isothermal titration calorimetry and surface plasmon resonance to quantify the affinity of these domains towards ubiquitin and polyubiquitin chains. Results: Here, we report the crystal structure of the UBA domain of Cbl-b in complex with ubiquitin at 1.9 Å resolution. Unlike previous structures, the first helix of the Cbl-b UBA domain is positioned parallel to the central strand b5 of ubiquitin and occupies the hydrophobic surface of ubiquitin. The UBA/ubiquitin interface was confirmed using NMR titrations and site-directed mutagenesis. NMR studies showed that the UBA domain from Swa2p binds ubiquitin similarly. Conclusions: The Cbl-b and Swa2p UBA domains display a novel mode of ubiquitin recognition by a UBA domain with unexpected similarity to ubiquitin-interacting motifs. In particular, the position and angle of the helix 1 of Cbl-b UBA is strikingly similar to that of the IUIM domain of Rabex-5 bound to ubiquitin.

FIGREF92.text: The role of naturally occurring charged polyelectrolytes in amyloid formation is still enigmatic; as an example, natural polyamines (e.g. Spermine) which are the main inducers of eukaryotic cell growth and proliferation show both induction and inhibition effects on amyloid formation of proteins which are related to amyloidosis diseases. Natural polyanions like DNA, heparins and adenosine derivatives which have important intra-and extracellular roles, are able to influence the progress of amyloid formation in proteins. These could be of importance in some particular disease states like diabetes, inflammation or necrosis. Methods: Far-Circular Dichroism, ThT fluorescence, Congo red absorbance and TEM. Results: We examined amyloid formation of HEWL in the presence of AMP, ADP, ASP, ATP, NAD, and NADP, but only in the presence of ATP, the rate of amyloid formation of HEWL increased dramatically. The other additives had neither increasing nor decreasing effect in this regard. TEM studies showed that fibrils that were formed in the presence of ATP over a period of 48 hours were unusually very thick. Conclusions: The unusual behavior of HEWL in the presence of ATP may be caused by a strengthening of the electrostatic interactions in the active site (previously shown to be a putative interaction site for indole compounds), or the existence of some specific site in HEWL for ATP which can increase the tendency of protein for fibril formation. FIGREF93.text: Acknowledgement: The work was supported by the RFBR (05-04-48955-and 06-04-48240-), NATO [PDD(CP)-(CBP.NR.RIG 982779)]. Mutations in human SCO2 gene (E140K, S225F) have been found to be responsible for fatal infantile cardioencephalomyopathy and cytochrome c oxidase (COX) deficiency, since they alter the physical conformation state of mature mitochondrial Sco2 protein and its ability to bind copper. Unfortunately, there is no effective therapy of such disorders. PTD-Technology, however, has the potential to treat metabolic disorders via protein therapy due to the ability of short amino acid sequences [named: Protein Transduction Domains (PTDs)] to facilitate transduction of proteins into mammalian cells.Methods: We have PCR-cloned, expressed the full length human Sco2 cDNA and produced recombinant L-Sco2 as fusion protein, bearing the HIV-1 TAT-derived PTD and other tags. Isolated inclusion bodies, containing the 10xHis-Xa SITE -TAT-L-Sco2-HA fusion protein, were solubilised in 1 M L-Arginine solution and incubated with cultured human U-87 MG (glioblastoma) and T24 (kidney epithelial) cells. Cytosol and mitochondria were prepared from transduced cultured cells and the transduced human recombinant 10xHis-Xa SITE -TAT-L-Sco2-HA fusion protein was detected by Western Immunostaining. Results: These experiments indicated that the fusion 10xHis-Xa SITE -TAT-L-Sco2-HA protein is transduced into mitochondria of both U87-GM and T24 cells through a time-and concentration-dependent process. Work on progress is expected to demonstrate whether this transduction could be able to resume the functional properties of mitochondria, including recovery of COX activity in SCO2 deficient cells. Conclusion: The transduction of recombinant Sco2 protein in mitochondria provides a model system for targeted delivery of proteins to treat mitochondrial disorders using PTD-Technology. PP3C-34 Identification of proteins modifying polyQ aggregation/toxicity in spinocerebellar ataxias S. Petrakis, A. Droege, A. Boeddrich and E. Wanker Max-Delbruck Center for Molecular Medicine, Berlin-Buch, GERMANY Introduction: Spinocerebellar ataxias (SCA) are a group of neurodegenerative diseases directly related to the accumulation of a physiological cellular protein. At least six forms of SCA are caused by the expansion of trinucleotide repeats (CAG) in the coding region of the relevant disease genes. Mutant proteins bearing expanded polyglutamine (polyQ) domains have the ability to misfold and form toxic oligomers that assemble into insoluble intracellular inclusions and lead to neurodegeneration.

PP3C-42 Investigation of human free kappa light chains thiolation process J. Tisonczyk, D. Haznar and R. Drozdz Department of Clinical Biochemistry, Collegium Medicum, Jagiellonian University, Krakow, POLAND Introduction: Immunoglobulin free light chains (FC) are products of B lymphocytes. During malignant B lymphocytes proliferation monoclonal FC may be excreted from B cells in high quantities. Passing rapidly through glomerular membrane of the kidney FC cumulate in urine as a Bence Jones protein. FC may also form deposits in many organs. Well organized fibrillar deposits of LC are responsible for the symptoms of al amyloidosis. Amorphous structure of LC deposits in kidney are characteristic for light chain deposition disease (LCDD).Post-translational modification of FC impact on their behavior and properties. As detailed mechanism of tissue protein deposits formation is not known intensive searches for markers of protein structural instability are performed. Methods: We analyzed 175 urine samples of patients with monoclonal gammapathy. Molecular forms of kappa light chains were analyzed by SDS electrophoresis, and native light chains were separated on high resolution agarose gels, and size exclusion HPLC. Thiols content was assayed by HPLC. Results: Lambda light chain are present mainly as 44 kDa covalent dimers linked by C-terminal cysteine. Contrary kappa FC molecules that are thiolated and linked with cysteine or another thiol are present in monomeric form. Process of thiolation of kappa light chain may change isoelectric point of FC molecule. Level of the thiolation of kappa FC varies between individuals in very wide range.

FIGREF97.text: School of Medicine, Indianapolis, IN, USA Filamentous inclusions made of the microtubule-associated protein tau in a hyperphosphorylated state are a defining feature of a large number of human neurodegenerative diseases (progressive supranuclear palsy, corticobasal degeneration, Pick's disease, argyrophilic grain disease and frontotemporal dementia and parkinsonism linked to chromosome 17 (FTDP-17T)). Currently, only little is known about the ability of fluorescent compounds to detect tau inclusions in brain. Here we show that (trans, trans)-1-fluoro-2,5-bis(3-hydroxycarbonyl-4-hydroxy)styrylbenzene (FSB), a fluorescent Congo red derivative, labels tau inclusions in tissue sections from a mouse line transgenic for human P301S tau and in cases of familial frontotemporal dementia and sporadic Pick's disease. Labelling by FSB required the presence of tau filaments. More importantly, tau inclusions in the spinal cord of human P301S tau transgenic mice were labelled following a single intravenous injection of FSB. These findings indicate that FSB can be used to detect filamentous tau in vivo. PP3C-46 Accumulation of HSP25 and HSP70 partially protects LLC-PK1 cells against the nephrotoxic drug acetaminophen M. FIGREF106.text: Methods/Results: Both isolation of synaptic vesicle fractions and deconvolution immunofluorescence of neuronal cell lines and primary neurons, demonstrate that AP-3-sorted lysosomal proteins selectively reside with synaptic vesicle proteins in endocytic compartments and synaptic-sized vesicle fractions. Fractionation of neuronal AP-3 deficient mouse brains revealed decreased levels of select cargoes in synaptic vesicle fractions, while ubiquitous AP-3 and BLOC1 deficiencies result in a concomitant increase of similar cargo. Furthermore, ubiquitous AP-3 siRNA depletion results in increased synaptic vesicle AP-3 cargo half-life and surface expression. Consistent with the regulation of synaptic vesicle content by lysosomal sorting machinery, ubiquitous AP-3 and BLOC-1 deficient mice exhibit altered motor coordination. Conclusions: Thus, synaptic vesicle cargo competition between the lysosomal sorting machinery, ubiquitous AP-3 and BLOC-1, and neuronal AP-3 synaptic vesicle biogenesis machinery regulates synaptic vesicle protein content. FIGREF112.text: PED/PEA-15 (Phosphoprotein Enriched in Diabetes/in Astrocytes) over-expression has been associated to impaired insulin-stimulated glucose transport. This effect is mediated by its interaction with the C-terminal domain of PhosolipaseD1 (known as D4) and impairment of phospholipase downstream signalling.Methods: PED/PEA-15 and D4 were expressed in E. coli. SPR and ELISA-like assays, combined with an approach of PED/PEA-15 tryptic fragmentation and subsequent HPLC fractionation, were used to set up different competition assays to identify a D4-PED/PEA-15 antagonist. The antagonist was delivered into PED/PEA-15-overexpressing L6 skeletal muscle cells (L6 PED/PEA-15 ) cells and its effects on PLD1 signalling were evaluated. Results: PED/PEA-15 bound D4 in vitro with a K D 0.4 lM. The N-terminal 1-24 region of PED/PEA-15 was identified as a competitor for this interaction. When delivered into L6 PED/PEA-15 cells, the peptide abrogated PLD1-PED/PEA-15 interaction, reducing PKC-a activity to L6 basal levels and restoring insulin-stimulated glucose uptake by about 70%. Conclusions: Impairing the PED/PEA-15/PLD1 interaction restores insulin sensitivity in skeletal muscle cells suggesting PED/PEA-15 as an important target for type 2 diabetes. FIGREF115.text: Deoxynivalenol (DON) is a mycotoxin which causes pathological digestive manifestations. Intoxication with DON inhibits protein and nucleic acid synthesis. In our study, the oxidative stress induced by DON and its possible implication in the apoptosis of CaCo-2 cell line was investigated. Methods: The concentration of 80 lM DON for the treatment of CaCo-2 cells was established by MTT test. The levels of superoxide anion and the activity of the scavenger enzymes implicated in the metabolism of ROS (SOD and catalase) were determined after 24, 48, and 72 hours of exposure. The caspase 3 expression was evaluated by imunocitochemical methods.

FIGREF123.text: Results: We have observed that the different forms of MMP9 can be distinguished on the basis of the sensitivity to its inhibitor. Then we have assayed the levels of MMP-9 not regulated by TIMP-1 and active MMP-2 in serum of patients with active MS and patients with stable MS. FIGREF125.text: of the influence of oligosaccharide phosphorylation on the stabilization of betaamylase-ligand complex M. Dudkiewicz and S. Orzechowski Warsaw University of Life Sciences, Warsaw, POLAND Introduction: The regulation of starch degradation in potato is weakly understood and differs from that of kernel germination.Although it has been demonstrated that a number of enzymes take part in the process of starch degradation, pathways regulating their activities are still not recognized. Starch phosphorylation is one of the most important factors affecting rate of starch decomposition in potato. There are at least two enzymes involved in starch phosphorylation process. Their main function is the phosphorylation of glucose residues in the chains of amylase and amylopectin. Present findings indicate that starch phosphorylation stimulates activity of amylases, but our knowledge in what way is still lacking. Methods: The aim of our analysis was to investigate the effect of phosphorylation on the intermolecular energies (kJ/mol) for stabilization of the complexes between the set of 6 different sugar ligands and S. tuberosum beta-amylase model based on the template of PDB structure 1Q6C and 1BFN. For performing protein-ligand docking procedures and calculating the binding energies, we applied the DOCK6 program suite and Glide 4.5 software. Results and Conclusions: We have observed a simultaneous effect of chain elongation, phosphorylation and chain branching. Results of flexible ligand docking show that the phosphorylation as well as the chain elongation increases the stabilization of the ligand-protein complex, but this tendency slows down for longer ligands and reverses for branched ones.

FIGREF142.text: and m-AAA proteases form a 2 MDa supercomplex in plant mitochondria J. Piechota, M. Kolodziejczak and H. Janska Department of Biotechnology, University of Wroclaw, Wroclaw, POLANDIntroduction: FtsH proteases and prohibitins are highly conserved proteins located in the mitochondrial inner membrane. It has been shown that yeast's m-AAA proteases and prohibitins form two independent 1 MDa complexes. These complexes interact with each other and form a 2 MDa supercomplex, which is supposed to be a part of a quality control of the respiratory chain complexes. Results: Arabidopsis possess two homologs of mitochondrial m-AAA proteases: FtsH3 and FtsH10. Expression of the FtsH3 in leaves is about 5 times higher in compare with the FtsH10. Level of the FtsH10 protein in ftsh3 mutant is highly increased and compensates the lack of the FtsH3 protein. This compensation occurs on posttranscriptional level, because the level of the FtsH10 transcript is not affected. Arabidopsis possess 5 active genes encoding prohibitins, which protein products from two high-molecular complexes with estimated masses of 1-1.5 and 2 MDa, respectively. FtsH3/10 proteases are present exclusively in one 2 MDa complex located in the mitochondria. Co-immunoprecititation experiments and 2D BN-PAGE analysis indicate close interactions between prohibitins and FtsH10 protease suggesting that the 2 MDa complex is a supercomplex composed of these two proteins. Conclusions: Presented results indicate that: (i) FtsH3 directly or indirectly controls the level of FtsH10 protein, (ii) prohibitins and m-AAA proteases form stable 2 MDa supercomplex present in the inner membrane of plant mitochondria, the excess of prohibitins being present in the 1-1.5 complex, (iii) interaction of m-AAA proteases and prohibitins is evolutionally conserved between yeasts and plants.

PP4A-6 Basic-FGF mediates M5 melanoma cell adhesion by regulating syndecan expression G. Chalkiadaki, D. Nikitovic, E. Fthenou, G. Chatzinikolaou and G. Tzanakakis Medical School, Department of Histology, University of Crete, Heraklion, GREECEIntroduction: Basic-fibroblast growth factor (b-FGF) is the major growth factor expressed by melanoma cells which regulates many cellular events including focal adhesion. Syndecans are membrane heparan sulfate proteoglycans (HSPGs) which have an important role in focal adhesion through their ability to interact with the extracellular matrix components such as fibronectin. We studied the effect of b-FGF on M5 human melanoma cells' syndecan expression as well as the adhesion on to fibronectin. Methods: After treating M5 cells with b-FGF (10 ng/ml) for 48 hours their syndecan 1 and 4 protein levels and gene expression were analyzed by Western blotting and Real-Time PCR respectively. M5 cells pretreated or not with b-FGF or treated with heparin (1, 10, 30 lg/ml) were detached with PBS/EDTA 5 mM or trypsin and seeded on to 96 well plates-coated with fibronectin (5 lg/cm 2 ). The number of adherent cells was determined by the fluorometric CyQUANT kit. Results: Real-Time PCR and western-blotting analysis showed that b-FGF treatment significantly decreased syndecan 1 and 4 expression (1.6-4.7 and 1.3-to 3.7-fold respectively). Cells detached with PBS/ EDTA showed quicker attachment (30 min) as compared to the cells detached with trypsin (3 hours). Importantly, b-FGF induced a 2-fold decrease in the number of cells adhered on to fibronectin, whereas treatment with heparin induced a 1.6-fold increase at the highest dose. Conclusions: These results indicate that b-FGF may mediate cell adhesion on to fibronectin by modulating the level of syndecan expression known to be involved in the cell and extracellular matrix interactions.

FIGREF151.text: After the neoadjuvant polychemotherapy (NPChT) it becomes possible to make an operation to delete the original tumor in patients having ovarian cancer (OC) at the late (III-IV) stages. But it has not been determined how many courses of NPChT are necessary. Methods: Il-1b, Il-4, Il-6, TNFa, INFa were determined in the blood serum of 76 patients having OC of III-IV stages before treatment and after NPChT and 12 patients having benign tumor (BT) by ELISA. Glycosaminoglycan (GAG) fractions in postoperative tissues were determined by S. Shiller' s method in L. Slutsky's modification. Results: The level of cytokines in patients having OC depends on the number of NPChT courses as well as the ratio GAG fractions in the blood serum (published in the Proceedings of 31st FEBS Congress). The content of all cytokines under investigation was higher after the 1-2 courses of NPChT and it was lower after the 5-6 courses of NPChT as compared with the level in the blood serum of patients having OC before treatment. The total content of GAG and its fractions in the tumor tissues at BT, OC and NPChT was not trustworthy different. The data can be considered as the inflammation reaction enhancement to the vessel destruction when neoangiogenesis is suppressed by NPChT.Conclusions: The possibility of operation in patients having OC (III-IV) after optimal number NPChT-courses can be diagnosed by the level of Il-1b, Il-4, Il-6, TNFa, INFa and by the ratio GAG fractions in the blood serum.PP4A-12 Oxidized laminin induces human umbilical cord endothelial cell ICAM-1 expression and monocyte attachment. FIGREF154.text: Multiple myeloma (MM) is characterized by the slow proliferation of malignant plasma cells in the bone marrow and by impaired hematopoiesis. The degradation of the components of extracellular matrix by proteolytic enzymes, such as MMPs, plays an important role in tumor progression, invasion, metastasis and bone remodeling. The aim of this study was to evaluate the expression of MMP-2 and MMP-9 in patients with MM. Methods: In this study, we include serum and bone marrow samples from 14 patients with MM. As controls we used respective samples from 10 healthy volunteers. The production of MMP-2 and MMP-9 was evaluated by gelatin zymography and Western blot analysis. The levels of MMPs were assessed measuring the intensity of the bands and image analysis. Results: The presence of inactive MMP-2 and MMP-9 was detected in serum and bone marrow samples from healthy donors and patients with MM. Significant decrease only in the inactive form of MMP-9 was detected in serum patients with MM compared with healthy donors. In contrast, the activity of both inactive and active MMP-2 and MMP-9 was significantly increased in the bone marrow samples in patients with MM. Conclusions: Serum gelatinases could not be suggested as a marker for the progress of MM. Although measuring the levels of gelatinases in bone marrow, where the disease is localized, can provide significant data regarding the progress of MM. Also in some patients the presence of the active form of MMP-2 and MMP-9, which was absent in controls may correlate to aggressiveness of the disease. PP4B-4 Molecular size hyaluronan differently modulates toll-like receptor-4 in LPS-induced cytokine production in mouse chondrocytes G. M. Campo, A. Avenoso, S. Campo, A. D'Ascola, G. Nastasi and A. Calatroni Department of Biochemical, Physiological and Nutritional Sciences, Section of Medical Chemistry, School of Medicine, University of Messina, Messina, ITALYIntroduction: Hyaluronan (HA) action depends upon its molecular size. Low molecular weight HA elicits pro-inflammatory responses by modulating the toll-like receptor 4 (TLR-4) or by activating the nuclear factor kappa B (NF-kB). High molecular weight HA, instead, shows anti-inflammatory effect by CD receptors and by inhibiting NF-kB activation. Lipopolysaccharide (LPS) -mediated activation of TLR-4 complex induces the myeloid differentiation primary response protein (MyD88) and the tumor necrosis factor receptor-associated factor 6 (TRAF6), with final liberation of NF-kB/Rel family members. Aim: The aim of this study was to investigate the influence of HA at different MW (low, medium, high) on TLR-4 modulation in LPSinduced inflammation in mouse chondrocyte cultures. Methods: mRNA and related protein levels were measured for TLR-4, MyD88, and TRAF6 in chondrocytes, untreated or LPS treated, with and without the addition of HA(two doses for MW). NF-kB activation, TNF-alpha and IL-1beta levels, and inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS) gene expression were also evaluated. Results: LPS increased all studied parameters and NF-kB activation. Low MW HA up-regulated TLR-4 expression, increased MyD88 and TRAF6, and the inflammatory activity in untreated chondrocytes, while enhanced LPS effect in LPS-treated cells. Medium and high MW HA exerted no activity in untreated cells and only the latter reduced LPS effects. Specific TLR-4 blocking antibody was utilised to confirm data. Conclusions: These data suggest that the regulatory effect exerted by HA at any MW on NF-kB activation may depend upon the interaction between HA and TLR-4 and thereby HA may modulate inflammation by its different state of aggregation. Significant increases in plasma Glycosaminoglycans (GAGs) levels, with respect to normal controls, were observed in patients with different types of diseases such as systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, and liver diseases. Plasma GAGs are mainly Chondroitinsulphates (CS), and a role of CS in modulating inflammatory responses might exist. The aim of this study was to evaluate the effects of GAGs purified from normal human plasma in reducing inflammation in a model of LPS-induced increase in proinflammatory cytokines in mouse articular chondrocyte cultures. Methods: Chondrocytes, without and with addition of human plasma GAGs (at threee different doses), were stimulated with LPS (50 lg/ml) for 24 hours, and increases of TNF-alpha, IL-1beta, IL-6, IFN-gamma gene expression and their related protein levels were mesured, as well as NF-kB activation, IkB alpha phosphorylation and apoptosis, evaluated by the increase in caspase-3 expression and its related protein amount. LPS treatment generated also high concentrations of the detrimental oxidant species NO evaluated in terms of nitrites, and its inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS) gene expression. Results: Added purified human plasma GAGs, mainly composed of C-4-S, at the three different doses, reduced inflammatory cytokines production by chondrocytes at both mRNA and protein levels, blocked NF-kB activation and cytoplasmatic IkBalpha phosphorylation, limited cell death by inhibiting apoptosis, and finally reduced the NO concentration.

FIGREF156.text: Methods: Human breast cancer epithelial cell lines MDA-MB-231 and MCF-7 were cultured in the absence or presence of zoledronate for 96 hour and cell proliferation was documented by WST-1 method. Syndecan-1 and glypican-1 expression at mRNA levels was ascertained by RT-PCR. Protein levels of syndecan-1 from cell extracts were detected with western blot analysis. Results: Zoledronate inhibits in a dose depended way cell proliferation. RT-PCR analysis showed that zoledronate significantly inhibited syndecan-1 and glypican-1 expression in both cell lines. Zoledronate was more effective in MCF-7. Protein levels of syndecan-1 were downregulated in both cell lines and zoledronate was more effective in MDA-MB-231. Conclusions: In this study we have shown that zoledronate inhibits cancer cell proliferation and downregulates two important for tumor growth and metastasis molecules thus giving it an anti-tumor potential. Zwierz 1 1 Department of Pharmaceutical Biochemistry, Medical University of Bialystok, Bialystok, POLAND, 2 Clinical Department of Endocrinology, Diabetology and Internal Diseases, Medical University of Bialystok, Bialystok, POLANDIntroduction: GDM is associated with glucose intolerance first time recognized during pregnancy. Identification of early risk markers may result in improved understanding of pathogenesis and identification of potential ways of intervention. HEX catalyzes the removal of N-acetylglucosamine or N-acetylgalactosamine residues from the non-reducing end of glycoconjugates oligosaccharide chains. The aim of our investigation was to determine the changes in HEX activity in GDM. Methods: Serum of 35 pregnant women with GDM, 20 women 3 months after GDM compared to the control groups: healthy women -25 in pregnancy, 20 non-pregnant. Placenta tissue of 15 GDM women compared to 25 healthy pregnant women. 75 g OGTT, HbA1c, BMI and blood pressure were estimated. HEX activity (pKat/kg protein) was measured by Zwierz et al method.

FIGREF157.text: Lp(a) contains glucose, galactose (Gal), mannose, N-acetylgalactoseamine (GalNAc) and N-acetyl glucoseamine (GlcNAc). Interestingly, Apo(a) contains the same sugar composition as Lp(a) except no GlcNAc. Lp(a) binds to lectins SNA, APA and RCA and to EC in a dose dependent manner. The Lp(a)-EC binding was inhibited by Gal in LPS-treated EC and by high concentration of GlcNAc. Sialic acid did not show inhibition. Conclusion: Lp(a) surface displays sialic acid, Gal and GlcNAc. Such heterogeneous surface sugars may represent full or partially truncated sugar chains. Gal and GlcNAc appear to contribute partially to the Lp(a)-EC interaction. The results suggest that desialylated Lp(a) may enhance Lp(a)-EC binding through the contribution of exposed underneath sugar moiety. FIGREF159.text: E. Giannopoulou 2 , D. Marioli 3 , C. Kalofonos 2 , N. Papageorgakopoulou 1 and A. Theocharis 1 1 Department of Chemistry, Laboratory of Biochemistry,University of Patras, Patras, GREECE, 2 Department of Medicine, Laboratory of Clinical Oncology, University of Patras, Patras, GREECE, 3 Department of Medicine, Laboratory of General Biology, University of Patras, Patras, GREECE Introduction: Human serglycin is the major proteoglycan of haematopoietic origin cells where it is packaged into secretory granules, contributing in their maturation, in packaging and secretion of proteases and granzymes and in haemopoietic cell differentiation pathway. Serglycin is highly expressed and constitutively secreted in multiple myeloma cell lines and endothelial cells. Secretion of serglycin may play a biological role in regulating the stability and activity of secreted proteases and other enzymes. Methods: Various cell lines of lung, breast, colon cancer and glioma were cultured. The expression of serglycin gene was detected by RT-PCR and products were identified by sequencing analysis. Core proteins of serglycin were also identified in cell extracts and culture medium by SDS-PAGE and Western blotting analysis. Localization of serglycin in malignant tissues was shown by immunohistochemistry analysis. Results: Human serglycin gene is transcribed in a mature mRNA of 1270 bp. Detection of transcriptional products in several cell lines also revealed the presence of an alternatively spliced transcript missing exon2, correlating with data from normal neutrophils. Core proteins varying in molecular weight were detected in several cell extracts and culture medium. The presence of serum induces the expression of serglycin in various cancer cell lines. Immunohistochemistry confirmed the expression of serglycin by cancer cells and its accumulation in malignant tissues. Conclusions: Serglycin proteoglycan is expressed by various cancer cell lines and is present in malignant tissues, indicating its participation in the development of malignancies. Aging, Institute of Biology, N.C.S.R 'Demokritos', Athens, GREECE Introduction: In vitro and in vivo data have shown that genistein can act both as an estrogen and an antiproliferative agent. Our group has shown that genistein affects the synthesis of the key matrix macromolecules glycosaminoglycans, proteoglycans and metalloproteinases by human malignant mesothelioma and breast cancer cell lines. The aim of this study was to examine whether genistein affects the expression of the ERs and ECM macromolecules, including proteoglycans and metalloproteinases and how ERa mediates the effect of genistein on ECM macromolecules in breast cancer cells. Methods: MCF-7 and MDA-MB-231 breast cancer cell lines were used. Expression of ERs/PGs/MMPs was examined by RT-PCR and western blotting. The importance of ERa on the effect of genistein was studied using siRNA and Real-Time PCR. Results: The effect of genistein on ERa expression was suppressive for 35 lM and inhibitory for 100 lM, while in both concentrations it suppressed the expression of ERb. Real-Time PCR analysis for ERa-suppressed MCF-7 cells showed that ERa mediates the effect of genistein (100 lM) on syndecan-2 expression, while is not related with the effect of genistein on syndecan-4 expression. It is also related with the effect of genistein (35 lM) on MMP-9 and TIMP-1 expression. Conclusion: The obtained results indicate that genistein may be of great value in prevention of breast cancer cells growth and metastasis, since represents both a transcriptional modulator of genes involved in this pathogenetic process and a suppressor of breast cancer cell invasiveness. FIGREF160.text: generated serum O-glycosylated protein profiles of patients with hydatidiform mole E. Mohamed 1 , A.-R. Puteri Shafinaz 1 , S. Z. Omar 2 and O. H. Hashim 1 1 Department of Molecular Medicine, Faculty of Medicine, University of Malaya, Kuala Lumpur, MALAYSIA, 2 Department of Obstetrics and Gynaecology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Malaya, Kuala Lumpur, MALAYSIA Introduction: Hydatidiform mole is a trophoblastic lesion characterized by hydropic swelling of the chorionic villi and trophoblastic proliferation. At present, it is classified as complete or partial mole on the basis of its histopathological features and karyotype. In this study, we have generated two dimensional electrophoresis (2-DE) profiles of Oglycosylated serum proteins of patients with hydatidiform mole and compared them with that obtained from normal pregnant and nonpregnant healthy control women. Methods: The expression of high-abundance serum proteins in newly diagnosed patients with hydatidiform mole (n = 14), relative to normal pregnancy (n = 10) and non-pregnant females (n = 12) was analyzed by subjecting unfractionated serum samples to 2-DE followed by detection of the O-glycosylated serum proteins with HRP-conjugated champedak galactose binding (CGB) lectin. Results: Volume analysis of highly-resolved spot clusters in the 2-DE profiles demonstrated different altered expression of the O-glycosylated serum proteins from patients with hydatidiform mole compared to normal pregnant females and non-pregnant controls. Conclusions: The lectin-based electrophoretic approach was capable of capturing differences in the expression patterns of serum O-glycosylated peptides from patients with hydatidiform mole.

Passi University of Insubria, DSBSC, Varese, ITALYIntroduction: In atherosclerosis as well as in restenosis, smooth muscle cells (SMC) have a crucial role contributing to the vessel thickening after a pro-atherosclerotic injury, quiescent SMC start to proliferate and migrate determining neointima formation. Hyaluronan (HA) accumulates in the neointima inducing SMC proliferation and migration.

FIGREF162.text: Photobiomodulation of epigallocatechine gallate cellular effects, seen in human T leukemic Jurkat cells A. C. Bobocea 1 , T. E. Fertig 1 , M. Pislea 1 , T. Seremet 1 , O. Doaga 1 , E. Radu 1 , J. Horvath 2 , E. Tanos 2 , L. Katona 1 and E Katona 1 1 Carol Davila, University of Medicine and Pharmacy, Bucharest, ROMANIA, 2 LASEUROPA, Budapest, HUNGARYIntroduction: Soft laser irradiation healing effects are yet far from being explained, as there are the antioxidant, anti-inflammatory and anti-cancerous effects of bioflavonoids. We previously reported metabolic modulation of soft lasers membrane effects, and photobiomodulation of quercetin antiproliferative effects in human T leukemia cells (Jurkat). In this study we focused on low power far-red and near-infrared laser and tea flavonoid epigallocatechine gallate effects on human T cells viability, proliferation and mitochondrial reticulum state. Methods: Human T cells were cultured in standard conditions, in presence/absence of various concentrations of epigallocatechine gallate. Semiconductor lasers with emission wavelengths/nominal powers of 680 nm/25 mW, and of 830 nm/50 mW, respectively, were used to expose cells to doses and irradiation regimes of therapeutical significance. Using appropriate molecular reporters, changes occurring in cells mitochondrial network, viability and cell cycle progression were followed up fluorescence/confocal microscopy and flow cytometry. Results: Epigallocatechine gallate alone induced changes in human T cells viability, proliferation and mitochondrial reticulum properties in a dose and exposure time dependent manner. Low level far-red and nearinfrared laser radiation induced wavelength, dose, and irradiation regime dependent changes in the same parameters. Depending on cells state, different laser irradiation doses/regimes could mitigate/reverse/ enhance the epigallocatechine gallate effects.Conclusion: The obtained data demonstrate significant soft laser and flavonoid effects, and photobiomodulation of flavonoid effects in human T cells. Acknowledgement: Partial financial support of the Romanian Ministry of Education and Research (grant CNCSIS 924/2006 and grant CEEX 74/2006) is gratefully acknowledged.

FIGREF164.text: Degradation of very long chain polyunsaturated dicarboxylic acids in mouse hepatocytes, a peroxisomal process S. Nguyen Duy 1 , M. Baes 2 and P. P. Van Veldhoven 1 1 Laboratory of Lipid Biochemistry and Protein Interactions, Department of Molecular Cell Biology, Leuven, BELGIUM, 2 Laboratory of Cell Metabolism, Department of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Leuven, BELGIUMPolyunsaturated fatty acids (e.g. arachidonic acid) can be omega-oxidized to dicarboxylic polyunsaturated fatty acids (DC-PUFA), bioactive compounds which cause vasodilatation and activation of PPARalpha and gamma. DC-PUFA can be shortened by beta-oxidation, and to determine whether mitochondria and/or peroxisomes are responsible for this degradation 20-carboxy-[1-14 C]-eicosatetraenoic acid (20-COOH-AA) was synthesized and given to hepatocytes from mouse models with peroxisomal dysfunctions. In contrast to wild type cells, hepatocytes from mice with liver-selective elimination of peroxisomes, due to Pex5p deficiency, failed to produce 14 CO 2 and labeled acid soluble oxidation products, indicating that peroxisomes are involved in the degradation of 20-COOH-AA. Subsequently, the oxidation of 20-COOH-AA was analyzed in hepatocytes lacking multifunctional protein 1 (MFP1) or MFP2, key enzymes of the peroxisomal beta-oxidation. Beta-oxidation of 20-COOH-AA was partially impaired in MFP1, but not in MFP2 knockout hepatocytes. Taken together, peroxisomes and not mitochondria are the site of degradation of DC-PUFA, and MFP1 is involved in this process. Peroxisome deficiency in men and mice causes structural and functional anomalies of the mitochondrial inner membrane. In order to elucidate the molecular mechanisms, we examined the physicochemical properties of the aberrant mitochondria and the origins of mitochondrial proliferation by gene expression analysis in mice with selective absence of peroxisomes from hepatocytes (L-Pex5 knockout mice). Methods and Results: Blue native electrophoresis on isolated mitochondria revealed that the levels of complex I were severely reduced, those of complex III and V to a lesser extent, whereas complex II and IV were unaffected. The crude mitochondrial fractions were subjected to Percoll gradient centrifugation. Glutamate dehydrogenase activity measurements revealed a strong induction of this enzyme, pointing to mitochondrial proliferation and a shift of mitochondria to lower density fractions in the knockout mice. Mitochondrial membrane fluidity and permeability were increased but only minor changes in lipid composition were detected. Quantitative PCR experiments showed dysregulation of several genes encoding nuclear receptors, co-activators, subunits of mitochondrial complexes and hepatic transporters and enzymes. Conclusion: The absence of peroxisomes from mouse hepatocytes has profound effects on mitochondrial respiratory complexes, biogenesis and metabolism.PP4C-10Oxidative folding of small TIMS is mediated by site-specific docking onto Mia40 in the mitochondrial intermembrane spaceD. Tokatlidis 1,3 1 Institute of Molecular Biology and Biotechnology, Foundation for Research and Technology Hellas (IMBB-FORTH), Heraklion, GREECE, 2 Department of Biology, University of Crete, Heraklion, Crete, GREECE, 3 Department of Materials Science and Technology, University of Crete, Heraklion, GREECE

FIGREF165.text: Mitochondrial diseases are associated mainly with mitochondrial dysfunction and increased production of reactive oxygen species (ROS). Our understanding of their pathogenesis is poor and effective therapeutic strategies are not available. Selenium compounds exhibit antioxidative properties and for this reason we investigate the effects of selenium on the level of ROS and expression of antioxidative enzymes.Methods: Cell lines. Human osteosarcoma cell lines: wild type (WT) cell line, cybrid line with 98% penetration of the mtDNA T8993G (NARP) and the line lacking mtDNA (Rho0). Western blotting: quantitative evaluation of the level of: thiredoxin reductase 1 (TrxR1), superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1), superoxide dismutase 2 (SOD2), glutathione peroxidase (GPx). Laser scanning cytometry: Determination of ROS level and cell cycle phases. Oxygen consumption measurements with Clark oxygen electrode. Confocal microscopy: mitochondrial and cytoskeletal organisation Results: We have found differences in ROS generation and in the level of expression of some antioxidative enzymes such as SOD1, SOD2, TrxR1 and GPx in NARP and Rho0 cells in comparison to WT cell line. Selenium supplementation causes decrease in ROS level and changes in the expression of antioxidative selenoproteins (TrxR1, GPx). Conclusion: This investigation have enhanced our understanding of mitochondrial diseases pathology and suggests selenium to be an effective therapeutic agent. FIGREF168.text: Myosin IXb (Myo9b) is a single-headed processive myosin that exhibits Rho GTPase-activating protein (RhoGAP) activity in its tail region. GAPs catalyze the inactivation of G-proteins by accelerating GTP-hydrolysis and thereby switching them from the GTP-bound active conformation to the GDP-bound inactive conformation. Both in vitro and in vivo, the Myo9b-RhoGAP domain shows a preferential specificity for Rho A, B, and C of the tested Rho-subfamily members of monomeric G-proteins. but it is currently not known whether the Myo9b Rho-GAP activity is regulated. Results: Myo9b is phosphorylated in vitro and in vivo, We identified four phosphorylated serine residues located in the tail region of Myo9b by direct nanoESI MS and HPLC-MS(/MS) analysis of a tryptic digest of recombinant rat Myo9b affinity purified from Sf9 insect cells. The phosphorylation of these sites could modulate motor, RhoGAP and/or other activities of Myo9b.

FIGREF170.text: of every tumour cell depends on the acquisition of several separate features. The key player in this process is actin cytoskeleton supervised by a vast variety of actin binding proteins including cofilin. In our studies we have concentrated on the basic problems related to higher invasiveness of cancer cells selected either in vivo or in vitro. Three different cancer models and their selected variants were examined. There were: human colon adenocarcinoma cells LS180, human melanoma cells A375 and rat hepatoma Morris cells 5123. We have focused on their invasive potential, morphology, actin polymerization level, distribution and the level of beta actin and cofilin expression. To assign the invasive factor of cells we used Transwell invasion assay on Matrigel coated filters. Quantitative densitometric analysis and confocal fluorescence microscopy were used to examine the expression levels and subcellular distribution of beta actin and cofilin. To measure the level of actin polymerization we conducted experiments based on a standard Dna-se I inhibition assays. Our data show remarkable differences between parental and selected cancer cells especially in the level of actin polymerization -higher in invasive cells, the level of cofilin and inactive phosphorylated form of cofilin. In more motile cells cofilin and beta actin were accumulated at their cellular periphery in co-localization with actin filaments. Summarizing, our data demonstrate a clear correlation between the metastatic potential of cells and the changes in organization of actin cytoskeleton triggered by cofilin.PP4D-16 Functional properties of integrin linked kinase in Drosophila E. Suh Department of Life Science, Division of Molecular and Life Science, Pohang University of Science and Technology, Pohang, SOUTH KOREAPost-translational modification of cellular proteins by ?-o-linked N-acetylglucosamine moieties (o-GlcNAcylation) involves a growing number of eukaryotic nuclear and cytosolic proteins. o-GlcNAcylation of intracellular proteins is a dynamic process that in several cases competes with and acts as a reciprocal modification system to phosphorylation. Here we report the inhibition of LPA-mediated ovarian cancer cell (OVCAR3) migration by o-GlcNAcylation. We found that ezrin, a membrane-cytoskeletal crosslinkers in actin-rich cell surface structures, was o-GlcNAcylated in hyperglycemic condition. Such a modification of ezrin by o-GlcNAc was inversely correlated with phosphorylation level of ezrin. Moreover LPA-induced cell migration was impaired by accumulation of o-GlcNAcylation by PUGNAc treatment. Taken together, our findings suggest that o-GlcNAcylation is an important signaling element in OVCAR3 cells that modulates the activation of ezrin involved in the regulation of cellular movement.

FIGREF174.text: RAF participates in migration of papillary tumor cells though formation and/or stabilization of focal adhesion contacts P. Baquero, I. Sanchez-Hernadez and A. Chiloeches University of Alcala de Henares, Madrid, SPAINThe classic Ras/Raf/MEK/ERK signal pathway is known to mediate cellular proliferation in various cell types. Activating mutations of B-RAF protein are identified in approximately 35-65% of human papillary thyroid tumors (PTCs). B-RAF mutations are associated with poor prognosis and thyroid-targeted expression of mutated B-RAF induces development of invasive thyroid cancer, as well as shows an increased level of EMT-associated genes. This indicates that B-RAF contributes to the aggressive behaviour of B-RAF-positive PTCs. The aim of this work is to study the role of V600E B-RAF mutation on cell adhesion and migration in PTC cells carrying this point mutation, as well as the signal transduction pathways involved in these processes. We observed that abrogation of B-RAF expression with siRNA increases adhesion to a fibronectin or collagen I matrix, and decreases migration through them. On the other hand, fibronectin adhesion increases Y347 phosphorylation of the focal adhesion kinase (FAK) as well as AKT phosphorylation, one of its known downstream effectors. The treatment of cells with the PI3K inhibitor LY294002 blocks fibronectin adhesion-induced AKT phosphorylation. Regarding the role of B-RAF on this pathway, knocking-down B-RAF expression decreases both FAK and AKT phosphorylation after adhesion to fibronectin. These data indicate that V600E B-RAF plays an essential role in the adhesion and migration of PTC cells through modulation of FAK activation, which result in the formation or stabilization of focal adhesion contacts after adhesion to fibronectin.PP4E-2Monocyte functional responsiveness following PSGL-1 mediated platelet adhesion is dependent upon platelet activation statusS. FIGREF175.text: eradication of all tumor cells seems to be the main obstacle against success of therapy in many cancers. Certain cell adhesion molecules (CAM) associated to tumor cells could be involved in cellular interactions that might influence the aggressivity and metastatic potential of a certain tumor. Systemic administration of mAbs, targeted against tumor associated antigens (TAA) and labelled by isotopes might be used in radioimmunotherapy. Recent studies consider several tumor associated antigens (TAA) like CEA, HER-2, mucins MUC-1, Tn and sialyl-Tn or the vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) as potential immunotherapeutical targets because they play an important role in releasing tumor cells from the primary tumors, in invasion processes and angiogenesis. TAA under study might be involved in new cellular interactions, changes in adhesivity and cellular mobility. The present study focuses on evaluation of expression and functional roles of CEA, mucins and VEGF expression associated to breast and ovarian tumor cells. Levels of TAA membrane expression associated to tumor cell lines were evaluated by flow cytometry. In addition we have further studied the cytotoxic capacity of specific anti-TAA mAbs in killing breast and ovarian cells from stabilized cell lines or isolated from animal induced tumors by performind by XTT assays. TAA could represent some of the first factors that influence the aggressivity and metastatic potential of a certain tumor. Data obtained will further be used in elaborating new antitumor immunotherapeutical strategies focused on isotope labelling of anti-TAA mAbs with biological functions.PP4E-4The potential roles of oxidized low-density lipoprotein in regulation of dendritic cell adhesionM. -C. Chen 1,2 , S. -P. Liao 1 and M. -C. Chou 1 1 Department of Microbiology and Immunology, Taipei Medical University, Taipei, TAIWAN, 2 Graduate Institute of Medical Sciences, Taipei Medical University, Taipei, TAIWAN Introduction: Oxidized low-density lipoprotein (oxLDL) is a kind of mediator containing lipids and contributes to regulate the inflammatory response. During the development of atherosclerotic lesions, it is characterized by the presence of large amounts of immune competent cells including T-cells and dendritic cells. In the microenvironment of atherogenesis, monocytes exit blood and enter tissues, where they can cross the endothelium and differentiate into macrophages or dendritic cells (DC) under the stimulation of oxLDL.Methods: Since dendritic cells (DC) are the most potent professional antigen-presenting cells, we will focus on analyzing the role of oxLDL stimulation on monocyte-derived dendritic cells. Results: OxLDL can trigger the expression of costimulatory molecules such as CD86, HLA-DQ, and CD40 and get involved in the stimulation of allogeneic T cells by dendritic cells. We further dissect the mechanism of the interaction of dendritic cells with cerebral endothelial cells under oxLDL stimulation. Second, we investigate whether important adhesion molecules on dendritic cell are regulated by oxLDL stimulation, and identify the significance of adhesion molecules in the functional interaction of dendritic cells with cerebral endothelial cells. Conclusions: In vitro experiment has revealed the ability of oxLDL to enhance DC clustering, correlating with the observation that DCs accumulate in the early stage of atherosclerotic lesion development.

FIGREF177.text: represents a malignancy with high incidence and mortality throughout women, its ethiology involving many genetic, immunological and biochemical factors. Increase of replicative capacity, loss of cell adhesion and angiogenesis process represent aggravating factors of clinical evolution for cancer patients. The main obstacle against the success of therapy in many cancers seems to be the impossibility of eradication of all tumor cells. The formation and spread of tumors is closely associated with decreased dependence on adhesion for growth and survival. Curcumin (CRM) is an active biological compound, extracted from Curcuma longa, and presents anti-inflammatory, -oxidant, -tumoral and -angiogenic properties. The present study focused on the potential influence of oncolitical treatment (doxorubicin, ADR) associated with natural compounds (CRM) or hydrogen peroxide on proliferation by cell cycle phases and apoptosis of breast tumor cell lines. Sensibility of tumor cells to different concentrations of ADR and/or CRM for various periods of time was evaluated by citotoxicity assays using MTT method. Effects of ADR or associated treatments on proliferation were investigated by evaluation of progression through cell cycle by PI technique and flow-cytometry analysis. Evaluation of percentages of apoptotic cells was performed by using Annexin V-FITC/PI coloration, followed by flow-cytometry. Identification of modulators of tumor cell growth and apoptosis might due to antitumor immunotherapeutical strategies focused on diminishing the primary tumor and controlling/eliminating the metastases.PP4E-10 Cellular localization of MAGI-1 caspase cleavage products and their role in apoptosis S. Ivanova 1 , U. Repnik 1 , L. Banks 2 , V. Turk 1 and B. Turk 1 1 Department of Biochemistry, Jozef Stefan Institute, Ljubljana, SLOVENIA, 2 International Centre for Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology, Trieste, ITALY MAGI-1 is a membrane associated guanylate kinase (MAGUK) present at the adherent and tight junctions, where it acts as a structural and signalling scaffold. Recently, we have reported MAGI-1 as a caspase target during FasL-, STS-and UV-induced apoptosis in different cell models(1). Cleavage of MAGI-1 at Asp761 between the second and the third PDZ domains by caspases was found to be an important step in proper, fast and efficient cell detachment during apoptosis, since the dominant negative mutant of MAGI-1 delayed cell detachment, but not the other signs of apoptosis, i.e. nuclear fragmentation and PS exposure (1). Since Laura et al.(2)  showed that the C-terminal part of MAGI-1 starting with the fifth PDZ domain resides in the nucleus, whereas the whole region containing PDZ domains 1, 2, 3 and 5 was found to be necessary for targeting MAGI-1 to the tight junctions, we further investigated the cellular distribution and possible proapototic role of MAGI-1 caspase cleavage products. Full length MAGI-1 exhibited submembrane localization, while the N-terminal caspase cleavage product of MAGI-1 is translocated to the cytosol and the C-terminal caspase cleavage product accumulated in the nucleus. When overexpressed, both N-and C-terminal MAGI-1 caspase cleavage products in MDCK cells exhibited minor proapoptotic activity, although their role in apoptosis is probably more passive (3).References: 1. FIGREF178.text: Biochemistry, Faculty of Science, Charles University, Praha, CZECH REPUBLIC,2  Institute of Microbiology, V.V.I. Czech Academy of Sciences, Praha, CZECH REPUBLIC Introduction: CD69 is the earliest activation antigen of lymphocytes, and an universal activation molecule of the cells of the immune system. Thus it has been an interest in the production of soluble stable forms of this membrane protein for their potential use in immune therapies. Methods: DNA fragment coding for the extracellular part of CD69 has been amplified by PCR, and transferred to bacterial expression vectors. The proteins were refolded, and purified by chromatography on S-Sepharose and gel filtration. Results: Soluble CD69 receptors are biochemically very stable, the most stable is the noncovalent dimeric form starting with glycine 70 . The therapeutic potential of these proteins has been proved in mouse melanoma models, where an injection of the soluble CD69 significantly reduced the size of tumors, and prolonged the survival of animals. Conclusion: Stable CD69 receptors proved to be efficient in animal tumor therapies. Biology, School of Medicine, University of Patras, Patras, GREECE,3  Laboratory of Cell Proliferation and Ageing, Institute of Biology, National Centre for Scientific Research 'Demokritos', Athens, GREECE Introduction: Mechanical loading factors at the bone-implant interface are critical for the osseointegration and clinical success of the implant. The aim of the present investigation was to study the effects of mechanical strain on the orthopedic biomaterial Ti-6Al-4V -osteoblast interface, using an in vitro model. Methods: Homogeneous strain was applied to human bone marrow derived osteoblasts (HBMDOs) cultured on Ti-6Al-4V, at physiological levels, by a mechanostimulatory system, based on the principle of fourpoint bending. Semi-quantitative reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction (sqRT-PCR) was used to determine the mRNA expression of Cbfa1 and osteocalcin at different loading conditions. The release of growth factors as a response to stretch was also investigated by transferring stretch-conditioned media to non-stretched cells and by measuring their effect on the regulation of DNA synthesis. Results: Mechanical loading was found that contributes to the regulation of osteoblast differentiation by influencing the level of the osteoblast-specific transcription factor Cbfa1, both at the mRNA and protein level, and also the level of osteocalcin. Both genes were differentially expressed shortly after the application of different mechanical stimuli, in terms of strain frequency, magnitude and time interval. Media conditioned from mechanically-stressed HBMDOs stimulate DNA synthesis more intensely compared to media conditioned from unstressed control cultures, indicating that mechanical strain induces the release of a mitogenic potential that regulates cell proliferation.Conclusions: In conclusion, mechanical loading of HBMDOs growing on Ti-6Al-4V implant surface contributes to the regulation of osteoblast differentiation by influencing the level of bone-related genes (osteocalcin) and transcription factors (Cbfa1). Moreover, mechanical strain induces the release of growth factors that induce DNA synthesis.
