Acknowledgements: This research was supported by an EPEAEK ''Pythagoras II'' grant. PP4-2 Expression of MMP-2 and MMP-9 in gastric cancer S. Gencer 1 , M. B. Irmak Yazicioglu 1 , G. Dogusoy 2 and A. K. Belli 2 1 Department of Biology, Fatih University, Istanbul, TURKEY, 2 Cerrahpasa Medical Faculty, Istanbul University, Istanbul, TURKEYGastric cancer is one of the most prevalent cancer types in the world today. Malignant tumors have the ability to invade normal tissue and spread to distant sites, giving rise to metastases, the major factors in the morbidity and mortality of cancer. During invasion and metastasis of tumor, the majority of connective tissue destruction is carried out by the matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs), which are divided into five groups namely, collagenases, stromelysins, gelatinases, membrane-dependent MMPs, and others. It is well known that Helicobacter pylori infection is correlated with gastric carcinogenesis. of the two gelatinases MMP-9 has been shown to be upregulated because of H. Pylori infection whereas MMP-2 was poorly affected gastric tumor biopsies. In this study, we investigated the expression levels of MMP-2 and MMP-9 genes which belong to the gelatinase group of MMPs. We studied 27 gastric tumor biopsy samples of which 60% are infected with H. pylori. The expression levels of genes were investigated by semi-quantitative RT-PCR. Both MMP-9 and MMP-2 expression was determined in 17 of 27 gastric tumor biopsies (63%). Ten out of 17 tumor samples that were MMP-9 positive (59%) and 8 out of 17 tumor samples that were MMP-2 positive (47) were also H. pylori infected. These results show that H. pylori infection is correlated with both MMP-9 and MMP-2 expression in gastric tumors.

FIGREF182.text: The aim of the present study was to employ an in vivo model of retinal excitotoxicity and investigate the neuroprotective effect of SRIF and analogs, when administered intravitreally. Methods: Adult Sprague Dawley (250-300 g) rats were employed. The animals received AMPA (21,42,84 nmol/eye) or PBS (50 mM) intravitreally. Time dependent responses(1,8,16,30 days) were examined in animals after AMPA (42 nmol/eye) injection. Animals received AMPA (42 nmol) alone or in combination with SRIF (10-5,10-4 M) or the SRIF receptor (sst) selective ligands BIM23014 (sst2/5,10-5,10-4 M), L-779,976 (sst2, 10-6,10-5,10-4 M), L-797,591 (sst1,10-4 M) and L-803,087 (sst4, 10-4M). Retinal cell loss and protection was assessed with immunohistochemistry (IHC) and TUNEL staining. IHC/western blot analysis and radioimmunoassay assessed the viability of sst2A receptors and tissue levels of SRIF, respectively, in control and AMPA treated tissue. Results: AMPA affected retinal viability dose-dependently and resulted in total and major loss of ChAT and bNOS immunoreactivity, respectively, 24 hours after its administration. This loss was sustained up to 30 days for ChAT-and 8 days for bNOS-expressing amacrine cells. No changes were observed in other retinal cells or in levels of SRIF and sst 2 immunoreactivity. SRIF protected the retina from the AMPA insult in a dose-dependent manner by activating selectively sst 2 receptors.

FIGREF187.text: Results: This work describes the distribution and expression of the ankyrin genes found in wMel genome in 11 Wolbachia strains that induce different phenotypic effects in their hosts. Most ankyrins present patchy distribution and expression patterns. The variation in the subcellular localization of the ank-proteins analysed suggests different possible functions. Conclusions: In conclusion, molecular and cellular analysis across different Wolbachia strains has revealed considerable variation in the distribution, expression and subcellular localization of ankyrin genes. This variation may reflect different roles of ankyrin proteins on the establishment of host-Wolbachia symbiosis and the induction of reproductive abnormalities such as parthenogenesis, feminization, male killing and cytoplasmic incompatibility.

FIGREF188.text: Bucharest, Faculty of Biology, Bucharest, ROMANIA Introduction: Respiratory complex I is the main entry site for reducing equivalents from the central metabolism to the respiratory chain in all organisms that have an electron-transport system. Deficiencies in complex I have been reported as the cause of many neurodegenerative diseases, such as Parkisonism. The Gram-negative a-proteobacterium Zymomonas mobilis, a member of the sub-group of bacteria from which mitochondria have evolved, can be used as a model for the study of interactions between the constituents of complex I. Methods: Extraction of the complex I enzymes was performed using a chaotropic reagent. Native PAGE and zymograms were performed according to Quiles et al.[1]. Purification of proteins with Ni + -NTA chromatography was performed according to Rohdich et al.[2]. Results: Zymomonas mobilis cells posses complex I NAD(P)H oxidase activity readily assayed in zymograms. The genome of Z. mobilis apparently contains only six putative genes, as compared to the 14 components of complex I in other bacteria. Two of the genes, predicted from the published genome of Z.mobilis ZM4 encoding products with NAD(P)H-oxidase activity are indicated as rnfE and rnfG homologues. Overexpression of the rnfG homologue resulted in a product which retains NADH-oxidase activity, but lacks full NADPH-oxidase activity. Conclusions: Both rnfG and rnfE homologues are required for full recovery of NADPH-activity of the respiratory complex I in Zymomonas mobilis cells.References: 1. Quiles et al., Plant. Physiol. Biochem. 2000; 38: 225-232. 2. Rohdich et al., Eur. J. Biochem. 2001; 268: 3190-3197. PP5A-4 Permeability transition in mitochondria from the Endomyces magnusii yeast R. Zvyagilskaya and E. Sukhanova Bach Institute of Biochemistry, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, RUSSIA Introduction: Mitochondria are of primary importance in initiating apoptosis in mammalian cells, and the major player in this process is the regulated non-specific, cyclosporin A-sensitive mitochondrial permeability transition (pore, mPTP). So far little is known about a mPTP-like pore in yeast mitochondria. Previously we have shown (Deryabina et al., Biochem (M) 2004; 69: 1261-1270.) that E. magnusii mitochondria possessing the fully competent respiratory chain and a high-capacitive 2+ transport system (Bazhenova et al., JBC 1998; 273: 4372-4377.) do not undergo the typical mPTP. The goal of this study was to induce another types of nonspecific permeability transition in tightly-coupled E. magnusii mitochondria. Methods: Large amplitude mitochondrial swelling and collapse of the membrane potential were used as parameters demonstrating mPTP-like induction.Results: Endomyces magnusii mitochondria did not undergo the Ca 2+ -fatty acid-dependent cyclosporine A-insensitive pore (Sultan and Sokolove. ABB 2001; 386: 52-61.) or a pore mediated by anaerobiosis, depletion of intramitochondrial adenine nucleotide pools, deenergization of mitochondria and by addition of high phosphate concentrations at acidic pH values. Prooxidants (a combination of phenylarsine oxide, menadione and oxaloacetate) caused only regulated membrane depolarization without swelling of mitochondria. ATP prevented prooxidant-induced membrane depolarization and this 'recoupling' effect of ATP was almost totally abolished by Mg 2+ . The only pore found in E. magnusii mitochondria was a highly regulated ATP-dependent + -channel (mito + ) of 'animal type' opened in response to diazoxide and GTP and closed in the presence of ATP and 5-hydroxydecanoic acid. The effect of ATP was partially reversed by Mg 2+ and P i .Conclusions: A role of the mito + channel in commitment of E. magnusii cells to a programmed cell death process in response to different stimuli is suggested.Acknowledgement: This work was supported by the Russian Foundation for Basic Research (grant 06-04-49687).

FIGREF192.text: We have performed biochemical, cell biological and genetic analyses in P. falciparum to characterize the biological function of PfPMT and validate it as a therapeutic target.

FIGREF193.text: Conclusion: Our biological and pharmacological studies validate PfPMT as an excellent target for the development of novel antimalarial drugs that could inhibit both intraerythrocytic infection and transmission. The conditionally lethal phenotype of parasites lacking PfPMT could be used to create an attenuated malaria vaccine. References: 1. Pessi et al., PNAS 2004; 101: 6206-6211. 2. Pessi et al., J. Biol. FIGREF195.text: Applied Biochemistry and Biotechnology, Bucharest, ROMA-NIA, 2 University of Agronomical Sciences and Veterinary Medicine Bucharest, ROMANIA Introduction: Rhizoctonia solani is one of the most important soil borne fungal pathogens which develops diseases in tomato crops and others. Among the possible biological control agents of R. solani are bacteria belonging to Bacillus genus that could be used for obtaining of bioproducts. The aim of our studies was the evaluation of the expression of some genes coding for defence proteins when beneficial bacteria where applied, in the presence or absence of plant pathogens. Methods: In our experiments we used a Romanian strain of Bacillus spp. isolated from rhizosphere. The expression of defence-related genes in tomato seedlings (Lycopersicum esculentum Mill.) var. Marmande was analysed for responses induced by following interactions: tomato plants -R. solani, plants -B. licheniformis and plants treated with a mixture of B. licheniformis-R. solani. Genes expression affected by interaction between tomato plants and pathogenic or non-pathogenic microorganisms was determined by using reverse-transcriptase PCR (RT-PCR) techniques and quantitative assays of peroxidase (PO), b-1,3-glucanase and phenylalanine ammonia-lyase (PAL).

Aberrant HuR functions in innate cells have been considered contributory to the development of inflammatory disease. Previously, we have utilized a system of conditional HuR-overexpression and revealed an unprecedented anti-inflammatory effect (1).

FIGREF199.text: Biochemistry, 2 Department of Microbiology, Biology Research Center, Baqiyatallah Medical Sciences University, Tehran, IRANIntroduction: Leishmaniasis is a spectrum of diseases whose clinical manifestations depend on a combination of host and parasite factors. The disease affects at least 12 million individuals each year, with about 300 million people at risk. The formation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) cause oxidative damage to a number of molecules in cells, including membrane lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids. Superoxide dismutase (SOD) inactivates the superoxide radical. Catalase (CAT) inactivates hydrogen peroxide. Also, reduced glutathione (GSH) is an important intracellular antioxidant that reacts with oxygen free radicals. Malondialdehyde (MDA) is the end product of lipid peroxidation.

Rapala-Kozik Biophysics and Biotechnology, Faculty of Biochemistry, Jagiellonian University, Krakow, POLAND Introduction: Candida species are involved in severe mucosal infections as well as in the life-threatening systemic diseases in immunocompromised hosts. The major virulence factors of this fungus include hyphal formation, phenotypic switching, extracellular hydrolytic enzyme production and recognition of host cells and proteins by surface connected adhesins. In this work we test a hypothesis that the array of host proteins attracted by the Candida cell walls include all components of the kinin-generating system which may be activated during the Candida-mediated infections.

FIGREF203.text: Polydnaviruses (PDVs), symbionts of parasitic wasps (Hymenoptera), are injected into hosts (Lepidoptera) along with wasp eggs. PDV genes are expressed within the host and their products alter the host's physiology and ensure endoparasitic embryo and larval development. Our group studies the relationship between the wasp Cotesia congregata, its symbiotic PDV (CcBV) and the parasitized host Manduca sexta and analyzes the roles of CcBV proteins in host immunosuppression. The CcBv ankyrin-like (Ank) protein family is comprised of nine members each possessing four ankyrin repeats resembling the inhibitory domain of cactus, the inhibitor of Drosophila melanogaster NF-jB. Methods: Six CcBV ank genes were cloned into insect and mammalian expression vectors. To measure the effect of Ank proteins on NF-jB transcription, we employed the Firefly luciferase gene under the control of an insect antimicrobial peptide gene promoter containing NF-jB-like binding motifs or a mammalian NF-jB responsive promoter in transcriptional assays. Expression constructs were tested in multiple lepidopteran cell lines, such as Bombyx mori Bm5, Trichoplusia ni HighFiveä and Spodoptera frugiperda Sf21, and in mammalian HEK293 cells. Results: For the insect systems, the best luciferase expression was observed in Sf21 cells. The assessment of CcBV Ank effects on antimicrobial gene activation is still in progress. For the mammalian system, preliminary results have shown that at least three Ank proteins inhibit NF-jB transcription by approximately 20%. Conclusions: Some Ank proteins are implicated in the NF-jB pathway of a mammalian cell line. This is also currently tested in the insect cell line Sf21.PP5B-24Development of an immunosorbent assay for the quantification of serotype-specific anti-Coxsackievirus antibodies M. Mavrouli, N. Spanakis, A. Tsakris and J. Routsias National and Kapodistrian University of Athens, Athens, GREECE

Gozdzicka-Jozefiak Adam Department of Molecular Virology, Faculty of Biology, Adam Mickiewicz University, Poznan, POLAND Introduction: Recent findings using two-dimensional elecrophoresis (2-DE) and tandem mass spectrometry analysis (LC-MS/MS) show, that milky sap of Chelidonium majus L. (Greater Celandine) is a complex mixture of 21 defence-and pathogenesis-related (PR) proteins [1]

FIGREF205.text: The incidence of mastitis in dairy cattle is highest at the drying off period and parturition, which are characterized by high levels of the lactogenic hormone prolactin (PRL). One of the most frequently isolated contagious pathogens causing mastitis is Staphylococcus aureus. However, the role of PRL on S. aureus infection in mammary epithelium has not been studied. We evaluated the effect of bovine PRL (bPRL) on S. aureus internalization in a primary culture of bovine mammary epithelial cells (bMEC) and on the expression of cytokine and innate immune response genes. Methods: Invasion assays of S. aureus ATCC 27543 strain in bMEC were carried out with different concentrations of bPRL. We analyzed the effect of bPRL on the expression of tumor necrosis factor-a (TNFa), interleukin 1b (IL-b), b defensin and inducible nitric oxide synthase (iNOS) by RT-PCR, as well as on NO production in bMEC infected with S. aureus. Results: bPRL (5 ng/ml) enhances 3-fold the internalization of S. aureus (ATCC 27543) into bMEC. Additionally, bPRL is able to upregulates the expression of TNF-a, IL-b and iNOS mRNAs. However, bPRL together with S. aureus infection did not modify the expression of TNF-a and iNOS mRNAs, while they down-regulated the expression of b defensin and IL-b mRNAs, as well as NO production. Conclusions: bPRL stimulates the internalization of S. aureus into bMEC. These cells were able to raise different innate immune responses to infection in the presence of the hormone, suggesting that PRL together with S. aureus regulate diverse host innate immune elements.PP5B-28Adenylate cyclase toxin, Ca 2+ influx and lipid rafts: impairment of cell adhesivenessH. Ostolaza 1,2 , C. Martin Plagaro 1,2 and G. Gomez Bilbao 1,2 1 Unidad de Biofıśica (Centro Mixto CSIC-UPV/EHU), Bilbao, SPAIN, 2 Departmento de Bioquıḿica, Universidad del Paıś Vasco, Bilbao, SPAINIntroduction: Adenylate cyclase toxin (ACT), a protein secreted by the whooping cough Bordetella pertussis, is an essential virulence factor for this bacterium. Its role in the pathogenesis of B. pertussis was clearly demonstrated in a murine respiratory model (Gross et al., 1992). Though ACT has been shown to bind in vitro a variety of cell types, in vivo studies strongly suggest that the natural hosts for ACT are immune cells such as alveolar macrophages and neutrophils, and a specific receptor, the a M b 2 ? integrin (CD11b/CD18), has been proposed in hematopoietic cells(Guermonprez et al., 2001). Integrins of the b2 family are heterodimeric receptors directly implicated in cell-cell or cell-ECM adhesion processes that are of vital importance for a correct functioning of the immnune system. In the present work we have investigated the calcium influx induced by ACT in Jurkat 774A.1 cells and its effects on the integrin-mediated adhesive properties of these cells. Methods: Intracellular calcium fluctuations were determined following calcium entry into Fura-2 loaded individual cells using Olympus microscope IX 50 based spectofluorometer.

FIGREF206.text: Human papillomavirus (HPV) is known to play an important etiological role in the genesis of cervical cancer, but only a very small proportion of infected women develop invasive cervical cancer. Recent studies have revealed that cervical cancers associated with high-risk HPV showed over-expression of the p16 protein.Methods: The cytological investigation and the viral determination were performed using 265 cervical swabs. The cytological spectrum varied from inflammatory process (130), ASCUS (24), LSIL (54) to HSIL (22). The viral genotyping was performed using a commercial kit (INNOLiPa). 52 HPV16 positive cases were tested by PCR/Southern blot for viral physical genome status. To clarify the relationship between p16 expression and HPV infection, immunocytochemistry and qPCR techniques were performed.

FIGREF207.text: Biology, Bucharest, ROMANIA, 2 Center of Applied Biochemistry and Biotechnology, Bucharest, ROMANIA, 3 Faculty of Biotechnology, Bucharest, ROMANIA Introduction: Plant cells perceive nonpathogenic bacterial colonization as an external aggression and defensive mechanisms are activated.

FIGREF208.text: Restriction of use of antibiotics has forced the poultry producers and researchers to look for other alternatives capable of effective protection of newly hatched chicks against Salmonella. The lectin mechanisms and oligoglucides involvement in bacterial adhesion suggested the subject of this research, the investigation of the interaction of some lectin preparations with Salmonella cultures in vitro and the investigation of the protective effect in vivo.

FIGREF209.text: Osta et al., Science 2004; 303: 2030-2032. The serine protease auto-transporters (SPATE) constitute a family of conserved, virulence proteins secreted by enteric Gramnegative bacteria. An auto-transporter polypeptide is comprised of three domains: an N-terminal domain required for its inner membrane translocation; an internal passenger domain secreted to the extracellular environment; and a C-terminal translocator domain capable of forming a (-barrel in the outer membrane and mediating the secretion of the passenger domain to the cell surface. Using the prototype SPATE protein Tsh as a model for the study of auto-transporter secretion, we wanted to identify amino-acid residues in the (-barrel that might play a role in the secretion of the Tsh passenger. Methods: Twenty known SPATE auto-transporters were aligned and four conserved motifs in the translocator domains were identified.

FIGREF211.text: Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, University of Podlasie, Siedlce, POLAND Introduction: Plants have constitutive/inducible mechanisms for resistance/ defence against insects. Chemical resistance of particular plant depends on specific molecules and their adverse effects to cell compounds/biochemical pathways of insect. Some o-diphenols (DP), monophenols (MP) and polyphenols (PP) of the cereal plant are recognizing as such molecules to the aphid. Biochemical mechanism of the phenolic toxicity and the aphid counter-adaptation, in particular the phenolic pro-oxidant capacity and the aphid anti-oxidant response are not specified. This paper reports on identification of H 2 O 2 and variability of the catalase (CAT) activity in Rhopalosiphum padi L. and Sitobion avenae F. in consequence of dietary DP , MP and PP. Methods: Assay of H 2 O 2 and CAT in extracts of aphids accomplished via the UV-spectrophotometry (wavelength: 240 nm).Results: H 2 O 2 is generated due to the red-ox reactions of DP and PP i.e. caffeic, gallic and chlorogenic acids and also (+) -catechin. Hydroquinone and MP i.e. p-coumaric and p-hydroxybenzoic acids are not specified as sources of H 2 O 2 in the aphids. Dietary DP and PP i.e. caffeic acid and (+) -catechin similarly as H 2 O 2 show inductive effects on the CAT activity of R. padi and S. avenae. Ingestion of the phenolics present within the wheat foliages has significant positive effect on the CAT activity of the aphids.

FIGREF212.text: Indirubins are potent inhibitors of cyclin-dependent kinases (CDKs) and glycogen synthase kinase (GSK-3). We investigated the activity of indirubins towards L. donovani promastigotes, amastigotes and transfectants over-expressing GSK-3b as well as the leishmanial GSK-3b (LdGSK-3b) and CDK1 (CRK3) homologues. Methods: The leishmanicidal activity of indirubins was assessed using the Alamar blue assay. Flow cytometry was used for cell cycle analysis and apoptosis-like death was evaluated using Annexin V/PI and Tunel labeling. LdGSK-3b over-expressing transfectants were used for purification of LdGSK-3b and subsequent kinase assays. Results: Out of sixteen indirubins tested 6-Br-indirubin-3'-oxime (6-BIO) was the most potent inhibitor of promastigotes and amastigotes with an IC 50 of 0.8 lM and induced G2/M cell cycle arrest, consistent with CRK3 inhibition and apoptosis-like death. Kinase assays showed that 6-BIO inhibits LdGSK-3b and CRK3 (kindly provided by Karen Grant) with IC 50 values of 150 nM and 20 nM respectively. However, LdGSK-3b overexpression in L.donovani counteracts 6-BIO growth inhibition (IC 50 of 1.57 lM) and G2/M phase arrest and reduces the levels of apoptosis-like death. Conclusions: 6-BIO was more active against CRK3, suggesting that selectivity of 6-Br indirubins for mammalian GSK-3 over CDKs(1)is not valid in Leishmania. Over-expression of LdGSK-3b counteracts the effects of 6-BIO, suggesting that LdGSK-3b is directly or indirectly involved in G2/M phase transition and 6-BIO-induced apoptosis. Our results validate both kinases as drug targets and open up the possibility of designing Leishmaniaselective indirubin-based inhibitors for treating leishmaniasis.Reference: 1. Meijer et al. Chem. Biol. 2003; 10: 1255-1266. FIGREF220.text: diyl]dimethylene} bispyridinium dibromide (1,4-DHP lipid) is a gene transfection agent[1]. Methods: 1.4-DHP lipid structure was calculated with ab initio quantum mechanics (program GAMESS) to obtain the charges for molecular dynamics (MD) with AMBER 8.0 force field. DHP-lipid molecules were subjected to MD from the initial structure of a periodic lipid bilayer-water box, with a small amount of excessive water on the lipid edges to ensure the mobility of lipid molecules. Results: After 14 ns of MD simulation the lipid molecules with the fatty acid tails started to squeeze from one bilayer layer to another one. After 35 ns few lipid molecules turned with their charged heads to the side of the lipid bilayer and after 100 ns a profound tubular micelle structure began to form. The tubular micelle structure becomes more perfect during the course of simulation of 300 ns.Conclusions: Conclusion is that one of the gene transfection agent 1.4-DHP lipid structures is a tubular micelle. Acknowledgements: Calculations were performed on computers of the Gdansk Academic Computer Center TASK. Reference: 1. Z. Hyvonen, A. Plotniece, I. Reine, B. Chekavichus, G. Duburs. FIGREF221.text: Results: Results indicate that the Tet O, Tet M, Tet A, Tet Q and Tet 32 classes of tetracycline resistance genes are the most commonly shared between individuals. Bioinformatic analyses of genes place them in wide ranging phylogenetic groups including Bacteroides, Firmicutes and Bifidobacteria. Conlcusions: The application of TRACA to the human GI microbiota enables access to genes present on mobile metagenome that might otherwise be difficult to obtain using cultivation based strategies. Tetracycline resistant genes are common to the mobile metagenome and metagenome of different individuals and show a wide range of diversity indicating different host species and the evolutionary divergence of this gene. Furthermore, the presence of genes that confer antibiotic resistance on the mobile metagenome may have significant implications for treatment of the host and also enable the spread of antibiotic resistance through the gene pool via horizontal gene transfer. Ruklisha University of Latvia, Riga, LATVIA Introduction: Despite the successful construction of L-valine overproducing strains during last years, research of optimum cellular physiology enhancing amino acid overproduction by these strains is still topical. FIGREF229.text: biosynthesis regulation by the AtoS-AtoC two-component system in DatoDAEB E. coli E. Theodorou 1 , M. C. Theodorou 1 and D. A. Kyriakidis 1,2 1 Laboratory of Biochemistry, Department of Chemistry, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Thessaloniki, GREECE, 2 National Hellenic Research Foundation, Athens, GREECEThe AtoS-AtoC two-component system in E. coli consists of the membrane bound AtoS sensor kinase and the AtoC response regulator. Upon acetoacetate-mediated induction, AtoS autophosporylates and consequently phosphorylates, thereby activating, AtoC. AtoC regulates positively the transcriptional activation of atoDAEB operon, encoding for enzymes involved in short-chain fatty acid catabolism. AtoS-AtoC system acting on its target atoDAEB operon regulates the biosynthesis and the intracellular distribution of short-chain poly-(R)-3-hydroxybutyrate (cPHB), a biopolymer with many physiological roles in E. coli, under acetoacetate or spermidine induction. The extrachromosomal introduction of the atoSC locus and the atoDAEB operon in Dato-DAEB strain increases cPHB levels in the presence of the inducers. Enhancement of cPHB is also achieved by the AtoS-AtoC system in the absence of its target operon. DatoDAEB cells overproducing the AtoS kinase accumulate only the basal cPHB levels independently to the presence of acetoacetate or spermidine. However, AtoC up-regulates cPHB in the absence of atoDAEB operon upon induction. Exposure of DatoDAEB cells which overproduce the AtoS-AtoC system or only AtoC to cerulenin or acrylic acid, results to reduction of cPHB levels. Cerulenin, the inhibitor of fatty acids biosynthesis pathway, caused the more pronounced down-regulation of cPHB. These data suggest that in the absence of atoDAEB operon, AtoC possibly regulates cPHB biosynthesis through the fatty acid metabolism pathways, with the biosynthesis being the most potent mechanism.This work was supported by doctoral research scholarships of the 'State Scholarships Foundation' and 'Onassis Foundation'. -AtoC system in E. coli is a member of the two-component system (TCS) family. Upon induction by external stimuli, the membrane sensor kinase AtoS autophosphorylates and subsequently it phosphorylates the response regulator AtoC, which activates the transcription of the atoDAEB operon encoding for proteins involved in short-chain fatty acid catabolism. Additionally, the AtoS-AtoC system and its target atoDAEB operon regulate the complexed poly-(R)-3hydroxybutyrate (cPHB) biosynthesis under acetoacetate or spermidine induction. Global analyses of the E. coli TCSs have revealed that AtoS-AtoC might be involved in many additional processes. This study aimed to investigate the possible contribution of the AtoS-AtoC TCS in E. coli chemotaxis. E. coli DatoSC and atoSC + and their transformed derivatives with plasmids overproducing the whole or part of the AtoS-AtoC TCS, were grown with Asp, Ser, Met or Glu as chemoattractants, in the presence of acetoacetate, spermidine, histamine, C48/80 or Ca 2+ . Chemotaxis was evaluated by determining cell motility using the swarm agar assay. DatoSC cells were not motile independently to the chemoattractant or the agent added. The extrachromosomal introduction of the AtoS-AtoC system in DatoSC bacteria restored their motility. The AtoS-AtoC expressing cells demonstrated an agent concentration-dependent motility in the presence of Asp and Ser. DatoSC cells expressing either AtoS or AtoC in trans demonstrated no response to the chemoattractants independently of the agents added. These data suggested that the AtoS-AtoC TCS may participate in the E. coli chemotactic response, thus being implicated in bacterial adaptation to continuously changing environments. PP6B-8 Cyclic ADP-ribose increases human mesenchymal stem cells proliferation through the modulation of spontaneous Ca 2+ oscillations R. Tao 1 , C.-P. Lau 1 , H.-C. Lee 2 and G.-R. Li 1,2 1 Department of Medicine, The University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, CHINA, 2 Department of Physiology, The University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, CHINA Introdution: Human bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells (hMSCs) playan important role in the regulation of hematopoiesis. Cyclic ADP-ribose (cADPR), a universal Ca 2+ mobilizer produced by hMSCs, has been demonstrated to be an important factor in the regulation of hematopoietic stem cells proliferation. However, its biological effects on hMSCs are not understood. This study was to investigate the effects of cADPR on Ca 2+ signaling, cell proliferation and differentiation in hMSCs.

FIGREF232.text: Cellular and Molecular Neurobiology, Hellenic Pasteur Institute, Athens, GREECE, 2 Group of Molecular Virology and Vectorology, Institut Pasteur Paris, Paris, FRANCE,3  Laboratory for Perception and Memory, Institut Pasteur Paris, Paris, FRANCE Introduction: Neural stem cells (NSC) remain in two areas of the adult mammalian brain, the subventricular zone (SVZ) and the hippocampus. Ongoing neurogenesis via the SVZ -rostral migratory stream (RMS) pathway maintains neuronal replacement in the olfactory bulb (OB) throughout life. The mechanisms of postnatal neurogenesis largely depend on controlling the balance between precursor cell proliferation and differentiation. Cend1 is a neuronal lineage specific regulator implicated in cell cycle exit and differentiation of precursor cells in the embryonic neural tube. Here we investigated its role in postnatal neurogenesis. Methods: For the functional study of Cend1 in vitro we used new generation lentiviral vectors in SVZ-derived neurospheres and explants to over express and silence Cend1, as well as Western blot, Real Time RT-PCR, Luciferase assay and immunohistochemistry to assess Cend1 functional potential in postnatal neurogenesis. Results: Endogenous Cend1 distribution in vivo revealed that it is expressed in low levels in neuronal precursors of the adult SVZ and in high levels in post-mitotic OB interneurons. We found that Cend1 overexpression decreases proliferation and favours neuronal differentiation, while its downregulation using RNAi vectors yields the opposite phenotype. Moreover, Cend1 overexpression down-regulates protein levels of Notch1 and its downstream effector Hes1, while forced expression of the proneural gene Neurogenin-1 in neurospheres up-regulates Cend1. Conclusion: Our results demonstrate that Cend1 participates in cell cycle exit regulation and neuronal differentiation mechanisms during postnatal SVZ neurogenesis and becomes crucial for the transition from neuroblasts to mature neurons when reaching high levels.PP6C-4 Induction of apoptosis with staurosporine in knockout H2AX mouse embryonic stem cells results in chromatin relaxation and disorganization N. FIGREF235.text: Institute, Athens, GREECE, 2 National Institute for Medical Research, London, UK Introduction: During development, control of proliferation of neuronal precursors plays a crucial role in determining the number of neurons generated. BM88/Cend1 is a neuronal protein that participates in the complex pathways regulating cell cycle progression/exit and differentiation in the central nervous system. Gain of function approaches both in vitro and in vivo in the chick neural tube, show that BM88 negatively regulates proliferation of neuronal precursors while promoting their premature differentiation. The opposite is observed with RNAi silencing in embryonic and adult neural stem cells. Physiologically, BM88 is expressed at low levels in neuronal progenitors and at higher levels in differentiated neurons, including the Purkinje and granule neurons of the postnatal cerebellum. Methods: We have generated BM88 knockout mice, in which the BM88 coding and 3¢ untranslated region have been removed and replaced by the b-galactosidase gene. To assess the effect of BM88 ablation, we used PCR, southern blot and immunohistochemistry. Results: Loss of BM88 in the cerebellum affects granule cell proliferation and differentiation. At postnatal day 6, the external granule layer characterized by extended proliferation, is augmented by 12% in BM88 null mice. BrdU incorporation is also increased by 20%, whereas the thickness of the internal granule layer, where differentiated granule cells lie, is reduced by 11%, as revealed by NeuN immunostaining.Conclusions: Our data illustrate the dual function of BM88/Cend1 in controlling cell cycle exit and differentiation in the developing of Thessaloniki, Thessaloniki, GREECE, 2 Immune Disease Institute and Department of Pathology, Harvard Medical School, Boston, MA, USA, 3 Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Thessaloniki, GREECE Introduction: Hemen (iron-protoporphyrin IX) is synthesized in mitochondria and imported from plasma as a by-product of hemoglobin catabolism. Intracellularly, heme promotes self-renewal and erythroid differentiation of hematopoietic cells through the regulation of globin and other genes. We investigated the transport, intracellular distribution and interactions of hemin with cell components involved in the activation of b-and e-globin genes. Methods: K562 cells were incubated with [ 59 Fe]-hemin and hemin uptake was measured under regular and serum-free conditions. Components from subcellular fractions of [ 59 Fe]-hemin cells were first isolated by heme-affinity chromatography and then characterised further by gel filtration and SDS-PAGE electrophoresis. Band shifting experiments were carried out to investigate whether hemin influences the interactions of nuclear transcription factors with globin gene promoters.

FIGREF240.text: Expression of insulin receptor substrate-1 promotes occupancy and activation of rDNA, cyclin D1 and c-myc promoters O. Dalmizrak 1 and R. Baserga 2 1 Department of Biochemistry, Faculty of Medicine, Hacettepe University, Ankara, TURKEY, 2 Department of Cancer Biology, Kimmel Cancer Center, Thomas Jefferson University, Philadelphia, PA, USAIntroduction: The insulin receptor substrate-1 (IRS-1) is a docking protein for both type I insulin-like growth factor receptor (IGF-IR) and insulin receptor (IR). IRS-1 sends mitogenic and anti-apoptotic signal. It also inhibits differentiation and promotes transformation of cells. IGF-IR is a transmembrane receptor and belongs to the tyrosine kinase receptor family. When activated by its ligands, it plays an important role in growth and survival of cells. Methods: BT-20 cells originated from a human breast cancer and they don't express IRS-1. Two different cell lines were derived from parental BT-20 cells, one expressing IRS-1 protein with a nuclear localization signal (BT-20/NLS) and the other expressing the high levels of IRS-1 (BT-20/159). Nuclear translocation of IRS-1 was determined by confocal microscopy. Chromatin immunoprecipitation was used to understand the occupancy of rDNA, cyclin D1 and c-myc promoters and activation of these promoters was followed by using luciferase reporter assay. Results: Our confocal microscopy results have shown that after stimulation with IGF-1, IRS-1 translocates to the nucleus. Nuclear translocation of IRS-1 has also been confirmed by chromatin immunoprecipitation experiments. It has been shown that IRS-1 binds both rDNA and cyclin D1 promoters in a time dependent manner and activates both promoters and also c-myc promoter. Conclusion: These results indicate that in BT-20 cells expression of IRS-1 activates promoters involved in cell growth and cell proliferation which affects the maintaining of transformed phenotype.

Fuchs 1 , D. Provaznikova 1 , I. Marinov 1 , K. Hematology and Blood Transfusion, Prague, CZECH REPUBLIC, 2 General Faculty Hospital, Prague, CZECH REPUBLIC Introduction: Transforming growth factor-beta1 (TGF-b1)-regulated apoptosis is still poorly understood and is cell type and context-dependent. Bortezomib (N-pyrazinecarbonyl-L-phenylalanine-L-leucine boronic acid, VELCADE, formerly known as PS-341 or MLN-341, Millenium Pharmaceuticals, Inc., Cambridge, MA) is the first member of proteasome inhibitors which obtained approval as chemotherapeutic agent for the treatment of relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma. We studied the effect of TGF-b1 and of bortezomib on induction of apoptosis in human acute myeloid leukemia cell lines ML-1, ML-2, CTV-1 and KASUMI1. Methods: Leukemia cells were preincubated for 24-96 hour without addition (control group) or with TGF-b1 (5 ng/ml or 10 ng/ml) or with bortezomib (4 nM or 10 nM). Apoptosis was detected by flow cytometry using annexin V-FITC/propidium iodide assay and by cell cycle analysis. Caspase-3-like enzyme activity was measured by enzymatic cleavage of fluorogenic peptide substrate, Ac-DEVD-7-amino-4-methylcoumarin. Statistical significance of the experimental results was analyzed by Student´s paired t-test. Results and conclusions: TGF-b1 inhibited DNA synthesis only in KASUMI-1 cells but not in other leukemia cells used. Bortezomib (10 nM) was potent inhibitor of DNA synthesis in all four types of leukemia cells and induced apoptosis in KASUMI-1, ML-2 and CTV-1 cells but not in ML-1 cells. KASUMI-1 and ML-2 cells were also sensitive to induction of apoptosis by TGF-b1 but in lesser extent than by bortezomib. Kinetics of apoptosis was different in individual cell lines and was slower in induction by TGF-b1 than with bortezomib. Acknowledgements: This study was supported by the IGA, Ministry of Health, CR (NR/9045-3). Alcohol consumption increases the permeability of the intestine, permitting certain bacterial endotoxins to pass through the intestinal wall into the portal blood stream. Upon reaching the liver, endotoxins stimulate the Kupffer cells, the infiltrating neutrophils and macrophages to produce cytokines. Chronic alcohol consumption activates certain detoxifying enzymes in the liver. The metabolism of alcohol by these enzymes generates ROS (reactive oxygen species) which, in turn, stimulate cytokine production. Proinflammatory cytokines IL-1ß and IL-6 elicit defensive responses in parenchymal cells, including activation of apoptosis (via IL-1ß). IL-6 plays an important antiapoptotic role in the liver, stimulating liver repair after injury. In addition, IL-8 promotes neutrophilia as well as neutrophil infiltration of liver tissue. We were interested in studying the cytokine signals which are involved in the development of alcoholic liver injury. Methods: We are focusing on three cytokines: IL-1ß, IL-6 and IL-8. The seric levels of these three cytokines were determined in 30 patients with chronic alcoholism (9 women and 21 men, ages 28-57 years), without any clinical or paraclinical proof of alcoholic liver disease using ELISA kits. Results: demonstrate a significant increase of IL-6 and IL-8 seric levels, by comparison with those obtained from the control subjects.Conclusion: IL-6 and IL-8 are implicated in the shift of the balance of cytokine-induced defensive and damage responses in hepatocytes. FIGREF245.text: , E. Yelo, M. V. Bernardo, M. J. Alcaraz, A. Parrado Department of Immunology, Virgen de la Arrixaca Hospital, Servicio Murciano de Salud-FFIS, El Palmar-Murcia, SPAINIntroduction: The Rho GTPases form a subgroup of the Ras superfamily that regulates a wide spectrum of cellular functions. Dock/CZH proteins are a new family of guanine nucleotide exchange factors (GEFs) for Rho GTPases. The Dock-D or Zizimin subfamily is composed of three members, two of which, Dock9 and Dock11, are activators of the Rho GTPase Cdc42. Here we report the molecular cloning of Dock10, identified as an Interleukin-4 (IL4) induced protein in B lymphocytes. Methods: Tissue expression of Dock10 was analyzed by Northern Blot. Differential expression and modulation by IL4 in lymphocyte subsets was analyzed by Western Blot. Stable clones of HeLa cells with inducible expression of Dock10 or HA-Dock10 were generated using the tet-off system. Subcellular expression was analyzed by immunofluorescence. In vitro interaction with major Rho GTPases, e.g. Cdc42, Rac1 and RhoA, was tested by pulldown assays. Results: Dock10 was expressed in a variety of tissues, being most prominent in peripheral blood (PB) leukocytes. Dock10 was expressed at similar levels in PB-B cells and PB-T cells. However, IL4 only induced Dock10 expression in PB-B cells. Dock10 was localized mainly in the cytoplasm of the Dock10-expressing clones. Dock10 interacted in vitro with nucleotide-depleted Cdc42 and Rac1, but not with RhoA. Conclusions: These data suggest that, like Dock9 and Dock11, Dock10 may act as specific GEF for Cdc42 and in addition for Rac1. The induction of Dock10 expression by IL4 in mature B cells suggests a role for Dock10 in IL4-induced B-cell activation.PP7A-30Nuclear targeting of FBPase is controlled by beta-adrenergic receptor signaling cascade A. Gizak and D. Rakus Department of Animal Psysiology, Wroclaw University, Wroclaw, POLAND Introduction: Muscle fructose 1,6-bisphosphatase (FBPase), a wellknown regulatory enzyme of glyconeogenic pathway has recently appeared to be actively transported into nuclei of cardiomyocytes. This surprising finding rised a questions concerning nuclear role of FBPase and the extracellular signals regulating its nuclear import. To addres these questions we have attempted to identify the membrane receptors and pathways transducing signals from cell surface to FBPase and engaged in the reversible FBPase targeting to the nuclei of the HL-1 cardiomyocytes. Methods: The effect of activation/inhibition of cardiomyocyte membrane receptors and their intracellular signal transduction pathways on nuclear transport of FBPase was analyzed in vitro, using immunofluorescence method, and in vivo, using protein transfection reagents introducing FITC-modified FBPase into differently stimulated HL-1 cells. Results: Results of both in vitro and in vivo experiments demonstrated that the most pronounced effect on nuclear localization of FBPase exerts stimulation of the beta-adrenergic receptors of HL-1 cells. Wihdrawal of noradrenalin from culture medium and inhibition of downstream target of beta-adrenergic receptor signaling cascade-protein kinase A resulted in FBPase active export from nucleus. Activators of adenylyl cyclase abolished the effect of noradrenalin withdrawal, suggesting that in FBPase nuclear import stimulation Gs protein is involved. Conclusions: Nuclear targeting of FBPase in HL-1 cells is under control of beta-adrenergic-dependent PKA stimulation. Since beta-adrenergic signaling regulates also cell division in neonatal and HL-1 cardiomiocytes, our results support the hypothesis that FBPase is engaged in the regulation of cell proliferation. decarboxylase (DDC) is the enzyme which catalyses the biosynthesis of dopamine (DA) by decarboxylating L-Dopa (L-3,4-Dihydroxyphenyl-alanine) to dopamine. In order to identify possible interactions of DDC with other proteins, the phage display method was employed, using as target molecule the human recombinant DDC. Specifically-bound phage clones were identified by sequencing. Interactions between human DDC and peptide epitopes, that share homology with Phophatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3k), as well as Neuroligin 3 (NLGN3) were detected. The PI3k signaling pathway has emerged as an important component required for the formation, survival and differentiation of the nervous system. Furthermore, synaptogenesis plays a central role in the survival of the nervous system. NLGN3 is a postsynaptic adhesion molecule that is related to neurodegenaration. Polyclonal antibodies, specific for PI3k and NLGN3, were raised in our laboratory and were found to immunopercipitate DDC activity in mouse kidney homogenates. Protein interactions were additionally studied by immunopercipitation under nondenaturing conditions followed by western blot analysis. Our data indicated the interaction between DDC with PI3k and NLGN3 in both, neural (SH-SY5Y) and nonneural (K293) human cell lines. The functional significance of the above observations is under further investigation.Acknowledgements: This project represents part of the graduate thesis of Miss Gkogkosi in the frame of the Graduate Programme in Clinical Biochemistry and Molecular Diagnostics leading to an M.Sc. degree. The Graduate Programme in Clinical Biochemistry and Molecular Diagnostics is funded by the EPEAEK grant from the Greek Ministry of Education. FIGREF248.text: of Wnt ligands and b-catenin in gastric tumors G. Sen 1 , S. Gencer 1 , M. B. Irmak Yazicioglu 1 , G. Faculty, Istanbul University, Istanbul, TURKEYWnts are a family of proteins which activate the wnt signaling pathway by binding frizzled receptors on the surface of the cell. Wnt pathway is commonly activated in many cancer types such as colorectal, oesophageal, and gastric cancer. In this study we aimed to analyze the expression of wnt genes and b-Catenin gene in gastric cancer tissues to determine the activity of wnt pathway in gastric carcinoma. We analyzed expression of Wnt1, Wnt3, Wnt4, Wnt5a, Wnt5b, and b-catenin genes in 21 gastric cancer tissues by semi-quantitative RT-PCR. We also studied b-catenin localization in parafine embedded tumor samples by immunohistochemistry. Results indicate that, Wnt1 is expressed in 15 (71.4%), Wnt3 is expressed in 9 (42.8%), Wnt4 is expressed in 13 (61.9%), Wnt5a is expressed in 17 (80.9%), Wnt5b is expressed in 13 (61.9%), and b-catenin is expressed in 13 (61.9%) out of 21 tumor samples. When we compare the co-expression of wnt genes and b-catenin in the tumor tissues, b-catenin was co-expresed with Wnt1 gene in 10 (47.6%), Wnt3 gene in 4 (19%), Wnt4 in 9 (42.8%), Wnt5a in 10 (47.6%), and Wnt5b in 7 (33.3%) out of 21 samples. However, immunohistochemistry results demonstrated that only 4 samples had nuclear b-catenin loacalization. Eventhough coexpression of Wnt and b-catenin genes were observed in tumor tissues localization results of b-catenin reveals that wnt signal is regulated by another regulatory molecule in the pathway or signal might be transduced by noncanonical wnt pathway in gastric carcinomas.

PP7A-48 Vasoactive intestinal peptide inhibits human retinal pigment epithelial cell proliferation via the adenyl cyclase pathway P. Kothary, N. Himani, J. Kim, J. Lee, S. Patel and M. Del Monte University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, USAPurpose: Human retinal pigment epithelial (hRPE) cells are specialized cells located between the choroid and neural retina. Abnormal proliferation of hRPE cells results in blinding proliferative vitreo-retinopathy. Since very little is known about the neural regulation of hRPE cells and the neuropeptide vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP) is known to influence the structure and function of hRPE cells, we examined the effect and mechanism action of VIP on hRPE cell proliferation. Methods: hRPE cell cultures were established from human eyes. Fetal bovine serum stimulated hRPE cell proliferation in presence and absence of VIP and H89, an adenyl cyclase inhibitor, was determined by the trypan blue exclusion method (T) and by 3H-thymidine incorporation (3H-thy). Data significance was analyzed by Student t test. Results: FBS (0-10%) stimulated hRPE proliferation in a dose-dependent manner as measured by 3H-thy as well as T. The addition of VIP (1 lM) inhibited FBS (1%) stimulated hRPE proliferation (3Hthy = 2.990 ± 1.041 vs. 12.116 ± 2.926, CPM ± SEM, n = 7, p < 0.05). Further, VIP (1 lM) inhibition of FBS (1%) stimulated 3H-thy was reversed in hRPE cells by H89 (1lM). (10289 ± 2191.7 vs. 2.990 ± 1.041, CPM ± SEM, n = 7, p < 0.05). Conclusion: We conclude that VIP inhibits FBS stimulated hRPE cell proliferation via the adenyl cyclase messenger pathway. Therefore, neural peptide control of hRPE cell proliferation may play a role in pathogenesis of proliferative eye diseases.

FIGREF254.text: Reference: 1. Lazarus et al. Nat Neurosci 2007; 10: 1131-1133. PP7A-52 Anti-fibrogenic effects of lithospermate B in human stellate cells and thioacetamide-induced cirrhotic rats K. S. Lee and Y.-H. Paik Department of Internal Medicine, Yonsei University College of Medicine, Seoul, KOREA Introduction: Lithospermate B (LAB) is an active component isolated from Salvia miltiorrhizae. We investigated the anti-fibrogenic effects of LAB and underlying mechanisms in hepatic stellate cells (HSCs) and cirrhotic animal model. Methods: For in vitro study, we used immortal human HSC cell line. MTS assay, intracellular ROS production, NF-jB transcriptional activation, and human MCP-1 were measured. Quantification of type 1 collagen in medium was done by Western blotting. For in vivo study, we used thioacetamide (TAA) to induce liver cirrhosis in Sprague-Dawley rats. Real-time PCR was used to quantify mRNA expressions of a-SMA, TGF-b 1, and collagen a 1. Results: LAB suppressed PDGF-induced HSCs proliferation (p < 0.05). H 2 O 2 induced increase in ROS formation in HSCs. LAB inhibited H 2 O 2 -induced ROS generation (H 2 O 2 vs. H 2 O 2 + LAB; 9.1 vs. 3.5-fold over baseline, p < 0.01). LAB significantly inhibited NF-jB activation in HSCs. Incubation of HSCs with LAB suppressed MCP-1 secretion compared to untreated controls (Untreated vs. LAB;239.2 ng/ml vs. 8.5 ng/ml, p < 0.01). LAB at higher than 50 uM significantly attenuated type 1 collagen secretion. Masson's trichrome stain showed attenuated hepatic fibrosis in TAA+LAB group (p < 0.05). mRNA expressions of a-SMA, TGF-b 1, collagen a 1 were significantly decreased in TAA+LAB group compared to TAA only group. Conclusions: Lithospermate B showed strong anti-fibrotic effects in both HSCs and cirrhotic rats possibly through potent anti-oxidative effect in human HSCs.

FIGREF261.text: Medicine, Institute of Laboratory Medicine, University of Pecs, Pecs, HUNGARY, 2 Department of Forensic Medicine, Faculty of Medicine, University of Pecs, Pecs, HUNGARYIntroduction: Hepcidin is the main hormone in human involved in regulation of serum iron level. It is synthesized by the liver as preprohepcidin, targeted to the secretory pathway, and cleaved into an active peptide by the serine protease furin. Hepcidin is acting through ferroportin: the hepcidin-ferroportin complex is internalized into the cells and degraded. Therefore high serum level of hepcidin reduces serum iron level. Methods: We used the BacterioMatch two-hybrid system, developed in bacteria to map the in vivo interactions of prohepcidin and hepcidin with ferroportin. To find the active binding portion of ferroportin, the protein was cut into parts, containing different number of transmembrane domains. To see the effect of hepcidin structure on binding activity, we systematically mutated one of each pair of cysteins to serine in the hepcidin molecule. Results: Preprohepcidin engages into weak interaction with the whole ferroportin molecule, but the binding is stronger with the ferroportin pieces. The M1 mutant preprohepcidin showed no interaction with ferroportin and with ferroportin pieces. The mature hepcidin is binding to whole ferroportin and to the first third portion of the N-terminal of ferroportin very efficiently. M1 mutant hepcidin gave no binding to the whole ferroportin molecule and weak binding to the ferroportin parts Conclusions: Our in vivo binding studies prove that mature hepcidin is binding much strongly to ferroportin compared to preprohepcidin, and it binds to the N-terminal part of the molecule. The binding between ferroportin and hepcidin will occur only if the disulphide bridges of hepcidin are intact. Pleiotrophin (PTN) is an 18 kDa secreted protein displaying high affinity for heparin. It has a neurite outgrowth promoting activity, is mitogenic for a variety of cell types, is angiogenic and is implicated in tumor growth and metastasis. In the present work, we studied the involvement of endogenous PTN in angiogenesis of the chicken embryo chorioallantoic membrane (CAM). Methods: A combination of methods was used, including western blot analysis, CAM transfection, angiogenesis assay, reverse transcriptasepolymerase chain reaction and haematoxylin-eosin staining of CAM paraffin sections. Results: PTN protein and mRNA amounts, as well as its interaction with receptor protein tyrosine phosphatase b/e (RPTPb/e) were maximal at days of on-going angiogenesis and decreased at later time points. Transfection of CAM cells with an anti-sense PTN gene construct led to a significant decrease in PTN amounts compared to vector control transfected CAMs, and a significant gene dose-dependent decrease in the number of CAM blood vessels. PTN is localized either in the endothelial cell lining of all vessels, or in the smooth muscle cells of the larger vessels. Interestingly, PTN was also detected in the nucleus of endothelial cells up to the 12th day of embryo development. This localization is possibly mediated by a direct interaction between PTN and nucleolin, as evidenced in both CAM and human umbilical vein endothelial cells, although the functional significance of this is currently unknown. Conclusions: These data suggest that endogenous PTN is involved in the development of new blood vessels in the chicken embryo CAM and that nucleolin may also have a role in this effect.PP7A-70 Regulation of mitochondrial morphology and cell survival by mitochondrial proteins: LETM1 and CTMP L. FIGREF262.text: Davila'' University of Medicine and Pharmacy, Bucharest, ROMANIA, 2 ''Stefan S. Nicolau'' Institute of Virology, Bucharest, ROMANIAThe activation of microglial cells represents the key element of the inflammatory response to viral aggression in acute viral meningitides (M-VIR) and encephalitis (E-VIR). The intensity of the inflammatory reactions and the efficacy of the protective mechanisms are two factors with control the course of neurological infections[1]. The present work is aimed to investigating the possible correlation of NT-3 with IL-6 in serum and CFS from patients with (M-VIR) and (E-VIR). The Pearson correlation coefficient (r) was calculated. The patients were divided into two groups: group I including patients with M-VIR, HSV-, treated or not with dexamethasone (DEXA+/DEXA-), n = 18 (20.3 ± 3.72 years) group II including patients with E-VIR, HSV+, DEXA+, n = 7 (20 ± 2.86 years. A negative correlation was found between NT-3 and IL-6 serum levels in patients of the group I DEXA+ and in those of the group II DEXA-with a moderate course, while a positive correlation between the two serum parameters was detected in patients of group II DEXA-who died. In addition, a negative correlation between the CFS NT-3 and IL-6 levels was found in survivor patients of the group I and II. The negative correlation between NT-3 and IL-6 suggests that NT-3 may exert a immunomodulatory action on IL-6 responses in survivor patients after the viral neurological infections. The absence of this correlation corresponded to imminence of death. In our study DEXA therapy did not influence the serum and CFS NT-3 dynamics.Reference: 1. R.B.Rock et al CMR, 2004; 17(4): 942-964. FIGREF268.text: Acknowledgements: Supported by Human Frontier Science Program (S.T.) and NIH grant CA055360 (D.B.-S.). Cell-matrix interactions initiate survival signals for several cell types. The loss of these interactions and subsequent loss of matrix contact results in anoikis, one form of apoptosis. Anoikis is regulated by cytokines such as TNF-a, a multifunctional cytokine involved in inflammation and other important cellular functions. We investigated the effect of TNF-a on MG63 osteosarcoma cell apoptosis, as a model to interfere with this process in normal and pathological conditions. Methods: Apoptosis induced by TNF-a+cycloheximide (CHX), was determined with nuclei DAPI staining, activation of effector caspase-3, proteolysis of its substrate PARP and expression levels of the Bcl-2 family of proteins. Results: MG63 were resistant to TNF-a-induced apoptosis unless they were pre-treated with CHX. Under these conditions the expression levels of TIMP-1, b 1 and a v b 3 integrins were reduced. MG63 cells treated with TNF-a only were resistant to apoptosis. In fact treatment of MG63 cells with TNF-a resulted in activation of the cell survival Akt/ PKB pathway and increased levels of TIMP-1 and a v b 3 integrin. This observation led us to suggest that TNF-a-induced up-regulation of TIMP-1 facilitates interactions between TIMP-1 and cell surface integrins and protects MG63 from TNF-a-induced apoptosis. Our results indicate that TIMP-1 interacts with b 1 and a v b 3 integrins; down-regulation of TIMP-1 expression by siRNA resulted in increased proteolysis of PARP and reduced Bcl-x L expression. Conclusions: Our data suggest that resistance to TNF-a-induced apoptosis correlated with increased expression of TIMP-1 which might protect osteosarcoma cells from anoikis through interaction with cell surface integrins and potentiation of the Akt-mediated survival pathway.PP7A-86Endogenous IL-1b and SOCS-1 induce cell apoptosis through suppression of the insulin signalling pathway in mouse pancreatic b-cells cultured in high glucose E. C. Tsilibary, P. D. Venieratos, G. I. Drossopoulou and P. V. Kitsiou Institute of Biology, National Centre for Scientific Research 'Demokritos', Athens, GREECE Introduction: Chronic hyperglycemia and inflammatory cytokines disrupt signal transduction pathways that promote b-cell survival, leading to the destruction of endocrine pancreas in type II diabetes We investigated the effect of high glucose concentration on the proximal events of insulin signalling in association with endogenous cytokine expression and b-cell survival in the mouse pancreatic b-cell line bTC-6. Methods: Western blotting and real-time PCR analysis were used to determine the effects of glucose on the activation of key insulin signaling molecules and IL-1b/SOCS-1 expression, respectively. Cell survival was assessed by TUNEL-FACS analysis and caspase-3 activation.

PP7A-88 Phospholipase D is involved in salicylic acid pathway in Arabidopsis thaliana suspension cells O. Valentova 1 , M. Flemr 1 , O. Krinke 1 , E. Ruelland 2 , L. Chemical Technology, Prague, CZECH REPUBLIC, 2 Universite Pierre et Marie Curie-Paris 6 and Centre National de la Recherche Scientifique, Ivry-Sur-Seine, FRANCE, 3 Institute of Experimental Botany AS CR, Prague, CZECH REPUBLICIn plants, the attack of an avirulent pathogen leads to the development of systemic acquired resistance (SAR). This defence mechanism involves a rapid increase in the intracellular level of salicylic acid (SA), both at the site of the infection and in distal tissues. SA triggers a complicated cascade of signalling events, which results in the expression of PR (Pathogenesis-Related) genes enabling the plant to coop with pathogen. The same signalling pathway is initiated in response to exogenous SA treatment. This study brings evidence of the crucial role of phospholipase D in the SA pathway. PLD catalyzes the hydrolysis of structural membrane phospholipids, yielding phosphatidic acid (PA), a second messenger involved in several plant signalling processes. In the presence of primary alcohols, PLD preferentially generates appropriate phosphatidylalcohols, which lack the signalling potential of PA. The presented results show the inhibitory effect of n-butanol on the induction of marker genes PR1 and WRKY38 in SA-treated Arabidopsis thaliana suspension-cultured cells. Clusters of 97 genes positively and 117 genes negatively regulated by PLD in response to SA were identified in a DNA microarray analysis of CATMA chips. The analysis of transcriptomic data indicated a close relation between the PLD activity and SA induced increase of polyphosphoinositides described previously in our laboratory(Krinke et al, 2007).Reference: Krinke O, Ruelland E, Valentova O, Vergnolle C, Renou JP, Taconnat L, Flemr M, Burketova L, Zachowski A. Phosphatidylinositol 4-kinase activation is anb early response to salicylic acid in Arabidopsis suspension cells. Plant Phys 2007; 144: 1347-1359. The renin-angiotensin system is a powerful signalling system for controlling controlling sodium balance, body fluid volume and arterial blood pressure. The octapeptide AngiotensinII (AngII) is the major mediator of this system. It is 3-8 fragments AngIV has sparked great interest because it enhances learning and memory and is anticonvulsant. These effects are not inhibited by AT 1/2 receptor antagonists but are mimicked by AT 4 receptor ligands pointing towards the involvement of the AT 4 receptor, recently characterized as the insulin-regulated aminopeptidase (IRAP), a membrane anchored zinc-dependent metalloproteinase. Methods: The metabolism of AngIV and LVVH7, both endogenous AT 4 receptor binding peptides was assessed in the presence of cell membranes of Chinese hamster ovary cells (CHO) and was compared with other angiotensin peptides. For this purpose we measured the inhibition of [ 125 I]-AngIV by these analogs in the presence or absence of divalent metal ion chelators. Results and Conclusions: The difference in potency between both experimental conditions indicates that these peptides are metabolized in the absence of chelators. This metabolism was prevented by the phosphinic derivative (R,S,S)-2-{3-[(1-Amino-ethyl)-hydroxy-phosphinoyl]-2-benzyl-propionylamino}-3-phenyl-propionic acid (compound 7B), an inhibitor of the metalloprotease aminopeptidase-N (AP-N). These findings explain recent data in which co-administration in the striatum of AngIV together with 7B at a concentration selective for AP-N elicited a more pronounced increase in the extracellular DA concentration than AngIV alone. By its capability to lengthen the half-life of exogenously applied AngIV in in vitro as well as in vivo experiments, 7B might represent an interesting tool in the study of AngIV mediated effects. PP7A-90 Nitric oxide-induced apoptosis of PC12 cells J. Varga, J. Bator and J. Szeberenyi Medical School, University of Pecs, Pecs, HUNGARYIntroduction: Nitric oxide (NO) plays a role in signal transduction events by different mechanisms: it activates guanylate cyclase and nitrosylates a number of proteins. In PC12 rat pheochromocytoma cells nerve growth factor (NGF) induces neuronal differentiation and promotes cell survival, and NO, as a second messenger, may have a role in these processes. On the other hand, high NO concentrations are cytotoxic. The aim of this study was to try to identify targets of NO in these processes. Methods: Sodium nitroprusside (SNP) was used as NO donor in wild type PC12 cells and a subclone expressing a dominant inhibitory Ras (MM17-26 cells). Standard techniques to analyze protein levels, protein phosphorylation and apoptotic events were employed. Results: Although SNP in small concentration accelerates NGFinduced differentiation of PC12 cells, it is unable to overcome the block of differentiation in MM17-26 cells. At high concentration SNP induces apoptosis in both PC12 and MM17-26 cells, accompanied by p38MAPK and JNK activation, cleavage of protein kinase R (PKR) and phosphorylation of eIF2a in both cell lines. NGF restores inhibited Akt phosphorylation caused by toxic SNP doses, but is unable to prevent SNP-induced apoptosis. Conclusions: The results of this work indicate that high concentrations of NO induce apoptotic cell death of PC12 cells in a Ras-independent manner. Death of the cells may be mediated by several stressactivated protein kinase pathways (p38, JNK and PKR), and by the inhibition of Akt-mediated survival signaling. Acknowledgements: This work was supported by grants from INTAS (51022), GVOP-362.

FIGREF270.text: graduate Program on Molecular Basis of Human Disease, Faculty of Medicine, University of Crete, Herakleion, GREECE, 2 Department of Clinical Chemistry-Biochemistry, Faculty of Medicine, University of Crete, Herakleion, GREECE, 3 Department of Pharmacology, Faculty of Medicine, University of Crete, Herakleion, GREECE Introduction: Adiponectin is the most abundant gene product in adipose tissue and circulates at high concentrations in the blood. It is believed that adiponectin has protective actions in the initiation and progression of atherosclerosis through anti-inflammatory effects which are exerted via macrophages, through suppression of the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines in response to LPS. We and others (Tsatsanis et al. BBRC 2005; 335 (4) 1254-63, Park et al. JBC 2007; 282 (30) 21695-703) have shown that the potential anti-inflammatory effect of adiponectin is due to the induction of macrophage tolerance. Here, we investigate the molecular mechanisms initiated by adiponectin that render macrophages tolerant to pro-inflammatory stimuli. Methods: Thioglycollate-elicitated peritoneal macrophages from TPL2-/-AKT1-/-and IRAK-M-/-mice were treated with adiponectin and LPS and molecular mechanisms of tolerance were studied with western blotting, Real time RT PCR and ELISA. Results: In this study we show that adiponectin controls macrophage tolerance by inducing IRAK-M expression via ERK/Tpl2 and PI3K/ AKT dependant mechanisms. IRAK-M expression is induced in mouse peritoneal macrophages upon gAd stimulation, leading to the suppression of the induction of pro-inflammatory cytokines by LPS. The tolerogenic properties of adiponectin were abrogated in IRAK-M deficient mice further supporting the involvement of IRAK-M in adiponectin induced macrophage tolerance. Conclusion: Adiponectin is an important regulator of macrophage activation, by lowering the magnitude of the inflammatory response via induction of IRAK-M, which is one of the major negative feedback mechanisms in TLR4 signaling.

FIGREF272.text: Activation of peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor b/d inhibits phenylephrine-induced MAPK and Akt signalling and prevents cardiac hypertrophy E. Galatou, T. Kelly and A. Lazou Laboratory of Animal Physiology, School of Biology, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Thessaloniki, GREECEIntroduction: Peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor b/d (PPAR b/d) is a transcription factor that belongs to the superfamily of nuclear receptors and plays a prominent role in the regulation of cardiac lipid metabolism. Activation of PPAR b/d has been also associated with inhibition of growth and inflammatory response. However the role of PPAR b/d in cardiac hypertrophy is not yet known. Methods: Adult rat cardiac myocytes were cultured in the presence of the hypertrophic agonist phenylephrine (PE) and/or GW0742, a specific synthetic ligand of PPAR b/d. Cell size was measured as an index of hypertrophy. Activation of kinases was determined by immunoblotting and expression of PPAR b/d was determined by RT-PCR. Results: Treatment of cardiac myocytes with GW0742 inhibited the PE-induced phosphorylation of extracellular regulated kinase 1/2 (ERK1/2), mitogen and stress activated kinase 1 (MSK1) and Akt. In addition, GW0742 inhibited the PE-induced increase in cell size.Conclusions: The results suggest that activation of PPAR b/d interferes with the signalling pathways of MAPK and Akt and this may contribute to the inhibition of cardiac hypertrophic growth. -terminal domain of the d-opioid receptor (d-OR) consists of 62 amino acids and contains the consensus 317YAFL320 motif. Recent observations from our laboratory have shown that the conserved YXXL motif within the C-terminal tail of l-opioid receptor (l-OR) serves as a docking site for STAT5A transcriptional factor binding, which is phosphorylated upon l-OR stimulation (1). In this regard, we sought to determine whether members of the STAT5 transcriptional factors interact also with the d-OR and whether STAT5 phosphorylation is universal among the opioid receptors. Co-immunoprecipitation and pull-down assays, using a GST fusion peptide encompassing the C-terminal region of the d-OR (d-CT), have shown that STAT5B interacts directly with d-OR. A truncated version of the d-CT that lacks the first 26 amino acids indicated the importance of the N-terminal portion of the d-CT for STAT5B binding. Additional co-immunoprecipitation experiments showed that STAT5B forms constitutively functional complexes with Gbc subunits and the d-OR. DSLET-activation of d-OR, expressed in HEK293 cells, resulted in a PTX-dependent STAT5B phosphorylation by the endogenous c-Src tyrosine kinase. Collectively, our results have shown the formation of dynamic complexes between STAT5B, Gbc and d-OR and reveal novel signaling pathways through which d-opioid receptor may modulate transcription in neurons and alter synaptosomal plasticity. Acknowledgement: This work is supported by the EU grant «Normolife» (LSHC-CT2006-037733) and the GSRT. Reference: 1. Mazarakou and Georgoussi. J. Neurochem. 2005; 93: 918-931. FIGREF277.text: M.-K. Oh, J.-K. Cho, S.-J. Park, N.-H. Kim and I.-S. Kim College of Medicine, The Catholic University of Korea, Seoul, KOREAIntroduction: Haptoglobin (Hp) is a plasma glycoprotein that roles as an antioxidant and an immunomodulator. An angiogenic activity of Hp has been also reported, although the action mechanism remains to be understood. Hypoxia-inducible factor-1a (HIF-1a) transcribes various angiogenic factors in physiological and pathological hypoxic conditions. To verify whether the HIF-1a can induce Hp gene expression, we investigated the Hp induction in human hepatoma cells transfected by HIF-1a gene, and analyzed the transcription-regulating sites within Hp promoter. Results: The results of RT-PCR and Western blot showed that the HIF-1a increased Hp expression in HepG2 cells. Hp promoter assay using luciferase reporter also showed the HIF-1a-induced upregulation of Hp gene expression. The luciferase assay using deleted and pointmutated Hp promoters and electrophoretic mobility shift assay demonstrated that a STAT3-binding element (SBE) and a cAMPresponse element (CRE) in Hp promoter (-183/-99) were required for the HIF-1a-induced Hp gene expression. In chromatin immunoprecipitation experiments, the DNA binding of HIF1a and STAT3 at the promoter region containing SBE/CRE was identified. Conclusions: These findings suggest that HIF-1a upregulates Hp gene expression in HepG2 cells and the transcriptional activity may be regulated by cooperative actions of HIF1a and STAT3 on the SBE/CRE sites located at -124/-94 of Hp promoter. FIGREF278.text: expression studies related to cancer diagnosis and treatment are important. Absolutely reliable housekeeping genes are essential for gene expression normalization. Incorrect housekeeping genes choice leads to experimental results interpretation errors including pathological gene expression evaluation and quantification. Within the course of our experimental studies we analysed (i) GAPDH expression regulation degree in human glioblastoma cells under hypoxic conditions in comparison to other housekeeping genes like b-actin, serving as experimental loading controls, (ii) potential GAPDH applicability as target for tumor therapeutic approaches, (iii) GAPDH expression differences between different astrocytic tumors WHO-grades. GAPDH & b-actin expression was comparatively examined in vivo in human low-grade astrocytoma & glioblastoma on both, protein & mRNA level, by Western blot & semiquantitative RT-PCR. Also, the same proteins and the HIF-1alpha protein regulation under hypoxia were determined in vitro in U373, U251 & GaMG human glioblastoma cells on mRNA and protein level. Results obtained showed no hypoxia-induced regulatory effect in three glioblastoma cell lines studied in vitro or in vivo. No association between hypoxia and GAPDH over expression in human glioblastoma was observed. GAPDH mRNA & protein expression regulation in response to hypoxic development in tumor cell environment in vitro & in vivo is not an absolute phenomenon, but occurs as a cellspecific post-transcriptional regulated event. GAPDH expression represents one alternative housekeeping gene and can be used as a loading control in glioma cells experiments. Therapeutic strategies involving GAPDH as target molecule don't represent a valid approach in conjunction with tumor hypoxia in human brain.PP7B-14The cylindromatosis tumor supressor (CYLD) is a key molecule in T cell development, activation and homeostasis A. FIGREF279.text: Pharmacology, School of Medicine, University of Crete, Heraklion, GREECE, 2 Institute of Organic and Pharmaceutical Chemistry, National Hellenic Research Foundation, Athens, GREECE Introduction: We have recently shown that Dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) protects neural crest derived cells against apoptosis, after binding on specific plasma membrane binding sites (mDBS), and the subsequent activation of pro-survival kinases and anti-apoptotic Bcl-2 proteins. Additionally, it stimulates the production and release of catecholamines from dopaminergic PC12 cells. Methods and Results: In the present study we screened in vitro a large chemical library of synthetic 17-spiro analogs of DHEA for their anti-apoptotic, neuroprotective effects. We have the following data: three of our synthetic molecules, namely BNN50, BNN93 and BNN124, were highly effective in protecting cultured sympathoadrenal PC12 cells against apoptosis with IC 50 : 0.09, 4.1 and 68 nM respectively, compared to 1 nM of DHEA. The three analogs bind with high affinity on mDBS (Kd: 0, 2, 11 and 0.3 nM respectively, compared to 1 nM of DHEA), and mimic DHEA in inducing the expression of anti-apoptotic Bcl-2 proteins. Furthermore, nanomolar concentrations of BNN50 and BNN93 stimulated the production of dopamine via transcriptional activation of tyrosine hydroxylase, the rate-limiting enzyme of catecholamine biosynthesis. Conclusions: Our results suggest that these chemical entities, deprived of the classical androgenic or estrogenic effects of DHEA, might prove lead molecules for the synthesis of novel neuroprotective agents.

FIGREF284.text: cadherin mediated cell proliferation silencing of CDH2 gene in human melanoma cell lines D. Ciolczyk-Wierzbicka, D. Gil and P. Laidler Medical Biochemistry Jagiellonian University Medical College, Krakow, POLANDDynamic regulation of cadherin expression is strongly correlated with the metastasis and progression of tumors, N-cadherin play an important role in controlling processes of cell division, migration, differentiation and death. In this study we are investigated role of N-cadherin in proliferation and Akt, ERK, b-catenin signaling pathway in human melanoma cells: WM793 (VGP), WM115 (VGP) from the primary tumor site and Lu1205 (lung), WM266-4 (skin) from metastatic sites. We are transfected melanoma cells with the small interfering RNA (siRNA) that targets of human N-cadherin gene (CDH2). siRNA sequences were generation in vitro transcription (Silencer siRNA Construction Kit-Ambion) and melanoma cells were transfected with oligofectamine ä (Invitrogen). N-cadherin, pAkt(Ser-473), b-catenin, pERK1/2(Thr202/Tyr204), cyclin D1, cyclin D3, p21 and p27 expression was determined by western blot analysis. The proliferation cell was performed using BrdU and crystal violet assay. Silencing of N-cadherin gene expression by siRNA process reduces: pAkt(Ser473), pERK1/2(Thr202/Tyr204), b-catenin, cyclin D1, cyclin D3 and increases expression of cell cycle inhibitors p21 and p27, parallel significantly decreased cell proliferation (in range 50-70%). Data suggest that, N-cadherin mediated in cell cycle in G1 phase regulation by Akt, b-catenin, and ERK signaling pathway. Acknowledgement: This work was supported by the State Committee for Scientific Research Poland: 501P/239/L Medical Collage Jagiellonian University.

Page Research Group on Brain Aging (EA 3808) University of Poitiers, Poitiers, FRANCE Introduction: It is well known that double-stranded RNA-dependent Protein Kinase (PKR) is not only activated in various models of Alzheimer's disease (AD) and in AD patients but also associated with neurodegeneration and cognitive decline observed in this dementia. Among its downstream targets, the Fas-Associated protein with a Death Domain (FADD) and subsequent caspase-8 are responsible for PKRinduced apoptosis in cells infected with virus. However, the role of PKR in DD receptor signalling in AD remains unknown. This project proposes to determine physical and functional interactions of PKR with FADD in Ab neurotoxicity and in APP SL PS1 KI transgenic mice. Methods: Differentiated human (SH-SY5Y) neuroblastoma cells were incubated with 20 lM amyloid b peptide 1-42 (Ab

FIGREF286.text: Gynecology, University of Halle, Halle, GERMANY, 2 Radboud University Nijmegen Medical Centre, Nijmegen, THE NETHER-LANDS,3  Institute for Pathology, University of Halle, Halle, GERMANY, 4 Clinik for Gynecology, University Hamburg-Eppendorf, Hamburg, GERMANY Introduction: Recently, we have identified Rho-GDIb, an inhibitor of Rho-GTPases, as a target of the transcription factor Ets1. Rho-GDIb is primarily expressed by haematopoietic cells, but also found in epithelial cancer cells. We studied the regulation and function of Rho-GDIb in breast cancer cells. Methods and Results: In breast cancer cells, Ets1 regulates Rho-GDIb expression on the RNA and protein level and binds to the upstream region of the Rho-GDIb gene as determined by ChIP analysis. In primary breast cancer, Rho-GDIb is co-expressed with Ets1. Suppression of Rho-GDIb expression by Rho-GDIb-specific siRNA increased cellular migration. cDNA-Microarray analyses identified Cox-2 as target of Rho-GDIb. This was confirmed by Q-RT-PCR and Westernblot analyses. Rho-GDIb stimulates Cox-2 expression partly by activating NFAT-1 depending transcription of the Cox-2 gene. Vav-1, an interaction partner of Rho-GDIb, also interfered with Cox-2 expression and NFAT-1 cellular distribution suggesting a cooperative action of Rho-GDIb and Vav-1 on Cox-2 expression. To explore the importance of Rho-GDIb for the survival of breast cancer patients, two cohorts including 263 and 117 patients were analyzed for clinical outcome in relation to Rho-GDIb RNA and protein levels, respectively. Expression of Rho-GDIb was not associated with either diseasefree or overall survival in the two patient population. Conclusions: The expression of Rho-GDIb in breast cancer is neither beneficial nor disadvantageous to the patient. This may be the net effect of two opposing activities of Rho-GDIb, one that suppresses tumor progression by inhibiting migration and the other that stimulates it by enhancing Cox-2 expression.
