PP7C-16 Activated protein C attenuates lipopolysaccharideinduced activation of cell death and tumour necrosis factor-alpha production in murine microglial cells M. Y. Egrilmez 1 , Z. Cavdar 1 , S. Genc 1 , K. Genc 2 and G. Guner 1,3 1 Research Laboratory, Dokuz Eylul University School of Medicine, Inciralti-Izmir, TURKEY, 2 Dokuz Eylul University Health Sciences Institute, Inciralti-Izmir, TURKEY, 3 Department of Biochemistry, Dokuz Eylul University School of Medicine, Inciralti-Izmir, TURKEY Introduction: Activated protein C (APC) is a natural anticoagulant with anti-inflammatory, anti-apoptotic, cytoprotective and anti-oxidant effects. The neuroprotective and vascular protective effects of APC have recently been reported. Recent studies have shown that APC is protective against cerebral and spinal cord ischemic injury. APC exerts its anti-inflammatory effect via reducing the levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines such as tumor necrosis factor-a (TNF-a) by suppressing nuclear factor-jB and activator protein-1 transcription factors. Microglial cells, the immune cells of central nervous system derived from myeloid lineage, were shown to be activated by lipopolysaccharide (LPS) in vitro. To investigate whether APC modulates glial cells in inflammatory conditions, we studied the effect of APC on LPS-induced cell death and TNF-a production in N9 murine microglial cells. Methods: We used murine microglial cell line N9 for the experiments.

FIGREF288.text: Conclusions: These results suggest that APC modulates microglial cells by promoting survival and repressing inflammatory responses in vitro. The modulation of microglial responses by APC might be involved in the beneficial effects of this molecule in central nervous system injury in vivo. Many hormone metabolites and neurotransmitters bear catechol groups in their molecules. Some of these biomolecules are involved in neurodegeneration. The catechol group is also found in xenobiotics. In this study, 1,2-dihydroxybenzene (catechol) was used to assess the role of this functional group in the induction of cell death. Methods: Neuroblastoma N2a cells were cultured and treated with catechol (1-200 lmol/l) for 72 hours to determine its EC 50 . Cell viability was studied by the MTT assay. L-Cysteine was used to test the protective effect of sulfhydryl groups in catechol-induced cytotoxicity. Monochlorobimane (MCB) was used to assess glutathione (GSH) depletion. The mode of cell death was investigated by flow cytometry analysis of cells labeled with annexin V and propidium iodide.Results: The incubation with catechol for 72 hours showed that the minimal cytotoxic concentration was 20 lmol/l. The calculated EC 50 after 72 hours was 38 lmol/l. L-Cysteine protected cells significantly in a dose-dependant manner. The use of monochlorobimane showed that catechol induced GSH depletion after 24 hours of incubation, prior to the induction of cell death. Furthermore, catechol induced apoptosis of N2a cells after 72 hours. Conclusions: Catechol is a functional group that induces glutathione depletion and apoptosis of neuroblastoma N2a cells. FIGREF289.text: Her2/neu protein is a member of the tyrosine kinase family of growth factor receptors. Its overexpression in breast cancer has been associated with increased disease recurrence and poor prognosis. Differential proteomic analysis was performed in two breast cancer cell lines MDA-MB-435/eb1 (transfected to overexpress Her2/neu) versus the mock-transfected MDA-MB-435/neo (1). Methods: Two-dimensional electrophoresis, in-gel trypsin digestion and HPLC nano-spray-MS/MS were employed for subcellular fractions of cell lysates in order to detect and identify proteins which are up or down regulated with Her2. Western blotting and reverse transcription PCR on cell-free and biopsy derived tissue extracts were performed in order to confirm the proteomic data. Results: Twenty one protein molecules differentially expressed in association with Her2 were identified and several were investigated for a new role in Her2 transformation. Gene Ontology (GO) analysis revealed a number of clusters of proteins based on their molecular function, particularly enriched on the binding function (ligands). Conclusions: Several proteins associated with Her2 overexpression were evaluated as possible cancer markers or targets for therapeutic intervention.Reference: 1. FIGREF292.text: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is a member of the herpesvirus family and it is implicated in the pathogenesis of Burkitt's lymphoma, infecting mainly B-lymphocytes. The transformation of B-lymphocytes by EBV depends on the activation of Nuclear Factor jB (NF-jB), triggered by the Latent Membrane Protein 1 (LMP1), a transmembrane viral protein, important for EBV-mediated B-cell proliferation. The aim of the present work was to define changes in the proteome of cells transformed by EBV, in order to characterize the mechanism of transformation and identify novel targets.

FIGREF293.text: (CYPS) protects human neuroblastoma SH-SY5Y cells aganist MPP + -induced neurotoxicity S. Han and W. Choe Department of Biochemistry & Molecular Biology, School of Medicine, Kyung Hee University, Seoul, KOREA1-Methyl-4-phenylpyridinium ion (MPP + ), the active metabolite of MPTP and inhibitor of mitochondrial complex, has been widely used as a neurotoxin, because it give rise to a severe Parkinson's disease-like syndrome with elevation of intracellular reactive oxygen species (ROS) level and apoptotic death. Cyclophilins (Cyps) have peptidyl-prolyl cistrans isomerase (PPIase) activity, catalyzes the isomerization of the peptide bond between pSer/Thr-Pro in proteins, thereby regulating their biological functions including protein assembly, folding, intracellular transport, intracellular signaling, transcription, cell cycle progression and apoptosis. In the present study, we investigated the protective effects of overexpressed cyps on MPP + -induced neurotoxicity in human neuroblastoma SH-SY5Y cells. Treatment of SH-SY5Y cells with MPP + caused the cell death associated with elevation of ROS level. Overexpressed cyps in SH-SY5Y cells increased the cell viability and reduced ROS level in cells. Our results suggested that overexpressed cyps in SH-SY5Y cells protects on cells against MPP + -induced neurotoxicity. Acknowledgement: This work was supported by Grant of Seoul RNBD program (NO. 11062). An increasing body of in vivo and in vitro evidence supports an immunoregulatory role for plasma glutamate (Glu). In healthy individuals plasma Glu is under tight regulation while at conditions characterized by immune-deficiency (AIDS, renal failure and malignancies) its plasma concentration is highly elevated. In vitro, high glutamate concentrations decrease stimulated T-cell intacellular calcium elevation and proliferation. Recently we proposed that elevated Glu is exerting its immunosupressive effects, at least partly, throught negative regulation of the main potassium condcuctance of T-cells namely; the voltage-gated potassium channel Kv1.3. In an efford to explore the site of action of high Glu in T-cells through which it suppresses channel activity we employed electrophysiological and molecular biology techniques in freshly isolated human T-cells. Methods: Patch-clamp, RT-PCR, and immunocytochemistry. Results: Herein, we provide converging evidence that elevated Glu (above 100 lM) decrease Kv1.3 channel activity through group II metabotropic Glu receptor (mGluR2/3) activation. Specifically, we demonstrate that in human T-cells: (i) Kv1.3 channel inhibition, by high Glu, is alleviated by the highly selective mGluR2/3 antagonist, LY341495 (ii) the mGluR2/3 receptor agonist DCG-IV decreased Kv1.3 channel activity dose-dependently and its effects were alleviated by LY341495, and (iii) mGluR2/3 receptors are expressed both in the mRNA and protein level. Conclusion: The above data demonstrates that human T-cells express functional group II mGluRs, and their activation is linked to Kv1.3 channel modulation. Given that Kv1.3 channels in T-cells regulate their resting and activated state, the above data suggest an immunomodulatory role for mGluR2/3.PP7C-26Proteomic analysis of HRAS-mediated oncogenic transformation of a human colon adenocarcinoma cell line -an approach to identify novel therapeutic targetsG. Ikonomou 1 , M. Samiotaki 1 , A. Pintzas 2 and G. Panayotou 1 1 Institute of Molecular Oncology, B.S.R.C. 'A. FLEMING', Athens, GREECE, 2 Institute of Biological Research and Biotechnology, N.H.R.F., Athens, GREECEIntroduction: Ras is a small GTP-binding protein mutated in approximately 30% of human cancers, playing an important role in initiation, progression and metastasis. A constitutively active, mutant HRAS gene (HRAS G12V ) has been introduced into an intermediatestage colon adenoma cell line (Caco-2). In this study, we probed the cellular and molecular mechanisms of RAS-mediated transformation, by profiling wild type cells versus HRAS-transformed clones.

FIGREF294.text: expressed proteins were identified by LC-MS/MS analysis. Western blot analysis, RT-PCR and siRNA were used for result validation. Results: We identified approximately 70 differentially expressed proteins. Of specific interest are groups of proteins that are implicated in basic cellular processes such as cytoskeletal organization, transcription, translation etc. Selected proteins were validated by Western Blot analysis and investigated at the mRNA level by RT-PCR. By using inhibitors of Ras effector pathways (MAPK, PI3K, NF-jB), we investigated the mechanism of their regulation by oncogenic HRAS. Posttranslational modifications have also been characterized. Particularly interesting are cytoskeletal proteins, such as gelsolin and fascin-1, which may be involved in HRAS-mediated transformation through their ability to affect actin polymerization. Conclusions: Several proteins reported to be implicated in cell transformation have been identified. Validation of their role in carcinogenesis may define novel therapeutic targets.

FIGREF295.text: Results: All Drosophila DSPs, except slingshot, are expressed in the adult head. Puckered is expressed in the adult CNS, both in neurons and in glia, with Puckered-expressing neurons forming a defined circuit. Disruption of neurotransmission within this circuit causes paralysis. Conclusions: Puckered regulates JNK activity in a specific subset of neurons in the adult CNS, which are implicated in the control of motor functions of the fly.

FIGREF296.text: K. Kim, S. Kim and W. Choe Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Medical Science and Engineering Research Center for Bioreaction to Reactive Oxygen Species, Biomedical Science Institute, School of Medicine, Kyunghee University, Seoul, KOREA Cyclophilins (Cyps) were identified as cellular binding proteins for the immunosuppressive drug cyclosporine A (CsA) and are constitutively expressed in most tissues. Cyclophilin B is found mainly in the ER lumen, and it has peptidyl-prolyl cis-trans isomerase (PPIase) activity that catalyzes protein folding reactions in cells. Reactive oxygen species (ROS) are generated as by-products of the mitochondrial respiratory process. They have emerged as an important signaling molecule based on their unique biochemical properties. In this study, we determined the possibility of role of CypB as a protector and an anti-oxidant. We performed immunoblotting and MTT Assay in Huh-7 cell, Human Hepatoma cell, after treatment with H 2 O 2 for 12-24 hours. And we analyzed of Cyclophilin B activity when cells were subject to H 2 O 2 . According to our results, overexpressed CypB increased cell viability though activation of ERK pathways. And as expect, overexpressed Cyclophilin B reduced ROS.

FIGREF299.text: dependent differential sensitivity of lung cancer cell lines to the chemotherapeutic agents N-methyl-N-nitrosourea and trichostatin A A. Koryllou 1 , T. G. Sourlingas 2 , M. Pratsinis 2 , M. Biological Research and Biotechnology, National Hellenic Research Foundation, Athens, GREECE, 2 Institute of Biology, National Centre for Scientific Research 'Demokritos', Attiki, GREECESince lung cancer is the most frequent cause of cancer death new therapeutic approaches are eagerly needed. Methylating agents constitute a widely used class of anticancer drugs and N-methyl-N-nitrosourea (MNU) is a model methylating agent. Another promising class of anticancer agents are histone deacetylase inhibitors (HDACIs). One of the most well-studied HDACI is trichostatin A (TSA). Although they are entirely different chemical compounds, both have been shown to induce apoptosis in cancer cell lines. However, their effects on human non small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) cells have not been elucidated. Cell death was assessed by cytofluorometry of DNA content and immunodetection of specific markers. Cytotoxic doses of either MNU or TSA induced apoptotic cell death in the NSCLC cell line H157 (p53 mut ). In A549 (p53 wt ), another NSCLC cell line, only TSA induced apoptosis while MNU induced a distinct form of cell death which is not apoptotic as confirmed by the lack of increase in the sub-G1 DNA content, PARP cleavage and caspase-3 activation. Cell cycle analysis in A549 cells, following MNU-induced DNA damage, revealed a DNA repair-dependent prolonged G2/M arrest accompanied by gradual degradation of cdc25A and hnRNP B1 induction at a later stage, both markers implying aberrant mitosis. The differential effect of MNU on the above cell lines is attributed to their different p53 status. The mechanism of MNU-induced cell death and the effect of histone hyperacetylation on it is currently under investigation. Acknowledgement: This research project (PENED) is co-financed by E.U.-European Social Fund (75%) and the Greek Ministry of Development-GSRT (25%).

FIGREF300.text: Methods: Two human breast cancer cell lines, MCF-7 of low and MDA-MB-231 of high invasiveness, were used. RT-PCR and western blotting were used for the study of ERs/PGs and siRNA and Real-time PCR for the effect of E2 on the expression of PGs through ERs. Results: E2 suppresses the expression of ERa in MCF-7 cells and enhances the expression of ERb in both cell lines. Furthermore, E2 upregulates the expression of syndecan-2 in MCF-7 and MDA-MB-231 cells and down-regulates the expression of syndecan-4 in both cell lines. After ERa suppression, E2 does not have the same effect in the expression of syndecan-2, as in scramble cells, while the expression of syndecan-4 is affected with the same way. Conclusion: The obtained results suggest that the growth-promoting properties of E2 in breast cancer are closely related with its action on the expression balance between ERa/ERb as well as the gene expression of certain proteoglycan types. PP7C-42 Tautomycetin selectively inhibits growth of colorectal cancer cells through p21 Cip/WAF1 induction via the ERK pathway J.-H. Lee 1 , J.-S. Lee 2 , S.-E. Kim 2 and K.-Y. Choi 2 1 Korean German Institute of Technology, Seoul, REPUBLIC OF KOREA, 2 Department of Biotechnology, Yonsei University, Seoul, REPUBLIC OF KOREA Introduction: Tautomycetin (TMC) is a potent T cell-specific immunosupressor. However, other functions of TMC such as growth control have yet to be characterized. Here we investigated the effects of TMC on the cellular proliferation and transformation. The consequences of TMC exposure on proliferation and transformation of various cell types were investigated related with the regulation of p21 Cip/WAF via the extra-cellular regulated kinase (ERK) signaling pathway.Methods: The effects of TMC on cellular proliferation, cell-cycle progression, and transformation were measured by bromodeoxyuridine (BrdU) incorporation, fluorescent activating cell sorting (FACS), and foci formation analyses, respectively. The effects of TMC on activations of ERK signaling and p21 Cip/WAF were examined by Western blot, reporter assays, immunocytochemistry, and phosphatase assays. Results: The proliferation and cell cycle progression of HCT-15, HT-29 and DLD-1 colorectal cancer cells were efficiently inhibited by 150 nM TMC. The anti-proliferation by TMC dependent on the ERK pathway dependent p21 Cip/WAF activation, and the TMC effects were abolished in HCT-116 colon and 8 other types of cells which did not induce p21 Cip/WAF by TMC. The crucial role played by p21 Cip/WAF1 in the ERK pathway-dependent anti-proliferative reponses by TMC was confirmed by using p21 Cip/WAF1 gene deleted HCT-116 cells. The TMC preferentially inhibited phosphatase activities of the Raf-1 regulators, PP1 and PP2A, with preference toward PP1. Conclusions: TMC impedes proliferation and transformation of colorectal cancer cells by inhibiting PP1 followed by the ERK pathway dependent p21 Cip/WAF activation. TMC could be a potential anticancer drug for the treatment of colorectal cancers retaining inducible p21 Cip/WAF .

FIGREF311.text: Sesquiterpene lactones (SL) have attracted attention during the last decade. They display several biological activities, including antitumor properties. In this study we investigated the effects of two naturally occurring SL (asteriscunolide A and tanapsin) on cell viability of human tumor cell lines. Methods: Compounds were isolated from Canary Islands´s endemic plants. We used HL-60, U937 and cells over-expressing human Bcl-2 and Bcl-x L proteins. Cytotoxicity was analyzed by colorimetric MTT assay. Apoptotic cell death rate was analyzed by fluorescent microscopy and by flow cytometry. Morphological changes were evaluated by electron microscopy. Cytochrome-c release, cleavage of procaspases, hydrolysis of PARP and activation of the mitogen-activated-protein kinases (MAPK) pathway were evaluated by western blot. Results: The SL were cytotoxic and potent apoptotic inducers. SLinduced cell death is mediated by caspase activation, since it was prevented by the pan-caspase inhibitor z-VAD-fmk, associated with cytochrome-c release and triggered in Bcl-2 over-expressing U937 cells and Bcl-x L over-expressing HL-60 cells. Treatment with SL induced the activation of MAPK-pathway, including extracellular signal-regulated kinases (ERK) 1/2, c-Jun N-terminal kinases/stress-activated protein kinases (JNK/SAPK) and p38 MAPK. Conclusions: These SL are cytotoxic against human leukaemia cell lines and cells over-expressing the antiapoptotic-proteins Bcl-2 and Bcl-xL, involving a caspase dependent cell death and activation of the MAPK pathway.PP7C-54Platelet-activating factor (PAF) and activity of its enzymes in heart failure patients P. FIGREF313.text: S.-J. Park, M.-K. Oh, N.-H. Kim, J.-K. Cho and I.-S. Kim College of Medicine, The Catholic University of Korea, Seoul, KOREAIntroduction: To investigate the molecular mechanism for the effect of auranofin (AF) on the induction of cell differentiation, the cellular events associated with differentiation were analyzed in acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL) cells. Methods: The APL blasts from leukemia patients and NB4 cells were cotreated with AF and all-trans-retinoic acid (ATRA) at suboptimal concentration. The HL-60 cells were treated with AF and subeffective dose of 1a,25-dihydroxyvitamin D 3 [1,25(OH) 2 vit D 3 ] in combination. The effect of AF was investigated on histone acetylation at the promoter of differentiation-associated genes and expression of cell cycle regulators. Results: Treatment with AF and ATRA cooperatively induced granulocytic differentiation of fresh APL blasts isolated from patients and NB4 cells. The combined treatment also increased reorganization of nuclear PML body and the histone acetylation at promoter of RARb2 gene. The AF also promoted monocytic differentiation of the HL-60 cells triggered by subeffective concentration of 1,25(OH) 2 vit D 3 . The combined treatment of AF and 1,25(OH) 2 vit D 3 stimulated the histone acetylation at p21 promoter and increased the accumulation of cells in the G 0 /G 1 phase. Consistent with this, the expressions of p21, p27 and PTEN were increased and the levels of cyclin A, Cdk2 and Cdk4 were decreased. Furthermore, the hypophosphorylated form of retinoblastoma protein (pRb) was markedly increased in cotreated cells. Conclusions: These findings indicate that AF in combination with low doses of either ATRA or 1,25(OH) 2 vit D 3 promotes APL cell differentiation by enhancing histone acetylation and the expression of differentiation-associated genes.

FIGREF314.text: destabilizes hypoxia-induced HIF-1a protein levels in HCT116 human colon cancer cell line. This destabilization of HIF-1a is resulted from the antioxidant activity of melatonin against ROS induced hypoxia. Moreover, melatonin suppressed the transcriptional activity of HIF-1 under hypoxia, leading to a decrease in the expression of VEGF. Melatonin also blocked in vitro tube formation, invasion and migration of human umbilical vein endothelial cells induced by hypoxia-stimulated conditioned media of HCT116. These findings suggest that melatonin could play pivotal roles in tumor suppression via the inhibition of HIF-1-mediated angiogenesis. FIGREF315.text: Molecular Physiology and Genetics SAS, Bratislava, SLOVAKIA, 2 Institute for Heart Research, SAS, Bratislava, SLOVAKIA,3  Institute of Normal and Pathological Physiology, SAS, Bratislava, SLOVAKIA Introduction: Nitric oxide (NO) plays important and multiple roles in the cells mediating a number of physiological and pathological processes. The aim of the study was to characterize the effects of chronic NO synthase (NOS) inhibition on the alterations of regulatory proteins of intracellular signaling pathways (mitogen activated protein kinases and Akt kinase cascades) and matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs). Methods: NO deficiency (NOD) in rats was induced by L-NAME treatment (40/mg/rat daily, 4 weeks). Levels and specific phosphorylation (activation) of proteins were determined by Western blot analysis and activities of MMP were analyzed by zymography. Results: The development of NOD was connected with decreased activation of both Akt kinase and extracellular signaling regulated protein kinases (ERKs), down-regulation of aFGF and H-Ras protein levels. The changes in ERK and Akt kinase correlated with decreased activation of eNOS and down-regulation of iNOS levels. Activities of tissue and plasma MMP-2 were decreased in L-NAME treated rat hearts. Gelatinolytic activity of approximately 20 kDa proteinase in plasma of L-NAME treated rats was increased. Conclusions: The observed changes point to the involvement of ERK and Akt kinase cascades as well as MMP-2 in responses of rat myocardium to NOD. FIGREF316.text: -alpha stimulates the invasiveness of a cholangiocarcinoma cell line via MAPK signaling R. Tohtong and P. Rattanasinganchan Faculty of Science, Mahidol University, Bangkok, THAILAND Introduction: The incidence rate of cholangiocarcinoma in Thailand is the highest in the world, showing a unique association with Opisthorchis viverrini infection. At diagnosis, most patients are presented with advanced disease, possibly with undetected metastasis, resulting in less than 12 months survival. Chronic inflammation and infiltration of immune cells at the infected site suggested that inflammatory cytokines secreted by these cells might be involved in the pathogenesis of CCA. Here, we investigate the effects of TNF-a in promoting the invasiveness of a cholangiocarcinoma cell line established from a Thai patient, RMCCA-1.

FIGREF317.text: A palmitoylated peptide, derived from the acidic carboxyl-terminal segment of the integrin aIIb cytoplasmic domain inhibits platelet activation V. Koloka, E. D. Christofidou, S. Vaxevanelis, A. A. Dimitriou, V. Tsikaris, A. D. Tselepis, E. Panou-Pomonis, M. Sakarellou-Daitsiotis and D. C. Tsoukatos Department of Chemistry, Sector of Organic Chemistry and Biochemistry, University of Ioannina, Ioannina, GREECEObjective: The platelet-specific integrin aIIbb3, via 'inside-out' and 'outside-in' signalling, plays a major role on platelet function. The aim of the present study was to contribute to the evaluation of the role of the acidic C-terminal region of the aIIb intracellular tail on platelet activation and aggregation. Methods: For the above purpose we examined the functional effects on human platelets of a palmitoylated peptide corresponding to the above amino acid motif, palmitoyl-K-LEEDDEEGE (pal-K-1000-1008). Results: Pal-K-1000-1008, was platelet permeable and inhibited platelet aggregation induced by 0.4 U of thrombin (IC50 = 164 lM). The non palmitoylated analog was inactive. A modified, scrambled acidic peptide (palmitoyl-K-GDDEELEEE), showed significant lower inhibitory activity than pal-K-1000-1008. A palmitoylated peptide corresponding to the membrane proximal cytoplasmic domain of aIIb, 989 KGVFFKR 995 (pal-K-989-995) induced platelet aggregation. Pal-K-1000-1008 was an inhibitor of human washed platelet aggregation induced by pal-K-989-995 (IC50 = 15 lM). Pal-K-1000-1008 inhibited phosphorylation of FAK and ERK, two protein tyrosine kinases involved in platelet activation and aggregation. Conclusions: Our results favour the assumption that the interaction of the membrane proximal sequence 989 KGVFFKR 995 of the intracellular domain of aIIb with the acidic terminal 1000 LEEDDEEGE 1008 motif may be an important structural factor in platelet signaling, leading to platelet activation and aggregation.

FIGREF319.text: that regulate vital cellular process are validated targets for the development of therapeutic agents for a wide range of diseases including cancer. Important and desirable properties of target drugs are high selectivity and low activity to normal proliferating cells. New protein kinases inhibitor maleimide derivate 1-(4-Cl-benzyl)-3-Cl-4-(CF 3 -phenylamino)-1H-pyrrol-2,5-dione (MI-1) has been synthesized and IC50 profile determined using 32 protein kinases. Revealed IC50 are in micromolar range. Studied compound displays cytostatic effects on cell lines HEK293 and MCF7. Significant oppressing effect was noted for cell in monolayer forming phase starting with 0.1 lM MI-1. Under influence of 1 lM and over cell growth inhibits up to 80-90%. IC50 of MI-1 for HEK293 and MCF7 are 0.711 l and 0.650 l respectively during 3-days treatment and 0.21 and 0.17 l during 5-days treatment. After incubation with maleimide derivate proliferative activity of cell lines was depressed, cell morphology was changed, subsequently cells detached and died. Subsequent incubations without MI-1 leads to partial recovery of cells morphology but cells growth remain oppressed. At the same time MI-1 does not influence on cell viability and morphology of normal endothelium cells after 3-days incubation. Administration of MI-1 in vivo (health rat) has not provoked changes of physiological state and blood characteristics, in particular hepatic enzymes (alanine and aspartate aminotransferases, alkaline phosphatase). Thus maleimide derivate (protein kinase inhibitor) may be considered as potential lowtoxic cytostatic drug.PP7C-84Noncanonical pathway stimulator Wnt5a is upregulated in gastric carcinomaS. FIGREF327.text: Effects of IL-17 on new cell line PC-MDS, established from patient with myelodysplastic syndrome V. Jurisic 1 , G. Bogdanovic 1 , K. Vesna 1 , G. Jovcic 2 and P. Medical Research, Belgrade, SERBIAIntroduction: It has been shown that IL-17 is important cytokine in autoimmunity. Since al effects of IL-17 on hematopoietic cells is not absolutely understudying, we here analyzed its effects on new cell line, entitled PC-MDS, obtained from patients with therapy related myelodisplastic syndrome. Methods: IL-17 effects where estimated by different methods as well as on diverse intracellular levels, after in-vitro treatment of PC-MDS cells in dose and time depending manner. Cell membrane alteration was analyzed by release of the cytosole enzyme (LDH) in supernate in terms of the total intracellular activity, calculated as percentage cell membrane alterations; the total intracellular metabolism after cell sonication by ultrasound; the cell growth by estimation of the total protein mass, measurements by SRB assay and cell proliferation by MTT assay. Additionally we analyzed cell cycle phase before and after treatment with IL-17 after 24, 48 and 72 hour by the Flow cytometry. Results: IL-17 induced significantly release of intracellular enzymes trough cell membrane with predominance of LDH in a dose and time dependent manner (p < 0.05, Mann-Whitney U-test). The maximal effects on cell death correlated with the cell growth inhibition and decrease of intracellular protein content. Conclusion: Inhibition of cell growth simultaneously with release of cytosole enzymes and loss of energy, analyzed in our study, suggest the role of IL-17 as molecules with capability to induce necrotic and apoptotic form of cell death in our cells.

FIGREF331.text: : A crucial role for recombinant BCG (rBCG) immunotherapy of bladder carcinoma has been suggested. Nevertheless, little is known about the relevance of interleukin-27 (IL-27) for bladder tumor surveillance in rBCG immunotherapy. Here we investigated the ability of multicomponent vaccines in enhancing anti-tumor effects in vivo. Methods: Treatment with combined IL-27 and rBCG was examined in syngeneic C3H mice. The delivery efficiency was detected by flow cytometry. Inhibition of tumor growth was monitored by bioluminescence-imaging system, with measurement of cytokines and phenotyping of infiltrating lymphocytes in tumors.Results: Increased immune cell infiltration and induction of apoptosis were noted after treatment with IL-27 plus rBCG DNA vaccines. Combination therapy with IL-27 and rBCG resulted in the highest longterm (>90 days) tumor-free survival frequency of 85%. Animals that were tumor-free demonstrated tumor-specific protection after rechallenge with MBT-2 cells. IL-27 alone and rBCG alone both delayed tumor progression, but only IL-27 plus rBCG significantly augmented long-term survival (80%) compared to the control group. At peak expansion, the combination treatment resulted in a 2-to 3-fold higher absolute number of circulating tumor antigen-specific CD8+ T cells than was stimulated by IL-27 or rBCG alone. Conclusions: Immuntherapy using IL-27 plus rBCG could be an attractive regimen for the treatment of bladder cancer. This approach presents new possibilities for the treatment of bladder cancer.

FIGREF332.text: Bucharest, Faculty of Biology, Center of Neurobiology and Molecular Physiology, Splaiul Independentei, Bucharest, ROMANIA, 2 INCDMI Cantacuzino, Laboratory of Cellular Immunity, Splaiul Indepedentei, Bucharest, ROMANIA Introduction: Despite the increased prevalence of peripheral diabetic neuropathy, its causes are still unknown. In our study, we have used a double transgenic mice (dTg) model, Ins-HA +/-/TCR-HA +/-, that develops a fulminant type of insulino-dependent diabetes. The goal of our study was to reveal the molecular mechanisms of diabetic neuropathy in neuronal primary cultures. Methods: Two transgenic mice lines are used: 1. the TCR-HA linecharacterized by the presence of a receptor on the surface of T lymphocites, and this receptor recognizes the hemaglutinin of the influenza virus A/PR8/34, and 2. The INS-HA line -presents the hemaglutinin of the same virus on the surface of the beta pancreatic cells. The offspring of these two lines are dTg mice. The presence of the transgenes, that are responsible for the etiophatogenesis of type I diabetes is determined by the PCR technique. Blood and urine glucose and corporal weigth are monitored after 4 and 6 weeks of life. Neuronal primary cultures are dissociated from dorsal root ganglia. Electrophysiological recordings of these neurons are perfomed by patch-clamp technique, whole-cell configuration.

FIGREF334.text: Victor Babes' National Institute of Pathology and Biomedical Sciences, Bucharest, ROMANIA, 2 National Institute for Chemical-Pharmaceutical Research and Development, Bucharest, ROMANIA Introduction: The development of novel nucleoside analogs with acceptable toxicity and reduced resistance-inducing capacity is still a challenge. New oxabicyclo[3.3.0]octane nucleoside analogs were synthesized by us starting from an intermediate of prostaglandin synthesis, to which uracil or thymine were linked.

FIGREF335.text: In inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) intestinal subepithelial myofibroblasts (ISEMF) affect the recruitment and activation of immune cells through the cytokine synthesis. Deregulation of cytokine secretion occurs in IBD patient intestinal tissue. Antioxidants down-regulate the cytokine synthesis in response to appropriate stimuli with the involvement of MAP-kinases (MAPK). Therefore, considering that GSH levels decrease in intestinal mucosa of IBD patients (i) we have evaluated the role of p38 and ERK1/2 MAPK in the redox regulation of the production of IL-6 and IL-8 in a human intestinal myofibroblast cell line, 18Co, stimulated with pro-inflammatory factors. Methods: 18Co cells were stimulated for 24 hour with inflammatory factors in different experimental conditions and the culture medium was used to assay IL-6 and IL-8 by ELISA Kits. GSH levels were measured by HPLC method. Results: Redox regulation of interleukin secretion in stimulated cells has been demonstrated. In fact, the decrease in GSH levels by treatment with buthionine sulfoximine (BSO) induced an increased production of IL-8 and IL-6; on the contrary the simultaneous removal of BSO and N-acetylcysteine addition restored the normal synthesis of interleukins. The inhibition of MAPK pathways abrogated the increased release of interleukins in GSH depleted and stimulated cells. Conclusions: These results show that the low GSH levels previously measured in the intestinal mucosa of IBD patients are related to increased cytokine production induced by MAPK activation. This event can be responsible of chronic inflammation and relapses.Reference: 1. Iantomasi T, et al., Biochem. Med. Metab. Biol. 1994; 53: 87-91. Acknowledgement: Grants: MIUR, Fondazione IBD (Torino).

FIGREF338.text: frizzled gene expression in gastric cancer cell lines G. Sen and M. B. Irmak-Yazicioglu Department of Biology, Fatih University, Istanbul, TURKEY Wnt receptors encoded by the Frizzled genes have a role in carcinogenesis and embryonic development.Helicobacter Pylori (H. pylori) is a pathogen which is highly related with gastric cancer. It is well known that H. pylori infection causes the activation of some signaling molecules such as GrbB2, Src family kinases in gastric cancer, however the effect of infection on wnt signaling pathway components in gastric carcinoma is not investigated. In this study, we aimed to examine the changes in expression of six members of FZD genes which are FZD1, FZD2, FZD3, FZD4, FZD8, and FZD10 after H. pylori infection. In order to illustrate the effect of H. pylori infection, two gastric carcinoma cell lines, MKN45 and 23132/87 were infected with H. pylori (cagA (-) ) for 6, 24 and 48 hours and expression of the genes was determined by semi-quantitative RT-PCR method. Results demonstrate that, uninfected MKN45 and 23132/87 cells had expression of FZD1, FZD2, FZD3, FZD4, and FZD8 genes. Following H. pylori infection of the cell lines, changes in expression of genes were observed in a time dependent manner. Whilst FZD1 expression was decreased in MKN45 cell lines after 48 hours infection, FZD2, FZD3, FZD4 and FZD8 expression was almost lost on both MKN45 and 23132/87 cell lines after 48 hours infection. Results showed that H. pylori infection might down-regulate wnt pathway in gastric cancer cell lines. Absence of cag gene in the bacteria can be the responsible for the negative correlation between infection and expression of the genes.

In our study cellulose derivatives with various substituents were used to investigate their anticoagulant properties. For determination of antithrombin specific activity (anti-IIa activity) of the polysaccharides was used a method based on ability of thrombin split synthetic oligopeptide substrates. Heparin specific activity against factors IIa (anti-IIa activity) and Xa (anti-Xa activity) was determined by 5-th International UFH standard. Coagulation time in thromboplastin and thrombin tests depends on concentration of cellulose derivatives and increase with higher concentration. For determination of cellulose derivatives anticoagulant effects were measured anti-IIa and anti-Xa amidolytic activities. Cellulose sulfates with degree of substitution (DS) from 0.6 to 1.7 and cellulose sulfates contain other groups supplementary (carboxymethylic, amido-and phosphate groups) with DS from 0 to 1.0 demonstrated anti-IIa activity from 1 IU/mg to 51 IU/mg, anti-Xa activity from 0.006 IU/mg to 5 IU/mg. It was shown that ellulose sulfates with DS 1.7 are potentional anticoagulant and has mainly specific activity to the antithrombin III.PP8A-2 Proteomic insights into LPS-induced signaling in plant cellsI. Makarov 1 , N. M. Mestechkina 2 , G. E. Bannikova 3 , V. D. Scherbukhin 2 and V. P. Varlamov 3 1 Haematological Research Center, The Russian Academy of Medical Sciences, Moscow, RUSSIA, 2 Biochemistry Institute of The Name A.N.Bah, The Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, RUSSIA, 3 Center ''Bioengineering'', The Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, RUSSIAPolysaccharides with anticoagulant and antithrombotic activities have been found in mammals, marine alga, nontoxic mushroom Auricularia auricula, medicinal plant Porana volubilis and invertebrates. The purpose of this work -research of an anticoagulant activity of a sulfate galactomannans (GM) with different molecular weights (MW) (for deriving low molecular weight GM -LMW GM -with the enzyme hydrolizis help it was used GM from yamopsis tetragonoloba (L.) Taub. seeds); evaluation of the possibility of a complexes formation between obtained samples and protamin sulphate. For determination of antithrombin specific activity (anti-IIa activity) of the LMW GM we used a method what based on thrombin abilities to split synthetic oligopeptide substrates. As a standard we took 5-th International UFH standard. Heparin specific activity against factor Xa (anti-Xa activity) determined with the help of the 1-st International LMWH standard. In order to determine anticoagulant effects of LMW GM anti-IIa and anti-Xa amidolytic activities were measured. Biospecific electrophoresis in 1% agarose with protamin sulphate was used for LMW GM/sulfate protamin complexes determination. Precipitation zones in the 'rocket' form were generated. The 'rocket' squares estimated with the help of PhotoM program. LMW GM weight MW 12.6; 54.2; 81.9; 132.3; 200.1; 245.6 kD demonstrated anti-IIa activity from 64 IU/mg to 87 IU/mg, anti-Xa activity from 6.8 IU/mg to 13.0 IU/mg. Any connection between MW and anticoagulant activities it is not revealed. LMW GM derivatives produced a concentration-dependent prolongation activated partial thromboplastin time test and thrombin time test. All from obtained LMW GM created complexes with sulphate protamin. It was observed moderate positive connection between height/square of the precipitation zones and antithrombin activity. LMW GM drivatives were obtained with the enzyme comlex hydrolisis help have specific antithrombin activity more 70 IU/mg, that is necessary for antithrombotic preparations. The height/square of the precipitation zones with sulphate protamin were found to increase with increasing antithrombin activity of LMW GM.Acknowledgements: This work was supported by the Russian Foundation for Basic Researches, Grants 05-04-08100-fr-, 05-03-32883-a, 06-04-08140-ofr. Health Research Institutes, Zhunan, TAI-WAN, 5 Institute of Plant and Microbial Biology, Academia Sinica, Taipei, TAIWAN Introduction: Plant viruses can be employed as versatile vectors for production of vaccines by expressing immunogenic epitopes on the surface of chimeric viral particles. Although several viruses, including tobacco mosaic virus, potato virus X and cowpea mosaic virus, have been developed as vectors, we aimed to develop a new viral vaccine delivery system, a bamboo mosaic virus (BaMV), that carries larger transgene loads, and generates better immunity in the target animals with fewer adverse environmental effects. Methods: We engineered the BaMV as a vaccine vector expressing the antigenic epitope(s) of the capsid protein VP1 of foot-and-mouth disease virus (FMDV). The recombinant BaMV plasmid (pBVP1) was constructed by replacing DNA encoding the 35 N-terminal amino acid residues of the BaMV coat protein with that encoding 37 amino acid residues (T128-N164) of FMDV VP1. Results: The pBVP1 infected host plants and generated a chimeric virion BVP1 expressing VP1 epitopes in its coat protein. Immunization of swine with BVP1 virions resulted in the production of anti-FMDV neutralizing antibodies and VP1-specific IFN-c. Furthermore, all BVP1-immunized swine were protected against FMDV challenge. Conclusions: Chimeric BaMV virions that express partial sequence of FMDV VP1 effectively induced not only humoral and cell-mediated immune responses but also full protection against FMDV in target animals. This BaMV-based vector technology may be applied to other vaccines that require correct expression of antigens on chimeric viral particles. FIGREF347.text: Considerable pre-clinical evidence suggests that some flavonoids can delay, or abrogate, carcinogenesis in rodents. Anthocyans are flavones, which occur ubiquitously in the plant kingdom and confer bright red or blue colour to berries and other fruits and vegetables. The aim of this study is to underline the antitumoral effect of the rich extract of anthocyans by analyzing different enzymes implicated in the cell redox process into a melanoma cell line (ATCC CRL-1585, C32). Methods: C32 melanoma cells were maintained in culture in Minimum Essential Medium Eagle supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum. After treatment with different concentrations of anthocyans, the whole extract was used in biochemical analyses. Total superoxide dismutase (SOD), glutathione reductase, and glutathione S-transferase assays were performed on cell supernatants. Lactate dehydrogenase assay was performed on media removed from cells after treatment. Protein concentrations were measured according to the Bradford method. Results: Our results show that: (i) the rich extract of anthocyans has a cytotoxic action in a dose-time dependent manner in the cell line used, (ii) in C32 melanoma cells, a detoxification process at 24 hours of exposure occurred, indicated by GST and GR level elevation, (iii) anthocyans treatment of C32 melanoma cells decreased the total SOD specific activity, which means that the antioxidant capacity of these was diminished and (iv) anthocyans interfered with the antioxidant capacity of C32 melanoma cells, which could have consequences on their viability. Conclusions: Ribes Nigrum anthocyans act as antitumoral agents through an antioxidative mechanism in C32 melanoma cells.

Zvereva Department of Virology, Moscow State University, Moscow, RUSSIA Introduction: G-CSF (Granulocyte-Colony Stimulating Factor) is a haematopoietic growth factor that regulates production of neutrophilic granulocytes. FIGREF351.text: National Institute of Research-Development for Microbiology and Immunology, Bucharest, ROMANIA Introduction: The aim of this study is to evaluate in vitro the antimicrobial activity of new synthesized amidic compounds using qualitative and quantitative methods. Methods: The new compounds are prepared in four stages beginning with the 2-phenoxymethyl-benzoic R1-substituted acids synthesis, then the aforementioned acid chlorides, the synthesis of N-(2-diethylaminoethyl)-anilines and finally the original amides synthesis. The antimicrobial activity was tested against Gram-positive strains (Staphylococcus aureus), Gram-negative bacteria (Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa) and fungal strains (Candida albicans). All tests were performed comparatively with reference strains: Staphylococcus aureus ATTC 25923, Escherichia coli ATTC 25922, Pseudomonas aeruginosa ATCC 27853, Candida albicans ATCC 10321. The qualitive screening of the susceptibility spectra was performed by three adaptated diffusion methods: paper filter disk impregnation with the tested substances solutions, the disposal of tested solutions in agar wells and the spotting of tested solutions on solid medium seeded with microbial inoculums. The in vitro antimicrobial testing was performed by binary microdilution method, in 96 multi-well plates, in order to establish the minimal inhibitory concentration (MIC). Results: The new amides structures and purity were determined using the elemental analysis, TLC methods and IR, 1H-NMR and 13C-NMR spectra.All tested compounds exhibited variable antibacterial and antifungal activities, with low MICs against C. albicans and Gram -positive bacteria (especially on S. aureus).Conclusion:The new compounds were evaluated for their in vitro antimicrobial activity showing a good activity against C. albicans and S. aureus. Thus, they represent new possible therapeutic strategy for the treatment of infections with these microorganisms.PP8B-4Nanoparticle-based DNA biosensor for SNP genotyping. Application to pharmacogenetic analysis D. K. Toubanaki 1 , T. K. Christopoulos 1,2 , P. C. Research and Technology Hellas-Institute of Chemical Engineering and High Temperature Chemical Processes (FORTH/ICE-HT), Patras, GREECE, 3 Department of Chemistry, University of Athens, Athens, GREECE, 4 School of Medicine, University of Crete, Heraklion, GREECE Introduction: Single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNP) constitute the most common form of variation in the human genome. In recent years, there is a continuously increasing interest in the development of simple, robust, rapid and low cost methods for SNP genotyping. We have developed a nanoparticle-based DNA biosensor, which allows visual genotyping of SNP without using specialized equipment. Methods: The genotyping method comprises three steps. (i) PCR amplification of a segment spanning the SNP of interest. (ii) Oligonucleotide ligation reaction using a biotinylated common probe and an allele-specific probe that carries a (dA) 20 segment. (iii) Detection of ligation products by the DNA biosensor. Gold nanoparticles functionalized with oligo(dT) strands are deposited, in dry form, on the conjugate pad of the biosensor. The ligation product is captured by immobilized streptavidin at the test zone of the biosensor and hybridizes with the oligo(dT) strands of the nanoparticles. A characteristic red line is generated due to the accumulation of nanoparticles. The excess nanoparticles are captured by immobilized oligo(dA) at the control zone of the strip, giving a second red line. Results: We have applied the proposed method to the genotyping of SNPs in the genes of drug-metabolizing enzymes, i.e. CYP2D6 (*3, *4) and CYP2C19 (*2, *3). The results were in full agreement with direct sequencing. Conclusions: The advantage of the proposed biosensor is its simplicity. The dry-reagent format minimizes the pipetting steps. Visual genotyping with no need for instrumentation decreases the cost and the need for highly qualified technical personnel. Nanospheres of carbon, known as fullerenes have attracted attention due to their applications in biomedicine. The studies regarding fullerenes and their derivatives are nowadays focused especially on their antitumoral and pharmacological effects. Photochemical activation of some types of fullerenes contributes to the antitumoral effects and defines their dual nature. Before heading towards clinical studies, toxicological aspects must be evaluated as there it is still insufficient data in the field of nanostructure's effects on the biological systems[1]. Our study is focused on the toxicological profiles of synthetic C60 fullerens functionalized with tetra-phenyl-porphyne-Fe (Fe-TPP) and tetra-phenyl-porphynepolyvnyl pirolidone (TPP-PVP), respectively. Methods: The synthetic fullerenes were tested on human standard lymphoblast K562 cell line (ATCC collection). The cellular viability was investigated by CytoTox 96 Non-Radioactive Cytotoxicity Assay (Promega). The proliferative capacity was evaluated as metabolically active cells number -CellTiter 96 Aqueous One Solution Cell Proliferation kit (Promega). Results: The viability of K562 cell line loaded with synthetic fullerenes is not affected compared to unloaded cells, especially in the case of C60 fullerene functionalized with TPP-PVP in a wide range of concentration. Also, we noticed an antiproliferative tendency in the case of C60 functionalized with TPP-PVP. Conclusions: Both functionalized fullerenes display no 'dark' toxicity on K562 leukemia cell line. We have registered a protective effect upon cell membrane integrity correlated with a slight antiproliferative tendency. Toxicological data will be used for further testing the compounds in photochemical activation experiments.Reference: 1. Panchapakesan, Oncology Issues Nov/Dec 2005; 20-23. In recent studies, the ywfBC-DEF genes were shown to carry biosynthetic core function genes and renamed as bacABCDE. In addition to this polycistronic operon (ywfBCDEFG), a monocistronic gene ywfH was shown to be required for the biosynthesis of bacilysin in B. subtilis 168. Very recently, our research group showed that a novel gene yvfI, which encodes a transcriptional repressor protein, belonging to GntR family repressor proteins, is essential for the bacilysin biosynthesis. Methods: In this study, we aimed to determine whether yvfI null mutation effect the expression of ywfH gene. TABREF25.text: One of relatively newly described protein visfatin belongs to the candidates for associated factors of metabolic syndrom. Visfatin is one of adiponectins, so-called cytokins, produced by visceral fat. It is also known as cytokin produced by lymphocytes to support maturation of pre-B cells, It is called pre-B cell colony-enhancing factor (PBEF). Gene for PBEF is in man localizated on chromosome 7q22.2 and code protein of 52 kDa. Visfatin has several biological functions also via regulation of NAD level. Visfatin induces acummulation of triacylglycerols (TAG) in preadipocytes and enhances TAG synthesis from glucose. Tissue culture of mouse preadipocytes 3T3-L1 and rat hepatocytes Fao were selected for our studies. Visfatin was in vitro released into cultivation media. New method of RNAi was used for specific knocdown of gene visfatin. In western blots with specific immunodetection we have found decrease level of visfatin protein after RNA interference experiments. Protein extract from cell lysate characterized by two-dimensional electrophoresis has revealed differences between transfected and control hepatocytes. MALDI-TOF analysis of selected protein spots from two-dimensional gels revealed absence of selected proteins under RNAi knockdown of visfatin.Two-dimensional gels were also compared by Image Master 2D Platinum program. New method for determination of visfatin enzymatic activity has been designed based on HPLC analysis in the presence of visfatin preparation from cell culture. Decrease uptake of 14 C-glucose was apparent in differentiated transfected hepatocytes. We have mapped several miRNAs inside the introns of putative tumour suppressor genes and have observed down-regulation in cancer cell lines compared to the non invasive counterpart, and in cancer cell lines compared to the drug resistant counterpart, once again classifying both as tumour suppressors. Kalantidis Plant Sciences, Institute of Molecular Biology & Biotechnology -FORTH and Department of Biology, University of Crete, Heraklion, GREECE Introduction: The exonuclease protein ERI1 has been described as an endogenous negative regulator of RNA silencing in a variety of model organisms. Here we present the first data on the role of ERI1 in the regulation of RNA silencing in plants.Methods: Agrobacterium tumefaciens-mediated leaf disc transformation was used to generate Nicotiana benthamiana lines stably suppressing and overexpressing the plant ERI1 ortholog. An ERI1 suppressor line was crossed with line GFP 5.3 generated in our lab (1) which has the characteristic to exhibit spontaneous short-range silencing of a GFP transgene without the occurrence of subsequent systemic GFP silencing. In addition the effect of ERI1 transient overexpression on small RNA species was tested. Results: In the progeny this resulted in systemic GFP silencing in close to 100% of all plants, possibly by allowing siRNA levels to exceed a threshold concentration. Stable ERI1 overexpression resulted in multiple phenotypic alterations, with defects including growth delay, disturbance of the photosynthetic apparatus including chloroplast morphology, and leaf deformations. These phenotypes are positively correlated with ERI1 overexpression levels. In addition, ERI1 overexpression negatively affected the concentration of small RNA species detected in the tissue analysed.S. Khan, A. Gardiner, I. Martinez, A. Boster, R. Ferris and R. While all pyrazoles could bind to both ER subtypes, certain showed a bias towards ERb. A subset of these pyrazoles was also shown to behave as full ERb antagonists while exhibiting marginal ERa antagonist properties. The ER subtype selective agonist/antagonist behaviour was modulated by the cycloalkyl ring fused to the pyrazole core. The ERb antagonistic pyrazoles inhibited estrogen and androgen stimulation of growth of LNCaP prostate cancer cells. Results: A new inhibitor was isolated from the tentacles crown of the annelid marine S. magnifica termed SmCI. It is a glycoprotein formed by 165 amino acids with 18 cisteine residues and 9 disulfide bonds (UniProt ID: PCPI_SABMA, AC: P84875). The full sequence information, revealed the presence of three BPTI Kunitz domains in SmCI structure, and a high homology with other Kunitz serine inhibitors. The crystals of the proteolytically-cleaved Cyt2Ba were obtained by the micro-batch method under oil. The structure was solved by molecular replacement using the refined structure of the mosquito larvicidal dendotoxin Cyt2Aa from B. thuringensis subsp. kyushuensis as a model. Results: Crystals of cleaved Cyt2Ba (residues 35-235) formed in space group C2, with cell constants a = 83.472 Å , b = 43.262 Å , c = 55.64 Å and b = 112.438°, contained one monomer in the asymmetric unit cell with a Vm of 2.26 Å 3 /Dalton and diffracted to 1.8 Å resolution. Its fold resembles that of the previously described fungal Volvatoxin A2 (VVA2) and the non-toxic form of Cyt2Aa. The structural similarity between these three proteins may provide information regarding the mechanism(s) of membrane perforating toxins.

Ozyhar 1 Department of Biochemistry, Wroclaw University of Technology, Wroclaw, POLAND, 2 Faculty of Chemistry, University of Wroclaw, Wroclaw, POLAND Introduction: Fish otoliths the dense crystals composed of calcium carbonate and an organic matrix, are primarily involved in gravity sensing and in the perception of sound. The Starmaker (Stm) was the first protein shown to be capable of influencing on the process of biomineralization of otoliths. Stm dictates the shape, size and selection of calcium carbonate polymorph, in a concentration-dependent manner.Methods: The Stokes radius Stm was determined by gel filtration chromatography on a Superdex 200 GL column and by dynamic light scattering. Native discontinuous PAGE at different concentrations of acrylamide was performed to estimate an native MW for Stm. MW for Stm was also determined by ESI-MS. Stm secondary structure content was probed with circular dichroism. Results: The identity of purified recombinant non-tagged Stm was confirmed by ESI MS showing MW of 64498 ± 2 Da. Subsequent gel filtration and dynamic light scattering experiments revealed extended conformation of Stm in solution, showing Stokes radius of 78.6 Å , which is much higher than expected for a globular protein of the molecular mass of Stm. Monomeric state for Stm was confirmed by native PAGE showing MW of 60 kDa. Circular dichroism revealed low content of secondary structures for Stm. Conclusions: A biochemical and biophysical analysis of the recombinant Stm indicate for the first time that the Stm is monomeric protein that exhibits properties of intrinsically disordered proteins. It consists of four subunits with six membrane-spanning domains and intracellular N-and C-termini. Calmodulin is the important mediator of calcium dependent regulation of TRPC6. The aim of this study is to map in detail C-terminal region of mouse TRPC6 that is capable of interacting with calmodulin.

TABREF119.text: PP3-31Kinetics and spectrophotometric studies of the effect of copper on xanthine oxidase M. Hadizadeh 1 , C. Khodadadi 1 , E. Keyhani 2 and J.Keyhani 2    Institute of Biochemistry and Biophysics, University of Tehran, Tehran, IRAN, 2 Laboratory for Life Sciences, Tehran, IRAN Introduction: Superoxide radical generated by xanthine oxidase (XO) plays an important role in various forms of ischemic and other types of tissue and vascular injuries and chronic heart failure. Thereupon inhibition of XO activity could lead to beneficial effects for the treatment of these conditions. In this study, the effect of Cu 2+ on XO activity was investigated. Methods: XO activity was measured by monitoring the formation of uric acid at 295 nm. The pH activity profile was established using a citrate-phosphate-borate buffer system (pH 2-13). The effect of Cu 2+ (in 12 concentrations ranging from 0.5 micromolar to 2 millimolar) on XO enzymatic activity as well as XO spectrophotometric properties was investigated at optimum pH after incubation of the enzyme and the metal for 0-10 minutes. Results: Optimum pH was 7.5. Addition of up to 1 micromolar Cu 2+ stimulated XO activity, while higher Cu 2+ concentrations inhibited XO activity. The increases (up to 26%) and decreases (up to 60% in 1.5 millimolar Cu 2+ and 100% in 2 millimolar Cu 2+ ) in catalytic efficiency were both time-and metal concentration-dependent. The type of inhibition was noncompetitive. Cu 2+ concentrations above 500 micromolar resulted in a red shift in the aromatic amino acids band maximum (from 277 to 305 nm) and a significant decrease in absorption.Conclusions: This study showed that Cu 2+ induced conformational changes in XO and, at low concentrations (up to 1 micromolar) stimulated the enzymatic activity while at higher concentrations, it inhibited the enzymatic activity which was completely abolished at 2 millimolar.K. D. Tsirigos, P. G. Bagos, S. K. Plessas and S. J. Hamodrakas Department of Cell Biology and Biophysics, Faculty of Biology, University of Athens, Athens 157 01 GREECE Introduction: Computational prediction of signal peptides and their cleavage sites is of great importance in computational biology. However, currently, there is no available method capable of predicting reliably the signal peptides of Archaea, due to the limited amount of experimentally verified proteins with signal peptides. Methods: We performed an extensive literature search in order to identify archaeal proteins having an experimentally verified signal peptide in order to evaluate the performance of various top-scoring signal peptide predictors (SignalP, PrediSi, Phobius). Results: We found 68 sequences, the largest number ever reported. A detailed analysis revealed some unique features of the signal peptides of Archaea, such as the unique amino-acid composition of the h-region with a higher than expected occurrence of Isoleucine, and a c-region resembling better the Gram-positives' sequences. As expected from these findings, prediction methods that are trained on Gram-positive bacteria perform better in correctly identifying the archaeal signal peptides. SignalPv3 performs better compared to SignalPv2, PrediSi and Phobius. Furthermore, the widely used practice of using a consensus of different predictors trained on sets of various organism groups, results in missing approximately 25-50% of the experimentally verified signal peptides. Conclusions: We provided for the first time a comprehensive analysis of archaeal signal peptides, based on experimentally verified signal peptides. We show here that archaeal signal peptides resemble better the respective sequences of Gram-positive bacteria, and thus, the respective predictors are performing better. However, a dedicated predictor trained solely on archaeal sequences is needed.V. Iconomidou and S. HamodrakasDepartment of Cell Biology and Biophysics, Faculty of Biology, University of Athens, Athens, GREECE

TABREF122.text: G. Joksic´1, M. Guc´-Sˇc´ekic´2, D. Vujic´2, V. Vukomanovic´2, A. Leskovac 1 , S. Petrovic´1 and P. Slijepcˇevic´3 Vincˇa Institute of Nuclear Sciences, Belgrade, SERBIA, 2 Institute for Mother and Child Health Care, Dr Vukan Cˇupic´, Belgrade, SERBIA, Brunel University West London, UKFanconi anemia (FA) is a genetically heterogeneous disease characterized by bone marrow failure, congenital abnormalities and a significant predisposition toward malignancies. Fanconi cells are highly sensitive to DNA crosslinking agents but their response to ionizing radiation is still unclear. This aimed us to investigate in vitro cellular radiosensitivity of FA cell lines (eight patients) and corresponing controls (six samples) employing enumeration of c-H2AX foci. Cells were irradiated in exponential growth phase using 60 Co gamma-rays, radiation dose of 2 Gy. Quantification of gamma-H2AX was assessed at various period of time after irradiation (30 minutes, 2 hours, 5 hours and 24 hours after irradiation). The mean value of DSBs/cell in unirradiated control fibroblasts was 1.17 ± 0.43, wheras in unirradiated FA cells DSBs/cell was 3.0 ± 2.13. The maximum of induced DSBs/cell was found 30 minutes after irradiation in both study groups (20.38 ± 3.76 in control, 21.99 ± 4.12 in FA cells, respectively). The level of radiation-induced gamma-H2AX foci in FA cells, 2 and 5 hours after irradiation significantly decrease when compared to controls, whereas after 24 hours FA cells have significantly higher level of DSBs/cell In FA cells. Numerous necrotic nuclei were found at recovery time of 2 and 5 hours, whereas at longer recovery period of time (24 hours) gamma-H2AX positive micronuclei were found. This study have shown that in FA cells repair mechanisms operate very inefficiently, leading to elevated apoptosis and micronuclei in growing cell cultures. c-H2AX foci represents very sensitive assay for estimation of intrinsic genome radiosenitivity, and demonstrate clear difference in behavior of FA and normal cells in response to ionizing radiation.R. Jordanova, E. Kostova, M. Groves and P. Tucker European Molecular Biology Laboratory, Outstation Hamburg, Hamburg, GERMANY Introduction: Lipid binding proteins (LBPs) play an important role in parasitic nematode's limited lipid metabolism. Several structurally novel families of LBPs in nematodes have been described, including the fatty acid and retinoid binding protein family (FAR). So far there is no 3D structure of any FAR protein. In C. elegans, used as a model for studying parasitic nematodes, eight Ce-FAR proteins have been described. Here we report our work on Ce-FAR-7, one of the most distinct members of the FAR family. Methods: For the crystallization experiment recombinant His-tagged Ce-FAR-7 has been purified via several chromatographic steps and saturated with palmitate. Since there is no model to allow the Ce-FAR-7 structure to be obtained by molecular replacement, isomorphous replacement and anomalous dispersion methods were employed, using sulfur atoms, heavy metals (Hg), Brions and crystals of selenomethionine-containing (Se-Met) protein. All data were collected using synchrotron radiation. Results: Native crystals diffract to 2.4 Å and the Se-Met crystals diffract to 3 Å . Space group is P21  2 1 2 1 with a = 32 b = 43 c = 102 Å and a solvent content of 45.9%. For the Hg soaked crystals the space group is P2 1 with a = 34 b = 42 c = 48 Å and beta = 74 with a solvent content of 40%. Conclusion: We report the first crystallization and X-ray analysis of a FAR protein and the ongoing structure determination. PP3-40 Studies on the contribution of helical protrusion to ATP-dependent conformational change of group II chaperonin using chaperonin complexes with helical protrusion deletions T. Kanzaki 1 , R. Masuda 1 , R. Iizuka 2 , K. Takahashi 3 , K. Maki 4 , K. Kuwajima 3 and M. Yohda 1 Tokyo University of Agriculture and Technology, Tokyo, JAPAN, University of Tokyo, Tokyo, JAPAN, 3 Institute for Molecular Science, JAPAN, 4 Nagoya University, Nagoya, JAPAN Introduction: Group II chaperonins exist in the archaeal and eukaryotic cytosol, and mediate protein folding in an ATP-dependent manner. Previous studies have shown that ATP drives the conformational change of group II chaperonins from the open-lid, substrate binding conformation to the closed-lid conformation to encapsulate unfolded protein in the central cavity. Since the lid is constituted by helical protrusions of eight subunits in a ring, its close and open should require cooperative action of them. However, the detailed mechanism of their cooperativity is still unknown. To elucidate this issue, we examined effects of existence of helical protrusion-deleted mutant (helical, 245-276) in the ordered fashion on the folding and conformational change ability of Thermococcus chaperonin complexes. Methods and Results: Chaperonin complexes including helicals could not fold denatured proteins and conformational change from open structure to closed structure wasn't observed by SAXS analysis. Interestingly, protease digestion, and fluorescent polarization assay have shown ATP-dependent motion of the lid of subunit. Conclusions: These results suggest that ATPs binding/hydrolysis to subunits promotes the motion of the lid of subunit independently, and subsequently the interaction between neighbouring helical protrusions in the ring induces the closed structure. length Alzheimer's amyloid-B peptide in vitro A. TABREF127.text: PP3-49 Structural analysis of FliM from Helicobacter pylori K. H. Lam 1 , T. K. W. Ling 2 and S. W. N. Au 1 Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biotechnology Program, Centre for Protein Science and Crystallography, Faculty of Science, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong SAR, 2 Department of Microbiology, The Chinese University of Hong Kong, Prince of Wales Hospital, Hong Kong SARHelicobacter pylori is the causative agent of duodenal ulcer, gastritis and gastric cancer. Around 50% of the world population has been infected with H. pylori. Motility and chemotaxis are important virulence factors for H. pylori infection. FliM, FliN and FliG compose switch protein complex that is essential for flagella biosynthesis and motility. The binding of phosphorylated CheY to the complex controls the direction of flagella rotation. Adherence of H. pylori to gastric epithelial cells is reduced in fliM mutant suggesting that the motor switch complex is crucial in gastric infection. To investigate the molecular structure of FliM from H. pylori, we have generated the soluble fragment of FliM M based on the solved structure of FliM M from Thermotoga maritima. Rod shaped crystals of FliM M were obtained. A 2.2Å structure of FliM M was determined by molecular replacement, and refined to R = 0.213, R free = 0.256. Comparison of the FliM M structure from H. pylori with T. martima will be discussed. Besides, identification of residues important FliM-FliG interaction is being analyzed by mutagenesis study. Knowledge gained from the present study will provide insight to the structural basis of flagella switching.J. H. Lee, W.-S. Jung, I. Hwang and S. Rhee Department of Agricultural Biotechnology, Seoul National University, Seoul, KOREA

Biologia, Universidade Federal do Ceara´, Fortaleza, BRAZILIntroduction: Pln149 is an antimicrobial peptide used in pharmaceutical and food industries. We have investigated Plantaricin analogues, their action on different bacteria/fungi species and their interaction with biomimetic membrane systems. Methods: Peptide synthesis was performed on solid phase (Fmoc chemistry) and purified by reverse phase in HPLC. Pln149-biomimetic systems interactions were investigated by CD, fluorescence, adsorption kinetics, surface elasticity, and microorganism growth inhibition assays. Results: Pln149 presented unordered structure in aqueous solution and when incubated with zwiterionic or positive liposomes, but underwent a conformational change to helix element with negative liposomes. Adsorption kinetics of Pln149 on DPPG monolayers showed that up to 6 lg/ml the peptide promotes a strong decrease in surface tension and disrupts the monolayer. Pln149 has bactericidal activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa and Staphylococcus aureus with MIC values of 156 lM and 78 lM, respectively, and inhibited C. albicans and S. cerevisae growth. Conclusions: Pln149 is attracted to negative membrane surfaces, undergoes an amphipathic a-helix induction and plays its role disrupting lipid bilayers as a detergent mimetic mechanism. Similar mechanisms were observed to the other analogues, but with different binding constants. Acknowledgement: Supported by Brazilian Agencies: FAPESP and CNPq.B. C. Mallick, J.-S. Kim and S.-O. Kang Laboratory of Biophysics, School of Biological Sciences, and Institute of Microbiology, Seoul National University, Seoul, KOREAIntroduction: The protein calfumirin-1 containing the EF-hand motifs from Dictyostelium discoideum bind Ca 2+ -ions with high affinity and regulate cell differentiations and proliferation. The mechanism of Ca 2+ -binding and the conformational changes is important and need to be address. We investigated the conformational changes and the structural stability induced upon Ca 2+ -binding to the protein at studied conditions. Methods: The coding region of CAF-1 was amplified by PCR, cloned to pET-15b-expression vector and expressed in E. coli as His-fusion protein. The protein conformational changes and thermal stability were monitored by using fluorescence and circular dichroism. The binding isotherms of Ca 2+ -CAF-1 were monitored by Isothermal Titration Calorimeter (ITC). Results: The stochiometric titration of [Ca 2+ ]/[CAF-1] binding showed 50% of the signal changes at a ratio equivalent to the binding sites in the protein. The thermal denaturation of apo-and holo-CAF-1 monitored by circular dichroism and the thermodynamics parameters obtained have good correlation to explain the protein stability. The stability against chemical denaturation was found to be Ca 2+ -ion dependant. The comparative binding of hydrophobic probe (ANS) to apo-and holo-CAF-1 indicates the conformational changes. The stability of the protein-Ca 2+ -binding interaction parameters were obtained by ITC experiments.Conclusions: The Ca 2+ -dependence conformational changes and stability of CAF-1 under physiological conditions helps to understand the mechanisms that required Ca 2+ -ions during the life cycle of D. discoideum. terminal domain of DsbD obtained by NMR spectroscopy D. A. I. Mavridou, J. M. Stevens, S. J. Ferguson and C. Redfield Department of Biochemistry, University of Oxford, Oxford, UK

TABREF130.text: Investigation of multi-state proteins: amino acids with a great number of contacts have an effect on the final stages of carboanhydrase B folding B. S. Melnik, S. R. Evdokimov and N. V. Kotova Institute of Protein Research, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow Region, RUSSIAWe have studied carboanhydrase B, a protein whose folding is complicated by the formation of three intermediate states. The main problem that arises when studying such complex proteins is what forces and interactions affect every stage of formation of their native structure.Here we analyze such influence of hydrophobic amino acids with a great number of contacts. Having measured the kinetics of folding/ unfolding of wild-type carboanhydrase B, its energy landscape, i.e. the location of all energy levels and heights of barriers between them, are calculated. This has allowed us using phi-analysis in studying mutant proteins and estimating the contribution of the mutating amino acid to the formation of every intermediate state. Aliphatic amino acids with a great number of contacts have been selected. We have measured the kinetics of folding and unfolding of three mutant proteins, in which amino acids L155, I208 and M221were substituted for alanine, using tryptophane fluorescence. Dependences of logarithm of the folding/ unfolding rate versus denaturant concentration (chevron plots) have been plotted. It has been found that the residues studied affect mainly the final slow stages of carboanhydrase B unfolding. Acknowledgments: This work was supported in part by HHMI award and the Russian Foundation for Basic Research (Grant No. 06-04-48955a).T. N. Melnik, H. V. Solonenko and B. S. Melnik Institute of Protein Research, Russian Academy of Sciences, Moscow, RUSSIA

OkunolaSolomon Hospital, Ibadan, Oyo State, NIGERIA Introduction: How cell division (and thus tissue growth) is controlled is very complex. Cells have a number of signalling systems that are capable of responding either to external stimuli or to internal stimuli. Reviews in this Biochemistry of Cell Regulation issue fall into two broad classes: those concerned with general questions and new experimental approaches in cell regulation, and those focused on recent exciting discoveries in regulation of specific cellular.

Gon˜i and H. Ostolaza Unidad de Biofisica and Departamento de Bioquimica, Universidad del Pais Vasco, Bilbao, SPAIN Introduction: Hemolysin (HlyA) is a protein toxin secreted by pathogenic strains of E. coli. Its membrane lytic activity requires submillimollar concentrations of Ca 2+ .Previous studies had shown that Ca 2+ binding by HlyA induces conformational changes that make the protein surface more hydrophobic, reaching a metastable state that is only stablized upon insertion into a membrane, or else through irreversible aggregation and denaturation. Ca 2+ binds a specific domain in HlyA, the nonapeptide repeat domain (NRD) rich in Asp and Gly, located in the C-terminal part of the protein.

Vizirianakis Laboratory of Pharmacology, Department of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Thessaloniki, GREECEIntroduction: Stable transfection of murine erythroleukemia (MEL) cells with full length mouse ribosomal protein S5 (RPS5) cDNA enabled us to establish two cultures (MEL-C14 and MEL-C56) that are capable to constitutively express RPS5 gene and synthesize recombinant RPS5. Upon challenge for differentiation, MEL-C14 and MEL-C56 cells exhibited alterations in the level of CDKs (CDK2, CDK4 and CDK6) and delayed their entrance in initiation of erythroid differentiation and cell cycle arrest at G 1 /G 0 . Methods: In this study, we explored the question whether RNAimediated silencing of endogenous RPS5 gene expression affects the growth and differentiation of inducer-treated MEL cells. Results: The data obtained thus far indicated that silencing of endogenous RPS5 gene expression interrupts the completion of erythroid differentiation program to occur in vitro. Interesting enough, however, recovery of normal RPS5 gene expression has allowed RNAi-treated parental MEL cells to complete their differentiation program at rates similar to that seen in untreated highly-inducible parental MEL cell cultures. Conclusions: These findings indicate that deregulation of RPS5 gene expression by either stable transfection or RNAi-mediated gene silencing alters the initiation and the onset of erythroid differentiation of MEL cells presumably by affecting cell cycle arrest at G 1 /G 0 and the function of CDKs. However, the precise mechanism(s) underlying the possible link between initiation of erythroid differentiation and changes in RPS5 gene expression is still unclear and needs further investigation.Institute of Molecular Biology and Biotechnology, Foundation of Research and Technology, Heraklion, GREECE, 2 Department of Chemistry, University of Crete, Heraklion, GREECE, 3 Department of Materials Science and Technolgy, University of Crete, Heraklion, GREECE

TABREF136.text: F. Rezaei 1 , Ali-Akbar Moosavi -Movahedi 2 and M. Habibi-Rezaei 1 School of Biology, College of Science, University of Tehran, Tehran, IRAN, 2 Institute of Biochemistry & Biophysics, University of Tehran, Tehran, IRANIntroduction: Red blood cells (RBCs) experience continuous oxidative insults by exposure to endogenous and exogenous Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS). The major source of intracellular ROS in the red cell is autoxidation of oxyhemoglobin, which generates superoxide which through dismutation, produces hydrogen peroxide (H2O2). Degradation of the heme moiety takes place in conjunction with the reaction of hydrogen peroxide with hemoglobin. Methods: Hemoglobin from human, bovine and camel (Arabian and Bacterian) was purified. The content of oxy-, deoxy-and met species were determined. Heme degradation products were identified by spectroscopic and representative fluorescence species. Results: By increasing the level of met hemoglobin, fluorescence products of heme degradation were reduced, in comparison with oxy-and deoxy-Hb species. Conclusions: The source of hemoglobin affects the susceptibility of the heme group against reactive oxygen species which is most probably due to the different microstructure of the heme pocket from various candidate sources.N. Rezaii and F. KhodagholiNeuroscience Research Center, Sheed Behesti Medical Science University, Tehran, IRAN
