TABREF138.text: D. Samyn 1 , M. Andersson 1 , S. Cornelia 2 , J. Lagerstedt 1 , J. Voss 3 and B. Persson 1 University of Kalmar, School of Pure and Applied Natural Sciences, Kalmar, SWEDEN, 2 University of Linko¨ping, Division of Molecular Genetics, Linko¨ping, SWEDEN, 3 University of California, Department of Biological Chemistry (School of Medicine)-Davis, CA, USAStudies have shown that the high-affinity phosphate transporter Pho84 on its own is competent as a transporter. Others indicated that the absence of the GTR1 gene product reduces the capacity of the Pho84 transporter with an impact on the phosphate uptake response. The soluble Gtr1 protein is classified within the Ras family of small GTPbinding proteins. A significant relationship between the general aminoacid transporter (Gap1p) and the Gtr1 protein concerning its role on the activity and plasma membrane trafficking of the transporter has been observed. These types of interactions are still under debate, particularly where Pho84 is involved. Intrinsic tryptophan fluorescence analyses performed on the wild type protein and specific mutants can provide us with specific data concerning the structural properties of the Gtr1 protein in either a nucleotide-free or -bound state. Data obtained from pure His-tagged wild type protein reveals a distinct change in fluorescence on interaction with GDP or GTP, compared with the nucleotide-free protein. The GTP hydrolyzing capacity of Gtr1 wild type (intrinsic GTPase activity) was determined by Thin-Layer-Chromatographic assay. Fluorescence measurements point out that Gtr1 undergoes conformational changes upon guanine nucleotide exchange. It is anticipated that the local environment of Trp 60 could be altered upon nucleotide binding due to its proximity to Gtr1's cognate switch II domain. Further fluorescence analysis on Gtr1 mutants will give further insight on the structural dynamic. The TLC assay gives us a tool to further determine the kinetics of the Gtr1 protein. Electron Paramagnetic Resonance is used to monitor Pho84/Gtr1 interaction.D. Samyn 2 , R. A. Zvyagilskaya 1 , F. Lundh 2 , J. Pattison-Granberg 2 , J.-M. Mouillon 2 , Y. Popova 3,4 , J. M. Kameshita Kagawa University, Kagawa, JAPAN Doublecortin-like protein kinase (DCLK) is a Ser/Thr protein kinase expressed in the central nervous system. The N-terminal domain of DCLK is highly homologous to doublecortin (DCX) and mediates microtubule association. The C-terminal kinase domain shares 40% sequence identity with the multifunctional CaMKs. Both DCX and DCLK are believed to be associated with microtubules and involved in neuronal migration and neuronal growth. However, the biological functions of the kinase activity of DCLK in vivo have not yet been clarified. To investigate the biological significance of DCLK, we cloned and characterized zebrafish DCLK (zDCLK). In this study, we examined catalytic properties of zDCLK and various mutants. Recombinant zDCLK(WT) showed kinase acitivity without being activated by Ca 2+ / CaM and CaMKK. The N-terminal deletion mutant zDCLK(378-810) containing kinase domain showed 2-fold higher activity as compared to zDCLK(WT). To investigate functional role of C-terminal region of

TABREF146.text: S. Sukprasert 1 , S. Thammasirirak 1 , T. Jamjanya 2 and S. Daduang 1 Department of Biochemistry, Faculty of Science, Khon Kaen University, Khon Kaen, THAILAND, 2 Department of Entomology, Faculty of Agriculture, Khon Kaen University, Khon Kaen, THAILAND Introduction: Fire ant (Solenopsis sp.) is a venomous insect. 95% of venom is alkaloids with allergic properties. Remaining is peptides promoting allergic activity. Many allergens are characterized in red imported fire ant (S. invicta) venom. In this study, we characterized an active protein, Sol g II, in S. geminata venom and its antibody production for antivenom development. Methods: Venom collection by capillary method under stereomicroscope. Peptide mass fingerprints (PMF) were analyzed by MALDI-TOF mass spectroscopy. For paralyzed dose 50 (PD 50 ) assay, sample was injected to cricket, those unable to turnover from overturn position were determined as being paralyzed. Results and Conclusion: Sol g II was the most major band in SDS-PAGE analysis of S. geminata crude venom. It composed of 6 isoforms in 2D-PAGE profiles. After PMF analysis, it showed high similarity to Sol i II. N-terminal sequencing revealed 90% identity to Sol i II. Anti-Sol g II antibody was raised with high titer (>1:1000). The antibody was able to increase PD 50 of S. geminata venom suggesting of its high potency to accelerate activity of alkaloids and to be used as antigen for antivenom production.H. Thirkettle, J. Girling, I. Mills, D. Neal and H. Whitaker CRUK Uro -Oncology, Research Group, Department of Oncology, CRUK Cambridge Research Institute, University of Cambridge, Cambridge, UKIntroduction: LYRIC has been reported to regulate key components of PI3-kinase and NF-jB pathways involved in tumorigenesis. The localisation of LYRIC is dynamic with its distribution altering with cell polarity, cell type and neoplasia. Different functions have been reported for LYRIC in different cellular locations, hence LYRIC localisation may regulate its function. Methods: Three lysine-rich regions within LYRIC were designated NLS-1, -2 and -3 and cloned into a GFP-tagged vector. The same regions were also deleted from LYRIC. COS cells were transfected with these constructs and their ability to target GFP to the nucleus was determined using confocal imaging and Western blotting. Posttranslational modification of LYRIC by ubiquitin and SUMO was established by immunoprecipitation. Results: The three lysine-rich regions within LYRIC target GFP to the nucleus and nucleolus. NLS-3 is the predominant regulator of nuclear localisation, whereas NLS-1 regulates nucleolar localisation. Using the NLS deletion mutants we have shown that they act cooperatively to regulate LYRIC distribution. NLS-2 is modified by mono-ubiquitination and SUMO and appears to act as a regulatory region. Conclusions: The different NLS regions have different functions in translocating LYRIC to different regions of the nucleus. Only NLS-2 is modified by ubiquitin and SUMO and this may regulate NLS function. We suggest that LYRIC localisation is regulated by a multifactoral process which could be targeted for therapeutic benefit. Thioalkalivibrio nitratireducens: structure of the enzyme complexes with substrates and inhibitorsT. Tikhonova 1 , A. Trofimov 2 , K. Polyakov 1,2 , K. Boyko 1 , A. Filimonenkov 1 and V. Popov 1 Bach Institute of Biochemistry RAS, Moscow, RUSSIA, 2 Engelhardt Institute of Molecular Biology RAS, Moscow, RUSSIAEight heme cytochrome c nitrite reductase (TvNiR) was isolated from the denitrifying sulfur-oxidizing haloalkaliphilic bacterium Thioalkalivibrio nitratireducens. Catalytic properties were characterized and structure of the TvNiR oxidized form was solved at resolution 1.5 A. It was shown that TvNiR exists in the solution as a stable hexamer containing 48 hemes c per molecule. Despite only about of 20% sequence identity with the structurally characterized five heme cytochrome c nitrite reductases (ccNiRs) the structure of the active site and arrangement of 5 from 8 hemes including catalytic heme have been similar in TvNiR and ccNiRs. Unfortunately TvNiR revealed the maximal activity in nitrite reduction and extremely low activity in sulfite reduction as compared to other ccNiRs. For study the relation between the active site structure and catalytic properties of TvNiR the high resolution structures of TvNiR (oxidized form) complexes with substrates (nitrite and sulfite) and inhibitors (azide and sulfate) were solved. It has been shown that the bond lengths and orientation of the ligands in the TvNiR active site differ from the similar ccNiR complexes, resulted in some dissimilarity in catalytic properties. It is known that reduced forms of ccNiR possesed increased affinity to substrates. Extremely low sulfite reduction activity of TvNiR allowed us to obtain the structure of TvNiR reduced form with substrate -sulfite. Comparative analysis of substrate binding with oxidized and reduced form is carried out. Acknowledgement: The work was supported by the grant of RFBR 07-04-01559-a.PP3-82Evolution of XPF function through de facto formation of dimers and degenerative mutationsK. Tripsianes 1,3 , G. E. Folkers 1 , N. N.G. Jaspers 2 , Jan H.J. Hoeijmakers 2 and R. Boelens 1 Department of NMR Spectroscopy, Utrecht University, NETHERLANDS, 2 Department of Cell Biology and Genetics, Erasmus Medical Center, Rotterdam, NETHERLANDS, 3 Department Chemie, Lehrstuhl Fr Biomolekulare NMR-Spektroskopie, Technische Universitaet Mu¨nchen, Mu¨nchen, GERMANYAbstract: In eukaryotes, XPF and ERCC1 proteins form an obligate heterodimer that functions as a structure-specific endonuclease in many aspects of DNA metabolism. The archaeal species, on the other hand, possess XPF homodimers with key properties of the XPF/ERCC1 enzymatic activity. Methods: We have used NMR Spectroscopy to determine the structures of the C-terminal XPF/ERCC1 interacting domains and of the socalled central domain of ERCC1, and to address the molecular details of their function in the coordinated nucleolytic activity of the heterodimer. Results: The structural data show that the XPF/ERCC1 interacting domains share the HhH 2 motif of the archaeal XPF counterpart and complex in the same manner as the archaeal species do. In contrast to archaea, however, the human domains are not functionally equal and only ERCC1 HhH 2 domain is involved in DNA binding[1]. The ERCC1 central domain shows again striking structural similarity with the active nuclease domain of the archaeal homodimer. Although the ERCC1 domain is devoid of the conserved catalytic residues and therefore is not active, it has acquired a novel protein-binding function[2]. Conclusions: We discuss the structure-function relationship of the homo-and hetero-versions of the enzyme, which can be unified under an evolutionary concept. That of duplicate genes (and their protein products), which preserved the ancestral 3D fold, but accumulated diverge mutations in different domains, leading to the complementary loss of conserved motifs and selective retention of different aspects of function present in the ancestral non-duplicated enzyme. Such an evolutionary scenario can explain the transformation from homo-to hetero-association and the accompanying differences in XPF repair site targeting strategy.References: 1. Tripsianes, et al., Structure 2005; 13: 1849-1858. 2. Tripsianes et al., NAR 2007; 35: 5789-5798. K. Uda and T. Suzuki Kochi University, Kochi, JAPAN

TABREF147.text: G. Nikolopoulos 1 *, D. Vlachakis 1 *, B. Waltenspiel 2 , W. Warren 2 , M. Vlassi 1 NCSR 'Demokritos' Institute of Biology, Athens, GREECE, 2 James Cook University, Comparative Genomics Centre, Qld, AUSTRALIA

TABREF148.text: T. Yamamura and T. Sakajiri Department of Food and Nutrition, Morioka College, Takizawa, Iwate, JAPAN Serum transferrin (Tf) tightly binds Fe(III), transports it with blood stream and delivers it to the cytosol of iron-requiring cells by receptormediated endocytosis. The iron-binding site can bind various metal ions besides Fe(III). However, only the Fe(III)-Tf complex can be incorporated into the cells by specific interaction with Tf-receptor. In this study, we calculated metal-Tf binding energies for Fe(III), Fe(II), Ga(III), Al(III), Cu(II), Ni(II) and Zn(II), employing Gaussian 03 with B3LYP/6-31G** basis set for ab nitio MO calculation. As a result, metal binding energy (-DE) was of the following order: Fe(III) > Ga(III) >> Al(III) > Cu(II) > Zn(II) > Ni(II) > Fe(II). This order had a good correlation with -log K (K: experimental binding constant), giving a correlation coefficient of 0.985. The result showed that the binding of Fe(III) to Tf produced large energy enough to induce the conformational change of the protein for the binding of the Fe(III)-Tf complex to the Tf-receptor. On the iron-Tf complex formation process, although the Fe(II)-Tf complex was much more unstable than the Fe(III)-Tf complex, it was assumed that Fe(II) more rapidly reacted with Tf than Fe(III), because dehydration energy for Fe(II) was smaller than that for Fe(III) enters the circulation from duodenum as Fe(II) through the iron transport protein ferropotin 1. Consequently, it is supposed that the Fe(II)-Tf complex is firstly formed and the bound Fe(II) is subsequently oxidized by hephaestin on the basolateral membrane of enterocyte of duodenum, resulting in the formation of the stable Fe(III)-Tf complex.PP3-88Structural basis for the revalence between bitter taste and pharmacological properties J. Yang, J. Fang and M. Shen College of Pharmacy and Nutrition, University of Saskatchewan, Saskatoon, SK, CANADA

TABREF149.text: Results and Conclusions: Most classes of drugs exhibit inconsistent taste properties except some groups such as antibiotics and antiviral drugs display dominantly bitter taste. The bitter taster receptors exhibited high structural similarities with the histamine H1-receptor (r.m.s.d. < 1.7 Å ). The active site of the bitter taste receptors resembles that of the histamine H1 receptor, suggesting that H1 antihistaminics may bind to the bitter taste receptors.E. Yelboga 1,2 , Z. Candan 1,2 , B. Binay 1,2 , B. Emel 1,2 , R.B. Sessions 3 , A. R. Clarke 3 and G.-K. Nevin 1,2 Department of Molecular Biology and Genetics, Faculty of Science and Letters, Istanbul Technical University, Istanbul, TURKEY, 2 Istanbul Technical University, Molecular Biology-Biotechnology & Genetics Research Center (MOBGAM), Istanbul, TURKEY, 3 Department of Biochemistry, School of Medical Sciences, Bristol, UK Introduction: NAD + -dependent formate dehydrogenase (EC 1.2.1.2, FDH)is the last enzyme in the metabolism of methanol in methylotrophs and catalyzes the oxidation of formate anion into carbon dioxide concomitant with the reduction of NAD + to NADH. One crucial role of this enzyme in industrial redox chemistry is to regenerate NADH from NAD + -and formate. However, it uses only NAD as a coenzyme. It would be also desirable to regenerate NADPH by using NADP as a coenzyme. Methods: In previous experiments we have enabled cmFDH to use NADP by the single mutation Asp159Ser (1). However, this mutant binds NADP very weakly. In this study, we explore further mutations in the coenzyme binding domain to improve the K M of cmFDH for NADP. Asp195Ala(D195A), Asp195Ser (D195S), Tyr196Arg (Y196R) mutations have been designed separately and together as a double mutant cycle by using Insight II (Accelrys) program on homology model of cmFDH based on Pseudomonas sp.101. Results: The designed mutant proteins are produced and purified. Kinetic studies have been carried out and the results have been compared with the wild type cmFDH protein. Conclusions: The results suggest that the residues in these positions are major determinant of coenzyme specificity in NAD/NADP-dependent dehydrogenases. Acknowledgement: Parts of this work are supported by Turkish State Planning Organisation in Advanced Technologies Program and Turkish State Planning Organisation (Project No: 90188) Reference: 1. Gul-Karaguler, et al., Biotechnology L. 2001; 23: 283-287. M. Zalewska 1 , Jean-Pierre Esteve 2 , F. Lopez 2 , B. Monsarrat 3 , C. Susini 2 , A. Ozyhar 1 and M. Kochman 1 Department of Biochemistry, Faculty of Chemistry, Wroclaw University of Technology, Wroclaw, POLAND, 2 INSERM U858, IFR31, CHU Rangueil, Toulouse, FRANCE, 3 CNRS, IPBS, Toulouse, FRANCE

TABREF150.text: Institute of Biochemistry and Biophysics, University of Tehran, Tehran, IRAN, 2 Islamic Azad University, Jahrom, IRAN,3  Department of Biology Payam-e-Noor University, Yazd, IRAN, 4 Department of Biochemistry, Tehran University of Medical Science, Tehran, IRANThe binding of silver nanoparticle to bovine hemoglobin (Hb) has been investigated by fluorescence, UV-Visible and circular dichroism (CD) spectroscopies at different temperatures of 293, 310, and 315 K. The results of CD and fluorescence spectra indicate a conformational change of Hb with addition of silver nanoparticle. The fluorescence data show that the binding of nanoparticle to hemoglobin is occurred in a single binding site, which shows a dynamic quenching procedure. Nanoparticle can reduce the fluorescence of tryptophanyl residues of Hb to a lesser extent. Furthermore, the addition of nanoparticle resulted in the little blue shifts of maximum peak position at different temperatures of 293, 310, and 315 K. Circular dichroism studies indicate a conformational change of hemoglobin in the presence of silver nanoparticle. The helicity of hemoglobin reduces in presence by increasing the concentration of silver nanoparticle at different temperatures. Thermodynamic analysis of the protein interaction by silver nanoparticle suggests that the binding process is only entropy driven.Division of Cellular and Molecular Biology, ''Victor Babes'' National Institute of Pathology, Bucharest, ROMANIA, 2 Department of Cellular and Molecular Medicine, ''Carol Davila'' University of Medicine and Pharmacy, Bucharest, ROMANIA, 3 Clinics of Hematology, University Hospital, Bucharest, ROMANIAMyelodisplasia/myeloproliferative disorders are conditions proved to affect not only leukocytes and erythrocytes, but also thrombocytes function. This report shows changes appearing in the expression of von Willebrand factor receptor (vWFR) of thrombocytes in patients suffering those disorders. The expression of vWFR on platelet surface was assessed by flow cytometry, while total receptor espression was evaluated by western blot using proteins in thrombocyte lysates. Three vWFR subunits (CD42a-c) were immunodetected on PVDF membrane and quantified by densitometry. Results showed significant alterations in expression level of CD42b (decreased by~25%, P < 0.05), while expression levels for CD42a and CD42c, despite lower, proved no statistical significance, by comparison with the levels in thrombocyte lysates of healthy persons. In conclusion, myelodisplasia/myeloproliferative disorders are accompanied by changes in expression level of essential proteins in thrombocyte function, suggesting an impaired function due to an improper stoichiometry of the receptor.Acknowledgment: This study was granted by Ministry of Education and Research of Romania (Research of Excellence Program, CEEX 62/2005). L. Albulescu 1 , E. Raducan 1 , D. I. Popescu 1 , E. Codorean 1 , M. A. Tanase 1 , M. Neagu 1 , O. S. Dima 2 , C. Tanase 1 and R. Albulescu 1 Victor Babes National Institute of Pathology, Bucharest, ROMANIA, Fundeni Clinical Institute, Bucharest, ROMANIA Introduction: Matrix metalloproteinases, key enzymes in tissue remodeling, are also associated with tumor growth. Numerous studies show modifications of MMPs activity in tumors; especially changes of serum/plasma levels of MMP2 and MMP9 in different carcinoma (mammary, pulmonary, gastric). A good correlation between MMP levels and tumor evolution transforms these enzymes into dual targets -of therapeutic and diagnosis interest. Significant changes (and well correlated) are visible in serum levels of some tissue inhibitors of metalloproteinases (TIMP), mostly for TIMP1 and TIMP2. The objective of this study was the assessment of a set of serum markers -MMP1, MMP2, MMP9, TIMP and CA19.9 in pancreatic cancer patients and the evaluation of their predictive value. Methods: Analysis of MMP1, MMP2, MMP9 and TIMP was done using xMAP array method (Luminex) and CA19.9 levels were determined by ELFA (Bio-Merieux kit) on sample sera from patients with pancreatic tumors and controls. Results: Average values of evaluated markers were: Controls: MMP1 -80,47 pg/ml, MMP2: 2915,46 pg/ml, MMP9: 5339,86 pg/ml, TIMP: 2,64 ng/ ml, Patients: MMP1 -31,86 pg/ml, MMP2: 2.360,33 pg/ml, MMP9: 10.776,61, TIMP: 3,835 ng/ml. Results analysis showed a very good correlation (p < 0,05) for MMP9; MMP1 presents significant changes compared with controls, but with bidirectional deviations -hyperexpression in untreated patients and underexpression in treated patients. Good correlation between elevated tissue remodeling serum markers and serum level of CA19.9 was observed. MMP9, TIMP) shows that MMP9 and MMP1 can be useful serum markers in the evaluation of pancreatic tumor evolution. H. Bouga 1 , I. Tsouros 1 , D. Bounias 2 , D. Kyriakopoulou 2 , M. Stavropoulos 2 , N. Papageorgakopoulou 1 , D. A. Theocharis 3 and D. H. Vynios 1 Laboratory of Biochemistry, Department of Chemistry, University of Patras, Patras, GREECE, 2 Department of Surgery, University Hospital of Patras, Patras, GREECE, 3 Laboratory of Biological Chemistry, Department of Medicine, University of Patras, Patras, GREECEIntroduction: Hyaluronan is a glycosaminoglycan responsible for the hydration of extracellular matrix. Its amounts and size are regulated by specific enzymes, the hyaluronan (HA) synthases and the hyaluronidases (Hyals). During various types of cancer alterations in the expression of these enzymes were observed. The present study focused on their expression and activity in samples from patients with colorectal cancer.

TABREF151.text: PP4A-8 Plasma and urine CTGF and glycosaminoglycans levels in children and adolescents with type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM). A possible link to diabetic nephropathy O. Ellina 1 , A. Chatzigeorgiou 1 , C. Mylona-Karagianni 2 , E. Tsouvalas 2 , M. Lyberi 1 and E. Kamper 1 Department of Experimental Physiology, Medical School, National and Kapodistrian University of Athens, Athens, GREECE, 2 Second Department of Pediatrics, Panagiotis and Aglaia Kyriakou Pediatric Hospital, Medical School, National and Kapodistrian University of Athens, Athens, GREECEIntroduction: Alteration of proteoglycans and their linear carbohydrates chains glycosaminoglycans (GAGs), in basement membrane (BM), cell surface and extracellular matrix (ECM) is implicated in the development of diabetic nephropathy by altering the negative charge of BM and modifying the bioavailability of growth factors to their signal transducing receptors. We examined plasma and urine-CTGF and GAGs levels, in relation to known inflammatory markers in type 1 diabetes mellitus children and adolescents, to evaluate their involvement in diabetic nephropathy. Methods: Plasma and urine-CTGF of 35 uncomplicated patients and 10 healthy controls(HCs) were measured by ELISA, while GAGs were measured spectrophotometrically. Markers of renal function, metabolic and inflammation state were estimated per subject. Our findings show that the loss of GAGs, responsible for the gradual loss of BM negative charges and the development of diabetic nephropathy, begins early in diabetic patients and is related to disease's duration and patients' inflammatory state. Our findings also suggest that CTGF might be involved in renal extracellular matrix modifications induced by diabetic hyperglycaemia.E. Ganea 1 , C. Laslo 1 , G. Putina 2 and R. Guta 2 Institute of Biochemistry, Bucharest, ROMANIA, 2 Institute of Chemical and Pharmaceutical Research and Development, Bucharest, ROMANIAIntroduction: Matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs), a family of zincdependent enzymes degrade extracellular matrix components, having an important role in physiological tissue turnover, homeostasis, and morphogenesis. An imbalance in the expression of MMPs and their specific tissue inhibitors contributes to various pathologies. Bringing MMP inhibitors to clinical trials was not successful; therefore, finding new synthetic inhibitors became an important task. In the present work the inhibitory effects of new heterocyclic, hydroxamate-based compounds, synthesized by our group have been studied. Methods: Enzymatic activity of MMP2, MMP7, MMP9 and MMP12, as well as of MMPs in biological media (synovial fluid, bovine brain homogenate separated by Sephadex G-100) was estimated by a sensitive fluorescent method on FS-6 substrate, and by gelatin zymography. The specific enzymes were identified by Western-Blot analysis. The activity of MMPs secreted into RPI medium by murine melanoma cell lines B16-F1 and B16-F10, respectively, was estimated as well.Results: The compounds (C1-C5) tested, inhibited MMPs with different rate, function of inhibitor and enzyme, e.g. C4 was six-times more efficient on MMP7 than on MMP2; inhibition rate of MMPs in the synovial fluid was 63-83% for C1-C5, and in the bovine brain homogenate, the inhibition was: 67%, 44% and 37% for C1, C2 and C3, respectively. The highest activity of MMPs secreted by B16-line cells was detected after the third passage and inhibited in a similar way. Conclusions: The inhibitory capacity and selectivity displayed by some of the above mentioned compounds suggest their therapeutic potential and in the future, may show promise for cancer and arthritis therapy.PP4A-10 An investigation of selenium levels in healthy Kilis goats M. Iriadam and N. Uren Department of Biochemistry, Faculty of Veterinary Science, Harran University, Sanliurfa, TURKEY

TABREF154.text: On the other hand, no or minor effect of 17-AAG on cell adhesion was observed for Bcr-Abl negative cell lines (JURKAT, Karpas-299, HL60) indicating that 17-AAG actually acts through Bcr-Abl destabilization. We demonstrated by immunobloting that the treatment of Bcr-Abl-positive cells with either Imatinib or 17-AAG leads to the decrease in the expression level and the cleavage of the protein ROCK1. The treatment with Imatinib lowered the expression level of kinases LIM1 and LIM2. By means of FITC-phalloidin staining, we showed that both drugs induce extensive decomposition ofF-actin cytoskeletal structures in Bcr-Abl positive cell lines. Our observations are in agreement with the lowered signaling through Rho/ ROCK/LIM pathway due to Bcr-Abl inactivation. Blatch 3 Nelson Mandela Metropolitan University, Port Elizabeth, SOUTH AFRICA, 2 Medical University of Lodz, Lodz, POLAND, 3 Rhodes University, Grahamstown, SOUTH AFRICAIntroduction: Hepatitis B is the most common serious liver infection in the world. It is caused by the hepatitis B virus (HBV) that attacks the liver. HBV can cause lifelong infection, cirrhosis and cancer. Hepatitis B e-antigen (HBeAg) is a viral protein associated with HBV infections and is often used as a marker of ability to spread the virus to other people. Therefore, detection of HBeAg is important in clinical diagnosis. Methods: Phage display technology offers a very efficient way to purify and characterize proteins by displaying them on the surface of the bacteriophage virion. In this study, HBe antigen was genetically fused to the minor capsid protein gp3 and displayed on the surface of filamentous phages. To assay the activity of the phage displayed HBe antigen, HBe-phages were tested by ELISA and used for immunization of BALB/c mice. Results and Conclusion: To obtain HBe phages, HBV E gene was cloned into phagemid vector and transferred into Escherichia coli TG1. Four clones was randomly selected and controlled by colony PCR. According to the PCR result, colony3 was rescued by M13 K07 phage and tested by ELISA for their affinity to Hbe antibodies. As the ELISA results were positive, BALB/c mice were immunized with col-ony3-phages. The immune response was detected with ELISA from blood samples and positive response was obtained. These results showed that HBe antigen can be displayed on phage surface without loss of activity and that phages can be effectively used as HBe antigen carrier for the production of monoclonal antibodies.E. TABREF156.text: G. Chalepakis 1 , E. Pavlakis 1 , P. Petrou 2 , R. Chiotaki1  and A. Makrygiannis 3University of Crete, Heraklion, GREECE, 2 University of Cyprus, Nicosia, CYPRUS,3  Alexander Fleming Biomedical Sciences Research Centre, Athens, GREECE Introduction: Fraser syndrome is a human disorder characterized by cryptophthalmos, syndactyly and renal defects, malformations that portray a group of the five so called bleb mouse mutants. Four of them, blebbed, head bleb, myelencephalic-bleb and eye-bleb result from mutations in four genes, Fras1, Frem1, Frem2 and Grip1. Mutations in human counterparts FRAS1 and FREM2 have also been identified in Fraser syndrome patients. Fras1, Frem1, Frem2 and Frem3 comprise the family of four extracellular matrix proteins, similar in primary structure and localization pattern and functionally correlated with embryonic dermal-epidermal adhesion, while Grip1, a PDZ-protein, targets Fras1 and Frem2 to the basolateral site of epithelia. Methods: Fras1 knockout mice were generated by homologous recombination. Immunohistochemical studies were performed to investigate the localization pattern of Fras1/Frem proteins. Electron microscopy was utilized to map their exact location in the extracellular space.Results: Immunohistochemistry showed Fras1/Frem proteins to be strictly colocalized in the mouse epithelial basement membranes during development, while ultrastructural studies revealed their colocalization in the sublamina densa. Consistently, bleb mutants develop subepidermal blisters resulting from dermal-epidermal detachment below the lamina densa. Moreover, abolishment of one protein from the basement membrane, results in absence of the rest. Conclusions: Recent findings suggest a functional interplay between Fras1, Frem1 and Frem2, succeeded by the formation of an interdependent macromolecular protein complex, stabilized by the simultaneous interaction of all three proteins. On the other hand, Frem3 appears to act autonomously being detected in epithelial basement membranes, even in the absence of the rest Fras1/Frem proteins.A. Radwanska 1 , D. Nowak 1 , D. MS profiling of O-glycosylated proteins in sera of patients with endometrial adenocarcinoma P. Abdul-Rahman 1 , B. K. Lim 2 , N. M. Yunos 3 , M. I. Adnan 3 and O. H. Hashim 1 Department of Molecular Medicine, Faculty of Medicine, Kuala Lumpur, MALAYSIA, 2 Department of Obstetric & Gynaecology, Faculty of Medicine, Kuala Lumpur, MALAYSIA, 3 Centre for Proteomics Research, Forest Research Institute of Malaysia, Selangor, MALAYSIAIntroduction: Endometrial adenocarcinoma (EACa) is a cancer arising from the epithelium of the uterine lining. It constitutes 60-80% of endometrial malignancies affecting women worldwide. At present, the best available tumour marker for diagnosis of this cancer is CA 125 which is elevated in a minority of patients with low stage disease. In the present study, we have used a lectin-based approach in combination with SELDI-MS to analyse the O-glycosylated serum protein profiles of patients with EACa and normal controls. Methods: Analysis of serum glycoproteins by SELDI-MS was performed utilising pre-activated ProteinChip arrays immobilised with champedak galactose binding (CGB) lectin. The developed lectin-array was used to capture O-glycosylated proteins with Gal or Gal(1-3Gal-NAc configuration in sera of patients with EACa (n = 12) and normal controls (n = 10). Peak profiles obtained from both cohorts were analysed using Biomarker Wizard software. Results: Optimisation experiments of the glycoprotein capture assay showed that the lectin-array was capable of retaining O-linked serum glycoproteins with masses ranging from 5000 to 40 000 Da. Comparison between the SELDI spectral profiles of normal individuals and patients with EACa elucidated differences in the clusters of peaks detected. Using the Biomarker Wizard software, comparison of the synthetic peak maps of the groups showed a pattern where two peaks were observed solely in the spectra of normal controls. In contrast, six peaks were found exclusively in EACa patients.Conclusions: The development of the new lectin-array enables analysis of O-glycosylated serum protein expression patterns associated with cancers and other pathological diseases. Conclusion: These findings demonstrate extremely novel features of the parasite enzyme, since neither soluble nor secreted forms of PSD have been previously described for any organism.Introduction: Mycoviruses with double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) genome are ubiquitous in fungi and their presence remains usually undetected due to the lack of perceptible phenotypic changes of their host. Conclusions: Cellular internalization of non-enveloped HCV capsidlike particles can induce specific MAPKs signaling events.Introduction: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a deadly opportunistic Gram-negative pathogen of immunocompromised, cancer, HIV, transplant and burn patients. TABREF191.text: Introduction:The Burkholderia cepacia complex (BCC) is a group of opportunistic pathogens that can cause severe infections in Cystic Fibrosis patients. Aiming at the identification of new virulence determinants of the BCC, a mutant collection of B. cenocepacia K56-2 was prepared, by random plasposon mutagenesis, and screened for impaired virulence using the nematode Caenorhabditis elegans infection model. Results and discussion: The P4A1 mutant strain was selected due its phenotype of reduced virulence to the C. elegans. Sequence analysis and homology searches revealed that B. cenocepacia P4A1 carries a Tn5 insertion in an ORF, here named pbr, encoding a putative protein 72% identical to the DNA-directed RNA polymerase subunit beta from Bacillus cereus AH1134. In silico analysis revealed that Pbr contains a HTH motif, putatively involved in nucleic acid binding. Sequence analysis of the DNA sequence upstream pbr revealed two ORFs, encoding putative proteins 97% and 91% identical, respectively, to the Pseudomonas chlororaphis phenazine biosynthesis PhzD and PhzF. The mutant was unable to produce phenazines. A putative gene encoding a protein of unknown function was also found upstream of the phzF gene. The search for homologous sequences in other BCC species with their genome sequences available, revealed that the locus here described is, most probably, unique in the BCC. Due to the low GC content of this locus, as compared to the median GC content of the genome, it is hypothesized that this could be part of a larger genomic region acquired through horizontal transfer.Acknowledgement: Work Funded by PTDC/BIA-MIC/65210/2006.

TABREF270.text: PP8B-13 Antiviral activity of liposome-incorporated ER a-glucosidase inhibitors A. Macovei, L. Catalin, N. Nichita and M. Trif Institute of Biochemistry, Bucharest, ROMANIA Backround: Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is an important human pathogen that causes chronic liver disease leading to death. The current antiviral therapy is inefficient and often leads to selection of drug-resistant mutants. Deoxynojirimycin-based iminosugar derivatives (NB-DNJ and NN-DNJ) are ER a-glucosidase inhibitors with antiviral activity against HBV. Treatment of HBV-infected cells with these drugs results in viral protein misfolding and degradation, impaired assembly of envelope proteins and secretion of less infectious viral particles. However, the drugs concentration used is rather high (for NB-DNJ) or associated with cellular toxicity (for NN-DNJ). To tackle these problems we developed a drug delivery system based on incorporation of the inhibitors in liposomes. Materials and methods: Liposomes were prepared using phosphatidylcholine, dioleoylphosphatidylethanolamine and cholesterol (7:2:1), by thin-film hydration followed by sonication. Empty liposome and liposome entrapped NB-DNJ and NN-DNJ were extruded under sterile conditions, resulting liposomes with a diameter of 200 nm. HepG2.2.2.15 cells stably transfected with the HBV genome were treated with either free or liposome entrapped drugs, for 9 days. The medium was collected and secreted virus was purified by ultracentrifugation and quantified by Southern blot. Results: HBV-infected cells were treated with either free of liposomeincorporated drugs, in concentrations ranging from 5 to 500 lM. NB-DNJ delivery by liposomes resulted in a 40 fold enhancement of the inhibition of HBV secretion when used at a concentration of 50 lM. The antiviral effect of NN-DNJ was improved by two fold only, however, a major reduction of cellular toxicity associated with this drug was observed. Conclusions: The antiviral effect of the iminosugars against HBV was greatly improved by liposome delivery, while cellular toxicity was reduced. Our findings point to the possibility of developing these formulations for anti-HBV treatment.H. H. T. Moreira 1 , M. O. Albuquerque 2 , R. C. M. Paula 2 , R. A. Moreira 1 and A. C. Oliviera Monteiro 1 CCS-UNIFOR, Ceara´, BRASIL, 2 CC-UFC, Ceara´, BRASILPolymeric nanoparticles, for drug incorporation, have been used, due to their good stability and half-life in biological fluids, site directed drug release and biodegradability biocompatibility. Polysaccharide modification has been explored to obtain lipophylic material, best absorbed by the body. Galactomannans, neutral water soluble polysaccharides, present in leguminous endospermic cell walls, have great potential for nanoparticle synthesis, due to their high viscosity, biocompatibility and biodegradability. Galactomannan (2 g) were solubilized in formamide (60 ml), under stirring, at 50°C. To this solution, pyridine (12 ml) and acetic anhydride (30 ml) were added at 54ordm;C, under stirring for 48 hour. The viscous solution obtained was purified by precipitation with successive washing with H 2 O and the precipitate, dryed at 40°C for 24 hour was stored at room temperature. Nanoparticles were prepared by emulsion of a galactomannan acetate solution (0.05% in DMSO) dispersed in H 2 O, in the proportion of 1:50, in the presence or absence of the surfactant agent SPAN 20. The FT-IR spectra confirmed that the acetyl moieties had been successfully introduced, as new peaks appeared at 1753/cm, 1375/cm and 604/cm, when compared to non treated galactomannan spectrum and both samples showed mono dispersion characteristics. No remarkable difference was found due to the use of surfactant, as nanoparticles obtained in its presence showed a size of 434 nm while in its absence nanoparticles of 449 nm were obtained. Acknowledgements: Supported by Rede Nanoglicobiotecnologia/ CNPq.O. R. Nascimento 1 , T. Prieto 2 , K. C. U. Mugnol 2 , P. A. Faria 2 , T. Rodrigues 2 , Y. Iamamoto 3 , A. M. Carmona-Ribeiro 4 and I. L. Nantes 2 Universidade de Sa˜o Paulo, Sa˜o Carlos, BRAZIL, 2 Universidade de Mogi das Cruzes, Sa˜o Paulo, BRAZIL, 3 Universidade de Sa˜o Paulo, Ribeira˜o Preto, BRAZIL, 4 Universidade de Sa˜o Paulo, Sa˜o Paulo, BRAZILIntroduction: It is well known that microinjection of exogenous cytochrome c is able to trigger apoptosis in cells. This fact points out the possibility to use efficient carriers for cytochrome c to induce cell death. Methods: Giant diocatadecyldimethylammonium bromide (DODAB) vesicles were loaded with cytochrome c and Fe 3+ Meso-tetrakis(2,4dichloro-3-sulfonatophenyl) porphyrin (Fe 3+ TDCSO 3 -Na + PP), incubated with K562, K562 Lucena (a multi-drug resistent cell) and aortic smooth muscle cells (SMC) and the samples analyzed by Trypan blue assay and fluorescence microscopy. Results: In the absence of porphyrins and cytochrome c, DODAB vesicles induced adherence and death in SMC and leukemic cells by affecting membranes integrity. Cytochrome c-loaded DODAB vesicles did not induce adherence but was very efficient to trigger apoptosis in SMC. In K562 and K562 Lucena cells, the loading of cytochrome c decrease significantly the capacity of DODAB to induce cell death. The association of Fe 3+ TDCSO 3 -Na + PP to DODAB vesicles was corroborated by changes in electronic absorption and paramagnetic spectra (EPR). Analysis of the complex TDCSO 3 -Na + PP/DODAB image by atomic force microscopy (AFM) revealed the formation of a nanowire net that exhibited peroxidase activity. The TDCSO 3 -Na + PP/DODAB complexes were efficient to induce cell death in both, leukemic cell lineages, and relative to the control in the absence of DODAB, they were slightly more efficient for K562 Lucena. Conclusion: diocatadecyldimethylammonium bromide was an efficient carrier to deliver cytochrome c to SMC but not to the leukemic lineages. The significant efficiency of TDCSO 3 -Na + PP/DODAB to induce death in a MDR cell points out a possible use in cancer therapy.Acknowledgements: Supported by FAPESP, CNPq and FAEP-UMC. PP8B-16 Large unilamellar vesicles sandwiched by chitosan for the controlled diphtheria toxoid liberation V. C. Rescia 1,2 and M. H. Bueno Da Costa 1 Laboratorio de Microesferas e Lipossomas, Centro de Biotecnologia, Instituto Butantan, Sa˜o Paulo, BRAZIL, 2 Departmento de Clinica Medica UNIFESP, Sa˜o Paulo, SP, BRAZILIntroduction: The association between chitosan and liposomes (REVs-Chi) stabilized by polyvinilic alcohol is proposed as a controlled delivery for Diphtheria toxoid (Dtxd). Because preparation method characteristics a pre-formulation study on the Dtxd structure is shown. Methods: The protein integrity after sonication with ethyl acetate in the presence of salts was followed by HPLC, CD, ELISA and fluorescence. Encapsulation: Dtxd in 0.5% chitosan was added to soy phosphatidylcholine/cholesterol/ethyl acetate. After micelle formation, by sonication, the formed organogel was resuspended in 1% PVA. Results: The protein solubilization increased to 98% in the presence of PO 4 2and decreased in the presence of Cl -, SCNand Mg 2 (5-40%). The Dtxd a-helical content was quite stable with minor exposition of hydrophobic residues (corroborated by measures on intrinsic Trp fluorescence). Round chitosan-sandwiched REVs (REVs-Chi) particles of 373 ± 17 nm containing 65% Dtxd were obtained. After 200 minutes of incubation in a simulated gastric fluid, 70% of the immunological active Dtxd was liberated from REVs-Chi in comparison to 100% of Dtxd liberated from pure REVs. In PBS, the Dtxd liberation from REVS-Chi was about 60%.Conclusions: REVS-Chi liberated soluble and immunological active Dtxd. The formulation can be use as vaccine particulate adjuvant. TABREF274.text: PP8C-5 Serum selenium levels and its relation to sociodemographic, lifestyle and dietary characteristics in healthy adults: the Attica study S. Letsiou 1,2 , T. Nomikos 1 , E. Fragopoulou 1 , D. Panagiotakos 1 , S. Antonopoulou 1 , S. Pergantis 2 , C. Pitsavos3  and C. Stefanadis 3Department of Science of Nutrition-Dietetics, Harokopio University, Athens, GREECE, 2 Department of Chemistry, University of Crete, Heraklio, GREECE,3  First Cardiology Clinic, School of Medicine, University of Athens, Athens, GREECE Introduction: Epidemiological studies suggest that low Se status is associated with increased risk for many diseases. Its determination may contribute to the assessment of human nutritional and health status. Methods: Selenium was determined in 506 adults (39 ± 11 years) by ICP/MS. The dietary intake was assessed using a semi-quantitative food-frequency questionnaire. Adherence to the Mediterranean diet was assessed by a validated special diet-score. Results: Men and women had similar serum selenium values [men(n = 296): 93.9 ± 31.6 lg/l, women(n = 210): 90.5 ± 35.1 lg/l, P = 0.27), while 88% of them had serum Se<125 lg/l (cut-off considered to be required for optimal glutathione peroxidase). Se levels were decreased with advanced age and smoking habits, and increased with the adherence to a Mediterranean type of diet, as well as with meat, and poultry intake (P < 0.05). Conclusions: Roughly 9/10 of the participants had low Se. For the first time in our population, we revealed that Se levels are inversely associated with age and smoking, while greater adherence to the Mediterranean diet seems to increase its concentration in apparently healthy adults. However, some other nutritional habits like the consumption of meat seem also to increase Se, in our sample. Effects of conjugated linoleic acid (CLA) on lipid metabolism in the skeletal muscle are not related with enhanced PPAR-a expressionD. Caetano Gonc¸alves 1 , L. C. Carnevali 1,2 , R. Eder 1 , W. P. Lima 1,3 and M. Seelaender 1 Molecular Biology of The Cell Group, Institute of Biomedical Sciences, University of Sa˜o Paulo, Sa˜o Paulo, BRAZIL, 2 University of Taboa˜o da Serra (FTS), Sa˜o Paulo, BRAZIL, 3 Federal Technological Education Center of Sa˜o Paulo (CEFET-SP), Sa˜o Paulo, BRAZIL

TABREF275.text: . Methods: Male rats were supplemented with CLA for 1 month and their weight and food consumption assessed. Fat content in the gastrocnemius muscle was determined. Muscular (gastrocnemius) CPT 1, CPT 2, LPL and PPARa gene expression was measured by RT/ PCR. Results: The weight gain in CLA was lower than control (P < 0.05), inspite of no alteration of food consumption. No modification of muscle fat content was observed in CLA groups compared with controls. Muscle CPT I, CPT II and LPL gene expression was enhanced (P < 0.05), while in expression of muscle PPARa was reduced in CLA, as compared with control groups (P < 0.05). Conclusion: CLA supplementation modifies lipid metabolism, enhancing fat acid oxidation in the muscle of supplemented rats, but this alteration is not accompanied by increase in PPARa expression.L. C. Carnevali Jr 1 , M. C. L. Seelaender 1 , M. Kuna 2 and G. P. Pueschel 2 Molecular Biology of The Cell Group, Institute of Biomedical Sciences, University of Sa˜o Paulo, Sa˜o Paulo, BRAZIL, 2 Universita¨t Potsdam, Institut Fu¨r Erna¨hrungswissenschaft, Biochemie Der Ernahrung, Nuthetal, GERMANYIntroduction: CAR (constitutive androstane receptor) is a key protein related with energy homeostasis, and its regulation by nutrients is poorly known. As n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA), as those found in fish oil (FO), are known to modulate lipid metabolism, we examined the effect of FO supplementation upon CAR mRNA expression. Since n-3 fatty acids are natural ligands to PPARs, we also sought to study the role of PPAR alpha in the mediation of FO effect upon CAR expression. Methods: Male rats were supplemented with n-3 for 5 days (in vivo experiments). In another experiment in vitro, primary hepatocytes cells were cultured. After 24 hour was added in the hepatocytes, 10 lM of WY14643 (PPAR alpha agonist), and the culture was continued for 48 hour more (total of 72 hour). CAR gene expression was measured by Real Time RT/PCR in both in vivo and in vitro experiments. Results: Gene expression of CAR was two-fold increased by FO (in vivo) and nine-fold by PPARa agonist WY14643 in experiments carried out in vitro. Conclusion: FO supplementation was able to induce CAR gene expression in rat liver probally through PPARa activation. These results suggest a mechanism of energy homeostasis control by CAR/ PPARa activation, where PPAR alpha-dependent induction of CAR appears to be of high physiological significance.J. Cascalheira 1 , S. Joao 1 , S. Pinhancos 1 , M. Palmeira 2 , S. Almeida 2 , R. Castro 3 and F. Domingues 1 Centro de Investigac¸a˜o em Cieˆncias da Sau´de, Universidade da Beira Interior, Covilha˜, PORTUGAL, 2 Centro Hospitalar da Cova da Beira, Cova da Beira, PORTUGAL, 3 Centro de Patogen˜ese Molecular, Faculdade de Farmacia, Universidade de Lisboa, Lisbon, PORTUGALIntroduction: High serum levels of homocysteine, low levels of sex hormones and mutations in the 5,10-methylenetetrahydrofolate reductase (MTHFR) gene have been proposed as risk factors for Alzheimer's disease. However, the simultaneous influence of these risk factors on Alzheimer's disease is not clarified and was investigated in the present study. Methods: The subjects were composed of 19 individuals diagnosed with Alzheimer's type Dementia (AD) (test group) and 36 healthy individuals matched for age and gender (control group). The study was approved by the local Ethical Committee; the subjects volunteered for the study and gave their informed consent. Blood samples were collected and serum concentrations of the studied biochemical parameters were determined. MTHFR 1298A>C mutation was screened by PCR-RFLP.Results: Multivariable logistic regression analysis was performed and the best model obtained included homocysteine (OR = 1.OR = 0.728, p < 0.001), uric acid (OR = 14.6, p < 0.001), vitamin B 12 (OR = 0.984, p < 0.004) and MTHFR 1298A>C mutation (OR = 23.4, p < 0.03) as predictors for AD. Conclusions: High serum concentrations of homocysteine, cholesterol and uric acid, and low concentrations of estradiol and vitamin B 12 , as well as the MTHFR 1298A>C mutation are associated to AD.T. Chervenkov 1 , D. Gerova 1 , B. Galunska 1 and V. Enchev 2 Medical University, Department of Biochemistry, Molecular Medicine and Nutrigenomics, Varna, BULGARIA, 2 Bulgarian Academy of Science, Institute of Organic Chemistry, Sofia, BULGARIAIntroduction: Natural compounds are widely tested for their antioxidant activity and potential use for supplementation therapy. Theoretical evaluation of radical scavenging activity of plant bioflavonoids rutin and quercetin in relation to their effect on oxidative stress markers in red blood cells (RBC) of cold-restraint stressed (CRS) rats' was the aim of the present study. Methodology: Ionization energy (HOMO) for quantitative estimation of radical scavenging activity and geometry optimization at Hartree-Fock level of theory using 6-31G basis set were used. Ab initio calculations were performed using GAMESS software. Rutin and quercetin (100 mg/kg) were applied orally 1 hour before the experiment. Oxidative stress was initiated using CRS-model. Thiobarbituric acid reactive substances (TBARS) as membrane lipid peroxidation marker, reduced (GSH) and oxidized (GSSG) glutathione related to endogenous antioxidant potential were measured in RBC hemolysates. Results: The calculated HOMO-energies of quercetin and rutin were -0.2880 and -0.2780 atomic units respectively, which mean higher radical-trapping potential for quercetin than for rutin. Biochemical studies showed markedly elevation of TBRAS (42%) and reduction of glutathione (33% for GSH, 18% for GSSG) after CRS-period. Pretreatment with quercetin increased GSH by 30% and they reach the control values. GSSG and TBRAS significantly decrease (P < 0.05). Pretreatment with rutin did not change the increased TBARS and GSSG. GSH decreased by 37%. Conclusion: In spite of similar quercetin and rutin calculated HOMOenergies, they differ in antioxidant potential evaluated in vivo. A possible reason may be due to the carbohydrate component in rutin structure, which impedes its penetration across the membrane.PP8C-10 Effects of olive extracts on free radical metabolism and glucose stimulated insulin release in INS-1E cell line exposed to H 2 O 2 A. TABREF278.text: Y. Kagawa 1 , K. Nakayama 2 , S. Iwamoto 2 and Y. Yanagisawa 2 Kagawa Nutrition University, Sakado, Saitama, JAPAN, 2 Division of Human Genetics, Jichi Medical University, Shimotsuke, Tochigi, JAPAN Introduction: In Asia-Pacific countries, both environmental modernization and hereditary traits of Mongoloid have been reported to cause rapid increase in lifestyle-related diseases (LRD). Single nucleotide polymorphism (SNPs) on genomic DNA can be used as a hereditary trait factor. Many reports have been published about cause-effect relationships between SNPs-LRD; however, reproducibility of those responsive factors is low. A decision-tree method of complexity-model was employed to select LRD responsive factors. Methods: Genomic DNA was collected from four Asia-Pacific regions including Thai, Palau, Mongol and China. Three indices of LRD (BMI, body fat, and serum leptin levels) were classified according to published criteria. WEKA Machine-learning system was used as decision-tree software. Age was added as a factor with different dimension. Selected factors were validated by ANOVA and Levine's test for equality of variance. Results: In Thai-males, WEKA system nominated GLUT1 (glucosetransporter 1)-SNP as most-responsive factor to body fat, which was followed by USF1-SNP (transcription-factor for lipid metabolism), but age was not selected as responsive factor. Differences between actual values of each genotype were validated (P = 0.002 for GLUT1 by Levene's, P = 0.071 for USF1 by ANOVA). Nominated factors for leptin levels of Thai-males were USF1 and age. Factors for leptin levels of Thai-females were age, PON1 (paraoxonase, high-density-lipoprotein associated enzyme), KCNJ1 (potassium non voltage-gated channel) and DGAT (diacylglycerol acyltransferase). Convincing responsive factors were not selected from mixed data of four regions. Conclusions: Decision-tree-analysis successfully selected the convincing results. Responsive-factors differed by ethnic group and gender.PP8C-19Melissa officinalis extract inhibiting the formation of advanced glycation end-productsS. Khazaei 1 , M. Shirvani 1 , S. Moshgelgosha 1 , F. Karimzadeh 2 and M. TABREF279.text: The level of glycation, change in structure of proteins and their binding to RAGE receptor of microglial cells were assessed by the methods of specific fluorescence, Congo Red Binding assay, circular dichroism, ligand blotting and Western blot analysis. Based on our results, we found that water-soluble extract of Melissa officinalis can slow down the formation of glycated proteins and transition in their secondary structure. BSA incubated with glucose in the presence of extract of Melissa officinalis , has much lower binding affinity for RAGE receptor.

TABREF280.text: PP8C-21 Isoflavone attenuates vascular contraction through inhibition of RhoA/Rho-kinase signaling pathway Y. M. Seok 1 , I. Baek 1 , Y.-H. Kim 2 , Y.-S. Jeong 3 , In.-J. Lee 3 , D. H. Shin 3 , Y. H. Hwang 3 and I. K. Kim 1,4 Department of Pharmacology, Kyungpook National University School of Medicine, Daegu, KOREA, 2 Department of Biochemistry, College of Natural Sciences, Kyungpook National University Daegu, KOREA, Division of Plant Biosciences, College of Agriculture and Life Sciences, Kyungpook National University, Daegu, KOREA, 4 Cardiovascular Research Institute, Kyungpook National University School of Medicine, Daegu, KOREAIsoflavones decrease blood pressure, improve lipid profiles, and restore vascular function. We hypothesized that isoflavone attenuates vascular contraction by inhibiting RhoA/Rho-kinase signaling pathway. Rat aortic rings were denuded of endothelium, mounted in organ baths, and contracted with U46619, a thromboxane A2 analogue or KCl in the presence of genistein or daidzein (10, 30 and 100 lM) for 30 minute or not. We determined the phosphorylation level of myosin light chain (MLC 20 ), myosin phosphatase targeting subunit 1 (MYPT1) and protein kinase C (PKC) -potentiated inhibitory protein for heterotrimeric myosin light chain phosphatase of 17 kDa (CPI17) by the Western blot. We also measured the amount of GTP RhoA as a marker for RhoA activation. Cumulative addition of U46619 and KCl increased vascular tension in a concentration-dependent manner, which were inhibited by pretreatment with genistein or daidzein. U46619 (30 nM) and KCl (50 mM) increased phosphorylation level of the MLC 20, which were inhibited by genistein or daidzein. Furthermore, both genistein and daidzein decreased the amount of GTP RhoA activated by U46619 or KCl. U46619 (30 nM) increased Rho-kinasedependent phosphorylation of the MYPT1 Thr855 and CPI17 Thr38 , which were also inhibited by genistein or daidzein. However, neither genistein nor daidzein inhibited PDBu-induced vascular contraction and CPI17 phosphorylation. In conclusion, isoflavone attenuates vascular contraction at least in part through inhibition of RhoA/Rho-kinase signaling pathway.PP8C-22Role of phosphatidylcholine and its hydrolyzates for efficient intestinal lipid transport in Caco-2 cellsT. Nakano 1 , I. Inoue 2 , S. Katayama 2 , R. Shinozaki 1 , K. Hatayama 1 , S. Hokari 1 and T. Komoda 1 Department of Biochemistry, Saitama Medical University, Saitama, JAPAN, 2 Department of Diabetes and Endocrinology, Saitama Medical University, Saitama, JAPANIntroduction: Phosphatidylcholine (PC) and its hydrolysates stimulate intestinal lipid absorption, however, their exact effects on lipoproteins and apolipoprotein (apo) metabolism remain ambiguous. We attempted to further delineate these effects using fully differentiated Caco-2 cells. Methods: Lipid micelles (oleic acid 0.6, cholesterol 0.05, monooleylglycerol 0.2, taurocholate 2 in mmol/l) with or without choline, PC, and lysoPC were applied apically to Caco-2 cells cultured for 3 weeks on filter membranes. 3 H-oleic acid and 14 C-cholesterol were added to the micelles when necessary. Secreted lipoproteins were analyzed by a HPLC method. Results: LysoPC had the most potent promoting effect on lipid uptake, and lipoprotein and apolipoprotein B-48 secretion among the molecules tested. LysoPC doubled the output of cholesterol and triglyceride as the lipoprotein component, but PC did not. PC increased the secretion of apoA-IV and altered the mRNA levels of lipid metabolism-associated transcription factors, PPARgamma (25%, p < 0.05) and hepatic nuclear factor-4alpha (-19%, p < 0.01). Conclusions: These findings indicate that PC regulates apolipoprotein metabolism, while lysoPC stimulates intestinal lipid transport by accelerating lipoprotein assembly and lipid clearance. Thus, the functional alteration of PC by PLA 2 hydrolysis appears to be intrinsically involved in the intestinal lipid absorption process.N. Kucuk, B. Vanizor Kural and A. OremKaradeniz Technical University, Institute of Health Sciences, Department of Biochemistry, Trabzon, TURKEY Introduction: Brassicaceous plants contain polyphenols, flavonoids and glucosinolates, and so have antioxidant and antiatherogenic effects. Antioxidants inhibit free radical reactions, and therefore protect lipoproteins from oxidation. Oxidation of lipoproteins play an important role in early stage of the development of atherosclerosis. Methods: In the present study, two different concentrations (10 and 50 lg/ml) of aqueous extracts of kale (Brassica oleracea var. acephala) were evaluated for protective effect of lipoprotein oxidation. After isolation of low density lipoprotein (LDL) of 10 healthy volunteers, LDL susceptibilities to copper-induced oxidation were determined by measuring the conjugated diene kinetics with and without kale extracts. Lag time [t (lag)] as a resistance to oxidation of LDL, diene conjugation rate and the total amount of diene produced were evaluated. Results: Resistance of LDL to oxidation increased but diene conjugation rate and the total amount of diene were decreased by increasing extract concentrations significantly. Conclusion: It was concluded that kale extracts decreased susceptibility of LDL, to oxidation. Furthermore, kale has beneficial effects against development of atherosclerosis.PP8C-24Hepatoprotective effect of clam extracts on alcohol-induced liver injuryS. L. Lee 1 , C. Y. Yang 2 and T. Y. Chin 3 Department of Biological Science and Technology, China Medical University, Taichung, TAIWAN, 2 Division of Animal Medicine, Animal Technology Institute Taiwan, Chunan, TAIWAN, 3 Department of Bioscience Technology, Chung Yuan Christian University, Chung Li, TAIWAN

TABREF281.text: F. Martinez, C. Millan, C. Cortes, M. J. Yan˜ez, F. Nualart and M. A. Garcia Department of Cell Biology, University of Concepcion, Concepcion, CHILE Introduction: The hypothalamus is involved in the modulation of the feeding behavior through its ability to detect changes in circulating glucose. Glucokinase (GK) and glucose transporter, GLUT2, are considered to be components of a glucose sensor system. Glucokinase plays a fundamental role in glucose homeostasis, catalyzing the high Km phosphorilation of glucose in tissues involved in glucose sensing mechanisms. Different studies have reported that GK mRNA is expressed in the hypothalamus, however, it has not been clearly determined if glial and/or neuron cells express this protein. Previously we have demonstrated that GLUT2 is localized in tanycytes, glial periventricular cells localized in the hypothalamus. Methods: In this study, we analyzed GLUT2 and GK coexpression in the hypothalamic region using QRT-PCR, in situ hybridization and immunohystochemystry analyses. Results: We demonstrate that GK mRNA is expressed in tanycytes. Real time PCR showed that GK expression in the hypothalamus increased gradually during post-natal life. Immunocytochemical analysis showed that both GLUT2 and GK are coexpressed in tanycytes. GK is mainly localized in the nuclei, while GLUT2 is observed in the cytoplasmatic area and apical membranes of these cells.Conclusions: Based on this evidence, we propose that tanycytes are responsible, at least in part, for a mechanism that allows the hypothalamus to detect changes in glucose concentrations. Acknowledgements: Supported by Conicyt-World Bank Grant ACT-02 and a Conicyt Thesis Grant (to FM).PP8C-26The effects of various inhibitors on b-galactosidase purified from the thermoacidophilic Alicyclobacillus acidocaldarius subsp. rittmannii isolated from AntarcticaK. Guven 1 , A. Kaplan 1 , R. Gul-Guven 2 , F. Matpan 1 and M. Dog˘ru 2 Molecular Biology Section, Science Faculty, Dicle University, Diyarbakir, TURKEY, 2 Science Education Department, Education Faculty, Dicle University, Diyarbakir, TURKEY Introduction: b-galactosidase is a member of glycosyl hydrolyses (GH; EC 3.2.1-3.2.3) which are known to cleave the glycosidic bond between two or more carbohydrates or between a carbohydrate and another moiety. Of these, thermophilic (including thermophilic bacilli), psychrophilic, and halophilic organisms belong to GH-42 family. The enzyme b-galactosidase has main biotechnological uses in the diary industry, e.g. removal of lactose from milk for lactose-intolerant people. Materials and Methods: An intracellular b-galactosidase from a thermoacidophilic Alicyclobacillus acidocaldarius subsp. rittmannii was purified by procedures described recently by Gul-Guven et al., (Enzyme and Microbial Technology, 2007, 40:1570-1577). The bacteria produce thermostable b-galactosidase (EC 3.2.1.23) activity, which exhibits its optimum at the neutral pH region. The pH and temperature optima for the purified enzyme are 6.0 and 65°C, respectively (10 minute assay).The homogenous enzyme had a specific activity of 113 U/mg protein, with a fold purification of 163 and a yield of 8% using the substrate ONPG.

TABREF284.text: C. Nasopoulou 1 , H. C. Karantonis 2 , N. Tsantila 1 , D. N. Perrea 3 , D. G. Iliopoulos 3 , S. E. Theocharis 4 , C. A. Demopoulos 1 and I. Zabetakis 1 Faculty of Chemistry, National and Kapodistrian University of Athens, Athens, GREECE, 2 Department of Science of Nutrition-Dietetics, Harokopio University, Athens, GREECE, 3 Laboratory of Experimental Surgery and Surgical Research, School of Medicine, National and Kapodistrian University of Athens, Athens, GREECE, 4 Department of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, School of Medicine, National and Kapodistrian University of Athens, Athens, GREECEIntroduction: Platelet Activating Factor (PAF), a potent inflammatory mediator, is implicated in atherogenesis. Fish consumption, one of Mediterranean diet characteristics, has been associated with lower incidence of Coronary Heart Disease (CHD). Consequently, fish polar lipids were studied in vitro and in vivo. Methods: Gilthead sea bream total polar lipids (GSBTPL) were isolated from its total lipids. Antithrombotic activity was tested in vitro on washed rabbit platelets. Antiatherogenic activity was studied in vivo using cholesterol fed rabbits. PAF-acetylhydrolase activity and platelet aggregation were determined in rabbit blood. Atherosclerotic damage was assessed by morphometric analysis. Results: GSBTPL inhibited PAF-induced aggregation with IC 50 = 85 ± 10 mcg GSBTPL. Rabbits fed on atherogenic diet enriched with GSBTPL exhibited increased PAF-acetylhydrolase activity, reduced platelet aggregation efficiency and reduced atherosclerotic lesion thickness up to 80%, compared with ones that consumed plain atherogenic diet. Conclusions: It is reported for the first time, that GSBTPL exhibit both antithrombotic and antiatherogenic properties. This further supports the theory of PAF implication in atherogenesis and suggests a biochemical explanation of the protective role fish consumption has against CHD.PP8C-30Apical -basolateral membrane distribution of DMT1 and ferroportin determines intestinal iron absorption M. T. Nun˜ez, V. Tapia, F. Go´mez, A. Rojas and P. Valde´s Departamento de Biologıá, Facultad de Ciencias, Universidad de Chile and Instituto Milenio de Dıńa´mica Celular y Biotecnologia, Santiago, CHILE Introduction: The importance of optimal amounts of iron for wellbeing is well established, being human iron deficiency an overspread nutrition quandary. Body iron levels are regulated by the intestinal epithelial through the coordinated action of two transporters: DMT1, which transports iron form the intestinal lumen into the enterocyte, and ferroportin, which transport iron from the cell into the blood. In this work, we studied the membrane localization of DMT1 and ferroportin and their associated iron fluxes, as a function of the iron status of intestinal epithelia (Caco-2) cells grown in bicameral inserts. Methods: Apical/basolateral membrane localization was determined by selective biotinylation and Western blot analysis. The movement of the transporters was determined by time-lapsed confocal microscopy. A double-isotope ( 55 Fe/ 59 Fe) technique was used to determine concurrent influx and efflux of iron into the apical and basolateral chambers. Results: Iron supplement resulted in the relocalization of DMT1 from the apical membrane into a basal domain, while ferroportin underwent internalization form the basolateral membrane into an intracellular pool. The relocalization of the transporters modified iron fluxes at both the apical and the basolateral membranes. Conclusions: The movement of transporters described here unveils a rapid cellular mechanism for the regulation of intestinal iron absorption. Acknowledgements: Supported by FONDECYT 1070840 and ICM grant P05 001-F. A. Valle, R. Guevara, F. J. Garcia-Palmer, P. Roca and J. Oliver Energy Metabolism and Nutrition Group, CIBER Fisiopatologia Obesidad Y Nutricion (CB06/03) Instituto Salud Carlos III, University of Balearic Islands, Palma de Mallorca, SPAIN

TABREF285.text: Y. Ozarda Ilcol 1 , E. Eroz1  and D. Aslan 2Uludag University, Bursa, TURKEY, 2 Pamukkale University, Denizli, TURKEY Introduction: Recently, various studies have emphasized the nutritional benefits of fish consumption to protect against coronary heart disease (CHD) mortality and stroke. Twice weekly consumption of oily fish containing omega-3 fatty acids (FAs), or 1 g eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA) + docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) daily is recommended. The content of EPA + DHA in erythrocyte membranes (expressed as a percent of total FA) is called 'Omega-3 Index', which appears to be the best FA metric for evaluating CHD and its inversely associated mortality risk. The high prevalence of CHD in Turks is known to be associated with dyslipidemia, but other relevant risk factors are being investigated. This study was designed to determine the erythrocyte membrane FA composition and omega-3 index in healthy volunteers from Northwest Turkey. Methods: Fasting venous blood samples were obtained from 207 healthy 18-to 45-year-olds. Erythrocytes were extracted, transesterificated then analyzed by Agilent 6890 gas chromatograph. Results: Fish consumption in the study group was once a week or less and there was no supplementation of EPA + DHA.

TABREF286.text: PP8C-33 Oral administration of Uncariae ramulus cum uncis inhibits the development of DNFB-induced dermatitis in NC/Nga mice J.-A. Jung 1 and C.-S. Park 1,2 Department of Microbiology (BK21), College of Medicine, Kyunghee University, Seoul, KOREA, 2 Kohwang Medical Research Institute, College of Medicine, Kyung Hee University, Seoul, KOREAEpicutaneously administered chemical haptens like 2, 4-dinitrofluorobenzene (DNFB) or fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC), evoke an Atopic dermatitis (AD)-like dermatitis reaction in NC/Nga mice under Specific Pathogen Free (SPF) conditions. Uncariae ramulus cum uncis (UR), is a popular herbal medicine used to treat stroke and vascular dementia in East Asia. In the present study, we examined whether UR suppress AD-like skin lesions in NC/Nga mice treated with DNFB or FITC under SPF conditions. Oral administration of UR to DNFBtreated NC/Nga mice was found to inhibit ear thickness increases and the skin lesions induced by DNFB, but not FITC. IFN-gamma production by CD4 + T cells from the lymph nodes of DNFB-treated NC/ Nga mice was significantly inhibited by UR treatment, although levels of IL-4 and total IgE in serum were not. These studies suggest that UR may suppress the development of AD-like dermatitis in DNFBtreated NC/Nga mice by reducing IFN-gamma production.PP8C-34Single cell assay by synchrotron-based X-ray microscopy and fluorescence mapping Ca 2+ and K + changes in pancreatic b-cells M. Altissimo 2 , R. Delfino 1 , M. Salomi 3 and L. Pascolo 1 University of Trieste, Trieste, ITALY, 2 CSIRO, Clayton, AUSTRALIA,3  ESRF, Grenoble, FRANCEIntroduction: In pancreatic b-cells, intracellular glucose levels regulate insulin secretion by acting on K + channels and varying membrane permeability to Ca 2+ . It is well established that, similarly to high glucose levels, the antidiabetic drug glibenclamide causes the closure of the K + Channels, with consequent depolarization of the b-cells plasma membrane, opening of the voltage-dependent Ca 2+ channels and insulin granule exocytosis. Recent studies suggest that sulfonilureas may act on additional unknown mechanisms which are responsible of abnormal Ca 2+ overloads. Methods: Synchrotron-based Scanning X-ray Microscopy (SXM) performed in phase contrast mode allows imaging of a single cell, with sub-cell resolution. X-Ray Fluorescence (XRF) detection coupled SXM allows elemental analysis, mapping and quantification in the cell. We used this technique to monitor K + , Ca 2+ and Mg 2+ variations in pancreatic insulin producing cells (RIN-5m). Cells were exposed for 4 hours either to high glucose concentrations (10 mM) or to therapeutic doses of glibenclamide (5 and 10 lM). Results: As expected, glucose causes a uniform increase of K + and Ca 2+ inside the cell. After exposure to glibenclamide, K + levels were comparable to those of cells treated with high glucose concentration, while the Ca 2+ content was noticeably higher (four times), the effects being concentration dependent. Conclusion: These results confirm the hypothesis that glibenclamide acts on multiple Ca 2+ regulating mechanisms. The obtained results clearly demonstrate that SXM coupled with XRF allows the simultaneous determination in a single cell of the K + and Ca 2+ distributions, also providing a realistic quantification.K. Sakuma and A. FukushimaKagawa Nutrition University, Saitama, JAPAN Introduction: Transcellular calcium (Ca) absorption in intestine consists of three sequential steps; Ca influx from intestinal lumen to the intestinal absorptive cells, intracellular diffusion towards the basolateral membrane and subsequent extrusion into the blood compartment. Epithelial calcium channel (TRPV6) in the first step, calcium binding protein (CaBP) in cytoplasm and Ca-ATPase (PMCA1) in the step of extrusion were characterized. While it has long been known that fructooligosaccharides (FOS) increase the Ca absorption, the mechanism has not yet been elucidated. Methods: To characterize the effects of FOS, we fed rats on a diet supplemented with FOS and analyzed the gene expression of TRPV6, CaBP and PMCA1. As a direct regulator of transcription, short chain fatty acids (SCFAs) that were produced by enteric bacteria were added to the medium of Caco-2 cells and mRNA levels were determined. Rat genomic TRPV6 clone was isolated and SCFAs responsive sequences were analyzed by the luciferase reporter assay. Results: The FOS feeding increased the mRNA levels of TRPV6 and CaBP but not PMCA1. The mRNA levels of TRPV6 and CaBP revealed the increase by adding propionate and butyrate in Caco-2 cells, while VDR and cdx-2 didn't show any change. The butyrate responsive sequences were determined between -71 bp and transcription start site of TRPV6 gene. Conclusions: FOS increase Ca absorption in intestine through the gene regulation by SCFAs. The new transcription factor except VDR and cdx-2 was suggested in that process.PP8C-36 SVCT2 transporter in early post-natal brain cortexK. Salazar 1 , M. A. Garcia 1 , C. Gonzalez 2 and F. Nualart 1 Department of Cellular Biology, Faculty of Biological Sciences, University of Concepcion, Concepcion, CHILE, 2 Physiology Institute, Austral University, Valdivia, CHILE

TABREF287.text: PP8C-37 Characterization of mendo (Antriscus nemorosa) and Mentha species polyphenol oxidase E. Savas 1 , N. Gencer 2 , M. Sayin2  and O. Arslan 2Balikesir University Susurluk Vocational High School, Balikesir, TURKEY 2 Balikesir University Science and Art Faculty, Balikesir, TURKEY Introduction: Polyphenol oxidases (PPO) (EC 1.14.18.1) are very important enzymes in food industry for their involvement in the enzymatic browning of edible plants. Herby cheese, a semi-hard, salty and herb added, is manufactured in small family businesses for their needs and commercial purposes from raw sheep's and cow's milk between May and June in the Eastern and Southeastern of Turkey. A number of herbs such as Allium sp., Thymus sp., Mentha sp., Antriscus sp. and Ferule sp. are used in making herb cheese. Enzymatic browning damages nutritional quality and economic value of herbs and herby cheese. Method: Polyphenol oxidase (PPO) was extracted from mendo (Antriscus nemorosa) andMentha species added into herby cheese on Van region in Turkey. Results: Mentha PPO showed activity to catechol and pregallol (K m values were 25 mM and V max values were 500 EU/ml/minute for catechol; K m values were 2 mM and V max values were 250 EU/ml/minute for pregallol). Mendo PPO activity was lower than Mentha PPO (K m values were 2.5 mM and V max values were 333 EU/ml/minute for catechol; K m values were 0.25 mM and V max values were 55 EU/ml/minute for pregallol). Its characteristics in terms of pH and optimum temperature, thermal inactivation, kinetic parameters were studied. Optimum pH and temperature for Mentha and Mendo PPO were found using catechol as substrate at pH 6.8 and 30°C, respectively. Heat inactivation studies showed temperature >40°C resulted in loss of enzyme activity. Conclusions: Heat process can be used safely in herby cheese production. Thus enzymatic browning could be prevented.M. Kotorma´n, A. Cseri and M. L. Simon Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Biology, Faculty of Science and Informatics, University of Szeged, Szeged, HUNGARY
