TABREF289.text: PP8C-41 Atherosclerosis inhibition and regression can be induced by extracts of olive oil and its respective pomaceN. Tsantila 1 , H. C. Karantonis 2 , D. N. Perrea 3 , D. G. Iliopoulos 3 , S. E. Theocharis 4 , C. Iatrou 5 , S. Antonopoulou 2 and C. A. Demopoulos 1 Faculty of Chemistry, National and Kapodistrian University of Athens, Athens, GREECE, 2 Department of Science of Nutrition-Dietetics, Harokopio University, Athens, GREECE, 3 Laboratory of Experimental Surgery and Surgical Research, School of Medicine, National and Kapodistrian University of Athens, Athens, GREECE, 4 Department of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, School of Medicine, National and Kapodistrian University of Athens, Athens, GREECE, 5 Centre for Nephrology, 'G. Papadakis' General Hospital of Nikea-Pireaus, Athens, GREECE Introduction: Platelet Activating Factor (PAF), a potent inflammatory molecule, is implicated in the initiation and progression of atherosclerosis and its specific inhibitors prevent atherogenesis. PAF inhibitors present in polar lipid extracts of virgin olive oil (OOPL) and olive pomace (PPL) were tested for their in vivo anti-atherogenic action. Methods: For the in vivo studies cholesterol fed rabbits were used. Atherosclerotic damage was assessed by morphometric analysis.Results: Virgin olive oil (VO), OOPL or PPL when added to rabbits' atherogenic diet -at amounts equivalent to their respective IC 50 values -inhibited atherogenesis up to 70%. Additionally, PPL and simvastatin also induced atherosclerosis regression (70% and 52%, respectively) in already formed atherosclerotic lesions. Conclusions: The anti-atherogenic effect of olive oil may be attributed to the presence of PAF antagonists in polar lipids fraction, capable of inducing atherosclerosis regression to an extent comparable to that of simvastatin.

TABREF290.text: Romanian diabetic patients have higher daily cholesterol and less monounsaturated fat diet intake and lower doses for statin prescribed. Correlations between plasma dROM and ceruloplasmin were calculated (r = 0.91 for Belgian group and r = 0.65 for Romanian group, P < 0.05). Intakes of saturated fats and cholesterol correlated positively with dROM (P < 0.05). Conclusion: This study demonstrates that the Belgian diabetic foot management (diet and drugs) gives a better glycemic control, a lower lipid, acute phase proteins and peroxides plasma levels versus Romanian diabetic treatment. These differences are important for wound healing.S. Wada, S. Kokura, Y. Naito and T. Yoshikawa Kyoto Prefectural University of Medicine, Kyoto, JAPAN Inhibition of cyclooxygenase-2 (Cox-2) has been reported as an important strategy for the prevention of various cancers. It is also known that tocotrienol has antiproliferative, antioxidant and pro-apoptotic effects and plays a role in the regulation of mitogenesis. We have investigated the effects of tocotrienol on Cox-2 expression and production of prostaglandin E2 (PGE2) in p53 deficient mouse embryonic fibroblasts (MEFs). MEFs were stimulated with 1 lg/ml of LPS and 100 IU/ml of IFNgamma after pretreatment with or without various concentrations of alpha-, beta-, gamma-and delta-tocotrienol. Expressions of COX-2 protein were analyzed by Western-blotting, concentrations of nitrite were measured by Griess reagent and PGE2 concentrations were measured by ELISA. MEFs treated with tocotrienol showed reduced expression levels of COX-2 proteins, which were induced by LPS and IFN-gamma, compared with non-treated cells. Concentrations of PGE2 in the medium of MEFs, activated by tocotrienol in the presence of LPS and IFNgamma, were lower than those in MEFs without tocotrienol. In addition, nitrite concentrations in the medium of tocotrienol treated MEFs were lower than those in non-treated MEFs. On the other hand, tocotrienols could not affect significantly on the concentration of Vascular endothelial growth factor. The antioxidant effects might be one of the mechanisms of Cox-2 suppressive effect of tocotrienol. The data obtained in the present study suggest that Tocotrienol appears to be an agent for use in cancer prevention.PP8C-44Relationship between serum resistin concentrations and insulin resistance indices in non-diabetic and diabetic obese subjectsG. Zadeh Mohammad 1,2 and N. Zarghami Mohammad 1,2 Nutritional Research Center, Tabriz University of Medical Sciences, Tabriz, IRAN, 2 Department of Clinical Biochemistry and RIA, Drug Applied Research Center, Tabriz University of Medical Sciences, Tabriz, IRANBackground and Aim: Resistin, an adipocyte secreted hormone, has been suggested to link obesity with type 2 diabetes and insulin resistance in rodent models, but its relevance to human diabetes remains uncertain. The aim of this study was to investigate the relationship between serum resistin concentrations with markers of insulin resistance and obesity in type 2 diabetes and non-diabetic obese subjects. Design and Methods: This cross sectional study consisting of 35 obese subjects with type 2 diabetes mellitus and 35 non-diabetics obese subjects. Fasting lipid profile was measured by the enzymatic methods. NycoCard HbA1c system was used to measure HbA1c. The Serum resistin and insulin levels were measured by using commercially available kits. The insulin resistance index was determined by homeostasis model assessment (HOMA-IR).Results: There was no significant difference in resistin levels between non-diabetic and diabetic obese subjects. While, resistin levels in (7.46 ± 0.29 vs. 5.51 ± 0.73 ng/ml) in diabetic women and (8.15 ± 1.01 vs. 5.97 ± 0.57 ng/ml) in non-diabetic were significantly higher than men in both groups. Serum resistin was not significantly related to any variables measured in both groups. In control group only, we observed a significant and negative correlation between diastolic blood pressure and resistin(r = -0.381; P = 0.024). Conclusion: Serum resistin concentrations are reduced in obese patient with type 2 diabetes, but are not associated with insulin resistance or obesity. Resistin links between obesity and diabetes in humans still controversial and needs to further investigation. (DGI-AGL2007-65907) Acyl-CoA synthetase involved in nitrile degradation and its substrate specificity T. Abe, Y. Hashimoto, H. Hosaka, K. Tomita-Yokotani and M. Kobayashi Graduate School of Life and Environmental Sciences, The University of Tsukuba, Tsukuba, JAPAN Introduction: We have extensively studied the biological metabolism of toxic compounds, nitriles. The microbial degradation of nitriles proceeds through two enzymatic pathways: nitrilase catalyzes the direct cleavage of nitriles to yield acids and ammonia; and nitrile hydratase (NHase) catalyzes the hydration of nitriles to amides, which are subsequently hydrolyzed to acids and ammonia by amidase. Recently, we reported an overall 'nitrile pathway' (aldoxime fi nitrile fi amide fi acid fi acyl-CoA) comprising aldoxime dehydratase, NHase, amidase and acyl-CoA synthetase (AcsA) of Pseudomonas chlororaphis B23.

TABREF294.text: PP8-5 Cryogenic effect of fish antifreeze protein (AFP) on one-cell stage transgenic mouse embryos by vitrification H. Bagis, T. Akkoc, S. Aksu and G. Cetinkaya TUBITAK, Marmara Research Center (MRC), Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology Institute (GEBI), Transgenic Core Facility, Kocaeli, TURKEY Antifreeze proteins (AFPs) have been demonstrated to bind to the ice crystals and inhibit ice crystal growth and inhibit ice recrystallization. Transgenic expression of the AFPs is much more elegant way of trying to improve cold tolerance. The purpose of the present study was to evaluate whether cryogenic effect of fish antifreeze protein (AFP) on one-cell stage transgenic mouse vitrified embryos. In this study, AFP transgenic and non-transgenic one-cell stage embryos, AFP and non-transgenic fresh mouse one-cell stage embryos were vitrified with 35% EG, 5% PVP in M2 medium supplemented with 0.4 M trehalose by solid surface vitrification (SSV) techniques. Warming was performed by dropping the vitrified droplets containing 500 ll 0.3 M trehalose solution at RT for 3 minutes. Recovered warmed embryos from each group were rinsed three times in M2, and then cultured to blastocyst stage in SAGE 1-2 medium under mineral oil at 37°C in a humidified atmosphere of 5% CO 2 in air. Results obtained from this study were summarized in table below. Data were analyzed by Chi-square and fisher's exact tests. The highest blastocyst and hatching blastocyst rates were achieved in transgenic vitrification group (80% and 22% for blastocyst and hatching blastocyst after vitrification, respectively), not different from that of the corresponding control groups (75% and 20%, respectively). In conclusion, in this study first time demonstrated that a transgenic mouse carried fish AFP, when expressed in the ovaries of transgenic mice, was effective at protecting the embryo in vitro development after vitrification. The same colon statistical significant (P < 0.001). Characterization of Atcay, the gene mutated in human Cayman type ataxiaT. Aoyama 1 , T. Nakao 1 , S. Hata 1 , C. Koike 2 , R. Sanuki 2 , T. TABREF295.text: G. Kavoosi 1 , S. Kaboudanian Ardestani 1 , A. Kariminia 2 , M. Zeinali 1 and M. H. Alimohammadian 2Institute of Biochemistry and Biophysics, University of Tehran, Tehran, IRAN, 2 Department of Immunology, Pasteur Institute of Iran, Tehran, IRAN Introduction: Protozoan parasites the genus Leishmania secrete a range proteophosphoglycans (PPG) known to be important for successful colonization Leishmania in the sandfly and for virulence in the mammalian host. PPGs are a large family extensively glycosylated proteins with some unusual and unique features. Methods: In this study we purified PPG from culture supernatant L. major metacyclic promastigotes by a combination anion and cation exchange chromatography. The heterogenity PPG was determined using SDS-PAGE and agarose gel electrophoresis. Protein, phosphate and glycan content PPG were measured by usuall analytical methods. Also we evaluate the effect PPG on oxygen species (ROS) and cytokines production by human peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs). Results: In discontinuous SDS-PAGE, PPG could not enter the resolving gel but after mild acid hydrolysis four band resolved. Agarose gel electrophoresis and immunoblot analysis using monoclonal antibody (WIC 79.3) indicated that PPG is a heterogeneous molecule. Compositional analysis showed that PPG preparation contains 67% glycan, 28% protein and 5% phosphate. Also, the effect PPG on ROS production and induction IL-10, IL-12 and IFN-c secretion by PBMCs isolated from healthy individuals was investigated. Water-soluble secreted form PPG at 1 lg glycan/ml seems to be a potent inducer ROS and IL-10 and to a lesser extent IFN-c and IL-12. Cytokines and ROS production was decreased in a dose-dependent manner as the concentration PPG increased to 100 lg glycan/ml. Conclusion: These results showed the ability L. major PPGs to down-regulate cytokine secretion by PBMCs implicating their role as immuno-suppressive surface molecules.PP8-10 Mutagenesis of Iranian firefly luciferase (Lampyris turkestanicus) for improvement of thermostability B. TABREF298.text: PP8-15 Effect of the antioxidant N-acetyl-L-cysteine pretreatment on the apoptotic response of HCT 116 p53 wild type and knockout colon carcinoma cell lines by preventing protein modifications caused by oxidative stress due to cisplatin treatment Y. O. Ateş , T. Tezil and H. Baş ag˘a Faculty of Engineering and Natural Sciences, Biological Sciences and Bioengineering Program, Sabanci University, Istanbul, TURKEY Introduction: The mechanism of action of the anticancer drug cisplatin (CDDP) has been elucidated presenting the importance of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in the induction of apoptosis. To investigate further on this phenomenon we added the antioxidant N-acetyl-L-cysteine (NAC) into the equation as NAC would act as an ROS scavenger. We used the p53 wild type (wt) and knockout (-/-) phenotypes of HCT116 as the protein p53 helps conserving the stability of the genome. Methods: To evaluate cell viability MTT Assay, for examining apoptotic cell death flow cytometric analyses by Annexin V staining, for cellular oxidative stress evaluation TBARS lipid peroxidation method and DCF staining both fluorometrically and flow cytometrically, for detect-ing carbonylation of proteins due to oxidative stress OxyBlot Western Blotting Assay have been performed on HCT 116 p53 wt and knockout cell lines with or without NAC pre-treatment as with varying concentrations of CDDP at different time points. Results:Conclusions: We suggest the decrease in the apoptotic response due to NAC pre-treatment indicates the significance of ROS induction by CDDP due to DNA damage and loss of function by carbonylation of anti-apoptotic proteins as a result of protein oxidation caused by ROS.H. K. Aynaci and A. SenDepartment of Biology, Faculty of Arts & Sciences, Pamukkale University, Denizli, TURKEY Cytochrome P4502C9 is one of the most important drug metabolizing enzymes and the rationalization and prediction of potential CYP2C9 substrates is therefore advantageous in the discovery and development of new drugs. 7-Methoxy-4-trifluoromethyl coumarin (MFC) was reported as novel and selective CYP2C9 substrate suitable for highthroughput screening. In this study, the selectivity of MFC for CYP2C9 was characterized in rat liver microsomes by monitoring the formation of metabolic product HFC using fluorescence spectroscope, Ex 390 nm and Em 502 nm wavelengths. Average methoxy-4-trifluoromethyl coumarin o-demethylase (MFCOD) activity of rat hepatic microsomes was found to be 0.122 nmol/min/mg protein. Apparent V max and K m values fish liver MFCOD using Lineweaver-Burk graph are calculated 0.218 nmol/min/mg protein and 0.96 lM, respectively. Furthermore, studies were carried out to determine the effects of various reaction conditions such as incubation time, enzyme content, pH and temperature on MFCOD of rat liver microsomes. It is ascertained that the enzyme activity was lineer until 200 lg microsomal protein amount throughout 75 minutes incubation at optimum pH and temperature; 7.5 and 30°C respectively. Immunochemical studies using anti-rat CYP2C IgG and in vitro inhibition studies using sulfaphenazole, quinidine, alpha-naphthoflavone and cimetidine are underway to further characterize the selectivity of the MFC. Nevertheless, results have shown that this assay can be used to measure CYP2C activity in this and other species.A. M. P. Lima 2 , M. A. Cerqueira 1 , B. W. S. Souza 1 , A. A. Vicente 1 , J. A. TABREF299.text: E. C. M. Santos 2 , A. C. O. Monteiro-Moreira 3 , M. J. S. Gallagher 1 and R. A. TABREF300.text: D. Badiu 1 , F. Roncea 2 and N. Roş oiu3    Faculty of Natural and Agricultural Sciences, 'Ovidius' University of Constanza, Constanza, ROMANIA, 2 Faculty of Pharmacy, 'Ovidius' University of Constanza, Constanza, ROMANIA,3  Medicine Faculty of Medicine, 'Ovidius' University of Constanza, Constanza, ROMANIAThe experiments effectuated in this paper has lead to obtained of six salves in two qualitative categories heaving like bioactive compounds the lipid extracts from Mytilus galloprovincialis Lmk., Rapana venosa molluscs and those mixed (1:1, v/v). The first category on simple salves have been constituted from: 4% lipid extracts (bioactive compounds), 10% lanoline, 1% Oleum lavandule and 85% vaseline. The second category of salves has different constituents excepting the bioactive compounds and Oleum lavandule: 4% cethylic alcohol, 2% white wax, 14% lanoline, 3% stearyc acid and 72% castor-oil. The purpose of this study regards the formulation and control evaluation over 90 days observation period of the six salves with lipid extracts from two molluscs which was consisted from: aspect, color, homogeneity, smell, pH, tension, the penetration method (consistence) and elongation capacity. The results at the final observation period has aloud us to see a difference from the two qualitative salves at consistence parameter which in simple salves are not frame in Reg CEE 796/2002 limits, differences which may be adapted through replacing of one or others ingredients from salves base. In addition, the bioactive compounds from marine mussels represent a source of new nutraceutical products, the exploitation of which is likely to lead to the discovery of new drugs and targets.PP8-20Evidence for antimetastatic action of coenzyme Q10 and GSH on a breast cancer cell lineM. Bahar 1 , S. Khaghani 1 , P. Pasalar 1 , M. Paknejad 1 , M. Eidi 2 , N. Ghannadian 1 , M. Baratchian 1 and H. Eftekhari 3 1 Tehran University of Medical, Tehran, IRAN, 2 Varamin Unit Azad University, Tehran, IRAN, 3 Baharafshan Istitute of Research and Development, Baharafshan, IRAN Introduction: To experimentally study the effect of dosage and co-incubation time of anti and pro-oxidant substances, we chose Matrix Metalloproteinase-2 activity as it is a widely accepted criterion of metastatic transformation. The overall goal was to study the effect of redox promoting agent on the tumor invasiveness from a single approach. Materials and Methods: MCF-7 was incubated with 1x, 0.5x and 0.25x of 122 lM coenzyme Q 10 , 2 mM N-acetyl cysteine and 20 lM Buthionine Sulfoximine on 6, 15, 24 and 48 hour manner. Integrity and H 2 O 2 content of cells were measured by DCFH-DA with FACS, and the released MMP-2 activity was measured by Gelatin Zymography and analyzed.Results: Large negative correlations were observed between NAC dose and intracellular H 2 O 2 . Furthermore, a large positive correlation was observed between BSO and intracellular H 2 O 2 and MMP-2 activity merely in the 6 hour co-incubation. In the case of CoQ 10 , large negative correlations were observed in almost all thesamples between CoQ 10 dose and intracellular H 2 O 2 quantity and MMP-2 activity (n = 4, p < 0.05). Conclusion: As it has been outlined in previous studies, NAC has the ability to inhibit the oxidation of zinc-cysteine band by annihilating the oxidative agents as a scavenging antioxidant. Our finding of BSO elevating the pro-oxidants status of the cell meets with the previous observations. Nevertheless, we found this phenomenon parallel to MMP-2 activity increase. The MMP-2 response to the CoQ 10 might indicate a strong congruity between CoQ 10 dose and MMP-2 activity mitigation which would itself necessitates more practical approaches to conclude a clinical effective anti-metastatic property for CoQ 10 therapeutic regimen.L. P. Moro 1 , M. T. Murakami 1 , H. Cabral 2 , A. Vidotto 3 , E. H. Tajara 3 , R. K. Arni 1 , L. Juliano 4 and G. O. Bonilla-Rodriguez 1 IBILCE-UNESP, Sa˜o Jose´do Rio Preto, BRAZIL, 2 USP, Ribeira˜o Preto, BRAZIL, 3 FAMERP, Sa˜o Jose´do Rio Preto, BRAZIL, UNIFESP, Sa˜o Paulo, BRAZIL Introduction: The latex from Euphorbia milii displays biologically and medicinally important applications such as potent molluscicide and a promising compound for treatment of parasitic tapeworm infections in alternative to the classic niclosamide.

TABREF301.text: Financial Support: CAPES (LPM), CNPq and FAPESP (GOBR). P. Peres Polizelli, B. M. Bonine, F. D. A. Facchini and G.O. Bonilla-Rodriguez IBILCE-UNESP, State University of Sao Paulo, Sao Jose do Rio Preto, SP, BRAZILIntroduction: Lipases catalyze the hydrolysis of carboxyl ester bonds present in oils and fats, being of great interest for different industrial applications. Immobilization is a useful technique for improving enzyme activity in reusability, possibility of continuous process, rapid termination of reactions, controlled product formation and easy enzyme removal from the reaction mixture. Materials and Methods: A lipase was purified from oleaginous seeds of Pachira aquatica (Peres-Polizelli et al. App. Biochem. Biotech., 2008, In press). Lipolytic activity was estimated by spectrophotometry using p-nitrophenyl palmitate as substrate and by alkali titration using soybean oil. The assay was performed for 90 minutes at 37°C. Alginate beads were prepared by ionic gelation using CaCl 2 as the cross-linking agent. Results: The lipase has 55 kDa, exhibiting highest activity at 40°C and pH 8.0. The activity increased in the presence of Ca ++ and Mg ++ , being inhibited by Hg ++ , Mn ++ , Zn ++ and Al +++ . The hydrolysis rate for nitrophenylesters was: myristate > caprate > palmitate > stearate > butyrate >acetate. The immobilized enzyme was more stable than the free one, and used up to six times without loss of enzyme activity. Conclusions: The isolated lipase could be used for different purposes, and the time dependent natural loss of activity can be significantly prevented by immobilization.Financial support: CAPES (PPP), FAPESP and CNPq (GOBR). the university and the public school N. R. S. Bossolan, L. M. Beltramini, M. R. G. Oliveira and T. H. G. Oliveira Instituto de Fisica de Sa˜o Carlos/Universidade de Sa˜o Paulo, Sa˜o Carlos, SP, BRAZILIntroduction: The teachers' professional and continuous development, promoted by Universities, can decrease the distance between the scientific-technological progress and your implications to the society, and reduce the cultural and social gaps that is observed in development countries. We intend to show how a course on molecular biology and biotechnology, addressed to elementary and high school teachers, can stimulate the search for the scientific and pedagogic knowledge's as well as and the importance of approximation between university and public school. Methods: A 32-hour course was offered to 53 science teachers from public schools of Sa˜o Paulo State. Strategies such as educational games, activities with plastic models in the construction of molecules, interaction with educational software, and laboratory classes were used. Data were collected by means of notes, filming in video and written answers to questions. Results: Results showed that the main goal of the participants was the search for the scientific and pedagogical knowledge, aiming at their professional development and for appropriate methods for the didactic transposition of these subjects, emphasizing the importance of the problematization in the use of educational resources. Teachers also emphasized the importance of the rapprochement with the university, which made them to feel encouraged to continue their studies at graduate level.Conclusions: The impact of the course on their professional and personal development was positive in the sense of having stimulating the search for new knowledge and to make possible the transposition into the classroom, particularly in areas involving the use of biotechnologies of social impact. Acknowledgement: Supported by Brazilian Agencies: FAPESP, CNPq. PP8-28 Link between ageing and mitochondrial DNA variation in the Latvian population A. Brakmanis 1,2 , A. Krumina 2 , L. Pliss 1 and V. Baumanis 1 Latvian Biomedical Research and Study Centre, Riga, LATVIA, 2 Riga Stradins University, Riga, LATVIAIntroduction: There is increasing evidence that some mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) polymorphisms are involved in ageing due to influence on the efficiency of oxidative phosphorylation. mtDNA haplogroup J has been reported to increase the individual chance to attain longevity in northern Italians and Finns, haplogroup K -in French and Irish. The aims of our research were: to verify if there is a link between mtDNA polymorphisms and ageing in Latvian population; to compare the level of heteroplasmy in mtDNA control region in three age groups. Methods: Objects for mtDNA polymorphisms analysis were 351 healthy unrelated Latvians 18-40 years old, 98 aged 74-89 years and 74 aged above 90 years. mtDNA haplogroups and point mutations were determined by PCR-RFLP analysis and direct DNA sequencing. Objects for heteroplasmy detection were 100 unrelated Latvians: 40 ranging in age from 18 to 40 years, 30 from 74 to 89 years and 30 above 90 years. In order to detect heteroplasmy the DGGE analysis was used. Results: The frequencies of haplogroups I and U4 were significantly lower, but that of haplogroup U5a significantly higher in the older age group (74-89 years) than in younger individuals. In the youngest age group point heteroplasmy was detected in six individuals (15%) at two positions, among individuals above 90 years old in eight cases (26, 6%) at six different positions. Conclusions: Our results support the hypothesis that certain inherited mtDNA polymorphisms may promote longevity. The mtDNA heteroplasmy level gradually increases with age, besides more heteroplasmic positions in the older age group were revealed.C. Camargo 1 , R. A. Silva 1 , C. L. Yano 1 , R. R. R. Sousa 1 , M. C. C. Gomes-Marcondes 2 , M E. F. da Silva 1 and H. Aoyama 1 Department of Biochemistry, Institute of Biology, State University of Campinas (UNICAMP), Sa˜o Paulo, BRAZIL, 2 Department of Physiology and Biophysics, Institute of Biology, UNICAMP, Sa˜o Paulo, BRAZILIntroduction: Quercetin is a flavonoid widely used as an antioxidant and recent studies have revealed its pleiotropic anticancer and antiproliferative properties. The Walker 256 carcinosarcoma (W256) presents an aggressive biological behavior, local invasive growth and high metastasis potential. The matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) are a class of proteinases capable of extracellular matrix degradation. Increased MMP-2 activity is associated with advanced tumor stages. In this work, we described an in vivo therapeutic treatment with quercetin on rats bearing W256. Methods: Rats bearing W256 were treated with different daily doses (10, 15, 25 and 35 mg/kg) of quercetin i.p., for 50 days. Rats and tumors weights were assessed three times a week. Survival and dose response (ED 50 ) were also determined. MMP-2 activity was assayed in liver extracts using gelatin zymography. Results: The quercetin dose of 10 mg/kg inhibited about 50% tumors growth (ED 50 ) in comparison with control animals (CTR). Rats bearing W256 treated with this quercetin dose showed that the MMP-2 activity decreased 0.67-fold (p < 0.001) in comparison with CTR. Conclusion: According to our results the inhibition of tumors growth observed through the tumors weight, survival and reduction of MMP-2 activity in treated animals strongly confirm the anticancer function of quercetin as a chemotherapeutic agent. Acknowledgement: Financial Support: CAPES, CNPq and FAPESP.PP8-30Biochemical characterization of protease activity in Aelia rostrataR. Campo-Guijarro 1 , F. Ortego 2 and M. Hernandez 1 Instituto Tecnologico Agrario de Castilla Y Leo´n, Laboratorio de Biologia Molecular, Valladolid, SPAIN, 2 Centro de Investigaciones Biolo´gicas, CSIC, Madrid, SPAIN

TABREF302.text: M. Can 1 , E. MacKinnon 2 , A. G. Mungan 1 , B. Akduman3  , A. Mungan 3 and B. Holub 2Karaelmas University, Zonguldat, TURKEY, 2 Guelph University, Guelph, ON, CANADA,3  Karaelmas University, Zonguldat, TURKEY Introduction: The aim of this study was to evaluate the fatty acid compositions of the serum phospholipid from men with prostate cancer and benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). Methods: Forty four volunteers with prostate cancer (age 69.9 ± 9.0 years) and seventy nine volunteers with BPH (age 67.2 ± 9.4 years) were included in this study and compared with thirty three volunteers without any prostate disease complaint (65.3 ± 10.1 years). Total and free PSA measurements were quantitated with solid phase chemiluminescent method on Immulite 2000 (Diagnostic Products Corporation). Lipids were extracted from serum samples and the serum phospholipids were separated from the neutral lipids by thin layer chromatography. The fatty acid methyl esters were analyzed on a Varian 3800 gas-liquid chromatograph (Palo Alto, CA) with a capillary column. Results: Interestingly, only two fatty acids in the cancer group showed statistically significant differences from controls; myristoleic acid (14:1) being higher and eicosatrienoic acid within the omega-3 fatty acid family (20:3 n-3) being lower. However, only the myristoleic acid was significantly higher than both controls and the BPH group, respectively. Conclusions: The higher myristoleic acid status in patients with prostate cancer could possibly serve in a compensatory and protective capacity or at a promontory manner at the level at the cellular level with respect to prostatic carcinogenesis. More extensive studies are needed to determine if dietary and/or blood levels of myristoleic acid, when measured in the future, show correlations with prostate cancer.M. Can 1 , S. Acikgoz 1 , G. Mungan 1 , E. Ugurbas 1 , H. Ankarali 2 , V. Sumbuloglu 2 , S. Demitras 3 and L. Karaca 3Karaelmas University, Zonguldat, TURKEY, 2 Karaelmas University, Zonguldat, TURKEY, 3 Ufuk University, Ankara, TURKEY Introduction: The aim of this study was to compare the Friedewald formula with direct homogeneous low density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) assay for the detection of LDL-C levels. Methods: Fasting serum samples were obtained for lipid analysis from 1001 patients. Total cholesterol (TC) and triglyceride (TG) levels were measured with enzymatic methods and the measurements of high density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C) and LDL-C levels were detected using direct methods. Results: The mean levels of serum TC, TG, HDL-C and LDL-C were detected within the normal reference range. The LDL-C estimated by the Friedewald formula was significantly correlated (P < 0.01) with the direct method but there was a negative bias among them. When evaluating the results according to the different levels of triglycerides, a positive bias observed with direct method, although the method has excellent correlation coefficient (P < 0.01). Conclusions: Laboratories can not use direct method as a substitute for Friedewald formula because direct method has not been standardized in large populations and increase cholesterol assay costs.Conclusion: In our study 5'NT ve ADA enzyme activities are determined high level in both CCL4 and SC groups. Using of 5' metilthioadenosine prevents CC l 4 induced lipid peroxidation and fibrosis(Simile  et al., 2001). In CC l 4 group, high level 5¢NT ADA enzyme activities have not protective about adenosine level Stobadine using didn't affect enzymatic regulation of adenosine metabolism and antioxidant effect. Thus, relationship between purine metabolism and CCl 4 toxicity need to be investigated by doing more studies.PP8-34Myospryn A desmin associated TRIM-like protein is essential for early zebrafish cardiac developmentA. Kouloumenta, M. Mavroidis, D. Beis and Y. TABREF305.text: A. H. Chaves Neto 1 , K. C. De Souza Queiroz 1 , M. P. Peppelenbosch 2 and C. V. Ferreira 1 Department of Biochemistry, State University of Campinas, Sao Paulo, BRAZIL, 2 Department of Cell Biology, University Medical Center Groningen, Groningen, THE NETHERLANDS Introduction: Regulation of protein kinases activities is crucial in the osteoblastic differentiation and may offer a promising way to define novel treatment strategies and prognosis of bone diseases. Murine preosteoblastic cells (MC3T3-E1 cell line) express an osteoblast phenotype providing an excellent in vitro model of bone development. Novel developed arrays containing consensus substrates for kinases are used to assess those kinase activities. Methods: We evaluated the in vitro phosphorylation of peptide arrays exhibiting the majority of PhosphoBase-deposited protein sequences on lysates from pre-osteoblastic cultured with ascorbic acid and beta-glycerol phosphate (traditional osteogenesis inductors) for 7 days. Some kinases which displayed differential activities were validated by Western blot technique. The synthesis of collagen type I, alkaline phosphatase activity and bone markers expression (osteocalcin, osteopontin and Runx2) were also examined to confirm the osteoblastic differentiation process. Results: Among the activated kinases identified, mitogen-activated protein kinase, PI3K and AKT were significantly altered. The up or downregulated expressed kinases covered a broad range of functional activities: (1) cellular communication and signal transduction; (2) nucleic acid synthesis and processing; (3) Cellular organization; (4) Storage and transport; (5) Energy and metabolism; (6) Protein synthesis processing and protein fate. Conclusions: These data show that kinome profiling using arrays of consensus peptides might have a broad application for understanding the molecular mechanism underlying osteoblastic differentiation. Besides, this technique could contribute for more accurate diagnosis, effective disease monitoring, and development of targeted and specific therapies of bone diseases.PP8-38Significance of the conserved Asn345 and Asn435 residues in the catalytic activity of Bacillus kaustophilus leucine aminopeptidase as evaluated by site-directed mutagenesisM.-C. Chi 1,2 , H. Huang 2 and L.-L. Lin 3 Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, National Chung Cheng University, Chiayi, TAIWAN, 2 Department of Life Sciences and Institute of Molecular Biology, National Chung Cheng University, Chiayi, TAIWAN, 3 Department of Applied Chemistry, National Chiayi University, Chiayi, TAIWANIntroduction: Leucine aminopeptidase (LAP; EC 3.4.11.1) is a cytosolic exopeptidase that selectively removes N-terminal amino acid residues from peptides and proteins. In this study, directed evolution strategy was pursued to characterize the role of Asn345 and Asn435 residues situated in the vicinity of the putative active-site residues of Bacillus kaustophilus LAP (BkLAP). Methods: The experimental procedures include site-directed mutagenesis, homology modeling, protein expression, metal analysis, tryptophan emission fluorescence, and circular dichroism. Results: We investigated the role of the conserved Asn345 and Asn435 residues by performing computer modeling and site-directed mutagenesis. Based on the modeling, these two residues interact with the carbonyl group of Ala348, where these interactions might maintain the zinc-coordinated residues at their correct positions. Replacement of Ala345 with Gln or Leu resulted in a dramatic reduction in LAP activity. A complete loss of the activity was observed in Asn435 variants. Measurement of intrinsic tryptophan fluorescence revealed alteration of the microenvironment of aromatic amino acid residues, while circular dichroism spectra were nearly identical for wild-type and all mutant enzymes. Conclusions: In conclusion, site-directed mutagenesis results provide the definitive evidence that residues Asn345 and Asn435 are crucial for the proper function of BkLAP. Protein modeling suggests that these two residues might play an important role in the maintenance of zinccoordinated environment of the enzyme. TEGT resulted in reduced apoptosis in vitro and impaired developmental process in vivoJ.-H. Kim, E.-R. Lee, J.-Y. Kim, H.-Y. Choi, B.-W. Kim, S.-W. Kim and S.-G. Cho Department of Animal Biotechnology and Bio/Molecular Informatics Center, Konkuk University, Seoul, Korea

TABREF306.text: M. K. Das 1 , R. S. Sharma 1 , M. Sardesai 2 , S. R. Yadav 3 and V. Mishra 1 Centre for Environmetal Management of Degraded Ecosystems (CEMDE), University of Delhi, Delhi, INDIA, 2 Abasaheb Garware College, Pune University, Maharashtra, INDIA, 3 Department of Botany, Shivaji University, Kolhapur, Maharashtra, INDIAIntroduction: The enzyme peroxidases have tremendous potential application in environmental and industrial biotechnologies. Evaluation of wild plant from stress environments may lead to identification of novel peroxidases. Evergreen parasitic plants are continuously exposed to a wide range of abiotic and biotic stresses. To prospect these bioresource field surveys of Western Ghats region were carried out and individuals of different species of mistletoe were collected. Methods: Total protein was extracted and fractionated by salting out. Different salt saturated protein fractions were subjected to gel-based peroxidase assay. Distinct activity was detected in one mistletoe species. The fraction showing peroxidase activity was subjected to ionexchange chromatography (DEAE-Sephadex A50). LCMS-MS analyses of the purified peroxidase was carried out. Results: Under reducing and non-reducing conditions, the SDS-PAGE profile showed a distinct 60 kDa band, however, plant peroxidases belong to class III family which is characterized with 28-44 kDa molecular mass. Staining with periodic acid-schiff's reagent confirmed its glycoproteinaceous nature. It showed excellent peroxidase activity with different substrates. LCMS-MS analyses showed its low homology with the other known plant peroxidases Conclusion: The 60 kDa peroxidase purified and characterized in the present study is novel. Its detailed characterization may help to establish potential use of a wild parasitic plant of Western Ghats. The purified peroxidase might have significance in environmental protection and development of industrial products.

Hianik 1 Comenius University, Bratislava, SLOVAKIA, 2 UPJS, Kosice, SLOVA-KIA,3  Institute of Experimental Physics SAS, Kosice, SLOVAKIA Introduction: DNA or RNA aptamers are synthetic, single-stranded oligonucleotides that fold up into unique three-dimensional structures,

TABREF316.text: Department of Biochemistry, College of Oriental Medicine, Kyung Hee University, Seoul, KOREA, 2 HelixPharms Co., Ltd., Seoul, KOREA, Department of Prescriptionology, College of Oriental Medicine, Kyung Hee University, Seoul, KOREA, 4 Department of Medical History, College of Oriental Medicine, Kyung Hee University, Seoul, KOREA, Department of Anatomy, College of Oriental Medicine, Kyung Hee University, Seoul, KOREA Polyphosphate kinase (PPK) is an enzyme that can catalyze the reversible transfer of the terminal phosphate of ATP to form a long-chain polyphosphate (polyP). We have recently shown that the open reading frame Rv2984 of the Mycobacterium tuberculosis H37Rv (Mtb) genome sequence encodes a functional polyphosphate kinase (PPK1 Mtb). In this study, we further characterized purified PPK1 Mtb for its substrates as well as functional domains responsible for enzyme activity. To the end, we synthesized polyP in vitro from ATP, GTP, or ADP as a substrate. Also, a set of deleted version of PPK1 Mtb was constructed and tested their enzymatic activity. Our results showed that PPK1 Mtb was able to use all three nucleotides as a substrate and the C-terminal 150 amino acids were important for the enzyme activity. Taken together these results indicate that PPK1 Mtb is a muti-functional enzyme.D. Iwanaga, M. Tanaka, R. Nagasaka and H. Ushio Tokyo University of Marine Science and Technology, Tokyo, JAPAN

Mustafaeva Bioengineering Department, Yildiz Technical University, Istanbul, TURKEY Introduction: In this study, as a model carrier polymer system the synthesis a biodegradable polyelctrolyte, poly(1-azabicyclo[4.2.0]octane), (PC), which has an heteroatom in its structure is explained. For obtaining PC, synthesis the monomer, 1-azabicyclo[4.2.0]octane, (C), was carried out by organic methods which then will be used in polymer synthesis (Lavagnino et al. J. Amer. Chem. Soc. 1960; 82: 2609).Methods: Polymers having different molecular weights were synthesized by cationic ring-opening polymerization and the characterization polymers were done by different methods such as UV and ATR FT-IR spectroscopy, GPC with four detectors and Zeta-Sizer. PC was treated with bromoacetic acid and obtained a water soluble polyampholyte which can be used a carrier for peptides, proteins and other biological molecules. Sadjadi Neuroscience Research Center, Shaheed Beheshti Medical Science University, Tehran, IRAN 2A protease the coxsackievirus B 3 virus is a major enzyme involved in the etiology heart disease and an attractive drug target. Despite this obvious importance, this enzyme remains poorly characterized at the structural level. The present communication deals with the prediction 3-dimentional structure 2A protease based on sequence homology with human rhinovirus 2A protease. Comparison the 3-dimentional structures reveals a remarkable similarity having a conserved domain in the core region, but they have different conformations at certain regions.

TABREF332.text: PP8-129 Soluble matrixmetalloproteinases quantification in leg ulcer fluid from chronic venous insufficiency M. Neagu 1 , G. Manda 1 , C. Constantin 1 , I. Neagoe 1 , L. Albulescu 1 , C. Tanase 1 , E. Codorean 1 , D. Boda 2 and S. M. Popescu 2 Victor Babes National Institute, Bucharest, ROMANIA, 2 Colentina Clinical Hospital, Bucharest, ROMANIA Introduction: Chronic venous insufficiency (CVI) is a common invalidating disease where the blood stasis is often associated with ischemia and inflammatory mediators that actively contribute to local inflammatory degradative pattern maintenance. The purpose of our study was to quantify soluble matrixmetalloproteinases (MMPs) associated to leg ulcer wound fluid in comparison with the tissue localized ones and evaluate their disease prognosis potential. Methods: Sterile fluid was harvested during surgery and a procedure was established for obtaining a completely clear sample. Soluble MMPs detection used Luminex IS 200 System and xMAP technology (Fluorokine_ MAP multiplex kit Human MMP) for the following soluble MMPs: 1, 2, 3, 7, 8, 9, 12 and 13. Soluble TIMP-1 was as well detected by means of ELISA using Quantikine Human TIMP-1 Immunoassay. Electrophoregram of the fluid samples was performed using Experion electrophoretic microfluidics system. Results: Due to the individual protein pattern of the harvested fluids, specific MMP or inhibitor activities were related to the total protein concentration of each fluid sample. Comparing the values obtained from normal sera (at the same protein concentration) in the CVI fluids MMP9 values are 4x more elevated, MMP2 2x and MMP1 19x, while their inhibitor TIMP1 is 200x reduced. The studied patients did not present any abnormal seric values of MMPs and TIMP1. Conclusion: Various patterns of soluble MMPs and TIMP-1 were associated with the disease progression, but overall a higher MMPs value and lower TIMP1 indicated a poor healing score in CVI. Chronic venous insufficieny is a common invalidating disease and evaluation of soluble matrixmetalloproteinases pattern in the leg ulcer fluid can be a valuable biomarker associated with disease progression.PP8-133Analysis of polysaccharide from Bifidobacterium G. Bambai 3 Virology Department, Iran University of Medical Sciences, Tehran, IRAN, 2 Razi Vaccine and Serum Research Institute, Karaj, IRAN, National Institute of Genetic Engineering and Biotechnology, Tehran, IRANIntroduction: Measles is a highly contagious disease and one of the major cause of childhood mortality in developing countries. Despite the widespread use of live attenuated vaccine since 1963, it still causes approximately one half million death in the world, annually. Measles Virus has two envelope glycoproteins: The H protein which has a key role in tropism, receptor binding, hemagglutinating activity and the F protein which. is responsible for the membrane fusion, and spreading the infection in the body. Both proteins can induce immune system to produce neutralizing antibody against virus. In this regard they can be used for combined recombinant vaccine production. In this study the gateway baculovirus insect cell expression system has been used as a means of expressing measles H and F genes. Methods: Measles Virus (AIK-C strain) genome was extracted from infected Vero cells. Then, H and F gene were amplified by specific primers during RT-PCR reaction and inserted into the intermediate vector (pDONR221) using BP recombination reaction. Recombinant baculovirus harboring H and F genes were consequently constructed by LR reaction, prepared by BaculoDirect TM Expression System kit. In next step, insect cells (Sf9) were infected with recombinant baculovirus In order to increase viral titer, recombinant baculoviruses were passaged four times in Sf9 cells. Synthesis of H and F proteins were verified by SDS-PAGE, western-blot and indirect immunoflourescene using goat polyclonal antibody against Measles Virus. Results and Conclusion: The H and F proteins were partially glycosylated and cleaved respectively, but it appeared that both of them were biologically active. Antibody against these recombinant proteins can neutralized virus infection in cell culture.PP8-165The effect of pre-conditionary hepatic ischemia on intestinal ischemia/reperfusion injuryI. C. back_matter.text: Human and animal studies have demonstrated that procyanidin-rich diets reduce the risk of cardiovascular diseases and atherosclerosis. Some beneficial effects have been attributed to the wellknown antioxidant activity of procyanidins. In this study, we investigated another potential role of procyanidins in cholesterol influx and efflux and inflammation in macrophage-derived foam cells. Methods and Results: We cultured RAW 264.7 macrophages with highly oxidized LDL (oxLDL), moderately oxidized LDL (moxLDL) or with LPS (0.5 lg/ml) and oxLDL (LPS + oxLDL) to induce foam cell. Then, cells were treated with procyanidins derived from grape seed (PE, 45 lg/ml) for the last 12 hours of incubation with the different lipoproteins (25 lg/ml). After lipid extraction, we determined that total and esterified cholesterol and triglyceride accumulation in foam cells were increased by lipoprotein treatment but reduced by PE incubation in all the foam-cell models. In order to asses the effect of PE on gene expression we determined the relative mRNA levels of CD36, ABCA1, iNOS and IkBa by RT-PCR. We show that PE reduced the oxLDL scavenger receptor expression (CD36), and enhanced ABCA1 (ATP-binding cassette A1) expression, a key regulator of macrophage cholesterol efflux, thus reducing lipid influx and inducing its efflux. PE also downregulated inflammatory related genes such as iNOS (inducible nitric oxide synthase) and IkBa (kappa beta inhibitor-alpha). Conclusion: We provide evidence that procyanidins may attenuate the development of foam cell formation by reducing cholesterol accumulation through the modulation of key genes in cholesterol flux and inflammation. Introduction: According to the data of WHO, in 1990 the percentage of infertile families reached 20%, and in 50% the infertility is connected with men's reproductive ability. Decrease in concentration and motility of sperm is observed in the world. Therefore, investigation of factors affecting the sperm motility is relevant. Methods: Sperm motility was determined using Gorjaev's chamber and expressed as the percentage of the motile sperms relative to the total number of sperms. Results: It was shown that oxidants (hydrogen peroxide, hydroxyl radicals and superoxide anions) decreased significantly (by 50-100%) the sperm motility. The sperm-specific isoform of glyceraldehyde-3phosphate dehydrogenase (GAPDs) was inactivated in the sperms treated with oxidants. It is suggested that oxidants decrease the sperm motility due to the oxidation of the sulfhydryl groups of GAPDs, a key glycolytic enzyme that is necessary for sperm motility. Interestingly, sodium citrate (pH 7.5) above 30 mM decreased the sperm motility by 90-100% after 5 minutes of incubation. The mechanism remains unclear. Significant increase in the sperm motility (by 20-35%) was observed in the presence of calcium ions. Conclusion: The sperm motility was shown to decrease in the presence of oxidants and sodium citrate and to increase in the presence of calcium ions. Oxidants decrease the sperm motility due to the oxidation of the sulfhydryl groups of GAPDs, a key glycolytic enzyme. The role of citrate and calcium is discussed. Acknowledgements: The work was supported by the RFBR (grant no. 06-04-48240) and NATO (PDD(CP)-(CBP.NR.RIG 982779)).

We have extensively studied the biological metabolism of toxic compounds, nitriles (1). Recently, we reported an overall 'nitrile pathway' (aldoxime -> nitrile -> amide -> acid -> acyl-CoA) comprising aldoxime dehydratase, NHase, amidase and acyl-CoA synthetase (AcsA) of Pseudomonas chlororaphis B23 (2). AcsA forms a carbon-sulfur bond in the presence of ATP and Mg 2+ , yielding acyl-CoA thioesters from the corresponding free acids and CoA. Very recently, we discovered amide (peptide) bond synthetic activity of AcsA. When L-cysteine was used as a substrate instead of CoA, N-acyl-L-cysteine was detected as a reaction product. Results: Acyl-CoA synthetase belongs to the superfamily of adenylateforming enzymes, whose three-dimensional structures are analogous to one another. We confirmed that amide (peptide) bond synthetic activity was also observed for acetyl-CoA synthetase from Saccharomyces cerevisiae which belongs to the superfamily. These results indicate that acetyl-CoA synthetase and acyl-CoA synthetase from not only prokaryotes but also eukaryotes would exhibit N-acylation activity generally. Luciferase also belongs to the superfamily, although the enzyme catalyzes the oxidation of luciferin in the presence of ATP and O 2 to generate oxyluciferin and light (hm). We found that firefly (Photinus pyralis) luciferase catalyzes the N-acyl-L-cysteine synthetic reaction (amide bond synthesis). These findings indicate the generality of the new reaction in the superfamily of adenylate-forming enzymes.

The effects of oxidative stress on the expression of PAI-1, tPA, uPA and uPAR in vascular endothelial cells Plasminogen activator inhibitor type-1 (PAI-1) is the primary inhibitor of tissue-type and urokinase-type plasminogen activators and play integral role in the control of the fibrinolytic system. High plasma PAI-1 level is a risk factor for thrombotic diseases such as myocardial infraction, stroke, and venous thromboembolism. PAI-1 is an early response gene known to be activated by hormones, cytokines, lipoprotein, angiotensin II, phorbol ester, and reactive oxygen species (ROS). The purpose of the present study was to establish whether or not an enhanced oxidative stress involving endothelial injury, activation of coagulation, and inflammatory reaction would induce an expression of PAI-1, t-PA, uPA or uPAR. Human endothelial cells were treated with hydrogen peroxide (100, 200 lM), sodium nitroprusside (1-100 lM) and oxidative stress were determined by lucigenin chemiluminescence and 2,7, dichlorofluorescein (DCF) fluorescence, respectively. PAI-1, tPA, uPA and uPAR transcription were determined by transfection of PAI-1, t-PA, uPA and uPAR promoter linked to a luciferase reporter. Ap1, Sp1 and NF and #954; B activity was determined by an electrophoresis mobility shift assay. Expression of PAI-1, t-PA, uPA and uPAR in vascular endothelial cells studied using microarray assay and confirmed by real time PCR.Introduction: Thromboxane A2 induces platelet aggregation and constriction of vascular and bronchial smooth muscle through the interaction with a G protein-coupled receptor that exists as two alternatively splice variants, termed TPa and TPb with different C-terminal cytoplasmic tails. TPa and TPb are usually co-expressed in native cells and form homo-and hetero-oligomers in transfected cells. Methods: Computational modelling techniques [1, 2] were first used to generate models of TPa monomer in free-and agonist-bound conformations, then subjected to docking simulations for modelling of TPa homo-dimers. Theoretical predictions were challenged by sitedirected mutagenesis of TPa and TPb. Wild type and mutant receptors fused to fluorescent proteins (GFP, CFP, YFP) were transiently expressed in HEK293 cells and their subcellular localization and dimerization studied by a combination of microscopy and fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) techniques. Results: The most supported model of TPa homo-dimer was characterized by contacts between helices 1 of monomers, whereby cysteine 35 residues lie at a distance predictive of an inter-helical disulphide bridge. Upon substitution of cysteine 35 with alanine (C35A) homo-and hetero-dimerization of TPa and TPb as well as TPa trafficking was greatly impaired. However, C35A mutant TP receptors did not significantly differ from wild type in terms of [3H]-SQ29, 548 antagonist binding and accumulation of inositol phosphates induced by U46619 agonist stimulation. Conclusions: Mutation of cysteine 35 greatly impairs dimerization of TP receptors as anticipated by computational modelling but leaves unaffected the binding and signalling properties of monomeric receptors.

Erbin is a novel SARA-interacting protein on early endosomes that negatively regulates TGF-b/ Activin signaling G. Sflomos 1,2 , E. Kostaras 1,2 , E. Panopoulou 2 , N. Pappas 1,2 , M. Hyvonen 3 , T. Fotsis 1,2 * and C. Murphy 2 * 1 Laboratory of Biological Chemistry, Medical School, University of Ioannina, Ioannina, GREECE, 2 Biomedical Research Institute, Foundation for Research and Technology-Hellas, Ioannina, GREECE, 3 Department of Biochemistry, University of Cambridge, Cambridge, UK Transforming growth factor beta (TGF-b) superfamily members are important regulators of many diverse developmental and homeostatic processes. SARA, an early endosomal FYVE finger protein, plays a leading role in this pathway by recruiting non-phosphorylated SMAD proteins to the receptor complex for phosphorylation. Furthermore, SARA also mediates receptor dephosphorylation by recruiting PP1 phosphatase to the activated receptor. Recently SARA has been shown to regulate the vesicular targeting of the photoreceptor protein Rhodopsin to newly synthesized discs. To further investigate the molecular mechanism of SARA action, we have undertaken the task of identifying additional SARA-interacting proteins. A yeast-two-hybrid screen identified the leucine-rich repeat (LRR) and PDZ domain-containing protein ERBIN as a binding partner of SARA. We have confirmed the interaction of ERBIN and SARA by pull-down assays and immunoprecipitation and have mapped the interaction domains on both partners. Furthermore, we have found that ERBIN is present on the early endocytic compartment and it also interacts with Activin Receptors. We have addressed the physiological role of this interaction using lossof-function approaches (siRNA) and we have observed that knockdown of the endogenous ERBIN enhances TGF-b/Activin-induced transcriptional responses, while gain-of-function reduces TGF-b/Activin-induced transcriptional responses. Thus, ERBIN appears to be a novel negative regulator of the TGF-b/Activin pathway. *These authors contributed equally.

The regulatory function of adenovirus E1A protein in JNK signaling pathway J. Shim Sejong University, Seoul, REPUBLIC OF KOREA The adenovirus E1A oncoproteins can induce resting human cells to enter the cell cycle providing an optimal environment for viral replication. On the other hand mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) signaling pathways mediated intracellular signaling, which is initiated by a variety of extracelluar stimuli. This signaling pathway may be involved in diverse cellular activities that include cell proliferation, differentiation, and apoptosis. The persistent activation of the SAPK/ JNK(c-Jun N-terminal kinase) pathway often mediates intracellular signaling that leads to cell death. We demonstrated that E1A acts as an inhibitor for SAPK in a dose dependent manner. Besides this report show that E1A proteins are the putative substrate of SAPK/JNK. Taken together, these results suggest a possibility that E1A counteract SAPK activation to prevent apoptotic cell death of host cells.

Behaviour of the peptaibol trichogin in a mixed hybrid bilayer lipid membrane array (nanoBLMs) S. Smeazzetto 1 , T. Ferri 2 and M. R. Moncelli 1 1 Dipartimento di Chimica, Universita´di Firenze, Florence, ITALY 2 Dipartimento di Chimica, Universita´di Roma 'La Sapienza', Rome, ITALY Introduction: The peptaibols are a family of antibiotic peptides isolated from soil fungi that exhibit anti-bacterial and anti-fungal properties. The name peptaibol derives from their chemical composition: peptides containing Aib (a-amminoisobutyric acid or a-methyl alanine) residues and ending in a C-terminal alchol. Trichogin is one of the shortest peptaibols (11 residues) and it has a fatty acyl moiety linked to the N-terminal amino acid (n-octanoyl). Trichogin is too short to fully span a membrane, so its mechanism of action must be different from the long peptaibols, like alamethicin forming voltage-gated channel. Methods: We are studying these peptaibols using a new experimental model of biological membrane [1] . This model is constituted of a polycarbonate membrane with 1 lm diameter holes, covered by an octadecanthiol (ODT) self-assembled monolayer (SAM) on Au. The bilayer lipid membranes (BLMs) spontaneously self-assemble on the holes of the polycarbonate membrane. The characterization and stability of the nanoBLMs have been characterized by electrochemical measurements: cyclic voltammetry, AC voltammetry and Impedance Spectroscopy. Results: We identified the typical range of values of specific resistance, specific capacitance and conductance for well formed nanoBLMs: 0.1MX<R*cm 2 <10 MX 0.4microF<C/ cm 2 <1microF and 0<j<5 microS/cm respectively. By means of specific resistance data, we furthermore proved that nanoBLMs can last up to 24 hours. Conclusion: We set up the protocol to incorporate the trichogin in the phospholipidic bilayer and to study its selectivity. Gomel State Medical University, Gomel, BELARUS, 2 Belarusian State University, Minsk, BELARUS, 3 Gomel State Technical University, Gomel, BELARUS Peroxynitrite (ONOO ) , oxoperoxonitrate ()1)) is one from the reactive species generated by activated neutrophils. The work aimed at understanding the mechanisms of neutrophil interaction with exogenous ONOOusing chemiluminescence and atomic force microscopy (AFM) methods. We examined the conditions of the luminescence development (luminol-, lucegenin-dependent and spontaneous chemiluminescence) when the cells interacted with ONOO ) . With AFM methods we investigated the morphology and surface structure of neutrophils treated with ONOO -, adhered to glass slabs, fixed with glutaraldehyde and dried. The intensity of the chemiluminescence accompanying the neutrophil interaction with ONOO ) increased with increasing in pH level (in range of 5-9) and ONOO ) concentration (in range of 0.005-1.0 mM). The luminol-dependent chemiluminescence kinetics was characterized by the presence of some stages during which the generation of superoxide anion radicals, nitrogen monoxide and myeloperoxidase reaction products were observed. ONOO-induced spontaneous chemiluminescence of neutrophils was enhanced (5-15-fold) after the pre-incubation of the cells with such neutrophil stimulating agents as fMLP and latex. Atomic force microscopy analysis of neutrophil surface showed that 0.1 mM ONOO) induced neutrophil spreading on glass surface and neutrophil degranulation. The increase of the incubation time led to the increase in the spreading and degranulation levels of ONOO-treated neutrophils and to the damage of neutrophil through the NET (neutrophil extracellular traps) mechanism (after incubation for 3 hour). The findings are evidence of the modulation of some neutrophilic functions by exogenous ONOO ) .

Role of PLC-c in the control of the fertilization and mitotic calcium signals in sea urchin egg L. Tosca, R. Glass and B. Ciapa Universite Paris-Sud, Orsay, FRANCE Introduction: Egg activation after fertilization is mediated by a transient rise in intracellular free calcium (Ca i ) that is followed by other Ca i transients necessary for mitosis progression. In sea urchin egg, the cADPr (cyclic ADP ribose) and the IP 3 (inositol 1,4,5-trisphosphate) pathways are both necessary to generate the fertilization Ca i signal. In this study, we demonstrate that PLCc (phospholipase C c) control both fertilization and mitosis Ca i signals. Methods: PLCc contains two SH2 domains allowing interaction with phospho-tyrosine residues. Fusion proteins containing the N-ter and/or C-ter SH2 domain(s) and an histidine 'tag' were generated (His-SH2-PLCc). Proteins that are not functionnal carrying R253A (N-ter SH2) and R364A (C-ter SH2) mutations, which prevents interaction with phospho-tyrosine residues, were used as controls. All constructions were injected before or after fertilization and Ca i was mesured using a fura-2 fluorescent probe (Axon Inst. Image Analysis System). Results: Our results indicate that inhibiting the PLCc pathway did not prevent the fertilization Ca i signal. All control mutated constructs were without effect. However, we found that the C-ter SH2 domain only was capable of inhibiting mitosis. Conclusion: Our results clearly show that PLCc is not sufficient to trigger the fertilization Ca i signal, contrary to what is widely accepted in the litterature. However, PLCc is absolutely necessary to control progression through the first mitotic divisions.Introduction: In recent years, there is increasing interest towards the development of analytical methods for testing the authenticity of food products commanding a premium price. Coffee is an important food commodity worldwide. The commercial trade consists almost entirely of the Arabica and Robusta species. The former is considered to be of superior quality and thus attracts a premium price. We have developed a rapid, simple and robust method that allows detection of the two species based on the genotyping of a single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) within the chloroplastic genome. Methods: DNA is isolated from coffee green beans and the segments that span the SNP of interest are amplified by PCR. Following purification, the products are subjected to two primer extension (PEXT) reactions in the presence of biotin-dUTP, using allele-specific primers that contain a (dA) 30 segment. The products are detected visually by a dry-reagent dipstick-type biosensor, in which the extension products are captured from immobilized streptavidin on the test zone of the sensor and detected by hybridization with oligo(dT)-functionalized gold nanoparticles forming a red line. A second red line is generated at the control zone of the biosensor by hybridization of the nanoparticles with immobilized oligo(dA). Results: Coffee amplicon mixtures were analyzed with this technique allowing clear discrimination of the two alleles. The dipstick test is complete within 10 minutes. Conclusions: The proposed dipstick assay is rapid and enables visual detection of either deliberate or accidental adulteration without the need for special instrumentation or highly qualified technical personnel.

Molecularly imprinted polymers that selectively recognize histamine F. Trikka 1 , K. Yoshimatsu 2 , L. Ye 2 and D. A. Kyriakides 1,3 1 Laboratory of Biochemistry, Department of Chemistry , Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Thessaloniki, GREECE, 2 Pure and Applied Biochemistry, Chemical Center, Lund University, Lund, SWEDEN,   3 National Hellenic Research Foundation, Athens, GREECE Molecular imprinting is widely used for the preparation of polymeric materials containing recognition sites of predetermined specificity. Imprinted binding sites are generated by co-polymerization of a functional monomer with a cross-linker in the presence of a template molecule. Removal of the template molecule from the formed polymer results in cavities within the polymer that is complementary to the template. Consequently, the polymer is able to rebind the template molecule with high affinity and specificity, in a manner comparable to antibody-antigen or receptor-ligand binding. In this work, MIPs selective for histamine were synthesized by bulk polymerization using methacrylic acid as functional monomer and ethylene glycol dimethacrylate as cross-linker. Binding affinity of imprinted polymers for histamine and structurally related compounds was studied in both organic and aqueous medium. The specific binding sites of imprinted polymer selectively recognize histamine over L-Histidine under aqueous conditions. When polymers were tested against other biogenic amines in aqueous media, MIPs were capable of binding three times more histamine than putrescine. Binding analysis of histamine imprinted polymers with histamine receptor antagonists and compounds related to histamine action was studied as well. In organic media, MIPs selectively recognized histamine over dimentidene, ranitidine and fluoxetine. In aqueous media MIPs bound two times more histamine than ranitidine when 0.3% (v/v) Tween 20 was added. Selectivity of MIPs over structurally and functionally related compounds in aqueous environment makes feasible its potential bioanalytical applications. Acknowledgment: This work was supported by the European Union program: Nanoimprinting Technologies for Selective Recognition and Seperation, Contract no: NMP4-CT-2005-516981.

back_matter.text: Monodispersed colloidal maghemite nanoparticles as conductors of magnetic hyperthermia for targeted dissolution of brain tumors 3 Institute of Biology National Center for Scientific Research 'Demokritos', Athens, GREECE, 4 Department of Radiology, University Hospital of Heraklion, Heraklion, GREECE Introduction: Ferrofluids are colloidal suspensions of single-domain magnetic nanoparticles, which are stabilized in water. Their long term colloidal stability is ensured by coating the nanoparticles with appropriate polymers, e.g. polysaccharides, to prevent aggregation and render these nanoparticles useful in medical diagnosis and therapy. Methods: Coated maghemite nanoparticles were prepared by mixing acidic iron solutions and added over in alkaline solution of NaOH. 1 wt% of dextran was added in the acidic media. Then 0.18 ml of ferrofluid (3.6 mg of maghemite) was injected in glioma C6 tumours grown in mice to 0.5 · 0.5 mm, in adult male Wistar rats. Following magnetic hyperthermia treatment for about 20 minutes the remaining glioma cell tumors were excised and processed for light microscopy. Results: Specifically in sites of ferrofluid injection but not in adjacent areas of tumour or normal tissue, nanoparticle-induced hyperthermia to 44°C via application of a magnetic field (temperature was monitored by an optical fibre thermometer), resulted in cell dissolution or cell damage: the remaining cells were deformed and appeared to be apoptotic with dense and fragmented nuclei, compared to the appearance of healthy cells in tumour areas free of ferrofluid. Apparently then the maghemite nanoparticles were able, by locally raising the temperature to interfere with cell viability and caused nanoparticle-targeted cell dissolution or cell death. Conclusions: The maghemite nanoparticles, because of their properties to conduct heat can be used as means to therapeutically intervene in massive tumours of the CNS by targeted tumour cell disruption and apoptosis. Introduction: Hepatitis B virus (HBV) is a small enveloped DNA virus, causing acute and chronic hepatitis, cirrhosis, hepatocellular carcinoma and considered a significant health problem worldwide. The proteins of HBV are the surface protein, the core protein and DNA polymerase. The HBV core genes codes for two different proteins; HBc antigen and HBe antigen (HBeAg). Presence of HBeAg in the sera of HBV infected individuals may indicate the high infectivity of the disease and poor prognosis of the disease treatment, so detection of HBeAg is important in clinical diganosis. Methods: One of the sensitive and commonly used methods to differentiate the type of viral infection and discriminate between acute and chronic hepatitis is ELISA, based on the use of monoclonal antibodies. In this study, BALB/c mice were immunized with HBeAg expressing M13 phage for the production of monoclonal antibodies specific for HBe antigen. It was expressed on the M13 phage by cloning of HBe gene into phagemid, transferring into E.coli TG1 and infection of positive clones with M13 helper phages. Results and Conclusion: After three subsequent immunization of BALB/c mice with HBe-phage, lymphocytes were isolated and fused with F0 myeloma cells. In order to maximize the probability of generating monoclonal antibodies, lymphocytes from spleen, lymph nodes and intraperitonal fluid were used. After selection of positive clones with ELISA, it was found that out of 690 hybrid clones, 10D12 was producing antibody recognizing both HBe antigen and human serum, whereas 5G12 was producing monoclonal antibody specific only for M13 phage.

A study for determining the direct effect of myeloperoxidase enzyme on doxorubicin Y. Basaran and H. Kuzu Yildiz Technical University, Bioengineering Department, Istanbul, TURKEY Introduction: Myeloperoxidase (MPO, EC 1.11.1.7) is an enzyme found in polymorphonuclear neutrophils and monocytes, and some populations of tissue macrophages. Myeloperoxidase plays an important role in the defense system against invading microorganisms and certain tumor killing actions via myeloperoxidase-H 2 O 2 -Clreaction system. Myeloperoxidase oxidizes various compounds such as phenols, anilines and their derivatives, and also b-diketons which may lead to the formation of free radicals. It has been hypothesized that peroxidase-catalyzed drug oxidation causes radical production, protein binding and oxidative stress cytotoxicity, and thereby contributes to reactive metabolite formation and cell death. This hypothesis includes the finding that peroxidase catalyzes the oxidation of drugs, carcinogens or xenobiotics to form radicals that cooxidize biomolecules and form reactive oxygen species [1] . From this standpoint, myeloperoxidase may cause free radical formation in drug metabolism. Methods: Myeloperoxidase was purified for the first time at sufficient amounts for laboratory scale experiments with good activity. The intensive effect of purified myeloperoxidase on Doxorubicin was studied for the first time. The reaction products which was formed at physiological temperature and pH (37°C; pH 7.2-7.3) were evaluated by using UV-Vis. spectrophotometer, FT-IR and LC-MS spectrometer systems. Results: The results obtained with UV-Vis spectrophotometer implied that the reaction took place. Occured reaction was clarified by evaluating FT-IR and LC-MS results for the products. Conclusions: The obtained data showed that Doxorubicin was fragmented with the formation of free radicals. Introduction: Dipeptidyl peptidase IV (DPP IV/CD26, EC 3.4.14.5) is a glycoprotein with multiple functions. As a serine protease, it could activate or inactivate biologically important peptides, involved in chronic diseases pathogenesis. Therefore, it could play an important role in the modulation of the immune response during inflammatory processes. The aim of this study was to evaluate the changes in serum DPP IV activity in adult patients with chronic diseases including inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD): Crohn's disease -CD and ulcerative colitis -UC; and rheumatoid diseases: rheumatoid arthritis -RA, psoriatic arthritis -PA, and patients with osteoporosis -OP. Methods: The diagnosis of CD, UC, RA, PA and OP were established on the basis of clinical history, laboratory, endoscopic and histological data. The control group included healthy blood donors. The serum DPP IV activity has been measured spectrofotometrically using Gly-Pro p-nitroanilide as substrate. Results: Serum DPP IV activities in patients with IBD (CD and UC) and RA were statistically significantly decreased compared with the levels in healthy controls (P < 0.001). In patients with PA and OP, serum DPP IV activities were not statistically significantly different from healthy controls. No statistically significant difference in the serum DPP IV activity between patients with CD and UC was found (P > 0.05). Conclusions: The results of this study sustained the statement that the serum DPP IV is involved in the pathogenesis of chronic diseases. The serum DPP IV activity appears to be useful as an available, non-invasive marker in the diagnosis of the disease activity. Introduction: Since embryonic stem (ES) cell-derived neural progenitors (NPs) have the potential to cure many diseases, knowledge of the signaling mechanisms that regulate their proliferation and differentiation is critical. We discovered the presence of functional mu opioid receptor (MOR) and kappa opioid receptor (KOR) in ES cells and NPs. To explore the relationship between opioids and ES cell-derived NP fate, we examined retinoic acid (RA) induced NP proliferation and differentiation upon opioid treatment. Method: An immunocytochemistry approach was taken that involved cell specific and BrdU antibodies to measure cell division and differentiation in NPs, treated with DAMGO (MOR agonist) or U69,593 (KOR agonist) for 1 or 5 days. Results: Both opioids inhibited NP proliferation and ES cell derived neurogenesis and astrogenesis. Some of these inhibitory effects were extracellular-signal regulated kinase (ERK) dependent. In contrast, mu and kappa opioids increased the number of proliferating ES-cell derived NG2 + oligodendrocyte progenitors (OPs). MOR and KOR immunoreactivity was detected in oligodendrocytes at three stages of their development. By using selective inhibitors, we found that the opioid induced proliferation of OPs was ERK but not p38 kinase mediated. Opioids did not affect proliferation of immature oligodendrocytes. Conclusion: Collectively, these results reveal that opioids can play a modulatory role in determining NP fate decisions. We have extensively studied the biological metabolism toxic compounds containing a triple bond between carbon and nitrogen such as nitrile (R-CN) (1) and isonitrile (R-NC). As for the latter compound, we discovered a novel enzyme that catalyzes the hydration isonitrile to the corresponding N-substituted formamide (R-NHCHO) in Pseudomonas putida N19-2 and named it isonitrile hydratase (2) . We recently discovered a novel enzyme, N-substituted formamide deformylase (NfdA) which catalyzes the hydrolysis N-substituted formamide to the corresponding amine and formate in Arthrobacter pascens F164 (3). Results: A. pascens F164 was able to degrade not only N-benzylformamide (which is an N-substituted formamide) but also the corresponding isonitrile, benzyl isocyanide. In the reaction the cell-free extracts prepared from the cells grown on media containing benzyl isocyanide as the sole nitrogen source, the isonitrile was confirmed to be hydrated to N-benzylformamide, which was further converted into benzylamine and formate by NfdA: isonitrile hydratase and NfdA activities were detected. These findings suggest that both enzymes are closely related in sequential isonitrile metabolism. We searched for an appropriate substrate whose reaction product was not degraded by NfdA and investigated the optimum culture conditions for the formation isonitrile hydratase. The highest enzyme activity was obtained when this strain was cultured in the presence N-benzylformamide as an inducer. This isonitrile hydratase was found to be an inducible enzyme depending on N-benzylformamide. Despite its importance in cell proliferation and tumorigenesis, very little is known about the molecular mechanism underlying the regulation of phospholipase D (PLD) expression. PLD isozymes are significantly co-overexpressed with cancer marker genes in colorectal carcinoma. Phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate (PMA) treatment, as a mitogenic signal in colon cancer cells, selectively increases PLD1 expression in transcription and post-transcription. Moreover, experiments using intraperitoneal injection of PMA into mice showed selective PLD1 induction in the intestine and lung tissues, which suggests its physiological relevance in vivo. Therefore, we have undertaken a detailed analysis of the effects of PMA on the promoter activity of PLD genes. Protein kinase C inhibitors, but not a protein kinase A inhibitor, were found to suppress the up-regulation of PLD1 but not PLD2. Dominant-negative mutants of Ras, Raf, and MEK suppressed the induction and activity of PLD1. Moreover, depletion of the supposedly involved proteins reduced the endogenous PLD1 protein level. An important role for NFkappaB as a downstream target of ERK in PMA-induced PLD1 induction was also demonstrated using the inhibitor, small interfering RNA, chromatin immunoprecipitation assay, and site-specific mutagenesis. Furthermore, inhibitors of these signaling proteins and depletion of PLD1 suppressed PMA-induced matrix metalloproteinase-9 secretion and PLD1 induction. In conclusion, we demonstrate for the first time that induction of PLD1 through a protein kinase C/Ras/ ERK/NFkappaB-dependent pathway is involved in the secretion of matrix metalloproteinase-9 in colorectal cancer cells.

Endoplasmic reticulum stress and the role of T-cadherin Introduction: Endothelial dysfunction plays a key role in the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis. T-cadherin is an atypical GPI-anchored member of the cadherin superfamily. It is up-regulated in atherosclerotic lesion. Grp78, which co-associates with T-cadherin, is a key mediator of endoplasmic reticulum stress. This means that T-cadherin may possibly play a key role in ER stress. Methods: Endothelial cells are treated with ER stress inducing agents. Agents that are used are thapsigargin (1 lM), DTT (1 mM), Brefel-dinA (5 lg/ml), Tunicamycin (3 lg/ml), Calcium Ionophore A23187 (2 lM) and Homocysteine (15 mM). Immunoblotting and quantitative RT-PCR are used in order to determine the modulation of T-cadherin expression during endoplasmic reticulum stress, and for the changes in expression of UPR signaling molecules such as GRP78, ATF3 and phospho-eIF2a. Silencing (use of siRNA) and over-expression of Tcadherin (adenoviral vector system) is used to study the ability of Tcadherin to influence endothelial cell survival responses during ER stress.Results: T-cadherin is elevated in ER stress. Cultured EC after treatment with ER stress inducing agents show increased mRNA and protein levels of T-cad at early time points. GRP78 is gradually elevated through time.Conclusions: The role of these molecules in protection of cardiac and vascular cells from ER stress has to be evaluated. Also new insights into the impact of ER stress signaling in regulation of endothelial function would be given. T-cadherin seems to be a key player in ER stress. This study will shed more light on the mechanism of cardiovascular disorders. Cordyceps sinensis (C. sinensis) is a precious medicinal fungus, which has been used in China since ancient times. In modern scientific studies, C. sinensis possesses several bioativities, such as antitumour, immunomodulatory, anti-inflammation, anti-atherosclerosis and anti-diabetes. Due to the medicinal properties of C. sinensis, it has become increasingly scarce in recent years and the price for wild C. sinensis has increased sharply. Therefore, mycelial fermentation of Cordyceps fungal species is a feasible and sustainable method for producing the medicinal fungus and its active compounds. Methods: Cs-HK1, a Tolypocladium fungus, is a new species isolated from wild C. sinensis and cultivated by liquid fermentation which containing glucose, yeast extract, peptone and trace amount of mineral ions. The exo-polysaccharide (EPS) was isolated from the culture broth by centrifugation; the supernatant was collected and mixed with four volume of 95% (v/v) ethanol for the precipitation of EPS. The EPS precipitate was recovered by centrifugation and freeze-dried. The carbohydrate and protein content of EPS was measured by anthrone sulphuric acid and Lowry method.
